column2: The Knoxville Register of Thursday, April 10, says that the Rebel troops were compelled to fall back upon Corinth on Monday evening, because they had run short of ammunition.

The Richmond Whig has a Southern account of the battle, from an unofficial source, however, and therefore, not altogether reliable. The writer evidently indulges in some exaggerations. After giving what he alleges were the numbers engaged on each side, he says:

Another batch of prisoners, numbering one hundred and fifty, arrived here on Friday, and were sent to Governor's Island. They are part of those captured at Fort Pulaski. Another batch is expected this morning. The men are uniformed like the Cape Hatteras prisoners, in rather dirty looking gray.

Gen. O.B. CONRAD, of Gilmer County, Virginia, is now in confinement in Wheeling, having been taken thither by National officers at Sutton, Braxton County, to whom he voluntarily surrendered himself a few days ago.
A special dispatch from Cairo, to the Times, says that Gen. MITCHEL is now at Juba, Miss., having burned the bridges across the Tennessee River, at Decatur and Florence.
Hon. E.M. Stanton, Secretary of War: Following is the report of killed, wounded and missing in Gen. W.F. SMITH'S Division of the Army Corps, April 16:

In the Senate yesterday, the bill to prevent frauds in laying out and opening streets in this City was ordered to a third reading; also the bill to provide for the construction of railroads in cities, and the bill to amend the law relative to the Superintendent of Poor and the Coroners of Kings County.

The telegraph has informed you of the surrender of Fork Pulaski, and the consequent state of excitement you can well imagine. The evening of Friday passed in suspense, but no fear was felt that the gallantry of the garrison had caused the silence of the enemy's guns, which had not been heard since 2 P.M. yesterday.
A portion of Gen. McDowell's army the day before yesterday marched from the vicinity of Warrenton Junction upon Fredericksburgh.

The Supply bill was made the special order for this afternoon. BILLS ORDERED TO THIRD READING. To prevent frauds in laying out streets in NewYork; to provide for the construction of railroads in cities; to amend the law relating to the Superintendent of Poor and Coroners of Kings County.

GENERAL ORDERS, No. 4. Brother Officers and Soldiers: Department Order No. 17 published the President's War Order No. 3, announcing the change in the limits and styles of this Department, and the assignment of an officer of superior rank to its command.

The Norfolk Day Book of yesterday, speaking of the arrival of M. MERCIER, the French Minister to Washington, at Richmond, speculates in relation to the objects of his visit, and says it is an event fraught with grave signification.
The paper presented herewith was read by the author, Dr. A.K. GARONER of this City, to the Sanitary Association, and received the approval of this body.

Gen. BANKS' advance column arrived here this noon, driving the enemy from the hill with artillery and cavalry charges, 6,000 of JACKSON'S troops passed through the town last evening, and encamped a short distance beyond. Last night it was currently reported that JACKSON was to be largely reinforced.

To Maj.-Gen. David Hunter, commanding Department of the South: SIR: I have the honor to report the conclusion of the operations of the siege of Fort Pulaski, in Savannah River, Ga., which have resulted in the capture of that fortress and its armament, and the unconditional surrender of the effective force of the garrison, amounting to 361, of whom 24 were officers; beside about 18 who were sick or wounded.

The following interesting and reliable account of the late battle in Arkansas was addressed to the Hon. G.G. VEST, through whose courtesy we are enabled to lay it before our readers this morning. The letter is from an officer of PRICF'S army, who was in the engagement:
The rebel leaders in the Cotton States, when urging secession upon the people of that section, assured them that in no event was there any danger of war being carried into their midst.
The following paragraphs foreshadow the revulsion of feeling which must have been occasioned by the fall of Island Ten. A correspondent of the Mobile Advertiser, writing from Memphis, April 1, says:

"Under the direction of the President," Gen. LEE is charged with the conduct of the military operations of the armies of the Confederacy. At the same time, the President appoints four Colonels as Aids to himself not to LEE, who also has four and the Secretary of War is authorized to employ 22 additional clerks.

Hon. HORACE GREELEY lectured on Friday evening, before the Ninth Ward Republican Association, on "One Year of Civil War." Previous to the lecture, Ex-Alderman STARR, on behalf of the Association, announced that they had determined upon a course of lectures, and had secured for speakers some of the most eminent orators of the City. [Applause.]
The Union feeling in this city, what little there is of it, is uncompromising in the extreme, and the indignation against those of secession proclivities unmitigated.
GENERAL ORDERS, No. 6. The General congratulates the army under his command on the imperishable honor won yesterday by a portion of it on the battle-field of Shiloh, near Pittsburgh Landing.

The Managers of the Northeastern Dispensary, corner of Lexington-avenue and Fifty-first-street, are arranging to throw open their capacious and well-arranged building for a brief home to a few, say five hundred if necessary, of our brave officers and soldiers now on the field of battle from this State, who may become wounded or disabled.

It is devoutly to be deplored that the report of the capture of the arch-traitor JOHN C. BRECKINRIDGE, at the battle of Pittsburgh Landing, has not proved true. The time has now come when their own personal safety will be the chief look-out of the leaders of the rebellion.

Amid the hurly-burly of battles, marches, skirmishes and retreats of the hostile armies along our vast frontier, a complete lull has prevailed for some time in the operations of the campaign along the seaboard of Georgia and South Carolina.

A special dispatch to the Tribune dated off Fort Wright, says that the firing on both sides, on Thursday, was very heavy. The mortars opened at noon. The enemy replied briskly from the land batteries, throwing shell clear over us and nearly across the river, they firing very accurate, and from very heavy guns.

The Picayune of April 1 says: Our Mississippi fleet, yclept, a few months ago, the mosquito fleet, promises to be, before long, a tolerably respectable one. it will be seen, by referring to our advertisements, that four more gunboats, with marine engines and boilers, are to be built in this city. Sealed proposals endorsed "Proposals for Gunboats," will be received till the 8th of April, at the Commandant's office, Naval Station.

HOMICIDE ON SHIPBOARD. Yesterday morning Officer HOLLAND, of the Harbor Police, received instructions from Marshal MURRAY to board the ship John Jay, just arrived from India, and to arrest THOS. BREEK, CHARLES BROWN and FERDINAND DEMAROHI, alias Hernando de Markel, upon the charge of having caused the death of a sailor named FRANK VHNSEN, by violent means.
The steamer Imperial arrived here last night, bringing 440 sick and wounded, 107 being prisoners, from Pittsburgh. This is the last of the wounded there.

A special dispatch to the Tribune, from Cairo, says that Gen. SHERMAN moved his division on Wednesday two miles further into the interior, and after a sharp skirmish, in which the enemy were defeated, with a loss of fifty or sixty killed, and as many wounded, he succeeded in maintaining his position.

The Memphis Avalanche, of April 4, has these paragraphs: "We are informed that some evil-disposed person cut the levee some twelve miles below the city on the Arkansas side, and the river has almost entirely submerged the plantation of B.L. ARMSTRONG, Esq.

The Fifty-third Regiment, N.Y.S.M., composed of very choice material, many of them being foreigners, and a majority natives of France, was lately attached to BURNSIDE'S Division of the "U.S." army of subjugation.

The final lecture of the course delivered by Prof AGASSIZ, before the Athenaeum Association, took place at Irving Hall on Monday evening last. The presence of Gen. SCOTT upon the platform elicited from the audience the most complimentary recognition, which was duly acknowledged by the old hero.

The United States steam transport Philadelphia, Commander BARTON, from Fort Pickens, on the 6th inst., and Key West on the 14th, arrived at this port, yesterday, in ballast, consigned to quartermaster TOMPKINS.

The rebel Gen. JACKSON has retreated before the combined movements of BANKS and MILROY, and it is not probable that another battle will occur in the valley of the Shenandoah, unless BANKS should rapidly advance and overlake the rebels.

In the Senate, on Saturday, the bill to prevent frauds in laying out and opening streets in this City was ordered to a third reading; also the bill to provide for the construction of railroads in cities, and the bill to amend the law relative to the Superintendent of Poor and the Coroners of Kings County. We see that the House of Representatives has taken another step in a path of needed reform, by the passage of the bill reported by the Judiciary Committee, amending the act establishing the Court of Claims. I send you a list of casualties as far as I can get: Dr. Everett, of Quincy, Ill, Brigade Surgeon of Prentiss' Division, killed early Sunday morning while cheering on the flying troops to return.

Private mercantile and banking letters from Europe continue to express the utmost surprise at the steady and comfortable condition of financial affairs in this country, pending a great and costly civil war. The writers could see how the machine of Government, for the conduct of the war, might be kept in motion

The step taken by the Republicans and other Union members of the Legislature to secure unity of action and harmony of counsels at the coming State election, is one of very marked importance. The details of their proceedings have not yet been published, so that we can comment only on the general results attained. It seems to he understood
The steamship Ellen S. Terry, (United States transport,) Capt. CHAPIN, from Newbern, April 17, and Hatteras 18th arrived here yesterday, consigned to the United States Quartermaster.

"Act as though you had good news." I flatter myself there can be nothing wrong in writing this. Although correspondents are forbidden to communicate anything definite or of interest, it is permitted them to be as vague and vapid as they please. As a general rule it is always well for loyal citizens, bearing Secretary STANTON'S Passes in their respective pockets, to act as though they had good news.

SIR: I have the honor to report the conclusion of the operations of the siege of Fort Pulaski, in Savannah River, Ga., which have resulted in the capture of that fortress and its armament, and the unconditional surrender of the effective force of the garrison, amounting to 361, of whom 24 were officers; beside about 18 who were sick or wounded.

Major-Gen. McDOWELL, remains in the city to-night, and returns to camp to-morrow. His forces are still. in possession of Falmouth, opposite to Fredericksburgh, a fact well-known to the rebels, wire occupy the latter city, and who are preparing to oppose any attempt of McDowell to cross the river; hence it is supposed that the loyal citizens of the United States may be trusted with the same in formation.

This is an Association of ladies, formed for the purpose of aiding, in such ways as may be necessary, young women, and others of their own sex, who are compelled to earn a livlihood, and yet have not the protection of parents or the safeguards of Christian homes. We find the following particulars of the expedition which recently destroyed the bridges over Bear Creek, in the Pittsburgh Landing correspondence of the Cincinatti Commercial:

The military situation at the mouth of the Mississippi becomes daily more and more intensely inter- esting. The City of New-Orleans is virtually besieged by land, lake, and river; and as we hear of the fall of one fort, and the assault upon another, our anxiety increases for the news that the metropolis of the South is once again under the flag of the Union.

Gen. PARKE and his associate engineers made a reconnoissance in force this morning toward Fort Macon. Major WRIGHT, in command of the Fifth Battalion Rhode Island Volunteers, with Company G, of the Fourth Rhode Island, under the command of Lieut. BOWEN, advanced from their encampment early in the morning and drove in the pickets of the enemy, which have until to-day maintained

My DEAR FATHER: God has again spared my life, having passed through the most terrible fight this continent has ever seen. The Waterloo of America has been fought, and we are the victors. On Sunday morning, April 6, at 5 o'clock, we were aroused by a sharp firing, commencing on our right, and running the whole length of our line, which was nearly two miles in length. The order was immediately given to

HIGHER GRADES WANTED IN THE NAVY. Gen. MITCHEL, the astronomersoldiler has resolved his single Brigadier star into the double star of the Major-General. Congress has done well in conferring the honor, for his gallant exploits richly merit it.

Advices from Commodore FOOTE are to Friday last, at which time the bombardment of Fort Wright was still proceeding. The firing on the day previous had been very heavy on both sides. On Friday the firing was not so brisk. The enemy had done no damage to our flotilla whether they had suffered any from our fire was not known.
Recent intelligence from Europe announces that another act of the Mexican drama is about to open, and discloses to us the respective parts which the several performers are to play.
SIR: You have not done men the honor to send me a copy of your minority report on the "Metropolitan Health Bill," a courtesy which I had reason to expect at your hands.

Three years ago, a consolidation of the Sixth and Seventh avenue Dutch Reformed churches took place, since which time they have been presided over by Rev. J.C. DUTCHEE, with the popular prefix of Union. The school numbers two hundred and ten pupils, and is of thirty years standing. Regular monthly meetings are held in order to advance the

Mr. FISHER, by unanimous consent, presented a petition from 83 workingmen of Syracuse, praying for the passage of an act to prevent negro immigration into the State, and setting forth that the great and increasing influx of negroes into the Free States is fraught with evil, and destructive of the value of free labor.
There has just arrived from Pittsburgh the steamer City of Memphis. She reached Paducah last evening from Pittsburgh, with 700 wounded, who are to be sent to Louisville.
The weather, to-day, is very unpleasant. A cold rain-storm, with a North wind, has set in.

The general election of Sachems and other officers of the Columbian Order came off last night at Tammany Hall, with considerable spirit; the rival parties, whose late sayings and doings were faithfully and exclusively recorded in the TIMES of Friday last, having nominated tickets very similar, but, to the knowing eye, essentially different.

Garret S. Moll vs. Israel Coddington et al. This was an action to recover damages alleged to have been sustained by the plaintiff by reason of the carelessness of the defendants, and to recover possession of certain premises.
STATED SESSION Monday, April 21, 1862. The Board met pursuant to adjournment. The President being absent, on motion of Alderman Jeremiah, Alderman Chipp was appointed Chairman pro- blem.

We would call the attention of amateurs, bibliophilists and general readers of choice literature to the advertisement in another column, of the greatbook sale now in progress by W.P. COOLEDGE, Trustee at No. 625 Broadway, under the rooms of the Art Institute.
The Senate is occupied in discussing and perfecting the Supply bill. 2 P.M. The Supply bill has just been read a third time and passed.
In the Senate yesterday, a petition was presented from free colored citizens of the United States, praying for colonization in Central America if possible. Memorials were presented for a ship ...

There was no session of the Board of Aldermen last evening, for want of a quorum. The Board of Councilmen did a large amount of routine business. The Mayor sent in a message recommending an appropriation for the relief of the Union refugees from Jacksonville, Fla., which was favorably received and $1,000 appropriated for that purpose--the money to be placed in the hands of the Mayor for distribution.

The movement of the army from Cassville to Forsyth, through a wild, mountainous country, which has now occupied six days, has afforded no opportunity for writing or sending communications. South of Springfield there is no mail, and the telegraph and Government Express are in the control of the Commanding-General. Letters can only be sent through the Government Express as a personal favor or by the slow conveyance of commissary wagons.

The execution of GORDON, last February, was a warning to all engaged in that abominable pursuit, that the man who now occupies the Presidential chair will not allow them, if caught, to escape with impunity.

THE WATER RATES THE TEMPORARY CLOSING OF A STREET TO FACILITATE THE OPERATIONS OF GOVERNMENT. A regular weekly meeting of the Board of Aldermen was held last evening, and in the absence of the President of the Board, Alderman WOOD, Alderman O'KEETE of the Twelfth Ward was called to preside. Mr. EDWARDS, of New-Hampshire, (Rep.,) introduced a bill, making appropriations for a bounty to the widows and legal heirs of volunteers who have died or may die, and of those killed or who may be killed, in the service. Referred to the Committee on Ways and Means.
The Vice President problem presented petitions in favor of a bankrupt law ; also in favor of a ship canal from Lake Michigan to the Mississippi River.

Gov. HARVEY, of Wisconsin, was drowned on Saturday night, at 11 o'clock, while passing from one boat to another, at Savanna, on the Tennessee River. His body had not been found when the dispatches left.

Sir Robert Cauliffe and Capt. Dulgell, of the Scotch Fusileer Guards ; Judge Warren, of Boston ; Col. Brewerton, U.S.A.; C.W. Chapin, of Springfield, Mass.; T.A. Jencks, of Providence; and Dr. Hoppin, J.F. Hoppin, and Dr. C. Hoppin, of Providence, are at the Brevoort House.

A severe rain-storm last night interfered seriously with telegraphing in every direction, and very little news from any of our armies in the field had reached us up to 2 o'clock this morning. Our latest advices form Yorktown indicate that the siege operations were progressing as rapidly as possible, and that the great struggle will soon commence.

THE PRESIDENT AND MR. CAMERON'S ARREST. The President sent a message to the House to-day covering a copy of correspondence between the Secretary of State and BENJAMIN H. BREWSTER of Philadelphia, relative to the arrest in that city of SIMON CAMERON, late Secretary of War, at the suit of PIERCE BUTLER, for trespass, vi et armis, assault and battery, and false imprisonment. Secretary SEWARD
In the Senate yesterday, the Supply bill, after a long debate, was read a third time and passed. An Executive Session was then held.

The NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES, No. 793, is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter, in wrappers, ready for mailing. It contains the LATEST INTELLIGENCE up to the moment of going to press. In addition, will be found, graphic letters from our correspondents at Headquarters, and letters from other divisions of the army.

Everything is quiet in front of us. Yesterday a cavalry reconnoissance penetrated the valley several miles toward Harrisonburgh, and report there are large quantities of forage and fresh provisions there.

The desultory cannonnading which had been continued throughout the night of the 16th, was this morning resumed with increased activity from our batteries; and two large-sized guns which had been planted during the night opened fire upon the right wing of the enemy's lines.

1. Field and company officers are specially enjoined to instruct their men, under all circumstances, to fire with deliberation at the feet of the enemy. They will thus avoid over shooting, and besides, wounded men give more trouble to our adversary than dead, as they have to be taken from the field.
The flood has now reached 28 feet 8 inches: 20 inches short of l854, which was the greatest flood ever known here. This is the greatest, except 1854.

The memorial of the undersigned, a Committee appointed on the 3d of April instant by the Chamber of Commerce of New-York, respectfully represents:

The United States transport Marion, Capt. PHILLIPS, from Port Royal on the 19th Inst., with mails and passengers to the Navy Agent, arrived yesterday. on the 19th inst., at 5:30 P.M., off Charleston harbor, saw United States steamers James Adger, Susquehanna, Flambeau and bark Roebuck. On the 20th, at 6:30 P.M., off Hatteras, a heavy fog set in, which continued until the Marion arrived at the lightship off Sandy Hook, at 7 A.M.

COTTON The market is firm, and hardening, particularly for American descriptions, which are a shade dearer than When the Canada sailed. Sales on Monday and Tuesday about 12,000 bales, including 4,500 on speculation and for export. The market, to-day, (Wednesday,) is firm, and tending upward; sales 10,000 bales.
A Sag of truce was received to-day. A Petershurgh paper of this morning, says that the Senate has refused to concur in the House resolution for adjournment.

news of another rebel buccanneer putting to sea comes from Liverpool. The Ovieto, a fast and powerful steamer, tell that port on the 22d of March, upon a cruise in pursuit of American merchantmen unarmed, as yet, but bound for some port where an armament awaited her. The English papers say with
Mr. BRIGHT, M.P., has returned the following reply to the address from the New-York Chamber of Commerce:
HENRY L. ROUT, one of the parties indicted by the Jury of the United States Circuit court in this City, for conspiracy and treason, has been released from custody, by order of the President.

The House concurred in the Senate's amendments to the bill to enroll the militia of the State, and organize the National Guard. The bill was then finally passed, and goes to the Governor for his signature.

The Admiralty have contracted with Messrs. SAMUDA for the construction of one of the cupola iron ships-of-war under the invention of Capt. COLES, of which the Monitor is an imperfect imitation. The price is to be 14.450, including everything, and the vessel is to be ready for launching on 8th February next, and to be delivered fit for sea on the 1st of June following.

Four steamers from Oregon and British Columbia have arrived within three days. The northern mining regious were becoming accessible again, and the steamers will doubtless return crowded with passengers.

The bills have been returned of Messrs, S. JACKSON Co., shipowners at St. Peter's Alexandria, but their liabilities are not more than aboout 15,000. About 20,000 in bar gold was taken to the Bank, yesterday, making a total of 336,000 since the last return.

Intelligence reached this city at an early hour yesterday morning that an engagement of some severity had taken place on the peninsula, on Wednesdaay afternoon, in which 10,000 men were engaged, 5,000 on each side. The fight is said to have been spirited, and continued from 3 until 7 o'clock P.M., when night closed upon the condict. At the time of this writing, we are without the full particulars.

The troops marched to the Warwick River, which, from the representations of a scout, was fordable for infantry, with a good bed for the Wheels of artillery. Our forces arrived at the river
The screw-steamer City of New-York, Capt. PETRIE, which sailed from Liverpool at 3 o'clock on the afternoon of the 9th, and from Queenstown on the 10th inst., arrived here yesterday morning.

From a gentleman, who left Memphis a few days after the battle of Pittsburgh, we leaarn that the rebels, putting both days of the battle together, claim the victory. Their claim rests on the supposition that more were killed, wounded and taken prisoners on the National side than on their owil.

George Jones et al. vs. George S. Brown. This action was brought to recover for goods sold and delivered to the defendant, amounting, as claimed, to the sum of $2,170. The plaintiffs now moved for a reference, and the defendant for a change of venue to Dutchess County, defendant and his witnesses being residents of Poughkeepsie. Both motions were heard together.

Our forces kept up an incessant fire on the enemy's works, yesterday, although it was not intended by us to bring on any general engagement; our object being to demolish some earthworks that the rebels had thrown up in front of their left wing the night previous, and opposite the line of Gen. HAMILTON'S Pickets.

The change of tone in the leading members of the Government, on the subject of armor-plated ships has not come a moment too soon, and has given a satisfaction as general as the dissatisfaction with the language of its former organs, Sir G.C. LEWIS and Lord CLARENCE PAGET.

In the Senate, yesterday, the Harbormasters bill was reported complete, and ordered to a third reading. The Judiciary Committee reported that they would not have time during the present session to act upon the Assembly Assessment bill.

The army was represented to be in high heart, and operations were progressing favorably. The letters from our special correspondents, which we publish this morning, give many interesting details of events which have occurred during the investment of the enemy's works.

Richmond papers of yesterday (Monday) morning contain a telegraphic report of the landing of our forces near Elizabeth City, N.C., and an engagement at that point. They admit that their forces retired to the Dismal Swamp Canal, with a loss of thirtyeight killed and wounded, and say that the Federal loss was heavy.

Gen. Hooker's Division reached the place of the present encampment last Friday, landing upon the site of a rebel encampment at the mouth of a small inlet, called Cheesemans' Creel. Three wellbuilt and substantial batteries were found here, which were abandoned several days previous to the arrival of our troops. The encampment at the rear of these

APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE ARMY AND NAVY. The two largest appropriation bills for the army and navy for the fiscal year ending July, 1863, have not reported from the Committee of Ways and Means, although the general impression is that they have been finally disposed of.

A special to tile Journal, from Cairo, says that the news from the fleet at Fort Wright is unimportant. The bombardment continues. The rebels have cut the levee on the Arkansas shore, opposite the fort, and fine farming lands there are now covered with, a lake of water for miles around. The residents, are greatly exasperated at this outrage.
The Ministry had given orders to increase the number of iron-plated ships. A conspiracy of great extent is said to have been discovered among the clergy of Bologna.
Steamship Asia, (Br.) Shannon Liverpool, E. Cunard. Steamers H. Borden, Loper, Philadelphia, Loper Kirkpatrick; Bristol, Charles, Philadelphia.

The Confiscation bill of Mr. BINGHAM met its fate, yesterday, in the House of Representatives. By a vote of 54 to 48 the House laid it on the table. Another bill, authorizing the President to emancipate the slaves of rebel owners, was then discussed, and tabled by a vote equally decidod.

Since my last, all the Brazilian world have been amusing themselves with the festivities of the carnival, which this year has been gayer than ever; undoubtedly, after Paris, this place has more extensive ideas for carrying out the Carnival than even any other European city.
SIR: I have the honor to submit the following report of the operations of the troops under my command, in connection with the investment and reduction of Fort Pulaski:
The news from all points is very meagre for this mail, and there is nothing of local interest.

ANOTHER COMMISSIONER NOMINATED. To-day the President nominated RUFUS KING, ex-Postmaster-General, to the Senate, as Commissioner under the Emancipation act, to fill the vacancy occasioned by the withdrawal of BERRETT. The fact aroused a storm of indignation among the Republican Senators. They assert that when they fought BU-...

The gunboat Tyler, while reconnoitering up the Tennessee River, captured the rebel steamer J. Robb near the mouth of Crane Creek. This is one of the boats which eluded our first expedition up this river after the fall of Fort Henry. Her name has been changed to Lady Tyler.
On the 9th of March, Gen. TORRELIO raised the standnrd of revolution in Sucre, taking the Commandante, Gen. SEBASTIAN AGREDA, prisoner, and proclaiming Gen. Ex-President BELZU.

The country remains quiet, and will, probably, till May, when the Electoral Colleges meet to count a new President in, in place of CASTILLA, and perhaps even till October, when he is to be installed. The people and newspapers continue to have great fears that Spain will pounce upon Peru after she is done with Mexico.

The Berlin papers publish a protestation of the University of Berlin against the electoral instructions of the Minister of Public Worship. The document is couched in a very independent spirit. The Professors of the University add a declaration to the effect that they will only act upon those political principles which rest upon a conscientious conviction and the free and independent exercise of the national will.
The districts of Kruschurze and Sultorina had offered to submit to the Turks, and had expelled VuCALOVITCH, who is said to have been wounded, and to have taken refuge in an Austrian territory.

TO THE GULF FOOTE and POPE are finding considerable difficulty in forcing their way down the Mississippi River. But it is not Much over a month since FOOTE left Cairo with his gunboats, and already he is fighting a hundred and seventy-five miles down stream from that point.

Capt. CUTTING, of Gen. BURNSIDE'S Staff, arrived here to-day with dispatches to the Government. He states that Gen. RENO commanded the National forces at the lated reconnoissance to Elizabeth City. Capt. CUTTING saw Gen. RENO just before leaving the Sound, and I learn from him the following particulars of the affair:

If the more ardent and sanguine among us are not fully satisfied with the progress of the National cause, it is for the reason that we do not consider how much we have gained, and how rapidly the rebels are being weakened in the loss of men and territory, but above all, in resources.

The monthly returns of the Bank of France show no material change in the cash on hand, the increase being less than a million francs. In the bills discounted, not yet due, there is a decrease of 74 millions, and in the current accounts a decrease of 47 1/8 millions.

We have already mentioned the opening night of the present annual exhibition of the National Academy of Design, and although our space will not permit of an extended notice of all the paintings good and bad, of which there are many we propose in this and a succeeding article, to call attention to those which for one cause or another, merit attention.

MY EVER DEAR FRIEND: Your letter of the 8th inst. reached me, and I avail myself of the earliest opportunity to reply. I feel deep regret for the sad intelligence it conveyed to my highly esteemed friend and fellow-prisoner, Lieut. DEMPSEY. I have been using my best endeavors to console him, and I am happy to say that he looks upon the matter in a truly Christian manner.
The steamship Bohemian, from Liverpool on the 10th, and Londonderry on the 11th, arrived at Portland at 6 o'clock yesterday morning.

Rebel marauders and guerrillas are making their appearance, with the green leaves, in quite a number of the counties of Western Virginia. We hear of them suddenly springing up in some unexpected quarter, attacking a hamlet, or a Union camp, or a supply train, or executing vengeance upon some loyal citizen, or in some other way disturbing the peace of the country.
A small rowbout arrived here this morning from Norfolk, containing three men, ono woman and two children.

A special to the Tribune from Cairo, to-day, says: The Memphis Appeal of the 17th is received. In an editorial devoted to the needs of the Mississippi Valley, it acknowledges the danger of a success by the National flotilla, and advises the employment of every one, black or white, to the extent of his ability, for the defence of that endangered stronghold. It advocates the construction of the most approved description of gunboats.
The Legislature adjourned yesterday forenoon sine die. Both Houses met at 9 o'clock. In the Senate the bill to provide for the public defence was killed.

The news from the Department of the Rappahannock is important. An officer who arrived in Washington last night, from the vicinity of Warrenton Junction, reports that the rebels are in strong force on the south side of the river, in the direction of Gordonsville.

SPRING EXHIBITION OF THE BROOKLYN HORTICULTURAL SOCIETY. The annual Spring exhibition of the Horticultural Society was opened, yesterday, at the Academy of Music, and will be continued during the remainder of the week. The display of choice and rare plants and flowers is better than at any previous Spring exhibition of the Society H.M. BARNES, Esq., of the Eastern District, alone having on the different tables more than one hundred pots, embracing some

President PEREZ continues to be feted by the people of Valparaiso. Balls, regattas, serenades, excursions by sea and land, firemen's processions, club performances, appear to be the order of the day and night. His Excellency was to return to Santiago at the close of March.

Valentine Sillcosks vs. Henry Bruner. This was an action for damages alleged to have been sustained by reason of the defendant's excavating the earth on the premises adjoining the plaintiff's houses on Wooster and Prince streets, in this City.
The Paris correspondent of the London Times thus writes of the present aspect of the Mexican question:
Both Houses met at 9 o'clock this morning. In the Senate the bill to provide for the public defence was killed.

Col. DONNELLY made a reconnoissance, to-day, toward this town. When approaching he was fired on by the rebel cavalry scouts. Two companies of the Ohio Cavalry were deployed on the left, toward Gordonsville Turnpike, the same number of the Vermont Cavalry on the right, and the Michigan Cavalry on the centre; Hampton's Battery, and the Connecticut Fifth, formed the reserve.
The Legislature of the State of Deseret assembled in this city on the l4th, in accordance with the proclamation of Gov. YOUNG. The Governor's message is patriotic. Two Senators have been elected.

The funds on the 11th opened with an improving tendency but afterwards became dull. Consols closed at 93 7/8@94 for money, and 94@94 7/8 for account. Notwithstanding the distribution of the dividends a considerable demand for money existed, and the terms for good bills were 2 @2 per cent. In the Stock Exchange it was difficult to employ money at 1 per cent.
The Park Barracks are now prepared for the reception of 100 sick or wounded soldiers, though some details in fitting up are still incomplete. Nurses and surgeons will be in attendance night and day.

story which reached us through Petersburgh and Norfolk, Va., that Gen. BURNSIDE, with five thousand troops, was defeated at Elizabeth City by one thousand rebels, obtained only credence enough to awaken some anxiety as to the where about and whatabout of the hero of Roanoke and Newborn, who we felt sure would give a good account of himself when he had the opportunity.

Davis vs. Hackley, the Messrs. Hope and Robt. T. Haws. The Court decided in this case that the plaintiff could read affidavits touching any new matter introduced by the defendants, and that the defendants should be allowed to reply to such affidavits, if they desired to do so.

There are not many matters of local interest now before the Washington public. The reported emeute in the Cabinet has excited more attention abroad than it did here. Mr. STANTON is said to have peremptorily demanded a change of military leaders in a certain department, which the President as peremptorily declined to make. Political experts said the Minister must resign but he did not.
Mr. TRUMBULL, of Illinois, (Rep.,) presented a petition from W. C. JEWETT for a defensive stand-still policy at Yorktown, C., to secure a reserve force of 250,000 men.
A dispatch from the fleet, dated 22d, says that for three days not a gun had been fired, the combatants seemingly satisfied to save their powder until something can be accomplished by its use.

Mr. Cox, of Ohio, (Dem.,) moved that the House proceed to the consideration of the Senate bill for the relief of the owners, officers and crew of the Danish bark Jorgen Lorentzen. He stated that the Secretary of State, for diplomatic reasons, desired the immediate passage of this bill. This vessel was seized by the blockading squadron under misapprehension, and taken to New-York. Eighteen hundred and fifty dollars is the sum proposed to be appropriated.

The one subject of thought and discussion continues to be the iron-plated steamers, floating batteries, cupola ships, C. It contains the LATEST INTELLIGENCE up to the moment of going to press. In addition, will be found, graphic letters from our correspondents at Headquarters, and letters from other divisions of the army.

David Colden Murray vs. Cornelirs Vanderbilt. This case has been stated in the TIMES on several occasions, and lastly in the issue of Dec. 17, 1861.

A gentleman arrived here to-day directly from Gen. McCLELLAN'S headquarters, and reports that our forces have greatly the advantage of the enemy, as time will show; that our sharpshooters are the terror of the rebel gunners. Our approaches command the rebel intrenchments. Everything is working as well as the most sanguine could wish.
A Special from Cairo to the Tribune says that the rise in the Tennessee River has reached here. The Ohio has risen an inch, and is still rising.

THE RETURN OF THE FRENCH MINISTER. As foreshadowed in my dispatch last night, the French war-steamer Gassendi arrived up the Potomac about noon to-day, with the French Minister, M. MERCIER, on board, direct from his mission to Norfolk and Richmond. When the steamer was off the Navy-yard salutes were exchanged, and another was fired at the Yard in honor of the French Minister.

In the senate, yesterday, a communication was received from the War Department, transmitting copies of contracts made by the Department in 1861. A great number of petitions from beer and malt liquor manufacturers were presented, asking for a reduction on the proposed tax. Mr. POWELL,...

The trial of Capt. ROBERT AVERY, Of the One Hundred and Second New-York Volunteers or, what is more familiarly known as "The Van Buren Light Guard" upon an indictment for murder in the first degree, was concluded in the Kings County Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday, when the jury rendered a verdict of "Not guilty." The history of this case was given briefly, in the TIMES yesterday.

A Special dispatch to the Chicago Times, from Pittsburgh, says that Gen. MITCHEL'S Division has arrived at Turcumbia, Alabama, and that he has now possession of 200 miles of the Memphis and Charleston Railroad. Large reinforcements arrived at Pittsburgh on the 22d inst.

Since my last letter steady progress has been made in the preliminary work for the capture of the fort. The Rhode Island and Connecticut troops alternate in picket duty, covering the engineers and their party while they are engaged, night and day.
The English Press and military authorities, have spoken, during the progress of this war, with undisguised contempt, or with severe rebuke, of the ability of our officers, both volunteer and regular.

A serious accident occured yesterday to the through train from this City to Washington, which resulted in the injury of several persons from this vicinity. The rear passenger car was thrown from the track, ten miles beyond the Susquehanna River, and striking against a dirt-car on a side track, was smashed to pieces, the passengers being scattered among the rubbish. A list of the passengers injured will be found in our dispatch.
rumor has reached us, based on statements made by passengers who have reached Cairo from up the Tennessee, that Gen. HALLECK has already attacked the rebel position at Corinth.

Better order never existed in an army than has prevailed among the troops occupying Falmouth. The stringent order directing all plunderers and marauders to be shot, if detected in the act, effectually prevented any destruction of property whatever during our advance upon Fredericksburgh, and since the occupation of our present quarters, but a single depredation was committed, which was immediately atoned for, and the perpetrators punished.

The Nashville Union is doing good service in bringing to light various interesting documents which the rebels would doubtless gladly have taken along with them in their precipitate flight from that city.

Our readers must have digested City Judge McCONN'S law, logic and other "beverages" by this time. A second reading of his letter satisfies us that we did injustice to this production when we only styled it "remarkable." It is more.

Late on Thursday night the United States steam transport Cossack arrived at this port, brining 149 wounded men from Newbern and Roanoke. They were in charge of Dr. WHITE, of the Ninth NewYork, and Chaplain J.B. CLARK, and were attended by Lieut. BENNETT, Dr. WHITE, Hospital Stewards HEVITAGE and COOK, and Nurses SMITH and HILL, of the Twenty-fifth Massachusetts, JAMIBSON of Fiftyfirst New-York, HERRICK and TILTON.

Deserters continue to arrive rapidly, and are taken up in the woods by our pickets, and thence conveyed to the flag-ship. I have had a conversation with one of them, from which I have derived many interesting facts.

In the Senate yesterday, Mr. SOERMAN present ed resolutions from the Legislature of Ohio, complaining that the rebel prisioners at Camp Chase in that State are allowed to retain the services of their slaves, thus practically establishing Slavery on the soil of Ohio. Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, said that he should call up the matter on Monday.

There are no local military items of special importance to report. At Fort Hamilton a great change has been made since Gen. BROWN went there. The General has the reputation of being's pretty stirct officer in fact, a martinet but, withal, a good man to a soldier who does his duty.

A special to the Times, dated Cairo to-day, says that passengers by the Bells of Memphis say that at Savanna they heard heavy firing in the direction of Pittsburgh.

Well, Mr. Editor, the Tammany election of Sachems,,which that excellent Democratic interpreter, the Leader, told us, in its long rallying article of last week, was to be "the most important," as well as the most thoroaghly canvassed and the most in tensely exciting that has ever taken place in the Society, is over.

A serious accident occurred to-day to the through train from New-York, at Charlestown, ten miles from the Susquehannah. The rear car was thrown off the truck by a misplaced switch, and after running 200 feet, struck sidewise against a loaded dirt car standing on a side track. The shock was very severe. Half the side of the car was stove in. The seats were demolished, and the passengers pitched headlong into the ruins.

A special meeting of the Chamber of Commerce was held yesterday afternoon, to take into consideration the subject of taxation and the best course of action to be recommended to the attention of Government for the raising of revenue to meet the altered circumstances of the country.

There is little danger that I shall reveal to you any of Gen. McCLELLAN'S plans in this letter. I may dash out as freely as I please and yet make no disclosure that the severest censorship might find fault with.

The rebels have decided to stake their cause upon two great battles at Yorktown in the East, and Corinth in the Southwest. At these points they have concentrated all their available forces in the two sections.
When the House adjourned yesterday the resolution of Mr. HUTCHINS, of Ohio, (Rep.,) was pending to censure Mr. VALLANDIGHAN, of Ohio, (Dein.,) for words spoken in debate against Senator WADE, c.

There has been very little firing for the last two days. The rebels are evidently saving their powder and shell for the grand fight. One of our sharpshoot ers shot a rebel picket through the lungs, yesterday morning, on the Yorktown road.

It is a bright, beautiful day. These April mornings in Virginia brim with more joyousness than crowns even the full cup of June in your more northern latitudes. It is impossible to sit and sip sunshine and cloud alternately and leisurely as we do among your mountains and valleys, one wishes to press the goblet, of which yon horizon seems the blushing rim, to his lips and drain it at a draught.

The steamers Belle of Memphis and Choctaw, from Pittsburgh Landing Wednesday morning, arrived last night. They were fired into 38 miles below Pittsburgh by a band of guerrillas, from behind some dwellings on the left bank of the Tennessee. The Choctaw received seven shots. Her mate was killed. The Belle of Memphis received twelve shots, mortally wounding one negro boy.
A flag of truce was sent to Norfolk, to-day, with dispatches. A pleasure party from Boston accompanied it. No news was made public, and it is stated no newspapers were received.

A tumor prevailed in Memphis last Monday, says the New-Orleans Crescent of April 4, that ANDREW JOHNSON had been shot and instantly killed in Nashville, and that the man who killed him had made good his escape. If not true now, probably it will be, some of these days.

The long reach of Plum Point shuts him out from our view.

A decimal system for the currency of coins, weights and measures, has been placed before Congress by JOHN M. VERNON, Esq., of New-Orleans. The system seems to be almost perfect in theory.

Operations at this place are temporarily suspended, by reason of the recent movement of Gen. POPE'S army up the Mississippi and Tennessee to Pittsburgh.
