The following manifesto has appeared in the Gorman papers of this City, and has been very extensively reproduced by the Gorman Pross throughout the country. thousands of adherents in this vicinity already, and is, therefore, of important interest:

Several deserters and refugees corroborate previous reports that JACKSON, after flying from our advancing column on Friday last, pushed forward to a point one mile north of Harrisonburgh, where a turnpike branches to the left, passing Magaugheystonn, on the south fork of the Shenandoah and the Blue Ridge, and running thence to Gordonsville. JACKSON'S ...
A sermon was preached last Sunday by Rev. N. L. RIOE, D.D., of this City, in which he took occasion to define his position on the great question of the day.
GENERAL: I have the honor to report to you, as commander of the second division of the army of the Ohio, the part taken by my brigade in the battle at this place on the 7th inst.
In a former article we noticed the pictures that were hung in the first gallery; in this, we refer to such as deserve mention, in the second and third galleries.

Maj.-Gen. C.F. SMITH died at Savanna, Tenn., at 4 o'clock this afternoon, of dysentery. He was taken sick shortly after the occupation of Savanna by the forces under him, and has been suffering and sinking slowly for some weeks, though his condition was not thought to be dangerous until the past week. His family have been notified of his death, and are on their way to Savanna.

The closing of most of the volunteer rendezvous has had a stimulating effect upon recruiting for the regular army. The various offices in the City booked upward of thirty men last week, which is more than double the weekly average of the last three months, and, in addition to this, the applicants generally were of a better class than those who usually present themselves for enlistment.

The combined movements ordered by Gen. FREMONT against the guerrilias in Webster County have proved eminently successful. Lieut. LAWSON, with one detachment employed in this service, has returned, and others are returning, in a severe running fight of seven miles, LAWSON killed 17 guerrillas and took 19 prisoners. The town of Addison, a small place, the only one in the new county, being deserted, was burned.

The recent battles, and a partial provision for expected requirements at Yorktown and elsewhere, have exhausted the stores of this Association, without meeting the pressing needs of the army, while the engagements now pending will inevitably most imperatively demand further large supplies of hospital stores. Under these circumstances the Association feel it to be their evident duty to appeal to the people of the ...
Hon, E.M. Stanton, Secretary of War: A fugitive black, just arrived from Portsmouth, brings the Petersburgh Express of yesterday, which contains the following dispatch:

NEW-ORLEANS is repossessed! The mortar and gunboat fleet of Capt. PORTER is in front of the City. The rebels have fled in conster- nation, after destroying, by military order, all the cotton in the presses and warehouses of the place, and burning all the steam craft at the wharves, except such as were required to carry off the munitions and supplies of the army, for which they would seem to have no use at home.

Hon. E.M. Stenton, Secretary of War Early this morning an advanced lunette of the rebels on this side of the Warwick, near its head, was carried by assault by Company II, first Massachuseitz Regiment. The work had a ditch six feet deep, with a strong parapet, and was manned by two companies of infantry, no artillery.

Your correspondent pleads guilty to a most grievous error in predicting the speedy downfall of Fort Pillow, and if pardon is granted for entering the field of prophecy on this occasion, he will promise never to do so again. Future military movements and results, we have now concluded, are among the most uncertain of all things, and we believe ...

The ship Black Prince, Capt. HOWES, arrived here this morning, from Ship Island 6th inst., vid Havana 15%, where she touched by convey Government dispotches to the United States Consul at that port. She also brings a large mail to this port.
The schooner Vigilant and J.J. Finlayson from Nassau, N.P., arrived here yesterday, bringing the rest of the wrecked steamer Karnak's passengers.

From a report received to-day, there is little doubt that the information communicated to the rebels in an editorial in Friday's issue of the Herald is being acted upon. The report alluded to is to the effect that a strong rebel force is concentrating, prob- ably from Richmond and Yorktown, at a point about six miles south of Fredericksburgh, for the purpose of disputing McDOWELL'S advance across the Rappahannock.

The Atlantic Monthly, for May, is as bright and fresh as the season. It opens with an excellent paper, entitled "Man Under Sealed Orders," from the pen of Rev. J. TREADWELL WALDEN, of Norwich, Conn., who takes an ariel flight with the electric telegraph and the steam-engine, and when they droop their weary wings, soars further...

Day and night the rebels continue to work on their intrenchments with the utmost vigor, and with- out suffering any serious molestation from our guns. Their miserable flag, which flaunted in proud defiance over a parapet on the day of our arrival, is less con- spicuous to-day.
The Memphis Aralanche of the 24d says, that on the 11th eighty Federal cavalry took possession of Pocahontas, Ark.
Steamer New Uncle Sam arrived from Pittsburgh this morning. There is no material change in military matters on the Tennessee.

The first volume of tho "Caxton Edition" of BAYARD TAYLOR'S works will be highly acceptable for either the library or the parlor. Substantially bound in cloth, of clear, large type, and embellished with numerous illustrative engravings, it is as serviceable in the hands of the studious as agreeable to the fancy of the cursory reader.

The full length and official report of what occurred in the House of Representatives on Friday, on the matter of Army and Navy con- tracts, is rather a discreditable exhibition of personalities. At the same time some public good may come of it, and certain private reputations will not profit by it.

The Journal of Commerce has been readmitted to the privileges of the mails. The Evening Express has never been excluded from them. Both are generously tolerated by the public authorities, but for no truth or genuine loyalty to the Government. The recent course of the one, in all that relates to the end of the war, le jesuitical; that of the other, sneaking and characteristic.

The military excitement here seems almost to have died out with the echoes of the guns that de- cided the possession of Pulaski. The little affair on Wilmington Island, of which I wrote you, was like a sharp thundergust succeeding a wild tempest; but the lightning marked its path with blood. The real warfare of elements also ceased about the same time; and the peaceful landscape now sparkles and glows in the brightest of sunlight.

When the British Government established the penny postage, the English law-makers saw that there would be a vast increase of correspondence, and that to give the people the greatest possible, advantage of the new facilities and low charges, and make the labor in tho Post Office as economical as possible, a11 redundant operations, useless ceremonies and everything like extra charges and double payments must be laid aside, or the new system would be a failure.
The river to still rising, and in some places gradually making its way over the levee.

The city is wild with rejoicing to-night over the news of the advance of our gunboats upon New-Orleans, in spite of the resistance of Forts Jackson and Philip, and the probable surrender of that city from the vile clutches of rebeldom, and its return to loyalty and trade with all the world. New-Orleans is probably in possession of Gen. BUTLER at present writing. The President is in high glee over the news.

New-Orleans has fallen! This glorious intelli- gence comes to us from the rebels, and we therefore have no right to doubt its correctness. The War Department has received the news from both Gen. WOOL and Gen. McDOWELL taken by the former from a copy of the Petersburgh (Va.) Ex- press, and by the latter from a copy of the Rich- mond Examiner of Saturday.

Thirty-nine soldiers (ten of them rebels) died to the Louisville hospitals last week. There are wounded and sick here from every Free State except New-York and the New-England States, and from every Slave State except the Carolinas, Georgia and Florida. Mrs. Judge MUIR reports to Mrs. N.B. SMITH, President of the Louisville "Soldiers' Relief Society," some two thousand hospital articles, besides several boxes crackers and rice from the Seventh Ward.
All the yards and lower masts of the Galena have been taken out, and nothing can be seen above deck but the smoke-stack.

A VISIT TO FREDERICKSBURGH. Mr. COVODE, from the Committee on the Conduct of the War, recently paid a visit to Falmouth, opposite Fredericksburgh, to note the movements in McDOWELL'S column. He returned yesterday, and after reporting progress, left in the afternoon train for Philadelphia, Harrisburgh and Pittsburgh.

A great deal of curiosity has been expressed of late as to the extent of the commercial relations of Nassau with the Confederate States of America. To gratify this very general desire, we have carefully examined the official records of the Customs, and are enabled to present subjoined a complete list of all the arrivals from the Contederate ports since the commencement of the Federal blockade.

The United States steamer Connecticut, Commander WOODHULL, from the blockading squadron, arrived at this port yesterday, bringing the mails and about two hundred sick and wounded seamen, from the various ships of the blockading squadron. She has also several refugees from Texas, who were taken from Matamoras by the United States gunboat Montgomery.

The destination of Commodore PORTER'S mor- tar flotilla is no longer a secret. It is bound to the Crescent City. The bomb-schooners are now anchored within the Mississippi Passes, and the large naval fleet of Commodore FARRAGUT, which is to operate conjointly with them, is also here, or hovering along the coast not far away, in readiness for entering the river at the shortest notice.

Yesterday afternoon the pickets of Col. DONNELLY'S Brigade, stationed eight miles hence on the Gordonsville Road, were attacked by large force of ASHBY'S rear guard, and driven back. One man named ISAAC ZELLY, of the Forty-sixth Pennsylvania Regiment, was killed, and three others wounded.

By the arrival of the steamship Connecticut at Hampton Roads on Saturday, the Navy Department has received dates from the Mississippi River to April 12, including dispatches from Flag-Officer FARRAGUT and Capt. PORTER of the bomb flotilla. At that time the steamships Mississippi and Pensacola were over the bar and the flotilla moving to be in readiness to take their positions.

The People of New-York vs. James Charles Halpin. This action is one of these brought to recover the penalty imposed by the 21st section of the act entitled. "An act to establish a Metropolitan Police District, and to provide for the government thereof," passed April 15, 1857.

Contrabands inform me that the most intense excitement exists around Norfolk, and great fear is felt of an attack by BURNSIDE. Nearly all of the troops have been sent from Norfolk, Portsmouth and Suffolk, to South Mills, to repel any advance that BURNSIDE might make.

Five contrabands left Portsmouth, opposite Norfolk, at 1 o'clock last night, and arrived here this morning. They bring several late papers and much valuable information. They are intelligent men, and give interesting accounts of affairs in the vicinity of Norfolk. They confirm the reported capture of New-Orleans by our forces, and state that much excitement prevails in the South regarding it.

The steamship North American, from Liverpool April 17, via Londonderry April 18, passed Cape Race at 11 o'clock yesterday (Sunday) morning. She was boarded by the news-yacht of the Associated Press, and the following summary of her news obtained, which is five days later.
I have before me a proclamation issued by ex-Gov. LETCUHER, published in the Harrisburgh Register of the 28th ult., calling for more troops, in which he uses this language.

Yesterday, no less than six desertors from the enemy, were conducted to headquarters, and the daily average for the past week will not fall far short of that number. A very important case of this kind occurred a few days ago, when a gentlemanly appearing person approached the pickets, and after giving the usual friendly intimations, expressed a desire to be led to the Commanding-General's quarters, where he was subsequently taken.
The steamer Estella, from Pittsburgh Landings has arrived.

By the arrival of the steamship North Amercan off Cape Race, we receive advices from Europe five days later. She left Liverpool on the 17th, and Londonderry on the 18th inst. The political news is not of much importance.

The ship Joseph Peabody has been forfeited to the Government, for smuggling. Trade has recently revived, to supply the demand for goods suitable to the Oregon and British Columbia miners, in advance of the anticipated large emigration thither. Business with the interior of the State continues unseasonably backward.

A trusty scout sent out by Gen. MILROY, went within seven miles of Staunton, and found there a rebel cavalry company, and learned that JOHNSTON shortly after leaving the Shenandoah Mountain, wes ordered back, but replied that its occupation by 10,- 000 Yankees made it impossible. He was then ordered to join JACKSON east of Blue Ridge which was being rapidly done.

Hon. EDWARD EVERETT publishes a graceful tribute to Lieut. WORDEN in the Boston papers, accompanying it with an appeal for subscriptions to some testimonial which shall show in a substantial manner the appreciation in which the public hold his services.

Among the numerous propositions for a scheme of finance or taxation, which shall produce a revenue equal to the greatly increased expenditures of Government, we have seen none that appears to accomplish this end so fully, and to which so few objections can be urged, as an uniform tax upon transfers, or sales of merchandise. The limit or amount of tax proposed is one per cent.

After many vexatious delays I have at last succeeded in reaching the advance of McDOWELL'S corps. Gen. AUGUR'S Brigade had already marched when I arrived at Catalet, and in the exigencies of the moment my horse had been pressed into service, thus rendering it impossible for me to follow, as not even a mule was to be had for either love or Treasury Notes.
The following memoranda from the pen of a gentleman who is familiar with New-Orleans, as it was at the middle of January last, have been handed us for publication:
A flag of truce to-day took dispatches and letters for the Union prisoners. No newspapers were received, or at least none came into the hands of the reporters of the Press.

Another cavalry reconnoisance yesterday met a rebel foraging party near Monterey. A sharp skirmish ensued, resulting in the death of five rebels, including one Major, and the capturing of nineteen prisoners. One man was wounded on our side.
A special dispatch to the Times, from Fort Wright, 28th, says:

Yesterday Gen. McCLELLAN, hearing that there were some officers in Washington who had not seen the review of the day but one previous, sent over an invitation to them to come out to Alexandria, where a review of 15,000 men, 42 guns, and a few horse was specially prepared for them by Gen. McDOWELL Lord LYONS and the members of the Legation were also invited, and were present.
Two prisoners and three deserters from the rebel army were taken yesterday morning within our lines. They belonged to Mississippi, Alabama, and Virginia regiments.

The United States gunboat Port Royal, Lieut. Commanding, GEORGE W. MORRIS left the Brooklyn Navy-yard yesterday afternoon on her trial trip, and was expected to return at a late hour. commodore GREGORY went out in her.
The steamship Bremen, from Southampton on the 16th April, arrived here yesterday morning. Her advices have been partially anticipated by the North American at Cape Race.

By advices from the Department of the Shenan- doah received to-day, Gen. BANKS, notwithstanding the bad roads, is cautiously pushing his advance toward Staunton, being already within a few miles of that place.

To the Associated Press: The rebels are apparently just realizing the fact that Gen. McCLELLAN is making extensive preparations to open the second siege of Yorktown. Up to yesterday, the works of our troops have steadily progressed, directly under the enemy's eyes, without any response from their guns, except an occasional shot sent to inform us that they were still there.

Joseph A. Veazie vs. Isaac Ames. This was an action to chargs the defendant, individually, as a stockholder of the American Blank Book Ruling and Paging company, with the payment of a note which that Company made in February, 1857, payable twelve months after date. An action had been brought against the Company, and judgment recovered for the amount of the note, with costs.
There can be no doubt of the capture of New Orleans. The Southern newspapers speak of it in the most dismal strain, and demand at the mystery of the surrender of the city shall be explained.

The reported receipts of the principal kinds of Produce since our last have been: 33 bbls. Ashes, 9,039 bbls. Flour, 9 bbls. and 172 bags Corn Meal, 2,868 bushels Wheat, 9,400 bushels Corn, 15 bushels Rye, 645 bushels Barley, 3,115 bushels Oats, 1,225 bushels Malt, 7,058 pkgs. Provisions, and 954 bbls. Whisky.

The time has come, in the rapid progress of events, for the Northern people to consider seriously their policy of reconstruction. Victories on the battle-field, capture of forts and batteries, the surrender of large cities and the military occupation of States as large as European kingdoms, are all very well ...

The rapid advance of Gen. Banks down the Valley of Virginia has brought him near Staunton, the capital of the valley region. Situated as the place is on the Central Railroad, the control of that important line of communication is thus placed in Union hands, so that the progress ...

It is conceded by every representative of the Press sojourning in this locality, that the present is the hardest of all hard times for correspondents. We have been put through the entire list of annoyances, and subjected to drivers tribulations. In the first place for a time at least our communications were forbidden the privileges of the mail unless first reviewed by the Government censor, as a schoolboy's ...

In other columns we give place to the manifesto addressed by the representatives of all parties in the State Legislature to their constituents. It recites a clear and comprehensive narrative of the events which have carried the country into the vortex of revolution ...

CENSURE OF SECRETARY CAMERON. The House adopted the resolutions reported by the Van Wyeke Corruption Committee, censuring ExSecretary of War CAMERON, but excusing Secretary WELLES from censure, Can the President allow a man with such a brand upon him to go as representative of the Government to the Court of the Cgar.

SOLDIERS: Your march upon Bowling Green won the thanks and confidence of your Commanding General. With engines and cars captured from the enemy, our advance guard precipitated itself upon Nashville. It was now made your duty to seize and destroy the Memphis and Charleston Railway, the great military road of the enemy.
The report of the Committee on the Conduct of the War, in reference to the atrocities perpetrated by the rebels upon the bodies of our soldiers who have fallen in battle shows, in its ...
The NEW-YORK WEEKLY TIMES No. 554, is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter, in wrappers, ready for mailing. It contains the LATEST INTELLIGENCE up to the moment of going to press.

Heavy bring on our right the morning, and heavy roll aroung us for the last fourteen hours, such has been the record of the day. The rebels have been endeavoring to am arrass our men at work in the trenches, and the elements seem to have ...

The Superintendent of Police received a telegram from St. Louis at a late hour last night, stating that RADETZSKI, the alleged murderer of FELLNER. was arrested in that city yesterday afternoon. An of ficer will immediately dispatched with a requisition from Gov. MOHKAN, for the purpose of bringing liba to New York, where the online is alleged to have been committed.
Joseph B. Vandervoort vs. Edward S. Gould. This was an action of ejectment, to recover the premises No. 18 Clinton-place, in this City.

To the Electors of the State of New-York: The undersigned, members of the Legislature, feel it incumbent upon them, on closing the session of 1862, to submit to the electors of this State some considerations as to the present condition of the country, and the political duties it devolves upon them.
in throwing up defensive works. He brings Memphis papers of the 26th. They contain little matter of interest, further than a confirmation of the fall of NewOrleans.

One hundred and one wounded soldiers are to arrive by steamer, this afternoon, from Newbern and Yorktown. They are on their way to their homes in the New-England States, and will be entertained for a short time at the rooms of the New-England Soldiers' Relief Association, No. 194 Broadway.
The news we receive from the rebels concerning New-Orleans is a remarkable medley, and the only fact that appears in it clear and certain is that the city is really in our possession.

DIED OF HIS INJURIES JOHN DIXON, the boy who was run over a few days ago by a car on Waterstreet, died yesterday at the City Hospital of the injuries received. Coroner NORRIS held an inquest, when a verdict of death from accidental causes was readered. The parents of deceased reside on Plymouth-street.

More than a week since, I mailed two letters by by the streamer Connecticut, under the impression that the was to return immediately North with dispatches from Commodore FARBAGUT. I was mistaken. She went down the Gulf to Galveston and Rio Grande with mails and supplies for the blockaders off those points, and is expected back to-morrow. I am glad that an opportunity is afforded me of sending some additional information.

A dag of truce from Norfolk, to-day, brought down the wife and family of Parson BROWNLOW, and also the wife of Congressman MAYNARD. The party, consisting of four ladies, two gentlemen and six children, are all from Tennessee. They bring the report that all the Union families of Tennessee have been ordered, by proclamation, to leave within ...

Gen. BANKS visited Gen. WILLIAMS' Division here last night and returned to Newmarket to-day, While here he received a dispatch from Washington announcing the occupation of New-Orleans by the Union forces. The Intelligence caused great joy

GOTTSCHALK'S CONCERT AT NIBLO'S SALOON. There can be little doubt that, whatever may be the opinion entertained by the professional musician respecting the merits of H.M. GOTTSCHALK, he is accepted by the public as one of the few artists who are...

A special dispatch to the Tribune from Cairo Says: The packet Diligence, from Tiptonville, reports an alarming stage of water in the Mississippi River. Hundreds of houses on the banks of the river at that place and New-Madrid are submerged, and thousands of cattle, sheep and hogs have been washed away.
The river has risen two inches in the last 24 hours. The steamer Belle Creole has arrived form Pittsburgh Landing. Her dates are to Wednesday noon.

It would seem that the illustrious mosstrooper, Dr. JENNISON, has achieved a victory over his Kansas persecutors. Gens. STURGIS and DENVER are said to have been relieved of their commands in the Territory, while the Doctor is relieved from his parole at St. Louis. Thus does everlasting justice vindicate itself.

THE VISIT OF M. MIRCIER TO RICHMOND. I have the best of authority for asserting that M. MERCIER, the French Minister, on his recent visit to rebeldom, did not see JEFF. DAVIS, and had no conversation in his offical capacity with any rebel officer. He did not recognize them as persons in authority.

I have just received a dispatch from Brig. Gen. MANSFIELD, to the effect that five negroes have arrived from Portsmouth. The contrabands report that Fort Macon was taken on Friday last. Eighteen rebels were killed and twenty-seven wounded.

Washington is in a state glorious excitement to-night over the news received by the Government that Fort Macon has surrendered to Gen. Burnside, and New-Orleans has surrendered to Gen. Butler; and last, though not least, the statement of the Richmond Examiner, that Gen. Beauregard has evacuated Corinth. By this favor from rebeldom, it will be perceived that the calculation, made in this correspondence last night, that Gen. BUTLER was in New-Orleans, was correct.

There hae been no change in the outward appearance of things at this place for the last two days. Certain indications now point to a speedy termination of our protracted siege, but I am not at liberty to say flow soon.

On the 24th inst., a company of cavalry from this place destroyed the extensive saltperte manufactory near Mellville Ark., and burned the building. Lieut. HICHOCK, of the Fourth Iowa Cavalry, was killed, and one private wounded in the skirmish with the rebels. A large quantity of supplies, hid, for the rebels' use, with deserters and Jayhawkers in the mountains, were captured by Gen. CURTIS' command.

Mr. HOWARD, of Michigan, (Rep.,) presented petittons in favor of a General Bankrupt law. Mr. WRIGHT, of Indiana, (Union,) presented a memorial of JOHN BROOK, offering to build a City Railroad in Washingotn in sixty days, and pay $10,000 annually to the city.

The NEW YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES, NO. 797, is Published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter, in wrappers, ready for mailing. It contains the LATEST INTELLIGENCE up to the moment of going to press.

fering to build a city railroad in Washington in sixty days, and to pay $10,000 annually to the city. A resolution offered by Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, relative to Kansas affairs, was laid over; also a resolution offered by Mr. DAVIS, declaring that the war shall be carried on for the restoration of the Union under the Constitution, and for no other purpose.

In my first letter form this place I intimated that Gen. Fremont was working vigorously, with all the means at his command, and stirring up all his Generals to advance movements, as far as practicable.

We are at last authoritatively informed that this large and flourishing commercial emporium of the South has fallen into the hands of Yankee vandals, who, by means of gunboats and hay bales, accomplish on water what they never can do by land. We have thus far received very brief particulars; but they are enough to satisfy us that the city has been evacuated by our troops, and is now in possession of the enemy.

Mr. BLAIR, of Missouri, (Rep.,) called up the bill, recently reported from the Military Committee, authorizing the appointment of a Board of Fortifications, to provide for the sea-coast and other defences of the United States, and other purposes, an abstract of which was published on the 24th of April.
By way of Fortress Monroe, through fugitive slaves, we have received Richmond and Norfolk papers a late as April 23 and 24 respectively, which furnish as the following interesting extracts:

The following correspondence, together with the announcement of the surrender of Fort Macon, N. C., taken from the Richmond Enquirer, of yesterday, which city it reached by telegraph, was, to-day, received at the War Department. The correspondence is between the Mayor of New-Orleans and Flag-officer FARRAGUT:
The Royal Mail steamship America, form Liverpool at 10 o'clock A.M. of the 19th ult., and Queenstown 20th, arrived at Halifax at 5 P.M. today. She has 35 passengers for Boston, No specie reported.
The United States vs. The Ship Hiawatha and her Cargo. The matter of the sale of the cargo of this vessel, which was postponed until this morning, came up again before the Court.
The news from Pittsburgh Landing is of the highest importance. Its transmission over the wires is prohibited.
The general hospitals here contain 913 inmates. Forty-two died in them this week.
A dispatch from Cairo says the news from Pittsburgh Landing is of the highest importance, but is not allowed to be telegraphed.

I am in receipt of a list of killed and wounded of the National troops who were on picket duty on the 27th, and in a skirmish with the enemy on the 26th ult. I subjoin it for the satisfaction of the friends of the injured:

Desertions from the rebel army here continue to be numerous. They are coming in daily, almost hourly, from various directions of their lines, and all agree in their statements of the rebel force, (about 100,000,) and of a very general depression of spirits among both officers and men. The news of our recent victories is kept sedulously from them. They were first informed of the fall of Island No. 10 upon coming into our camp.

Gov. LETCHER has issued a proclamation, under date of April 28, calling upon the Justices of the Peace in the frontier counties of Virginia to take active measures to apprehend and punish the "spies and disloyal persons who are continually making their way through the frontier counties of this State, and through counties in the possession of the enemy, giving them information detrimental to the Southern Confederacy and to the State of Virginia."

The following circular letter has been addressed by the Secretary of State to the several American legations labroad. It is proper to say the present text is a translation from a French version, which appears in the Archives Diplomatiques:

A detachment of recruits arrived here yesterday, in charge of a Sergeant, and were sent to Governor'S Island. They were enlisted in Boston, by Lieut. BROOM, for the general service. Lieut. BROOM was very successful last month, having enlisted more men than any other officer on the general recruiting service.

Since we have had so much of weather and so little of food lately, the usual highly original question of "What do you think of the weather?" has been laid aside for a little while especially that the question is answered in the face of every man and the more interesting one of "How's your appetite?" is employed in its place, with a vigor truly tantalizing in the present state of food.

The weather to-day is warm and clear, and highly favorable for the operations of the army. Three or four rebel boats made their appearance off Sewell's Point this morning, and seemed to be placing buoys to mark the channel.
The latest news from the fleet says it was generally believed that a simultaneous attack would be made by the fleet before the close of the week.
A dispatch received last night at headquarters, from Gen. Cox, of the Kanawha Department, speaks of still-continued storms. The roads are frightful.

It is rumored that the Senate will decline to substitute any other measure for the Tax bill passed in the House, pleading the want of time for the discussion of the scheme advocated by the Boston Board of Trade and the New-York Chamber of Commerce. The plea is frivolous. The bill passed by the House is a monstrosity, deformed by these, among a variety of other defects:

The mails by the steamship North American, bringing English papers to the l7th ult., reached this City last evening. The news is not so late as that of the America, though we find in our files a few extracts of interest.

The rebel plan of campaign and line of operations in the Southwest was, until a brief time ago, sufficiently grand and comprehensive. Their lines swept from the Cumberland Mountains through Central Kentucky with "impregnable" works at all important points crossed the Mississippi at Columbus, from Athenes continued to the westernmost verge of Missouri, with outposts extending through the Indian and New-Mexican frontiers..

Gen. R. Saxton, U.S.A.; Col. Manleverer, and Lieut. Stevenson, of H.B.M. Thirtieth Regiment, from Canada West; George Livermore, of Boston; Capt. Jas. L. Day, of Connecticut, and Mr. McDonald, of Montreal, are at the Fifth-avenue Hotel.
The new iron-clad steamer Ironsides, it is expected, will be launched from the yard of CRAMP SON, Kensington, some day next week, though the exact time has not been fixed upon.
Our correspondent at Fortress Monroe has received Norfolk and Petersburgh (Va.) papers of Thursday, and on information contained in them, telegraphs as follows:
By way of Fortress Monroe, we have Petersburgh, Richmond, and Norfolk papers as late as April 29, from which we make the following extracts:
A Participant in the battle of "Sawyer's Lane," (this is the name given to it by Col. WRIGHT,) on the 19th of April, furnishes the following to the Norfolk Day Book:

On Tuesday, a steamboat was seen, with a load of rebel tropes, at Yorktown. They probably came from West Point, thirty miles above, indicating that the enemy are being reinforced, instead of preparing to evacuate.

As soon as the Committee of the United States House of Representatives had reported on the Reciprocity Treaty, Hon. A.T. GALT, the Canadian Minister of Finance, drew up a counter-blast, in the shape of a report to His Excellency the Governor-General, in Council, which alludes not only to the pamphlet issued by that Committee, but also to the memorial of the St. Paul Chamber of Commerce.

The reported receipts of the principal kinds of Produce since our last have been: 71 bbls, Ashes, 11,515 bbls. Flour, 1,307 bags Corn Meal, 13,263 bushels Wheat, 450 bushels Rye, 775 bushels Barley, 1,295 bushels Oats. 3,095 bushels Malt, 7,945 pkgs. Provisions, and 804 bbls. Whisky.

CAPTAIN: The brief telegraphic report, which I gave the 9th inst., is not sufficient to present even the general outline of the battle of Pea Ridge, and with the reports of my Commanders of Divisions, I now submit a more general detail.

The remains of Gen. C.F. SMITH will arrive here this afternoon, and be received by the military; after which, they with lie in start until Tuesday afternoon, when the funeral ceremonies will take place. The Home Guards will participate in the ceremonies.

After a bombardment of eleven hours by two Batteries of mortars and one of Parroit guns, Fort Macon, with its garrison, armament, provisions and stores, was surrendered to Acting Major Gen. PARKI, commanding the Third Division of Gen. BURNSIDE'S army, on the 25th inst. The casualties on our side were one killed and two wounded; of the enemy, eight killed and twenty wounded.

Oddly enough, Oddly enough, the uniform success of all the expeditions di- rected by the National Government against the various rebel strongholds is, perhaps, in a considerable degree owing to the monstrous exaggerations indulged in by the rebels. No sooner is it conjectured that a certain point is aimed at by the National force than rebel report forth with endows the locality with every conceivable and inconceivable means of defensive and offensive warfare.

The pilot-boat Chase, from Nassan, N.P. for this port, says the Charleston Merchry, 29th was chased ashore by the Lincoln fleet, on Saturday last, and grounded on the Raccoon Keys, where she was burned by the officers and crew, to prevent her falling into the hands of the enemy. She had on board a cargo of sait, The officers and men have serived here.

We understand that the impression has gone abroad that the Provost Marshal of this district has established a scale of prices for produce to be sold at. Such is not the fact. The only material alteration that has been made in the market is the abolition of huckstering or forestalling.

Our Law column on Monday contained a sketch of the arguments urged by the learned counsel of the Liquor Dealers' Association, before the General Term of the Common Pleas, in behalf of Sunday dram-selling. The history of the case is worth relating; the argument we leave to the able and honest Court to which it was addressed.

On the the 18th ult., the army forces under Gen. RENO, debarked at Cobb's Point, N.C., for the purpose of destroying the locks of the Disinal Swamp Canal. Having retired without accomplishing the object, Commander ROWAN determined to destroy the canal with the naval forces under his command. The following is the report of the sucessful accomplishment of the work:
The United States transport steamer Empire City, Capt. BARTON, from Port Rayal, on the 30th ult., arrived at this port early this morning.

For some length of time, there has been movement on foot in this City, having a view toward the erection of a new Opera-House, and we believe that the arrangements with a view toward it have at length been definitely completed. The wishes of those who have been engaged in maturing this scheme were to build a theatre, and, in building it, to do away with two of the all abuses...

The interest and agitation produced beyond the Atlantic by the late exploits of American ironclad vessels of war, is not only unabated, but seems, to judge from the contents of each succeeding European mail, to be rather on the in- crease.

The news from New-Orleans, confirming the fall of that city, has been read here with sorrow, but we are not dispirited, and do not doubt our final success.

The schooner Levi Rowe Capt. KELLER. arrived at this port yesterday, from Nassau, N.P. which port she sailed from on the 19th of April. She brings us the Nassau Guardian of that date, and the following inteligence from our Consul at that place.

During a passage through many, and a sojourn in a few of the towns on the line of the Rock Island, and Michigan Southern and Northern Indiana railways, during the past week, we have ascontained, by inquiries and personal inspection, that the growth of winter wheat never looked more promising. Col. DAVIDSON, of the Third Mississippi Regiment captured at Fort Donelson, died at Fort Warren on Tuesday. His body has been sent to his friends.

According to reliable information from Richmond, the planters have determined to raise no tobacco this season, and the military had seized the stock on hand, to prevent its falling into the hands of the Federal army.

The Memphis Argus, of the 29th of April, has the following dispatches: CORINTH, MONDAY, April 28. Gen. BEAUREGAND is moving large bodies of troops southward; some go by railroad, and others afoot. A few have gone west. It is generally understood that he is evacuating the place, though he declines answering questions. He says that President DAVIS understands his movements.

The Savannah Republican states that the prisoners released from Hilton Head and returned to Charleston, represent that frequent communication is kept up between the enemy and the main land. The Savannah pagers, they say, are received regularly and of the latest dates, by the fleet and the garrison on the Tybee. The Republican adds:

We append a brief synponsis of the proceedings of the Court-martial that condemned the above person, in order to a correct understanding of the matter alleged against him, and for which he yesterday, at 22 minutes past 11 o'clock, suffered the exterme penalty of the law at the military camp at the New Fair Grounds.

We judge from all we can learn that affairs in East Tennessee are in a most deplorable condition. The passage of the law by the legislature at Memphis, authorizing a draft has tested the greatest consideration a among the Union men who were willing to stay at home and quietly pursue their ordinary avoca- tions, and reports reach here that thousands are flee- ing into Kentucky, to avoid being forced into the Con- federate army.

The following, from the report of Lieut. Commanding GWIN, of the United States gunboat Taylor, addressed to Commander FOOTE, has been received at the Navy Department. The report is dated Ham- burgh, Tenn., April 23:

A portion of our troops were ordered under arms this morning before light, indications leading one of the Generals to suppose that the enemy were preparing for an attack at daybreak. It was a false report, however, the enemy making no demonstration; nor are they likely to do so, being abundantly satisfied if they can make good their position where they are, without desiring to assume the offensive.
The War Department at noon to-day received advices from Gen. HALLECK, from which it is inferred that important events will take place in the neighborhood of Corinth within the next two or three days.

To Hon. E.M. Stanton, Secretary of War: SIR: I have the honor to report my safe arrival at ship Island on the 21st of March, after a series of casualties, set forth in my last report from Port Royal to the General commanding the army, but from thence no further accident.
The various Societies religious and benevolent commenced their anniversary celebrations yesterday, and will continue during the week as follows:
To Hon. E.M. Stanton, Secretary of War: Your dispatch is received. A soldier's highest reward for service is to merit and receive the approbation of his superior officers.

At an early hour on Sunday, under the profound darkness of the night, the entire rebel army in and near Yorktown, reckoned by common report at a hundred thousand men, evacuated their intrenched position, leaving their heavy guns, a vast amount of ammunition and medical stores, and the private property of their officers behind them.

The Thirty-eighth Anniversary of the New York Bible Society took place last evening in the church corner of Fifth-avenue and Twenty-ninth-street. The exercises were commenced by reading of the Scriptures and prayer by Rev. Dr. SHEDD.
The Santa Fe mail has arrived.

A very able discourse was delivered, last evening before a large and attentive audience, at the Madison-square. Presbyterian Church, (Rev. Dr. ADAMS',) by Prof. HOWARD CROSBY, D.D., of Rutgers College, New-Brunswick, N.J. It was the occasion of the Anniversary of inquiry of the Union Theological Seminary; there was, consequently, a large attendance of the members and friends of the Association.

ERAL'S DEPARTMENT. On Wednesday last Mr. WILSON introduced a bill in the Senate for the reorganization of the Adjutant-General's Department of the Army. It is understood that this measure was initiated at the suggestion of the President, and has the warm approval of the Secretary of War, and of all the experienced Generals now in command.
The following two important circulars have been addressed to the foreign ministers, announcing the reopening of communication with Southern localities reconquered from the insurgents:

We publish in the TIMES of this morning the opinion of Judge SELDEN in this important will case, who, with Judge SUTHERLAND, dissented from the judgment of the majority of the Court. The litigation commenced in March, 1856, at the death of Mr. HENRY PARISH, and is now terminated by the judgment of the Court of Appeals.

Evidence is accumulating that it is the intention of the enemy to evacuate Yorktown shortly. Nothing decisive has been received, but many rumors looking in that direction have been brought in by deserters, and appearances indicate it all along our line.

The news of the evacuation of Yorktown by the rebels produced a prodigious sensation in Washington, and before the full facts were obtained, the same wild clamor against Gen. McCLELLAN was raised that assailed him after the enemy's abandonment of Manassas. There were hundreds of heroes in political life who always knew the rebels never had thirty thousand men at Yorktown, and never intended to fight there.
A special to the Times from Cairo to-day says that a refugee from Memphis brings the news of the occupation of Baton Rouge by the Federal forces, and the passage up the river of the gunboats.
The Merrimac, with two steamers, made her appearance yesterday afternoon. After sailing around Sewall's Point for two hour, she returned to Crancy Island, without exchanging a shot.
American Anti-Slavery Society, Dr. Cheaver's Church, Union square, 10 o'clock A.M., and evening. American and Foreign Christian Union, at Irving Hall, Fourteenth-street, 10 o'clock A.M.
The steamship Hammonia, from Southampton on the 23d ult., arrived at this port late last night. Her advices are three days later.

There was evident pleasure depicted on the countenances of divers Congressmen to-day, while a short-lived rumor prevailed that Gen. McCLELLAN's advance column of Union soldiers had been drawn into an ambuscade near Williamsburgh, and severely handled by the rebels.

When, three weeks ago, the Envoy of the French Government sought permission to visit the rebel capital, and having obtained it, left upon his mysterious errand, public curiosity was profoundly stirred. What at a moment so critical could be the business between the French Emperor and the rebel chief? Was it in the interest of France, or of mankind, or, more strictly, of the American people, that these impenetrable negotiations were to be conducted?
COTTON Sales, for two days, 20,000 bales; market firm, with an upward tendency; but prices are unchanged. Speculators and exporters took 10,000 bales.

The Tenth Annual Convention of the National Typographical Union was commenced yesterday morning at 10 o'clock, in the chamber of the Board of Councilmen, City Hall, JOHN M. FARQUKER, of Chicago, President, in the Chair, and THOS. J. WALSH, of New-York, Secretary. Delegates were present from the States of New-York, Pennsylvania, Missouri, Massachusetts, Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Rhode Island, Iowa, Ohio and California.

In the Senate, yesterday, after the presentation of petitions, the bill to limit the number of Major and Brigadier-Generals, was reported back from the Military Committee, with an amendment making the number of Major-Generals thirty instead of twenty. This amendment was adopted. A de- bate then occurred in reference to the number of Brigadier-Generals proper to appoint a point which was not decided.

Hon E.M. Stanton, Secretary of War: Our cavalry and horse-artillery came up with the enemy's rear guard in their intrenchments, about two miles this side of Williamsburgh. A brisk fight ensued just as my Aid left. SMITH'S Division of infantry arrived on the ground, and, I presume, carried his works, though I have not yet heard. The enemy's rear is strong, but I have force enough up there to answer all purposes.

The NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES, No. 798, is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter, in wrappers, ready for mailing. It contains the LATEST INTELLIGENCE up to the moment of going to press.

Yorktown was evacuated entirely by the rebels at 2 o'clock on the morning of the 4th. During all the preceding day and night they kept up a heavy firing on our batteries all along the lines to cover their retreat. Our pickets pressed their positions on the morning of the 4th, and entered their abandoned intrenchments.

The firing from the rebels yesterday extended along our entire lines. The principal point aimed at was the Old Mill, on the Yorktown road. Several 68-pound shells fell in close proximity to it, without doing any damage.

The steamship Hammonia, from Southampton on the 23d ult., with advices from Europe three days later, arrived at this port late last night. The news is not specially important. The news of some of the recent great successes of the National arms had reached England, and created some excitement. The comments of the London Times on these events will be found elsewhere in this morning's TIMES.
No further news has been received at the War Department from Fortress Monroe or Yorktown. The boat for Cherrystone had probably been delayed by the storm which prevailed in that region.
The steamship Northern Light, Capt. TINKLEPAUGH, from Aspinwall on the 27th ult., arrived at this port yesterday, with the California mails and treasure $623,058.

The following statement, dated yesterday, on five Rappahannock, has reached Washington. A colored man came in to-day from the other side of the river, and represented himself as JEFF. DAVIS' coachman. From an examination of him, this is proba- bly the truth. He repeats scraps of conversations overheard while driving Mr. and Mrs. DAVIS in the carriage, and between Mr. DAVIS and those who came to see him.
The Twenty-ninth Anniversary meeting of the American Anti-Slavery Society commenced yesterday morning, in the Church of the Puritans.
Judge McCUNN has returned to the charge, his opportunity being the charge to the Grand Jury. We should-grieve profoundly to find ourselves classed with those who see no good in this magistrate.
MONTEREY, Tenn., Tuesday, May 6. Rain has fallen in torrents for the past thirty hours, putting the roads in a horrible condition.

WASHINGTON, Tuesday, May 6. Mr. TEN EYCK, of New-Jersey, (Rep.,) presented a petition, asking euqal privileges in the mails for certain newspapers.

PHILADELPHIA, Tuesday, May 6. The remains of Gen. C.F. SMITH, the hero of Fort Donelson, were removed from Independence Hall, to their last rosting-place at Laurel Hill, this afternoon. The ceremonies, which were of the most solemn character, were participated in by a large number of officers of the army, including Gen. ROBERT ANDERSON, and the navy, together with all the civic dignitaries.

A pleasant little story is told in our English files, of the way in which the British ship Emilie St. Pierre, a prize of our blockading squadron, made captive her captors, and sailed into Liverpool the other day with all sail bent and colors flying.

In the Senate, yesterday, a resolution was offered by Mr. SHERMAN, of Ohio, and laid over, asking the Secretary of War for copies of all reports of the battles at Pittsburgh Landing. The Homestead bill was taken up and passed--33 to 7.

WASHINGTON, Tuesday, May 5. THE MISSION OF M. MERCIER--A CONFIRMATION. The Washington Star of this evening has news from Richmond so strongly confirmatory of my account of the reasons of the French Minister's visit to the rebels, that I send you the leading points. It purports to be a letter from Fortress Monroe, dated on Sunday, and says:
The steamship Edinburgh, from Liverpool on the 23d, and Queenstown on the 24th ult., arrived at this port last evening. The advices are one day later than were received by the Hammonia.

The United States steam transport Ben De Ford, Commander J.C. PARKER, Jr., arrived at this port last night from Port Royal, having sailed thence on the 3d inst., at 4 P.M. She brings forty-three cabin passengers, five children, and eighty-two passengers in the steerage, and a number of refugees from Jacksonville.

U.S.S. TUSCARORA, ALGESIRAS, Friday, April 11, 1862. The merchants of New-York may at last regard the career of the Sumter as closed. We have managed to keep her closely blockaded in Gibraltar for two months, having the advantage of lying in hospitable Spanish waters, from which British impudence could not eject us, and finally the pirate appears to be giving up in despair.

A dispatch from Gen. McCLELLAN to the Secretary of War, dated 10 o'clock on Monday night, announces that he had found the enemy in large force and strongly intrenched at Williamsburgh, under command of Gen. JOE JOHNSTON himself, and evidently intending to dispute his progress towards Richmond with all their power.

Proofs accumulate as to the correct ness of our special Washington advices yesterday concerning the real object of the visit of M. MERCIER to the rebel Capital, and the nature and purport of his communications with the rebel leaders.
It is almost bewildering to attempt to follow the campaign in the Virginia peninsula, as reported in the rapid throng of telegrams.
The screw-steamer Edinburgh, Capt. MIREHOUSE, which sailed from Liverpool at 3 o'clock on the afternoon of the 23d, and from Queenstown on the 24th ult., arrived here last evening.

WASHINGTON, Tuesday, May 6. The United States gunboat Huron captured, on the 19th ultimo, off Charleston, the schooner Glide, of Charleston, while attempting to run the blockade. She was bound to Nassau, and was loaded with 100 bales of cotton and five fierces of rice. Her papers and logbook were thrown overboard during the cruise.

Prophesying has proved rather a profitless business since the war began, yet the number of parties who have gone into it, and the amount of capital invested and sunk in it, both on this side of the water and abroad, was never greater.
Of the partisan rebel troopers who annoy the rear of our army in Tennessee, the most noted is a cavalry corps commanded by one MORGAN.

BIVOUAC, IN FRONT OF WILLIAMSBURGH, Monday, May 5, 1862--10 o'clock, P.M. Hon. E.M. Stanton, Secretary of War: After arranging for movements up York River, I was sent for here. I find Gen. JOE JOHNSTON in front of me, in strong force, probably greater a good deal than my own.
ATCHISON, Kansas, Tuesday, May 4. The municipal election to-day resulted in the election of most of the Union and anti-jayhawkets ticket by a majority of 30.

The work of reducing the rebel strongholds will be commenced this morning. How long the struggle will be prolonged no one is able to prophesy. We all know that a formidable task is before us; that desperate men, fighting for the last stake, are our opponents. But of our ultimate success every body is confident.

Brig.-Gen. STORGLS arrived here yesterday, and to-day assumed command of the District of Kansas, Gen. DENVER is ordered to the command of all the troopps in Southern Kansas. So we go. Another ProSlavery General arrived, and if the telegraph is to be believed, still another is coming. Gen. HALLECK reports JIM CRAIG, of St. Joseph, Mo., as ordered to command in the Indian Territory.

Gen. FREMONT has issued a circular containing instructions in regard to prisoners, somewhat as follows: Prisoners will not be surrendered to the Unit- ed States Marshal until they are indicted.

veyor ANDREWS and his Deputy, W. BROWN, in company with Officer O'KEEFE, boarded the Columbia, yesterday, upon her arrival from Havana, and took into custody a young man who gave his name as JOHN WM. HAMMOND, upon the charge of being an officer in the rebel army.

The British screw-steamer Phaton brought with her from Vera Cruz to Havana several documents of interest lately published in Mexico. The first of these is a manifesto from President JUAREZ, dated April 12.

An expedition, consisting of eight hundred men, with two pieces of artillery from SIMONSON'S Battery, started from Huntsville on Saturday last, for the purpose of destroying the bridge over the Tennessee River, near Bridgeport, thus preventing any advance upon our position from Richmond or Chattanooga. Any reinforcements intended for Corinth (according to the plan of BEAUREGARD, as revealed in the telegram which I have already sent you) would also be cut off.

Yesterday afternoon, a detachment of the Fifth New-York Cavalry made a reconnoissance toward Harrisonburgh. When five miles this side they encountered upwards of 200 of ASHBY'S Cavalry. They charged upon them and pursued them within two miles of town. Ten rebels were killed and six taken prisoners.
There is nothing very "stunning" in the way of news from these "scratchings," everything being quiet except the Legislature, which is in session, and that is anything but quiet.

The friends of Hon. SIMON CAMERON, ExSecretary of War, gave him a public dinner, at Harrisburgh, Penn., on Saturday evening last, preliminary to his departure for Uurope. Mayor KEPNER presided, and, after the cloth was removed, Mr. CAMERON made a speech in response to a toast in his honor, which the Harrisburgh Telegraph reports at length. After reviewing some recollections of early life indicative of the vast progress made by Harrisburgh, Mr. CAMERON said:
I avail myself of the departure of the steamer Haze for New-York to forward a few items of interest, which have occurred since my last dispatch.

Fort Jackson, which is by far the stronger work, is a regular pentagonal bastioned fortification, having two fronts bearing on the river, and three on the land side. The land fronts have each a glacis and covered way, and the channel is commanded by a battery of twenty-five guns.
Yesterday morning our troops followed up the retreating rebels with great rapidity, and overtook them at Williamsburgh, where they fought all day.

PATE'S PIANO-FORTE PLAYING. On Saturday night, the fifth and last concert of the Brooklyn Philharmonic Society was given at the Academy of Music, with an attractive programme, including orchestral selections from SPOHE, LISTZ and MENDELSSOHN, and two operatic airs from TOMBESI, with piano-forte compositions by THALBERG and WOLLENHAUPT for Master WILLIE PATE.

For a naval battle of varied and thrilling interest, in which not only ship fights ship, and cannon thunders responsively to cannon, but in which ships fight forts, ships (wooden ships) fight iron-clad rams, fight chain barriers, masked batteries, fire-rafts, fire-eaters and whatever other warlike enginery Southern ingenuity may have devised, there is nothing equal to the one fought near the mouth of the Mississippi for the possession of the Southern metropolis.
Our naval loss at the battle on the Lower Mississippi was but two boats, the Varuna and Maria J. Carlton.

He is the denizen of a country eight millions of the inhabitants of which are willing to allow him to exist there in the capacity of a slave,and eighteen millions are unwilling to allow him to exist there in any capacity at all.

In the Senate yesterday, a number, of petitions were presented, among them one from citizens of Maryland, asking for the repeal of the act abolishing Slavery in the District of Columbia. The House bill to provide for the deficiency in the appropriation for the payment of volunteers, and for the payment of troops in the Western Department, was reported.
The flag of truce, which went up James River yesterday morning to receive released prisoners, returned to-day without having accomplished its object. The boat anchored all night off Day's Point.

The regular news letter from Old Point, is received. It says the mail boat Nelly Baker arrived just before the Old Point boat left, and reported that Gen. McCLELLAN was in Williamsburgh, having driven the enemy from his position there.

The recent threatening of hostilities between the United States and Great Britain has affected the quiet La Plata as would a terrific storm. For more then a month all the vessels that came in stayed, except here and there an adventurous bark. Purchases for the United States or for England were nearly suspended. One American vessel, the Brothers, was sold to sail in future under a German flag, and two Balti- more vessels changed flags.

THE CONGREGATIONAL SOCIAL REUNION will take place at the Brooklyn Academy of Music this evening at 7 o'clock. Among the speakers announced are Dr. THOMPSON, Prof. HITCHCOOK, Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER, Dr. EELLS and WM. ALLEN BUTLER, Esq. The plan of combining short, pithy addresses with sociability, singing and instrumental music, is an attractive feature of this meeting.

Our army correspondent in North Carolina is indebted to Prof. MAILLEFERT and Capt. HAYDEN, Submarine Engineer Corps, for the accompanying draft of the battle-field of Camden, or South Mills, fought on the 19th of April. These gentlemen accompanied the expedition, and were all the time present on the field.
I wrote you last that a Mr. TAYLOR, reported a Union man, and believed to be such on the strength of a pass he held from Gen. POPE, was shipping his cotton to New-York.

The enemy evacuated this place and their works in front last night, the rear guard passing through about 6 o'clock. At 9 o'clock Gen. McCLELLAN and escort entered the town and took possession. About one hundred and fifty of the enemy's wounded were left behind, without any rations, medicine or surgeons. They also left a number of their dead unburied. All of our wounded in yesterday's engagement who fell in their hands were left behind.

William Donohue vs. John Kelly. Sheriff, et al. This was an action to recover possession of certain personal property. The defence set up was that the sheriff seized the property, which consisted of about $1,200 worth of liquors, under an execution in favor of James Wallace, his codefendant, and against one Peter Murphy.

The gallant fighting of the National soldiers under Gen. McCLELLAN on Monday was too much for the rebels, and on Tuesday night they evacuated their new position at Williamsburgh, and continued their retreat toward Richmond, followed on Tuesday morning by our victorious troops.

THE AMERICAN UNION ITS EFFECT ON NATIONAL CHARACTER AND POLICY ETC. By JAMES SPENCE. (Third Edition.) London: RICHARD BENTURY, New Burlington-street. 1862. Among the literary productions evoked in England by the present American rebellion, the above work of Mr. SPENCE is ranked the foremost, on account of its supposed thoroughness and fairness. The author lays no claim to impartiality. A brief outline will set forth its shining qualities.

We learn that large shipments of Quarteremaster's and Commissary stores are now being made to Monterey from Clarksburgh, both by wagons and by pack mules. The mud on the roads along the route is, in many places, belly deep to the horses.

By the arrival of the Columbia from Havana we receive advices from Vera Cruz to the 24th ult. The news is important, and indicates immediate hostilities between the French and the Mexicans, in fact, hostilities had already commenced.
The Royal Mail steamer Australasian, Capt. ANDERSON, which sailed from Liverpool at 8.30 on the morning of the 26th, and from Queenstown on the 27th ultimo, arrived here last evening.

THE NEWS FROM WILLIAMSBURCH, The news from Williamsburgh, to-day, of the expulsion of the rebels from that stronghold by Gen. McCLELLAN, is an extinguisher on his enemies. Men who reviled him yesterday, now admit that he is "all right," and must make havoc of the retreating rebels. PRESIDENT LINCOLN AND SECRETARY STANTON...

The following documents give a complete idea of the operations of the mortar fleet. They are furnished by our Special Correspondent, whose letters we published yesterday morning:
