London, at the close of its great Easter holiday, was thrown into a fever of excitement by the arrival of a steamer with the most important news which has been received since the great war in America began. The fall of Island No. 10 was expected.

The important news which we publish this morning, that the iron-clad man-of-war Ga- lena, and two gunboats, started up the James River early yesterday morning, with the object of cutting off the retreat of the rebel army southward, indicates a speedy and decisive issue to the campaign in Virginia.
A dispatch from Fayetteville announces that the advance of Gen. Cox, composed of part of the Twenty-third Ohio, under Maj. COWLEY, occupied Giles Court-House and Darrows, on New River, yesterday.
The following is a list of the killed and wounded, so far as they relate to the regiments named: THIRTY-SEVENTH NEW-YORK REGIMENT.

Accounts from Yorktown to Wedne noon bring us reports that Gen. McCLELLAN was at that time some distance beyond Williamsburgh, in full pursuit of the flying rebel army, which was retreating in the greatest panic across the Chickaboundry River. Our forces came up with them the second time about eight miles from Williamsburgh, where they attempted to make another ...

The anniversary meeting of the New-York Anti Slavery Society took place last evening, at the Cooper Institute. The room was crowded with one of the finest audiences in every respect that has gathered in anniversary week.

The reported receipts of the principal kinds of Produce since our last have been 53 bbls, Ashes, 18,069 bbls, Flour, 123 bbls, and 501 bags Corn Meal, 23,028 bushels Wheat, 3,450 bushels Corn, 30 bushels Barley, 2,013 bushels Oats, 8,857 pkgs. Provisions, and 1,499 bbls, Whisky.

At the annual Commencement of this popular and growing institution, which took place on Wednesday evening, 7th inst., there were gradnated thirty students. The exercises were highly complimentary to the patrons and friends of the University. The orations of the young gentlemen who spoke evinced a practical, as well as a theoretic knowledge of the legal science.
The boat from Yorktown to-day brings reports from the army to 12 o'clock M. The enemy was still in full retreat, and followed closely by our cavalry.
We have this day transferred the MERCHANT TAILORING DEPARTMENT of our business from the second floor of the store corner of Broadway and Warrenst., to the second floor of our store.
A correspondent of the Cincinnati Gazette, writes under date of Pittsburgh Landing, April 30:

The Convention convened Tuesday morning, at 10 o'clock, in the Chamber of the Board of Councilmen, President FARQUHER of Chicago, in the Chair, and a quorum present. The Convention listened to an address from the presiding officer, in which he briefly alluded to the progress made by the Typographical Union, which, not even the hated rebellion of the South had obstructed, and predicted greater success in the future than any enjoyed in the past.

Mr. BROWNE, of Rhode-Island, (Rep.,) from the Committee on Elections, called up the Iowa contested election case. It refers to Mr. VANDEVER, and involves the question whether, under the Constitution, a member of Congress can hold this position at the same time that he has a military commission, and is in command of a regiment.
A special dispatch from Cairo to the Times says:

The Annual Reunion of this Society took place in the Academy of Music last evening. The house by 7 o'clock, the hour announced for the exercises to commence, was filled from parquette to gallery, a major portion of the audience, as is usual on such occasions, being composed of ladies. The stage was occupied by a large number of clergymen and a num- ber of distinguished laymen, representing nearly if not every ecclesiastical denomination.

Two thoroughly "reliable gentlemen," Kentuckians, who have just arrived from New-Orleans, report that all along the Mississippi, from Memphis to New-Orleans, there is one general bonfire of property, particularly of cotton, of which 11,700 bales were burned at New-Orleans.

In the Senate yesterday, Messrs. FOSTER, of Connecticut; DOOLITTLE, of Wisconsin, and DAVIS, of Kentucky, were appointed a Special Committee to consider the Humphreys impeachment case presented by the House. The House bill, to establish a port of entry and delivery at Hilton Head, S.C., was passed. A petition from citizens of Florida, asking the passage of a confiscation bill, was presented.

All day yesterday the great army was moving forward. At the right, Gen. LEW, WALLACE pushed on until near Bethel, where he camped for the night. In doing this, constant skirmishing ensued between his command and the enemy. Their pickets swarmed on every hillside, and for hours rapid volleys of musketry were interchanged. As the rebels fled back ...
The following is from the American's account of the battle at Williamsburgh:
In this Court, yesterday, before Judge McCUNN, John Sullivan was tried for grand larceny, and acquitted.

Our naval force here, consisting of the Crusader, Coast-survey steamer Bibb, and the gunboat Hale, have had little else to do lately but keep a close watch of the rebels, with a purpose to prevent the erection of batteries on Edisto River. Yesterday, however, the monotony was agreeably broken.

There is a great jubilee in the army to-day. At noon to-day 100 guns were fired in honor of the York- town victory. Consolidated bands visited Gens. BANKS, WILLIAMS and HATCH, and played patriotic airs through the streets. They also visited the camp of the Ira Harris Cavalry as a mark of honor to their gallant charge yesterday.

Brig. Gen. HARVEY BROWN has handed us for publication the following orders regarding the dispo- sition to be made of sick and wounded soldiers arriving in this City. A large number of disabled soldiers possibly 1,000 are expected to reach here to-day:
Mr. BAYARD, of Maryland, (Dem.,) presented a petition for equal privileges to all the Press of the country.

The following extracts from a letter from a medieal member of the Sanitary Commission, dated Cairo, April 24, will warm the heart of the country. They are of singular interest, in showing the ample scale on which the outgushing benevolence of the broad and generous West is enabled to set, through the peculiar facilities for transportation afforded by its great network of navigable rivers:

The United States transport Ocean Queen, Capt. TERRY, Iron Yorktown, Va., arrived at this port last night, having on board 800 sick and wounded soldiers from the army at Yorktown. The men are in charge of Dr. BUCK. The Ocean Queen has anchored in the North River. We could not obtain a list of the names of the men, as there is no list on board the ship.

Capt. CHARLES S. BOGGS, of the United States gunboat Varuna, which was fought so splendidly after the squadron had passed the forts, writes as follows to his wife, who resides in New Brunswick, New-Jer- sey:
At a meeting of the officers of the Harris Light Cavalry, held in camp near Fredericksburgh, Va., the following resolutions of their Committee were adopted:
It was inad- vertently stated in the TIMES yesterday that Gen. SICKLES has remained in this City while his nomination has been pending in the Senate. The fact is otherwise.

When operations began on the peninsula, by the retreat of the rebels from Yorktown, Gen. McCLELLAN announced that there should be no delay that he would follow up the enemy, and "push him to the wall." This promise was iterated and emphasized in his official dispatches, as though he felt that there was a certain amount of skepticism touching the army of the Potomac that needed to be overcome.

Old Point was astir at an early hour this morning, with rumors of anticipated events of an important nature. The visit of the President and two members of his Cabinet indicated that something unusual was on foot, and this was fully realized by the events of the morning.

Steamship Albany, CHADSEY, from Newbern, N.C., 2 days, with mails and passengers, among whom are Capt. PIERCE, of the schooner John Au- mach; also Capt. W.H. TULFORD, of the schooner Messenger, which were wrecked two weeks ago, on the North Carolina coast, arrived here yesterday morning. Nothing has been done by the expedition, since the taking of Fort Macon.

day, passed a bill organizing the Territory of Arizona, and providing for it a territorial government. About a month ago, JEFF. DAVIS' Congress Passed a bill for the same purpose. JEFF. DAVIS at present has the advantage, in that he actually holds and possesses the re-...
FLAG-OFFICER: Your boldly conceived and splendidly executed plan of battle having resulted in perfect success, leaves me time to make up the report of my division.

Preparations are being made on Governor's Island for the erection of a supplementary hospital for the accommodation of sick prisoners and other invalids who may be sent to the island. It will be a flame building, capable of holding three hundred men.

A boat from Pittsburgh arrived here last night, and reports that our army was within two miles of Corinth, that heavy firing was going on with our extreme advance, but it was thought that no general engagement was progressing.
I learn by steamer from Yorktown, that Gen. McCLELLAN had advanced twelve miles beyond Wil- liamsburgh, and has had several skirmishes with the enemy, routing them with heavy loss.

It was Mr. THANKS TO GEN. McCLELLAN. It was Mr. LOVEJOY who yesterday moved the vote of thanks to Gen. McCLELLAN in the House of Representatives. The act was doubtless penitential, and certainly eminently becoming. For months the radicals, of whom LOVEJOY is the typical man, have delighted in denouncing the generalship, the fighting qualities, and who is now in pursuit of the flying enemy.
We have no later news from Gen. McCLELLAN'S army this morning. It probably advances too fast for the Telegraph corps to keep pace with it.
A brigade of rebels is encamped on the opposite side of the river, about six miles below Fredericksburgh. Contrabands who came in to-day say it is Gen. FIELDS'.

Two gentlemen, who have been in the South since the commcement of the blockade, arrived here to-day. They left Memphis two weeks since, com- ing to Jacksonport on the steamer Sam Hale, which arrived there last Tuesday, but her officers learning that our troops were marching on that town, she immediately started down the river.

The United States steam transport Oriental, Capt. Tuzo, from Port Royal 6th inst., arrived at this port Friday night. Nothing of importance had taken place at Port Royal since last advices. Steamers leave Hilton Head daily for Beaufort, Otter Island, Ediste, Daufuskie, Pulaski and Tybee.

A marked change, every one must have observed, has come over the American Press during the last six months, indicative, like most general features of the Press, of a corresponding condition of the public mind.
The Merrimac remained off the point all night. The Monitor went up this forenoon and fired a few above into Sewall's Point.

THE FIGHT IN HAMPTON ROADS. The fantas tic tricks performed by the Censorship can find no happier illustration than in the dispatch of Commodore GOLDSBOROUGH, printed in another column. For several weeks the fact that Government had turned into the waters of Hampton Roads a flock of steam-rams, destined to run down and destroy the Merrimac, has been known to half the loyal people at the North, and probably to every rebel at the South.
It has been often said that the contempt which has been felt at the South for the peo- ple of the Northern States, has been one cause of the present rebellion.
"It is worth fighting ten battles to get in such a home," said one of the suffering young soldiers yesterday to the lady in attendance.

A PROBABLE SUICIDE. About 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon a man named WM. HOWES, of Boston, was found with his throat cut, in the rear of a lager-bier saloon, near the Coroner's office, in Centre-street.
A terrible fire is now raging at Troy. The bridge over the Hudson River took fire about 11 o'clock, and has been consumed.

It is refreshing, sometimes, to look over the records of old times and to uncover some of the hidden testimonies left by our predecessors to the cause of truth and freedom. The sentiments of the prominent men of Virginia, thirty years ago, in behalf of emancipation, are well known and frequently appealed to in our discussions.

A battle has been fought with the enemy's rear guard just outside of Williamsburgh, where light earthworks had been erected, beside other intrenchments. The Commanding General sets down the loss on either side to be about two thousand killed, wounded and missing one-third killed outright.

The Thirtieth Anniversary of this Society was celebrated at Irving Hall on Thursday evening Rev. Dr. DE WITT called the meeting to order, and after prayer had been offered, the Secretary read the annual report. It states as follows:
It was predicted and expected by the Southern Press, and Southern clergymen, even, that New-York would be deluged with vice, crime, and bloodshed, when the war for the Union should once begin.

We have again to announce the adjournment of the Legislature of this State without the enactment of the New-York Health bill. As there has been a widespread interest in this measure, it is but right that we should explain the course of legislative action in regard to it, and the causes of its ultimate failure.
I have been shown an extract from your paper on the 19th ult., purporting to describe an interview between myself and a person who called on me in relation to the relief of the Florida refugees.

The Fortress Monroe correspondent of the Philadelphia Inquirer writes, under date of May 8: A Council of War was held in Norfolk last Friday; Secretary of War G.W. RANDOLPH, and MALLORY, Secretary of the Navy, Gen. HUGES, Brig.-Gen. BLANCHARD, and the Colonels of the different regimenth stationed at Norfolk and Portsmouth, were in attendance.

Kentucky and Louisville yesterday sent to Pittsburgh Landing another large sanitary boat, (Capt. SHERLEY'S Telegraph No. 3,) equipped by Drs. PERIN, CHIPLEY and BELL, and carrying many excellent volunteer nurses, of both sexes. She will remain at that Landing in readiness to help take care of the wounded in the impending battle.
Our ships have been pretty well riddled, and we have had both killed and wounded on board all of them, but, thank God, much fewer than we had reason to anticipate.

A special dispatch to the Times, from Cairo, to-day, says: "Arrivals to-day from Pittsburgh state that the rebels were attacked by Gen. GRANT on Wednesday, a few miles west of Corinth. Their line was con- stantly falling back, though in perfect order.

Difficult as it is to catch the rebels, in their frequent flights from the battle-field, it is, per- haps, even more difficult to do so in argument. There is no way of cornering a rebel, even by the stern logic of facts.

The battle of the 6th inst. is proven to have been upon a much larger scale than was at first supposed, and the number of the killed and wounded on both sides exceeds considerably the figures given at the close of the engagement. The most severe fighting occurred on our left, at which point we sustained our heaviest losses.

We had a very interesting interview, yesterday afternoon, with Assistant Adjutant-Gen. FERRSE, who acted as volunteer Aid-de-Camp to Brig.-Gen. FRANK PATTERSON during the battle of Williamsburgh, Va., on Monday last.

A special dispatch to the Tribune, from Cairo, says: "A report reached here last night that a Lieuten- ant from the gunboat Benton yesterday approached the works at Fort Wright, and could see no signs of life there. He used a glass, as he approached nearer to the works, and could see but two laborers there, and although he could look right into the works, not a soldier could be seen."

FIRES. At about 12 o'clock yesterday morning, the paint manufactory of Messrs. HENRY WALDEN Co., Nos. 189, 191, 193 and 195 Water-street, together with most of the contents, was destroyed by fire, involving a loss of $50,000, upon which there...

The anniversary meeting on behalf of the American Board of Commissioners was held at Ir- ving Hall, Friday morning. MARK HOPKINS, D.D., LL. D., presided, and a very large audience was present. After prayer, by Rev. Mr. WYCKOFF, of Albany, and singing by the audience, under the direction of Prof. HASTINGS, Secretary WOOD read a statement, of which the following is an abstract:

Gen. MILROY was confronted, day before yesterday, by forces said to be those of JACKSON, JOHNSON, and EWELL. After sharp skirmishing with a portion of JACKSON'S army, he was joined by SCHENCK, who had made a forced march of thirty-four miles in one day.
At 2 o'clock this afternoon there met together fifty members of Congress, including Senators and Representatives of all parties and sections.
The following debate took place in the House, on Friday, Mr. LOVEJOY'S resolution, to secure perpetual freedom in the Territories of the United States, being under consideration:

A fire broke out in the cooper shop of the Auburn State Prison at six o'clock last evening, destroying that building and a large amount of stock and tools belonging to the cooper contractors, Messrs. A. MILLER Co.

Now that the smoke of the battle has somewhat cleared away, I am able to give you a more connected account of the engagement, on Monday, between our advance guard and a large force of rebels who opposed our entrance into this town.

The reported receipts of the principal kinds of Produce since our last have been 64 bbls. Ashes, 20,173 bbls. Flour 155 bbls, and 569 bags Corn Meal, 22,596 bushels Wheat, 28,474 bushels Corn, 13,693 bushels Oats, 1,310 bushels Malt, 5,642 pkgs. Provisions, and 1,165 bbls. Whisky.

Deserters from the enemy report that the recent Union victories have caused the greatest depression of feeling among the rebel officers, who look upon their cause as hopeless. Their soldiers are very ragged, and without the means of getting new clothing. Hundreds would desert if it was generally known they would be kindly received by our officers. The enemy's ranks are daily becoming thinned by desertions.

The hospitals here, to-day, present a sad sight, and one that brings home to the heart a painful realization of the horrors of war. By this hour most of the wounded brought up by the Commodore have found comfortable quarters at the Adams Hotel Hospital, and at the National Hospital, and many private houses in the vicinity, fitted up by the Government, are also occupied.

The Congressional meeting held in the Capitol to-day, to organize an opposition to the ultra-Abolition measures proposed in Congress, was attended by about fifty members. This was a much fuller attendance than was generally expected, and the movement becomes more formidable, if it be true, as I am informed, that many more sympathize with it than were present at the meeting.

I arrived here from yorktown at about 6 o'clock. The distance is twelve miles the time consumed in traversing at on horseback about five hours. I thought I had been bad roads before; Indeed, I felt quite sure, after my observations and experiences on the peninsula, that I could realize the depth and bottomlessness of a Virginia road in a bad season.

Three rebel deserters came in to-day. They con- firm the statement you have already received relative to the rebel force. They state that the rebels intend giving us battle when we cross the river, but it is not probable that they have been made acquainted with the General's plans.

MOVEMENTS OF CONSERVATIVE CONGRESSMEN. The Committee appointed by the Congressional Caucus of yesterday had a meeting last night, and talked over their programme, and Mr. CRITTENDEN, the Chairman, was requested to draw up some reso- lutions for an adjourned meeting of the committee to-morrow morning, at 10 o'clock.

The commodious and delightfully-located dwell- ing and grounds at the foot of Sixty-fifth-street, to which the aged, and infirm, and poverty-stricken of our colored population look as a haven of rest and protection from the rude reminders which would constantly offend them in the outer world, contains at present 340 invalids.

The news this morning is of the most glorious and exciting character. Within the last fortyeight hours great blows have been struck against the rebellion, which make it reel and totter to its very foundation.

Although the full announcement of the Russian loan has taken place, the price of Consols was unaltered from Saturday. The amount of the Russian loan open for subscription on the London Stock Exchange and all the continental cities,l is 10,000,000. The French Finance Minister has sanctioned its introduction on the Paris Bourse.

The Operatic and Concert-loving portion of our fashionable world is about at length to commence its annual repose, having terminated a musical season, which may fairly be considered one of the most singular we have for many years had in this City. Half a dozen of weeks of opera, scattered over the past six months, have been grudgingly given to the habitu s of the Academy of Music.

The news which yesterday electrified the nation was second only in importance to that of the capture of New-Orleans. The capture of Norfolk was the event of all others most eagerly desired by the loyal population of the country.
The following was received at the War Department this morning: FORT MONROE, Saturday, May 10 Midnight. Norfolk is ours, and also Portsmouth and the Navy-yard.

The Public Credit has advanced rapidly on the Stock Exchange within the past fortnight. On Saturday week the sales of the Public Funds of 1881 at par at the Board of Brokers, was deemed an event so auspicious and gratifying as to induce an exchange of congratulations between the President of the Board and the Hon. Secretary of the Treasury.

The Bremen steam ship Hansa, Capt. VON SEENTEN, from Bremen April 27, and Southampton 30th, at noon, with the United States mails, and 74 cabin and 147 steerage passengers, arrived at 2 o'clock this morning. The advices are six days later.

The pursuit of the retreating rebels by our troops, under command of Gen. STONEMAN, has in every respect been successful. His headquarters are now twenty-seven miles from Richmond, while the advance, consisting of the Eighth Illinois Cavalry, is five miles abond. The enemy is in sight, and gradually falling back.

I saw, in the National Intelligencer, an article quoting a passage from senator DOOLITTLE'S speech, the purport of which was that the war was carried on by Constitutional power, only to reinstate the Constitutional Government of the United states and any departure from that, by anti-constitutional measures, was much to be dreaded, especially as it could be quoted, in Europe, to show the failure of a written Constitution of Republican Government.

The speed with which events are proceeding is steadily accelerated. The gap between great advantages and splendid victories is constantly less, while no reverse intervenes to retard the movement which, in so many days not months or years is to bring the rebellion to an end.
In the United States Senate, on May 7, in response to an interrogatory as to the number of Major and Brigadier-Generals who had been confirmed, Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, said:

The weather, for the past two or three days, has been beautiful, and the foliage has come forward with great rapidity. Even in this mountainous section of country, which usually is far behind the seasons of lower latitudes, the ground is carpeted with verdure, and the little flowers peer forth from their nooks between the rocks, reminding one that the Spring-time is verging into Summer.

Old Point this evening presents a most stirring spectacle. About a dozen steams transports are loading troops. They will land on the shore opposite the Rip Raps and march direct on Norfolk. At the time I commence writing, (9 P.M.,) the moon shines so
The meeting of conservative Members of Congress, in accordance with the cail read in the House on Friday, was held at the Capitol on Saturday. Hon. JOHN J. CRITTENDEN, of Kentucky, presiding.

A very destructive fire occurred in this city, commencing on Saturday at noon and raging until sundown. The fire originated in the covered wooden bridge which crosses the Hudson at this point, and the property of the Rensselaer and Saratoga Railroad company. About 1,000 feet of this structure was destroyed.

To Hon, Gideon Welles, Secretary of the Navy: The naval engagement, for which the rebels have been preparing, took place this morning. The rebel fleet, consisting of eight iron-clad gunboats, four of which were fitted with rams, came up handsomely.

To the People of the Confederate States of America. An enemy, waging war in a manner vio alive of the usage of civilized nations, has invaded our country. With presumptuous reliance on superior numbers, he has declared his purpose to reduce us to submission. We struggle to preserve our birthright of constitutional freedom. Our trust is in the justice of our cause and the protection of our God.

We learn through Capt. Hill, of the steamer Schultz. Who arrived here last night at 10 o'clock, that our batteries at Day's Neck and Hardy's Bluff, on James River, were attacked by three of the enemy's ginboats yesterday morning at 8 o'clock, and silenced in a short time.

The first news that greeted us this morning was that the Merrimac had been blown up by her officers, and was no longer to dominate our fleet in Hampton Roads. The news at first seemed too good to be true.

The Merrimac is blown up. At 4 o'clock this morning a bright light was observed from Fortress Monroe, in the direction of Craney Island, which was supposed at first to be a signal of some description from the Merrimac.

I seized the first opportunity, to-day, to take a, look at the fortifcations by which Norfolk has been so long defended against our fleet. It is easy to see that their strength has not been exaggerated. The works on Sewall's Point are quite extensive, intended for forty guns

In the Senate, yesterday, after some business of no particular importance, the bill providing for the collection of direct taxes in insurrectionary districts, was taken up, debated at considerable length, and finally passed with only three dissenting votes, after being amended so as to provide for an additions tax to cover all the expenses of the collection and she salaries of officers appointed under the bill.

Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS, in a Proclamation dated at Richmond on the 3d instant, commands that on Friday next prayer shall be offered up in all Richmond churches, that the Almighty will "strengthen and protect the hosts going forth to battle," and " restore...

The desperation of the rebel cause in the Missis- sippi culminated yesterday in an attack on the flotilla. Early on Saturday morning eight of their gunboats came round the point above the fort and boldly attacked our fleet.
THE RETURN OF THE PRESIDENT.

FRANKLIN'S Division, army of the Potomac, reached Yorktown on transports on Monday morning. The town had just been evacuated by the rebels. On the dock were quantities of Quartermasters' stores, provisions,knapeacks, In a box, nicely packed in cotton, as trophies, were two 200-pound conical shot. On one was inscribed the following:

We give this morning a very full and special account of the advance upon and occupation of Norfolk, by our forces under Gen. WOOL, and all the circumstances which planned that important movement. Secretary STANTON, it appears, was mistaked, in announcing as he did, in his dispatch from Fortress Monroe, that the Gosport Navyyard bad not been barned by the rebels.

The colored people of this City and vicinity made a most enthusiastic demonstration yesterday in honor of the Abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia. There was a prayer meeting at Shiloh Church, at 5 A.M., a flag, raising at the same place at 3 P.M., a grand mass meeting at Cooper Institute, and a ball at Metropolitian Hall, Prince-street, in the evening, The rejoicing among the colored population was most general and hearty.

The sieamere Courier and City of Allon arrived this afternoon from Pittsburgh Landing, with news to noon of Saturday, up to which time no general engagement had taken place. On Thursday, the 2d, a battalion of the Seventh Illinois Cavalry, under command of Major APPLINGTON, accompanied Gen. PAINE from Farmington on a reconnolesance of the enemy's position.
The screw steamship Etna, from Liverpool April 30, calling at Queenstown on the 1st inst., arrived here last evening.
We give herewith a diagram, showing the iminute topography of the famous rebel Capital, upon which Gen. McCLELLAN, is now advancing with such rapid strikes.
To Hon. E.M. Stenton, Secretary of War: On the 9th of May, Friday afternoon, I organ- ized a force to march against Norfolk. On Saturday morning, the 10th of May, the troops were landed, un-

The Paris letter-writer of the London Herald says the eagerness of the Emperor for an end to the American civil war has received a new fillip. The common sentiment in Paris, the correspondent says is despondency at the

There are only a few cities of importance on Southern seaboard remaining for our fleet now to capture. These are Wilmington, Charleston and Savannah on the Atlantic coast, and Mobile on the Gulf coast. The rebels say that Gen. BURNSIDE is about to attack Wilmington, which, when captured, will complete our possession of the

In another column, we publish a letter from NAPOLEON to Gen. PRIM, the commander of the Spanish forces in Mexico; also a brief comment of a Madrid journal. The matter is not recent, but it is important, as showing the disposition, at that time, of France and Spain to fraternize in the invasion of Mexico.

We have no intelligence of any special value here from the main body of the army. There seems to be no doubt that FRANKLIN's forces have joined the main body, and that both are pursuing the retreating rebels.

I have just come in from Falmouth, have to report that one of the enemy's infantry pickets, consisting of twelve privates and a Lieutenant, was yesterday afternoon captured by shirmishers of the Harris Light Cavalry, about four miles below Fredericksburgh.

The Commercial has the following Southern news: The Memphis Avalanche, of the 6th inst., says that the telegraphic news from Richmond is painfully sig- nificant. Gen. McCLELLAN seems to have been preparing the same fate for Richmond that Gen. BUTLER and Commodore PORTER got up for New-Orleans.

An adjourned meeting of the Conservative members of Congress from all the States " to defeat the schemes of the Abolitionists and Secessionists," was held this evening in the Hall of Representatives Mr. CRITTENDEN in the Chair, and Mr. Cox, Secretary.

A meeting of the citizens of New-York, mer- chants and others, will be held at the rooms of the Chamber of Commerce, corner of William and Cedar streets, on Wednesday, the 14th inst., at 12 o'clock noon, to consider the duty of providing means of relief for the destitute and suffering people of Troy, many of whom have been rendered homeless by the late serious conflagration of a large portion of that city, Signed.
Mr. LOVEJOY, of Illinois, (Rep.,) moved that the House concur in the Senate's amendments to the bill establishing a depot of agriculture.
T.P. TROTT, of the Contract Office, Post-office Department, left Washington to-day for Norfolk, to open the Post-office at that place. The mails will be sent by the old route, vid Fortress Monroe.

In the Senate yesterday the Pacific Railroad bill was reported back from the Special Committee by Mr. McDOUGALL, who moved to make it the special order for Thursday next. The motion failed. The bill to protect the Indians who have adopted civilized habits was passed. A joint resolution to provide for the presentation of medals of honor to enlisted men and volunteers was reported from the Military Committee, and passed.
By the British brig. Alma, Capt. BOODIE, from Nassau, N.P., we learn that the confederate steamship Orito, from Southampton, had just arrived with a cargo of arms for the rebels.

Gen. FREMONT arrived here early to-day at the head of his army, having come, by forced marches, to the relief of SCHENCK and MILROY. He immediately reviewed the regiments here stationed, and rode out a little beyond town.

The steamer Wyandank arrived at the Navyyard this morning, about 9 o'clock, from the month of the Rappahannock. Her officers report that on Sunday the gunboats Freeborn and Island Belle cut out of Piankatank River, which enters Chesapeake five miles below the mouth of the Rappahannock, two large-sized rebel schooners, one unloaded, the other having a heavy assorted cargo, but mostly whisky.

The city continues very quiet. Most of the stores are closed, but it is expected they will open in a day or two, except in cases where the occupants have left the city with the army. Some excitement still prevails, but it is supposed in a few days, when communication is fully opened with the Northern ports, confidence will be completely restored.

Our readers are familiar with the more notable facts in the recent history of Rev. W.G. BROWNLOW, of Knoxville, Tenn., better known by the sobriquet of the "Fighting Parson." Concerning his earlier career, not so much is known, and the public impression is, that the redoubtable preacher is a rough-and-ready fighter, an effective speaker, a good hater, and a mixture of strong elements, good and bad.
The steamship Jura, from Liverpool, May 1, via Londonderry, May 2, passed father Point at 2 o'clock this morning, with 34 cabin and 311 steerage passengers.

By the arrival off Farther Point of the steamship Jura, on her way to Quebec, we have advices from Europe to the 2d of May one day later. It is again asserted by the Paris correspondent of the Independmece Belge that France and England intend to interfere in the af- fairs of the United States. The foundation for the statement is not given.

We continue to receive assurances that the rebel army intends to make a final stand, a desperate, determined effort at resistance in front of Richmond. Advices from Norfolk assert that this is the universal opinion there. Of course it is. This is the pretext on which Gen. HUGER justified to the citizens of that place his abandonment of them.
Mr. McDOUGALL, of California, (Opp.,) from the Special Committee, reported back the Pacific Railroad bill, and moved that it be made the special order for Thursday next.

There must presently be either a great battle or a grand retreat in the Southwest. The immense army of Gen. HALLECK the largest column under any one commander in the field-is so close upon the rebel works and army, and his movements are now so menacing and dangerous, that it will be impossible for BEAUREGARD to remain inactive in his present position for many days longer.

A flag of truce went up the James River yesterday morning, and returned at 2 o'clock this morn- ing. Three hundred and five prisoners of war were sent up, to be released on parole, but eighty-five of them refused to give parole and will be sent to Washington.
The Fortress Monroe correspondent of the Baltimore American gives the following highly important information in a letter dated the 12th inst.
Since the commencement of the dog-show at BARNUM'S, the following premiums have ben awarded: MONDAY. The $1,000 premium was awarded to FRANCIS BUTLER, Esq., for his great Siberian Blood- hound.

The President, having no constitutional objections to offer, will unquestionably sign it; and out of the overtasked Treasury will be taken, at the lowest estimate, some $30,000 a-year, to affect what might have been effected for tithe of the sum.

the policy of relaxing the blockade of our Southern coast will be extended as speedily as possible to Norfolk. The inhabitants of that section of Virginia, and of the whole Peninsula between the James and York rivers, are actually suffering for the necessaries of life.

The steamship Niagara, Capt. STONE, which left Liverpool at 10 A.M. of the 3d, and Queenstown 4th, arrived this evening with 35 passengers for Boston and 58 for Halifax, together with 4,000 in specie for Halifax. She will sail at 9 0'clock for Boston.

Mr. WALTON, of Vermont, (Rep.,) reported back from the Committee on Printing the joint resolutions requiring the Superintendent of the Census to keep records of the names of adult males, heads of families and freeholders.
Lewis H. Meyer and Edwin Stucken, Claimants of the Steamer St. Lawrence, her Tackle, , Appellants, vs. William W. Tupper and Edward R. Wilcox.
To-day our pickets took possession of an evacuated rebel camp three and a half miles from Corinth and the rebel pickets were driven in.

At last the monotony is broken. We have had a fight and a glorious one, too, purely naval, with nearly an equal number of boats on each side, and have sent the rebels back down the river badly crip- pled. They attacked us this morning at 6 o'clock, and before eight they were so badly whipped that they will never again attempt such a job.

BOROUGH. In the present situtation of affairs on the Peninusule, infinite interest attaches to the movements of the gunboats and ironclads that are pushing their way up James River toward Richmond. For whether the rebel force between the Chickahominy and the James awaits and gives battle to the army of Gen. McCLELLAN, or makes another, and this...

Hon. EDWARD STANLY arrived in this City yesterday, by steamer from San Francisco, en route for Washington, whither he goes to signify his acceptance of the Military Governorship of North Carolina, to which he was been appointed by Mr. LINCOLN. On April 9, he resigned his position as City and County Attorney of San Francisco, and his letter announcing this elicited the following response from Gov. STANCORE:

serve with satisfaction that the Commercial Advertiser and the World have made the most ample retraction of the injurious intimations, contained in those papers some weeks since, against the integrity of the head and cheif subordinates of the Interior Department. Our own information did not verify those accusations.

Last evening Parson BROWNLOW was invited by Mr. STETSON, of the Astor House, to meet the New-England Soldiers' Relief Association at supper. An excellent collation was served, and around the table sat some of our most distinguished citizens CHARLES GOULD, Esq., President of the Relief Association, in the Chair. After some preliminary proceedings, the Chairman introduced "the Rev. Dr. BROWNLOW."
Vague rumors of threatened intervention in America continue in circulation, and the dullness and decline in cotton is attributed to them.

In the Senate yesterday, a petition from citizens of Indiana was presented by Mr. WRIGHT, of that State, asking Congress to stop the agitation of the negro question, and attend to the business of putting down the rebellion. The resolution to suspend the payment of the troops actually employed in the Department of the West, until certain charges of fraud could be investigated, was considered, but laid over without action.

Hon. EDWARD STANLEY arrived here yesterday, from California, on his way to North Carolina. With him came the San Francisco papers announcing his resignation of an important civil position in that city and his determina- tion to accept the post of temporary Governor of North Carolina, tendered him by the President. The news is in all respects gratifying.

pression given by the announcement that Suffolk had been captured by the Union forces, was that BURNSIDE had done too late what he should have done long ago. It is a relief to find this charge unfounded. Sufflok is in the hands of Gen. WOOL'S Division; white BURNSIDE is doubtless carrying out with entire success his movement toward the interior of North Carolina.
A portion of Gen. DAVIS' and Gen. ASBOTH'S Divisions, and two of Gen. STOLL'S regiments, left here to-day for the North. An adequate force is still here, however, for operations in this direction.

ate Committee which went to Yorktown to ascertain whether Gen. W.F. SMITH was drunk or not at a recent engagement of our troops with the rebels, have returned. They report that he was not drunk, that there was never the slightest foundation for the story, and that he is one of the most meritorious officers in the service.

A brief dispatch from Gen. WOOL to the War Department announces that Suffolk is in posses- sion of our forces Maj. DODGE having gone down from Norfolk and occupied it. Suffolk is south- east of Norfolk, at the junction of the Norfolk and Petersburgh and the Seaboard and Roanoke Railroads.

"In the woods," means about six miles from Pittsburgh, and five miles from Hamburgh the latter, a beautiful lit- tle town on the west bank of the Tennessee River, and at present the headquarters of Gen. POPE.
The steamship Champion, Capt. SEABURY, from Aspiawall, on the 5th inst., with California mails, treasure and passengers, arrived at this port yesterday morning.

period when for months all eyes were direcred to Charleston, and the intense desire and passionate cry of the whole country was that the traitor city that inaugurated rebellion should be assailed, captured and punished. But we think very little about Charleston now, and the country is quite willing patiently to await the pleasure of the Government in regard to its capture.
The British steamer Solent, which left Cartagena on the 3d inst., arrived at Aspinwall next day She brings letters from Bogota to April 15.

At a meeting of the Committee, chosen by the Republican and Union members of the Legislature, held at the Astor House, on the 14th day of May, 1862, L. TREMAIN was chosen temporary Chairman and EDWARD DODD temporary Secretary.

Speaking of the Committee, or rather of the four members who repaired thither, he assumes to assure your readers that

The United States vs. The Sloop Advocate. This vessel was a fishing-smack, captured by the New-London on Dec. 1, 1861, in Mississippi Sound. She was appraised by a Naval Surveyor, and was appropriated to the use of the United States. The appraisal, with her papers, her master and part of her crew, were forwarded to this port.
LAW. Recorder HOFFMAN has done the cause of public morality good service by his deflaitive decision in the matter of the Concert-Saloon "Pretty-Waiter-Girl" nuisance.

Gen. McCLELLAN'S headquarters were established here yesterday, and are now pleasantly located on the banks of the Pamunkey River. The main body of the army is rapidly concentrating at the point designated by the commanding General. The Quartermaster and Commissary stores are in abundance. The advance guard of the army, under Gen. STONEMAN, Still remains at White House, within sight of the enemy's position.

The reception of Parson BROWNLOW at the Academy of Music, last evening, was a decided success. The building was crammed, and the stage was filled with distinguished citizens of all parties. WM. M. EVARTS, Esq., presided. Parson effective and characteristic strain, and was applanded to the echo. His most fervent hope was to be able to help hang the rebels of Tennessee.

On motion of Mr. FENTON, of New-York, (Rep.,) the House proceeded to the consideration of the bill introduced by him for the adjudication of claims for the loss and destruction of property belonging to loyal citizens, and the damages done thereto by the troops of the United States during the present rebellion.

The order comes to-night to Gen. KEYES' corps to prepare to march to-morrow morning, Gen. SMITH'S Division leading at 5 o'clock, COUCH following at 6 o'clock, and CASEY coming next at 7 o'clock. We are to push on toward the Chickahominy in conjunction with the movement from West Point.
Mr. WADE, of Ohio, (Rev.,) presented petitions in favor of confiscation.

The NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES, No. 800, is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter, in wrappers, ready for mailing. It contains the LATEST INTELLIGENCE up to the moment of going to press.
In the Court yesterday, before Judge McCUNN, James Joyes was tried for grand larceny and acquitted.
A special dispatch to the Times, from Cairo, by the City of Memphis, from Pittsburgh Landing, says:

The National Arms would achieve a very great and permanent advantage in the Southwest, if, while the rebel force is massed at Cerinth, and the Cotton States are drained of fighting men to swell it, a few detachments of our great army could be spared to advance upon and occupy these States their forts, strategic positions and capitals. In the Senate, yesterday, a memorial from merchants and others of New-York was presented, asking for the speedy passage of the Pacific Railroad bill. The Indian Appropriation bill was debated, and an amendment was adopted, authorizing the President to discriminate against those tribes which have taken up arms against the Government. The Confiscation bill, reported from the Special Committee, was taken up and debated until the adjournment.
In an official report to the Superintendent of the Coast Survey, Lieutenant-Commanding T.S. PHELPS states:

Mr. SHERMAN, of Ohio, (Rep.,) made a statement in reference to a remark made by Mr. HOLMAN, of Indiana, in the House, who said, speaking of the Investigating Committee, that he (SHERMAN) was on the Committee and received $8 a day. Mr. SHERMAN said that he had been on two committees: one the Kansas Committee, the other the Naval Investigating Committee, but neither committee ever charged or received a cent of compensation or mileage.

The same force of our troops that were here last night are here this morning. Another body of our men are stationed about two miles at our right, at a place called cumberland. The main force has not yet come up but will probably be here tomorrow.

A continuous stream of Union residents of the valley are pouring into town, under the mistaken belief that our army is retreating, and a knowledge that detachments of rebel cavalry are visiting every farm-house, impressing all males between fifteen and sixty.

The rebels apparently are unwilling to risk their cause in the open field, and are withdrawing their fores from the Border to the Cotton States, to avail themselves of the advantage given them by a wide distance from the base of the operations of our Government, and by a malarious climate.

The Newark Advertiser gives a prominent place to a letter dated "on the Pamunkey, May 10," which it says was written by an officer high in command in the First New-Jersey Brigade, who was a witness of what he describes. He writes:

Our march since leaving New-Creek has been over good, dry, Summer roads, on a red shale foundation, totally unlike the Great Valley east of us. The weather has been good, and the troops in good spirits. Many of the inhabitants along the route have been of secession sympathies, but were prudently inclined to be very civil.

The Navy Department has information that on the 1st inst., Acting Volunteer Lieut. NICKELS, of the Onward, dispatched Acting-Master SLEEPER in his vessel's launch in chase of the schooner Sarah, about 100 tons burden, endeavoring to run the blockade of BaltiBay on the coast of South Carolina. Her crew thereupon ran her ashore and burned her, themselves escaping.

It would be an exceedingly easy thing just now for a column of our army to advance southward via Norfolk and Suffolk, and seize and possess the State of North Carolina. People who have never seen a battle have generally the crudest ideas possible relative to its true character. Nor have the efforts of the immense gang of correspondents done much toward clearing up the mysteries which shroud the "Valley of the Shadow of Death" through which a conflict rages.

We are glad to learn that the Naval Committee of the House has acted favorably on a bill to establish new grades of rank in the navy. Ten orders are provided for by the bill, including Admirals, Commodores, The measure is one greatly needed, and its adoption has often been urged in these columns. It cannot be doubted that favorable action will at once be taken upon it by both the ...

MAGOFFIN, or in any way to interfere with his legitimate functions. The late Legislature of Kentucky--as loyal a body as ever was convened in any State--did not think ...

The Secretary of the Treasury has issued full instructions to the various Collectors, respecting clearances to ports opened by proclamation of the President. These instructions authorize clearances at any time before the 1st of June; but vessels so cleared are not to enter such ports until on or afterthat date.

The Sons of New-England met at the Fifthavenue Hotel, past evening, Hon. BENJ. W. BONNEY, Esq., in the Chair, and CEARLES GOULD, Esq., Secretary, for the purpose of making proper arrangements for the reception of Commodore FOOTE, and appointed a committee for that purpose, consisting of the following thirteen gentlemen, with power to add to their number. Connecticut, Gen. P.M. Wetmore and Mr. John Wadsworth; Rhode Island, Rev. ...

Human sorrow is contagious. Few hearts are so steeled to suffering that even the sight of a bear robbed of her whelps will not moisten the eye of pity. Weeping Rachels always awaken sympathy--whatever doubts there may be as to the virtue of mother or children. It is enough to know that the children "are not" to open the fountains of compassion.

The delay in the appearance of the Great Eastern is accounted for upon the supposition that she did not leave Milford Haven until the 7th, the day following that announced for her departure. In any event, assuming her ability to make the Western transatlantic trip in ten days, she is now fully due here, and her arrival may occur at any moment.
The capture of Pensacola is announced in a dispatch from Gen. HALLECK'S army. This news was brought to the Union lines, from Corinth, under a flag of truce.

A steamer has been chartered by the Government and is now loading at the Navy-yard, Brooklyn, for the Gulf Blockading Squadron, to sail on Monday, the 19th inst., and will take the mails.

The Steamer De sota has arrived from the fleet. She brought no news. Not a gun or a mortar had been fired by either side for two days. The rebels and Nationals are basily engaged repairing damages and getting ready for the next encounter.

The telegraph announces the withdrawal into the interior from Yorktown, of the Confederate army, and also the ascent of Federal gunboats to West Point, on York River, 20 miles below its formation by the junction of the Pamunkey and Mattapony. The only direction by which our army could reach the interior was up the Peninsula, between the York and James Rivers, through Charles City and New Kent Counties.

The following extract from a private letter from New-Orleans, received by an eminent commercial house in this city, has been kindly handed to us for publication. It is dated 27th of March, and the writer is a British subject, holding an influential position in New-Orleans:
The correspondent of the St. Louis Democrat, with Gen. STEELE'S column, writes from camp, within six miles of Pocahontas, under date of April 26:

This magnificent vessel, in command of Capt. WALTER PATON, again visited our harbor yesterday morning, after a splendld run across the Atlantic having satled from Milford Haven at 2 P. M. of the 7th inst., and arriving off Sandy Hook at 6 A.M., 17th, thus making the passage in much less than ten days. She brings a large number of passengers, a mail and considerable cargo.
The steamship Great Eastern, Capt. WALTER PATON, which left Milford on the evening of the 6th inst., arrived here yesterday morning.
The steamer Atlantic, Capt. O. ELDRIDGE, arrived at this port yesterday, having left Port Royal on May 14. She brings the mails, and 201 bags of cotton, consigned to Collector BARNEY.

By the arrival of a gentleman yesterday from Norfolk, Va., we learn several facts of interest to the public. He states that the grand army of Gen. McCLELLAN is slowly but surely making its way to Richmond, and before another Sunday rolls around, the brave Union soldiers will have full possession of the rebel Capital.

FROM THE TWO GREAT ARMIES Advices from Gen. HALLEOK'S army, dated yesterday, and from Gen McCLELLAN'S army, dated to-day, have been received at the War Department. The former was in close proximity to the enemy, but no engagement had taken place. The latter was consentrating, and bringing up supplies, preparatory to a movement.

The steamer "Diligent, from Hickman, brought up a second load of refugees from Memphis and other points South, to-day. All tell the same story of hardships endured in traveling on foot thrrugh the woods and swamps, and subsisting on such provisions as could be carried in their pockets. The party is almost entirely composed of men in the prime of life. They bring Memphis papers of the 13th.

Parson BROWNLOW delivered an address in the Brooklyn Academy of Music last evening, under the auspices of the Mercantile Library Association. The house was filled a long time before the hour announced for the address to be commenced, and many persons went away because they were unable to obtain seats.

The Memphis papers, of the 14th inst., are looking or the great battle at Corinth with terrible interest. They estimate the National Army at sixty thousand, and insist that it is greatly demoralized. They say they do not allow themselves to think of being deeated.

We have definite advices from Washington that the action of the President in the matter of Gen. HUNTER'S order, liberating the slaves in South Carolina, Georgia and Florida, will be in harmony with the prudent and conservative course he has heretofore taken on this question of Slavery, whenever it has come up for his practical action, in any form. Gen. HUNTER, in the issuing of the order, acted entirely upon his own...

Not a day passes without engagements of a triffing nature, in which, not unirequently, several hundred are engaged. The division of the army under Gen. POPE, on Tuesday last, were engaged in an important action of this nature at Monterey, capturing sixty prisoners breaking up a camp of the enemy, and occupying in force the ground from which they retreated. But in the action twenty of our men were killed and wounded.
The following report from Capt. DAVIS, commanding the Mississippi flotilla, pro tem., was received this morning at the Navy Department:

The Richmond papers publish large numbers of advertisements urging enlistment in companies of "Partisan Rangers." J.D. IMNOOEN, who proposes to be Colonel of one of these regiments for service west Of the Blue Ridge, says in his appeal:
A recent order appoints Major RICHARD NIXON, of the Ninety-ninth New-Fork Volunteers, Assistant Provost-Marshal of the Department of Virginia, for the City of Norfolk and the surrounding country.

We have already given the details of the rout of Col. MORGAN by the Federal forces under Col. DUMONT, at Lebanon, Tenn. The Shelbyville (Tenn.) News, of the 8th inst., thus alludes to MORGAN'S exploits before the fight:

Next to successes that are utterly incomprehensible, the grandest efforts of Official Intelligence are in reporting defeats that are equally beyond the power of mere human wit to fathom. There is this about the former, however that people soon learn to allow a certain amount in these announcements of exaggerated triumphs.

The record of last week will demand no very gorgeous blazon in the calendar of war. Upon it no victories figure. The Union arms made no advance, by sea or land, tributary to the great result of the contest. In the Southwest Gen. HALLECK continued to press in cautiously but closely upon the lines of BEAUREGARD, apparently rating the strength, position

SIR: The rear divisions of the army under my command, which had been delayed a considerable time in rebuilding the Duck River bridge, left Columbia on the 21st inst. I left on the evening of that day, and arrived at Savanna on the evening of the 5th. Gen. NELSON, with his division, which formed the advance, arrived the same day. The other divisions marched with intervals of about six miles.

The rebels having abandoned their formidable works across the peninsula at Yorktown, an immediate advance was ordered, and the Federal army bivouacked on Sunday night, May 4, in the following positions: Gen. HOOKER'S Division in the swampy woods, one and a half miles from, and opposite to the centre of the enemy's line of works near Williamsburg.

A dispatch from Gen. McCLELLAN to the War Department, dated 10 o'clock P. M. of the 17th, states that a combined naval and army expedition had proceeded some twenty-five miles up the Pamunkey River, from White House, and forced the rebels to destroy two steamers and some twenty schooners. The expedition, Gen. McCLELLAN says, was admirably managed.

A NEW AND DANGEROUS COUNTERFEIT. An attempt was made on Saturday evening to put in circulation counterfeit $5 bills on the Bank of America, of this City. Quite a number of the up-town shopkeepers were swindled by the rogues before the fraud was detected. It seems that the counterfeiters had formed a plan to circulate these spurious notes simultaneously in New-York, Brooklyn and Jersey City.

When Fort Pulaski was taken by the troops under command of Gen. BENHAM, there were about twenty sick and wounded prisoners, whom it was consented should be returned to their homes, provided an equal number should be returned to us. Some of these were so much hurt and so seriously ill that they could not be removed with safety until within a week past. On Friday last, May 9, Capt. A.B. ELY, Assist

You will be naturally astonished to see in the European journals of this week, and especially in those of Paris and Brussels, a revival of the discussion on an intervention in American affairs. It is quite certain that there is not the least foundation for this new discussion on an obsolute question, and it may interest the reader to know how it was started.

The following private letter from an officer in our army to his father, was not intended for publication, but it is written with so much spirit, and records incidents so striking in their nature, that it cannot fail to be read with interest:

The Committee on Commerce of the House of Representatives have reported favorably on the bill creating the office of Solicitor of Customs for this port. We find in the Evening Post an abstract of their report, and assuming that it sets forth the document correctly, we are at a loss whether most to wonder at the old errors of fact or the new ones, or the errors in the conclusions drawn from them.

You were right in your editorial comments on the proposed military movement in Kentucky. The object is not to set up a "Military Governor" in that State, but merely to establish a military State Guard of one or two brigades, under a military commandant, deriving rank and authority from the United States. The Governor of Kentucky, MAGOFFIN, is exercising his civil powers with reasonable satisfaction at pres

PATRICK'S headquarters an Adjutant of the Harris Light Cavalry came galloping up, his horse reeking with foam, and reported that our cavalry skirmishers while out on a reconnoissance on the Bowling Green road, had captured a whole infan

The steamship Great Eastern arrived at this port Saturday morning, having left Millord-Haven on the 6th inst. Her advices are two days later than were received by the America. The news is of very little importance. The principal item is the assertion of the Paris Patric of the 4th inst., that M. MERCIER, the French Minister to this country, had a long conference with JEFF DAVIS,

Yesterday afternoon a fire broke out in the cowstables attached to the distillery of S.L. HUSTED SON, made famous a few years ago by the exposures in LESLIE'S illustrated Newspaper and the investigations which followed these exposures. The distillery is located on the block bounded by Flushing, Park and Franklin avenues and Ryerson-street.

The latest advices from Gen. CURTIS are that his forces are between Learcy and Little Rock, Ark., and rapidly marching on the Capital. Gen. RECTOR has called on the militia and people generally to come out. Large numbers have applied to Gen. CURTIS for protection, who desire to come under the old flag.

GOTTSCHALK once more appears at Niblo's Saloon to-morrow ex-evening, with such a congregation of musical talent as rarely assist in a single concert, and there is little doubt that, late in the season as this appearance may be, it will be as crowded by the fashionable and musical population of the City as have been the most paying of his preceding concerts.

At 12 o'clock last night, the Pensacola Navy-yard and forts were set on fire and destroyed. When the enemy discovered what was going on, Fort Pickens opened a furious bombardment and kept it up during the conflagration, but without doing any damage to any one.

The universal topic is, of course, the President's proclamation denouncing and repudiating the unauthorized conduct of Maj.-Gen. HUNTER. It was understood, yesterday, that the President would wait till advised of the authenticity of the alleged proceeding of HUNTER. But to-day it was tooobvious that the miichief would be irreparable if immediate action were not taken, and hence the proclamation. The effect in Washington has been most happy and reassuring.

Any one disposed to argue that truth and justice have very little to do with the regulation of human affairs, could not be readily silenced. We are led to express this opinion by the acts of the Allies in Mexico and the sentiments contained in an article on European intervention in that country, taken from the London Times and published in our columns of yesterday.

The Macon Telegraph condemns in severe language the conduct of the rebel troops at Bridgeport, by which the most important gateway to our State was opened to the enemy, and the possession of all our rich mines of deposits of coal, iron and saitpetre placed in imminent danger. Martial law has been proclaimed over Charleston and for ten miles surrounding.

We copy the following letter from Col. CROCKER, who, with Major CASSIDY, both of the Ninety-third Regiment New-York Volunteers, is now held as a prisoner by the rebels, from the Herald of yesterday. It relates to the manner in which these two officers fell into the enemy's hands:

The reported receipts of the principal kinds of produce, since our last, have been: 46 bbls. Ashes, 26,803 bbls. Flour, 843 bbls. Corn Meal, 369,156 bushels Wheat, 102,823 bushels Corn, 13,356 bushels Rye, 8,150 bushels Barley, 423 bushels Oats, 250 bushels Malt, 11,502 pkgs. Provisions, 1,185 bbls. Whisky.

The trial of Judge HARDY, of the Sixteenth United States District Court, ended to-day before the State Senate. He was convicted by a two-thirds majority (required by the Constitution) of disloyalty to the Government in uttering seditious language.

At the time of the preparation of this dispatch, no official dispatch had been received regarding Commodore GOLDSBOROUGH'S expedition up the James River, but the following statement, gleaned from the Evening Star and other sources, it is believed embrace the material facts:

In his address to the Senate yesterday, Mr. SUMNER was eminently successful in clearing up doubts attending the right of the National Government to confiscate the property of rebels. There was little difficulty in proving them to be criminals, and consequently amenable to constitutional penalties; and it was no loss easy to prove them public enemies, and therefore exposed to the extra-constitutional penalties imposed by the laws of war.

The President has issued a Proclamation repudiating the allged order of Gen. HUNTER as unauthorized and of no validity or effect, and reserving to himself alone the right to determine whether he can constitutionally and should adopt such a policy if the war eventually should make it necessary. The Proclamation will be found elsewhere in our columns.
The Vice-President pro tem, presented a memorial from the merchants of New-York asking for a General Bankrupt law.

No one can be surprised by the announcement that Gen. HUNTER'S military order, emancipating all the slaves in South Carolina, Georgia and Florida, on the absurd pretext that "martial law and Slavery are incompatible in a free country," is repudiated by President LINCOLN. Gen. HUNTER will be largely indebted to the President's forbearance if he is not recalled.

Mr. BINGHAM, of Ohio, (Rep.,) from the special Committee of the House, reported articles of impeachment against WEST H. HUMPHREYS, Judge of the District Court of the United States for the several Districts of Tennessee.

It is stated that the Marquis DE LAVALETTE would return to his post at Rome in the course of a few days.

The public mind will persist in regarding the public safety as everybody's affair.

Is there any Union sentiment at the South? is a question often asked among us, and more often abroad. And all eyes watch the progress of our armies, to see if any indications of the existence of such a sentiment are to be found. New-Orleans has been a point of especial interest in this regard. The New-Orleans Crescent of April 28, three days after the arrival of Com. FARRAGUT's vessels before the city, says:

The corner-stone of the new Kings County Court-house was laid at 4 o'clock last evening, with appropriate exercises. The Court-house is being erected on Joralemon, directly opposite the bend of Fulton-street, at the City Hall, and will extend through to Livingston-street.

The army commenced moving at an early hour this morning in the direction of Richmond, and will oncamp some miles in advance of this place. The advance, under Gen. STONEMAN, reached the railroad bridge at the Chickahominy yesterday. It is a long trossle bridge, two spans only of which are burned. It can be rebuilt in a very short time.

MRS. HOEY'S BENEFIT.--Wallack's Theatre will be filled this evening by the most fashionable, brilliant audience of the season. The statement may be made advisedly, for the simple reason that Mrs. HOEY this evening takes her annual benefit, on which occasion the most fashionable, brilliant audience of the season always does assemble. "A Romance of a Poor Young Man" will be played, though it is a matter of indifference what the entertainment may be.

Various rumors continued to float about relative to the political significance of M. MERCIER'S visit to Richmond, but they are all apparently disposed of by an announcement made in the House of Commons by Mr. LAYARD, on the 9th inst., to the effect that M. MESOIER went to Richmond without any instructions from his own Government, and that his visit was attended with no political result whatever.

The tone for the day was given us this morning by the dispatch announcing the repulse of our gunboats from Fort Darling. The terms of the dispatch are probably needlessly alarming, as the document itself is unsatisfactory in details.

We We have repeatedly urged upon Government the necessity of establishing a loyal and legitimate Government for the State of Florida. It is now more imperative than ever; and its authority might now at once be extended over the whole surface of the State. For two weeks past there has been no little confusion in the political circles of Washington. For a time the most skillful pilots seemed to have lost their charts, and no one could give an intelligible opinion of the actual stage of the war, or of the purposes of the Administration, or of the probability of serious dissensions among our own people, or of intervention in our affairs by foreign nations.
Voluminous dispatches have been received by the Government from the Gulf. They relate principally to the details of the recent movements connected with the capture of New-Orleans.

The Fifty-sixth Anniversary of the Orphan Asylum Society of the City of New-York took place Wednesday morning at the Asylum, Seventy-fourthstreet, near the Bloomingdale Road. The day was quite propitious, and a very large audience assembled to witness the most interesting exercises of the children. The large hall of the Institution was quite filled, and the major portion of those present was composed of the gentler sex.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your monetary article, in your issue of the 17th inst., I notice that certain resolutions, offered at a meeting of the stockholders of the above-named Company, held in Boston on the 15th, were rejected. This, under the circumstances, was proper, as the meeting was a special one, convened to vote upon the proposition to issue bonds for the purpose of building the road from Aurora to Chicago.

THE CALL FOR TROOPS. The War Department has called for no definite number of troops, but has reopened the recruiting stations, lately closed by order. Some new regiments will be raised for special service, as in Kentucky, for the military commandant appointed there. Beyond this, no formal call has been made on States for volunteers. The main object is to obtain a reserve to fill up existing regiments. The radicals exaggerate this matter.

In the Senate, yesterday, petitions for a General Bankrupt law were presented; also, a petition from citizens of Maryland, asking for the better enfocement of the Fugitive Slave law in the District of Columbia. A. resolution calling upon the secretary of the Navy for official reports of the late naval battle on the Mississippi was adopted.

To Hon. Ira Harris, United States Senate. DEAR SIR The Newspapers have informed us that the House of Representatives, with little debate and in great haste, refused to consider the Bankrupt bill, and postponed all action upon it until next December. The manner "of its taking off" was so strange, that the great debtor and creditor interests through our country are all amazement.

Dispatches have been received from Gen. Cox, commanding in the fight at Princetown on the 18th. It was a very warm affair, in which some 30 were killed and 70 wounded on our side. Prisoners taken by us, state that the rebel loss was double or treble ours.

Hon. EDWARD STANLY, whom President LINCOLN has chosen to be Governor of North Carolina, leaves New-York to-day for Newbern, the old Capital of the State, and which will be the seat of its Provisional Government. It is agreed On all hands that Mr. STANLY is the very best man that could have been selected to fill this delicate and responsible mission.

It has existed for seventy years, with States having both free and slave institutions.

One sad reflection mingles with the whirl and excitement of our modern life the old-time depth and heartiness which gave color and tone to existence seems to be, day by day, departing. Old customs, quaint legends, odd usages connecting the acts of each time and season of our existence with homestead, family memories of the past, and thereby giving richness and depth to the sensations of the present, seem, among us, to be dying out.

SABBATH-SCHOOL ANNIVERSARY. The annual celebration of the Brooklyn Sabbath-school, postponed from Tuesday on account of the inclement weather, took place yesterday. The ringing of the bells at 11 o'clock A.M. the signal to be made in case the parade was to come off made the hearts of not less than twenty-five thousand children thrill with pleasure, and promptly the members of each school proceeded to the appointed rendezvous.

Since my last letter by the Roanoke no intelligence of importance has arrived from Mexico, and we are all on the tip-toe of expectation to see whether the cohorts of the would-be modern Caesar have had a triumphal march to the capital, or whether the Mexicans have proved their title to be freemen.

The Norfolk Day Book, which was allowed to continue its issue by Gen. VIELE, after the occupation of Norfolk, on condition that it should be respectful in its tone, was to-day suppressed, in consequence of a communication in yesterday's paper signed "Inquirer" which, in severe language, assails those Union citizens who have taken the oath allegiance to the United States.

By an arrival from Havana we receive later intelligence from Mexico, but nothing of importance. The reports of fighting which have previously reached us, are not confirmed, though there are rumors that collisions had taken place. The account states that the French had entered Puebla.

Your readers know that Boston is a moral town. They have doubtless heard how once each year the vital piety, of which its atmosphere is redolent, attracts the gentle shepherd from all the eccleslastical folds of New-England, who, after enjoying a six days' hospitality, return to recount to their accustomed charges the wonders they have seen, and the thoughts which those wonders excite in their minds. We are at this moment under that annual visitation.

MR. RAREY'S ENTERTAINMENT. At the Cooper Institute, on Tuesday evening, Mr. RAREY, the celebrated horse-tamer, gave an exhibition. He experimented on three horses, one of which was a most vicious brute, that, just before being brought upon the stage, kicked the groom in attendance, and completely demolished a glass door.

Mr. PORTER, of Indiana, (Rep.,) moved to postpone till Wednesday next, the motion made by him yesterday, to reconsider the vote by which the House, on Monday, rejected the bill to confiscate the slaves of rebels.

Within the past three days the disposition of the whole rebel army before Richmond seems to have been changed. The Kansas State Senate, sitting as a Court of impeachment has found JOHN W. ROBINSON, Secretary of State, guilty of high misdemeanor, by a vote of 17 to 4. On the remaining charge the Court found him not guilty.
Gen. BURNSIDE returned to North Carolina this morning.

The steamship Bavaria from Southampton 4th, and the China from Liverpool and Queenstown 8th inst., passed this Point at 11 o'clock this morning, and were both boarded by the news yacht of the Associated Press.

The Sub-Committee of the Joint Fire Department, selected to gather all the information that can be obtained in regard to Petroleum, consisting of Aldermen STRONG, BELKNAP and GREEN, held an adjourned meeting at the City Hall, Saturday evening, specially for the purpose of hearing any testimony that the friends of the parties interested in the traffic might have to say.
In the Convention, to-day, a bill was passed appropriating $50,000 in Defence Warrants, for the care of the sick and wounded soldiers.
At the request of the Atlantic Telegraph Company, the Admiralty has ordered the steamer Porcupine to prepare to take soundings. She would be ready in about ten days.
The Paris Monileur this evening contains a notice of the blockade of the Mexican ports Tampico and Alvarado.

Capt. DAVIS, the flag-officer of the Western river fleet at Memphis, in his official report of the naval battle that resulted in the surrender of that place, gives great credit to Col. CHARLES ELLET, Jr., the commander of the Ram Fleet, which did such remarkable service in the engagement.
The Aldermen met yesterday for the first time in several weeks in the regular chamber of the Board, which has been undergoing repairs, and is now completed in the most elegant and tasteful manner.

The present war has changed many of the opinions of the world. It has effectually exploded the notion that Cotton is King. That supposed monarch is dethroned, and his own infatuated followers are now consigning the object of their idolatrous worship to the flames.

We are still at anchor in the Stono river, near Legreeville, a pretty little village of planters' houses on John's Island, about three miles from the sea, and eight from Charleston. It has long been used as a Summer resort for the wealthy cotton lords of these innumerable islands, but has been deserted since December last, the residents having foolishly imagined that we would follow up the great advantage gained at Port Royal.
The Vice-President presented a memorial from citizens of New-York, in favor of the enlargement of the Erie and Oswego Canals.

On Sunday morning Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER lectured his people upon the sin of covetousness, under which general head he included certain sins of shopping, picture-buying, house-building, and so on, reserving an especial rap for the benefit of the city railway companies, who, in addition to whatever individual rapacity they may possess, are open to a very serious charge in regard to the treatment of drivers and conductors.

Mr. DAWES, of Massachusetts, (Rep.,) from the Committee on Elections, made an adverse report on the petition of CHARLES HENRY FOSTER, asking admission to a seat as Representative from the second district of North Carolina.

To give a truthful, consistent add connected account of the beginning, progress and end of a great battle that was never seen except by those engaged in it, and by them, each for himself, but a very small share, may perchance appear very entertaining and satisfactory to friends at a distance, and yet give no very accurate idea of the great tragedy that was actually enacted.

The Grenada (Memphis) Appeal, of the 12th, contains the following: AUGUSTA, Ga., June 11. Fighting continues in the vicinity of Charleston The papers from that City this morning contain the particulars of a sharp engagement on James Island. On Tuesday afternoon, which continued until dark.

We left Old Point at 10 o'clock on the morning of the 13th, with a flag of truce, under command of Capt. MILWARD, and arrived here on the evening of Sunday. On board were Judge CRUMP and Dr. TAYLOR, of Richmond, both returning under a flag of truce, and also five Confederate prisoners, released on parole.

The NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES, No. 809, is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter, in wrappers, ready for mailing. It contains the LATEST INTELLIGENCE up to the moment of going to press.
The British steamship Solent arrived at Aspinwall, from Carthagena, day before yesterday. She brings dates from Bogota, the capital, to the 16th May.

We have further rebel reports of the preliminary operations of our forces against Charleston. A dispatch from Augusta, Ga., dated the 12th, informs us that a sharp engagement took place on James Island, on Tuesday afternoon, which continued until dark, the occasion being an attack on our forces, to present them from occupying a certain piece of wools.

The forces under the command of Brig.-Gen. WRIGHT, crossed from Edisto Island to Seabrook's Point on the 29th, 30th and 31st May. The Sixth Connecticut was the first regiment landed and were thrown out as an advance. They had a skirmish with the rebel pickets on Sunday morning, June 1, and at the second attempt, drove the enemy across the river and obtained possession of the bridge.

To-day the right wing of the army was attacked by the rebels at a point little anticipated. It has been known for several days that the enemy has been lurking about Hanover Court-house, and a smelt force has been detailed every day to watch his movements.
