The steamship Ariel, from Aspinwall on the 8th inst., arrived at this port yesterday, with the mails, passengers and treasure from California. She brings intelligence of the wreck of the British screw steamer Mutine at the entrance of the harbor of Navidad, near Manzanilla, on the coast of Mexico.

Immense preparations are being made throughout all the cities, towns and villages of the loyal States for such a celebration of the coming Fourth of July as has never been witnessed in the history of the country. We do not hear, however, that New-York, the Metropolis of the Union, has yet done anything for, or even begun thinking of a fit observance of the natal day of the Republic.

The Massachusetts arrived from City Point this afternoon, whither she had been under a flag of truce. The result of the communication is unknown, but Col. KANE, of the Pennsylvania Bucktail Rifles, who was captured by the rebels recently in the Valley of the Shenandoah, comes down as a released prisoner on parole for exchange.
A judicious sifting of the public and private advices received from Europe during ten days past, presents, in an unpleasant light, the possibility of European intervention in the American question.

A citizen of Memphis, who has taken the oath of allegiance, has just returned from Granada, Miss., and reports that a rebel army, 65,000 strong, has concentrated there, and that business was brisk and provisions plenty.

A FATAL ACCIDENT IN THE CENTRAL PARK On Saturday last, as Mr. THOMAS P. SHERLOCK and his wife were riding in a one-house conveyance through the grounds of the Central Park, the horse suddenly took fright and at once became unmanageable. To the Honorable the Board of Supervisors: GENTLEMEN: I cannot approve your resolution authorizing and directing "the Comptroller to pay to the order of the Commissioners for building the new City Hall" "the sum of forty thousand dollars." Nor can I sign any warrant for the payment of money toward the expenses of building the new court-house, until the Commission is filled.

It is a bright, beautiful Sabbath morning, and we are marching out to our devotions to the music of grander anthems than ever echoed through church aisles. Our organ-pipes are great-ribbed, loud-lunged cannon, and the octaves that issue from their bur- nished throats would probably astonish any of the audiences that on bright Sundays are accustomed to gather around the porches of your City churches, to hear the music within.

STANLY, which was delivered at Washington, N.C., on the 17th inst., before the great Union Mass-meeting, was full of moderation and eloquence, and it may be pronounced one of the finest productions of the day. President LINCOLN arrived in this City on Monday night, and proceeded immediately to West Point by a special train on the Hudson River Railroad accompanied, it is stated, by Gen. POPE. Gen. SCOTT is at present stopping at West Point, and it is conjectured that the object of the President's visit is to confer with him on the progress of the campaign.

THE STRAWBERRY CARNIVAL. The strawberry carnival was at its height last week, and would have continued through the present, weather permitting. At no time within the memory of the oldest inhabitant, has the delicious strawberry been so abundant or so cheap as during the present season. The number of distinct varieties, too, is remarkable, and all have, as a general rule, reached the market in good condition.

THE ELEVENTH WARD HOMICIDE. The Coroner commenced the taking of testimony in this case yesterday afternoon. Officer ADEL D. HUNT, of the Eleventh Precinct, who made the arrest of MICHAEL MORAN, one of the parties suspected of having aided in the commission of the homicide, was examined at length by Coroner NAUMANN.

POPULAR EXCITA BILTY. Whatever mystery attended the visit of the President to West Point is sufficiently cleared up. The Republic is not in danger, Washington is safe, Gen. McCLELLAN is neither dead or defeated, JACKSON has not gobbled up FREMONT.

The steamship Coatzacoalcos arrived from New-Orleans about 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon. Her dates are to the 18th inst. The newspapers by her contain a variety of interesting news, which, together with our correspondence, will be found below.

Our letters from New Orleans this morning, and the extracts from the Press of that city, will be found deeply interesting. The condition of this Southern metropolis, as it slowly rises from the slough of rebellion into the clear atmosphere of loyalty, furnishes a most instructive subject to the political philosopher, as well as to every patriot who looks to the final pacification of the South, and the unification of the whole Republic.

Our advices from Gen. McCLELLAN'S army this morning are highly important. Dispatches from the General to the War Department announce that our pickets on the left were advanced considerably yesterday, under sharp resistance on the part ...

Hon. E.M. Stanton, Secretary of War: We have advanced our pickets on the left con siderably, to-day, under sharp resistance. Our men have behaved very handsomely. Some firing still continues. (Signed,) GEO. B. McCLELLAN,

WHERE WAS THE PRESIDENT? Whether President LINCOLN has visited West Point or whether he has not, is now the absorbing topic in Washington. While on the one hand it is positively stated that he was yesterday closeted with Gen. SCOTT, it is on the other affirmed with equal positiveness that he was at the same time holding confidential conversation with Gen. McCLELLAN.

Martial law is just proclaimed in Norfolk and Portsmouth. The municipal election was to have taken place to-day, but as some collision was anticipated between the rebels and the Unionists, Gen. VIELE, late last evening, the 23d, issued the following proclamation:

We suppose that, by an attentive perusal of our daily budget of correspondence and telegrams from our army in front of Richmond, the reader will obtain as correct an idea of the situation and prospects there as it is in the power of words to give.

We are now in regular receipt of Union newspapers from North Carolina, South Carolina and Florida from New-Orleans, Memphis, Nashville, and many points in Tennessee from all parts of Kentucky, Missouri and Western Virginia from Norfolk, Alexandria, and other places in Eastern Virginia; in fact, they come to us from more than half of the region lately held by the late rebel Confederacy.

The Nelly Baker, mail-boat from White House, brought down from Headquarters this evening half a dozen deserters from the rebel army, and as many Secessionists arrested near our lines on suspicion of having given information which led to Gen. STUART'S recent cavalry, raid around our army.

The NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES, No. 812, is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter, in wrappers, ready for mailing. It contains the LATEST INTELLIGENCE up to the moment of going to press.

The "Jameson " Democratic Convention, which assesmbled under a People's call, was not very largely attended, but quite spicy. ALLEN HAINES, of Portland, was temporary Chairman, and FRANCIS G. BUTLER, of Farmington, President.

The Board of Aldermen met yesterday and received a message from the Mayor vetoing the ordinance for establishing the St. Joseph's Hospital for wounded soldiers in the Central Park. A donation of $2,000 was made to the charitable fund of the Fire Department. The Board refused to concur with the Councilmen in appropriating $2,000 for the celebration of the 4th of July.

ROSTAN on Wednesday evening, to witness the closing entertainment offered their friends by her accomplished students.

The mails by the steamship Arabia, at Boston, from Liverpool on the 14th inst., reached this City yesterday morning.
Mr. TRUMBULL, of Illinois, (Rep.,) presented several petitions in favor of a ship canal from Lake Michigan to the Mississippi River.

All is still quiet in the Department of the Shenandoah. That is, the somewhat strengthened force of Gen. BANES has not disturbed the enemy, and the enemy have not disturbed us since our arrival here. And yet the town and suburbs bear unmistakable appearances of a country in a state of war.

In the Senate, yesterday, petitions were presented in favor of a ship canal from Lake Michigan to the Mississippi, and of a bankrupt law. A bill for the relief of the widow of Gen. C.F. SMITH was reported from the Committee on Pensions. The bill to grant the proceeds of certain public lands to aid in the construction of the Northern Pacific Railroad was passed.

Speculation upon the movements of our army before Richmond has almost entirely ceased. The recent heavy rains have caused a rise in the Chickahominy, which will somewhat retard the progress of events. The railroad from White House is in good

The Press is generally commenting upon the Franco-Mexican imbroglio, as though the full news of the defeat of the French, near Puebla, had reached France. We believe we are entirely correct in stating that nothing more than the rumor of the defeat of the French.
The members of the House shortly after assembling proceeded to the Senate to attend the Court of Impeachment for the trial of Judge HUMPHREYS.

Gen. HOOKER, at 9 o'clock this morning, advanced his Division with the view of occupying a new position. The result was that his troops met with a most determined resistance from the enemy, which lasted until four o'clock in the afternoon, but the rebels were forced to give way before the invincible courage of our men.

CARLTON, with his forces, has entered Arizona. On the 25th of May he was at the Pimos villages, a cluster of Indian ranches on the Gila River. Col. WEST, with the advanced guard, had entered Tucson and taken possession. This town is 90 miles south of the Pimos villages, and it is the centre of the region that was settled before the recent devastations of the Indians.
Last evening one of our gunboats moved up and shelled the rebels on the Petersburgh road, but without any casualties on the side of the rebels, according to their own account of the affair.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: In addition to the varieties of Chronic Bronchitis, described in my last letter, there are several others, which are of less importance, because less common in their occurrence.

At the third day's racing, to-day, there were between three and four thousand spectators. The weather was beautiful, and the track, considering the late heavy rains, in good condition. The first race was a single dash of one mile, and was won by JOHN HUNTER'S Miss Jessie, beating Lexington, filly, and Erolite half a length, in 1.46 .
The Hendrik Hudson and Issac Newton, of the People's Line of North River steamers, are said to have been chartered by Government.
The House resumed the consideration of the bill providing indemnity to loyal citizens for losses and damages to property through United States troops, etc.

The United States transport Ericsson, Capt. LOWDER from Tortugas 16th inst., Key West 18th and Port Royal 23d, arrived here yesterday morning. She brings a large mail from all the above places, and has 181 passengers, among whom is Gen. BENHAM and Staff. She has also on board 57 wounded soldiers, who were wounded in the late engagement on James Island, S.C. They are in charge of Surgeons CRAVEN

Gen. FREMONT, it will be seen by an order from Secretary STANTON, has been relieved from his command of the First Army Corps of the Army of Virginia, at his own request. Gen. RUFUS KING is appointed to the command in his place.

Gen. FREMONT on Friday turned over his command to Gen. SCHENCK, next highest in rank, and with his personal staff and an escort of cavalry left Middletown yesterday morning on his way to New-York.
The commanding officer of the United States steamer Winona, Lieut. F.T. NICHOLS, lately addressed a letter to the authorities of Rodney, Miss. from which the following is an extract:

Ohio Regiment, besides several officers, was attacked by a large force of rebel cavalry yesterday, about twelve miles from this city. The rebels destroyed the locomotive, burned the cars, killed ten of our men, and captured several officers, including Col. KINNEY, Majors PRIDE and SHARPE.

GENERAL ORDERS NO. 2. The annexed Special Order No. 284, from General Headquarters, are hereby brought to the notice of all persons raising recruits at this depot, under General Orders No. 31.

We have received a copy of the Christian Banner, published at Fredericksburgh, Va., by JAMES W. HUNNICUTT. Mr. HUNNICUTT, in a long article headed "Rebellion and Stubborness," sets himself right on the secession question. He says that a faction of "ill-natured politicians," whose motto was " rule or ruin." attempted to usurp the reins of Government.

Seven bridge-burners were executed at Atlanta, Ga., on the 18th inst. Arrangements had been made for them all to be swung off at the same time; but two of the ropes breaking, the men fell to the ground instead of into eternity. But these two were quickly brought to their feet, new ropes adjusted to their necks, and an end at once put to their earthly career.

A resolution looking to the transfer of the Branch Mint of the United States from NewOrleans to St. Louis, was entertained by the House of Representatives a short time ago. The proposition, with our present light upon the subject, seems neither wise nor politic.
The Atlanta (Ga.) Confederacy, of the 18th, publishes the dispatch, which we have had, announcing the movement of BEAUREGARD to Richmond, and says:

Gen. FREMONT having been superseded in command of this Department by the order appointing Gen. POPE his inferior in rank over the army of Virginia, and having asked and been refused leave of absence, has, at his own request, been relieved from duty.

We have advices from Key West to June 23. Gen. J.M. BRANNAN and staff were to leave on that morning on board the prize steamer Circassian, for Hilton Head. The Circassian would thence, probably, come to this port.

TO REFUGERS AND OTHERS HAVING NEGROES TO HIRE. The railroad from Danville to Greensborough is about to begin construction, on a large scale, and requires a numerous force of laborers, as well as overseers of experience, who can come well recommended.

CONTRIBUTIONS TO OUR WOUNDED SOLDIERS BY PUBLIC SCHOOL No.48. While Churches and association are providing for the wounded in our hospitals, and the benevolent of both sexes are giving their time and means in alleviating the sufferings of the noble defenders of our country, the teachers and pupils of some of the New-York Public Schools are doing "what they can" for the cause. Ward School No. 48.

The United States Mail steamship Marion, Lieut. J.D. PHILLIPS, United States Navy, commanding, arrived at this port yesterday morning, from New-Orleans on June 21, with merchandise and passengers to SPOFFORD, TILESTON Co.

The second cargo of sugar from New-Orleans, since the raising of the blockade, consisting of 278 hogsheads, arrived in this port yesterday. The prospects are, that, whether or not cotton comes forward from the South this Summer, we are likely to get a respectable supply ...

Just sixty-five years ago yesterday, the corner-stone of the Duane-street Methodist Episcopal Church was laid, by Rev. GEORGE ROBERTS. So far as known, but two who were present at the time are now living. The occasion was celebrated with appropriate exercises in the church yesterday?Methodists from all parts of the City flocking to participate.

On Thursday evening at 7, I left Fair Oaks for the White House. The train had left the station at Savage's, early in the evening, so I turned my horse's head toward Bottom's Bridge, and concluded to ride the short distance of twenty miles. A battle had been fought on our right that day, but it was impossible to ascertain, at headquarters, any of the particulars.
William H. Seward and Thurlow Need left the Actor House, yesterday afternoon, at 5 o'clock, by the Norwich route, for Boston. The cause of tneir departure is unknown.

On motion of Mr. WILLEY, of Virginia, (Union,) the bill for the admission of West Virginia as a State, was taken up, the question being on the amendment offered by Mr. SUMNER, that after the 4th of July, 1863, with in the limits of said State of West Virginia, there shall be neither Slavery nor involuntary servitude. otherwise than for the punishment or crime, whereof the party shall be duly convicted.

The terrible excitement we have gone through during the past week has entirely subsided, and a calm but determined feeling of hope has taken possession of all minds. There is nothing of any consequence new from the seat of war, and all our energies here are at present devoted to attending to the brave fellows who have come to us wounded or sick from the dreadful ordeal through which they have just passed.

In the Senate, yesterday, the Confiscation bill as returned from the House was taken up. Mr. SHERMAN, of Ohio, moved that the Senate recede from its amendment and agree to the House bill. All is quiet here to-day; the only apprehension felt being in regard to our boats going up and down the James River. The rebels are trying to make themselves very disagreeable there, firing into our boats without regard to any peaceful or humanitarian mission in which they may be engaged.

A balloon observation, yesterday morning, disclosed the fact that the rebels are encamped to the southwest of us, and some twelve miles distant from this point; their main line being from five to six miles from that of ours.

The steam transport Haze, Capt. CLIFT, arrived yesterday morning from Harrison's Bar, the headquarters of Gen. McCLELLAN'S army, whence she sailed on Friday afternoon last. She arrived at Harrison's Bar on the 5th inst., and remained nearly a week. She took out a large cargo of war material, including ordnance and rifles, and sixty tons of fixed ammunition.

A PROBABLE HOMICIDE IN ESSEX-STREET. About 2 o'clock, yesterday morning, a serious stabbing affray occurred in Essex-street, between Broome and Delancey, during which a German baker of the Tenth Ward, named ADAM CHRISTMAN, was cut in the neck and shoulder so severely that no hopes are entertained of his recovery.

The statesmen of England are surrounded by difficulties. If cotton is not king, it must be allowed to be a hard subject. It is one that is giving Europe great tribulation. On Friday, the "Fourth" was celebrated with considerable circumstance in this city, though not with so elaborate and extensive a display as last year, for then we had all professions, businesses and trades represented in a grand procession, and the schools too were there from the various wards of the city.

When Gen. GREENE was conducting the war on the part of the colonies, in South Carolina, during the closing years of the Revolution, it was his habit to go into "Summer quarters" during the hot weather, Winter in that climate being much more favourable for military operations than summer.

A LIVELY TIME AT THE PROVOST-MARSHAL'S OFFICE. There was a very large crowd at the Provost-Marshal's office in the early part of the day, yesterday, the visitors all wishing to get their passports, for the purpose of leaving by the steamers for Europe.

There is nothing new from Gen. McCLELLAN'S army this morning. We are unable even to guess where the army is at the present time. Our Washington correspondent states that everybody there is in a state of complete be wilderment regarding Gen. HALLECK'S plans.

JOSEPH TAYLOR, of Warren County, Miss., a Union man who lives about six miles from Vicksburgh, on the Yazoo, comes to St. Louis on the Queen of the West, a refugee and a volunteer. He is well acquainted in Vicksburgh, and up to the 18th of July was in the city almost daily, thus being fully acquainted with the state of things there.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The object of this communication is to suggest, through your influential journal, to the public and to the "Powers that Be," the propriety of the Government accepting "substitutes" in anticipation of an actual draft.
The steamship Anglo-Saxon passed this point at 5:30 this afternoon. Her dates are from Liverpool, 7th; Londonderry, 8th; but the Londonderry dispatch has failed to come to hand.
In consequence of the abandonment by our troops of certain districts under cultivation, the late inhabitants thereof have been driven from their homes and are now without employment.

Italian affairs have suddenly assumed that turn which those who have at heart the good of the young nationality have all along looked forward to with anxious forebodings. It has been foreseen that the trying moment for Italy would be that when GARIBALDI should see fit to move on some new enterprise which VICTOR EMANUEL would be constrained to oppose.

One day's later advices from Europe have been received by the arrival off Cape Race of the steamship Anglo-Saxon. She left Liverpool on the 7th, and Londonderry on the 8th inst. The news is not specially important.
At a little before 6 o'clock, last evening, FELIX MENALI shot his son twice, in the woods, about half a mile from Fort Hamilton, inflicting wounds which resulted in death a short time afterward.
Our indefatigable Senator arrived in this city on the 3d inst. He was immediately besieged by the hosts of friends, and "otherwise," who had been eagerly waiting for his arrival.
The hospital steamship Daniel Webster, Capt. BELTHEN, arrived at this port yesterday morning from Harrison's Landing and Fortress Monroe, bringing 129 sick soldiers to the Sanitary Commission.
The Thirty-fourth Massachusetts Regiment, Col. GEOROR D. WILLS, arrived in Jersey City from Boston in the City of Boston, on saturday morning, on route for the seat of war.

THE ARMY OF THE POTOMAC. Gen. McCLELLAN is known to be still at Harrison's Landing. The rebels seem not to be pressing him closely.
Our National Debt, and the current expenditure by which it is growing, have come to be matters of absorbing interest to the entire nation.
Affairs in regard to GARIBALDI'S movements were unchanged.
MAGOFFIN has done the best thing possible for himself, in resigning the supreme magistracy of Kentucky.

No one truthful dispatch from the National Capital has caused a more spontaneous and universal thanksgiving than that which yesterday informed our readers that the gallant CORCORAN was at last released, had set foot upon loyal ground and was on his way to report at headquarters.

The Brooklyn Times has the statements of a lady and two daughters, who left Richmond a week ago last Wednesday morning. They say that a mass meeting was held before the recent battles, and it was debated whether or not they should burn the city.

The United States transport Arrowsmith arrived here on Saturday with sick and wounded from McCLELLAN'S army. The sick are mainly low with typhoid fever. The invalids were all taken to the Government Hospital at Newark, N.J., under charge of Dr. JANEWAY.
No village, perhaps, has occupied a more prominent position, in connection with the present rebellion, than Harper's Ferry.
The new Tariff seems to be working very satisfactorily, as far as the Government is concerned, for since it took effect the receipts for duty at our Custom-house have measurably increased.
Another war meeting will be held on Fort Green. Tuesday afternoon, at 4 o'clock, to encourage volunteering. This will probably be the largest meeting ever held in America.
Gen. SIGEL, who occupies the advance, near the Rapidan, reports that this morning the enemy made a feint of an attempt to cross the river, but he drove them back. All is quiet.

The Army of the Potomac has to-day returned to view a second time the battle-fields of Williamsburgh. Over four months have passed away since this army, powerful in its numbers and confident in its leader, drove the rebels out of their intrenchments.

The repulse of Gen. BRECKINRIDGE is one of the most signal victories yet achieved by the Union arms. The rebel chief came with sixteen regiments of infantry, a body of cavalry, and ten pieces of field artillery. Before he set out on the fatal march, he assured his soldiers that they would breakfast in the capital of the State. The feast they found in readiness was something they did not anticipate.

We see it stated that CASSIUS M. CLAY is to have a command in source Department of the West. We are glad of it. It will give scope to the very great ability which he hay always been reputed to possess, but which, through some unlucky combination of circumstances, he has never been able to use.

The extraordinary activity at the Brooklyn Navy-yard, continues unabated. There are nearly 4,000 men employed in the different workshops, and in the laborers' gangs. Some of them are frequently at work night and day.

The Penitentiary opened in Lima, the past week is a remarkable structure; remarkable not only for its dimensions, solidity and completeness, which via with those of the best prisons of Europe and America, but as the inauguration of a series of public works, which, under the guidance of the same masterly mind, are destined to regenerate this imbecile, priestridden, faction-mad country.

Orders have been sent from the Navy Department to the commandants of the different Navy-yards and squadrons to half-mast their flags and fire minute guns on a certain day, in deference to the memory of the late Rear-Admiral Rain, U.S. Navy, whose death at Philadelphia was announced by telegraph on Friday.

During the past month, a portion of the army of the Mississippi has moved from its old station, around and about Corinth, eastward. There were a couple of very good reasons for this: 1. The protection of the Memphis and Charleston Railroad, 2. The health of the army. It is a notorious fact, that an army suffers more by inaction than enduring all the fatigues of the severest campaigns and actual loss by battles.

Gen. POPE's entire command, with the exexception of a rear-guard, crossed the Rappahannock this morning. His advance commenced moving from Culpepper, at 3 o'clock, Monday evening, and the rear-guard left on Tuesday morning, at 9 o'clock, closely followed by the advance guard of the enemy.

This is the residence of Hon. ROBERT MALLORY, M.C. Yesterday he addressed his constituents here, explaining the course of the Administration upon the more exciting topics of the day, the proceedings in Congress, and his own votes and doings therein. The audience was large, and the personal part every one bears in the course of events rendered the occasion both solemn and interesting.

It is a well-known fact that the German element and the Irish element in the United States entertain a certain antipathy to each other. This is quite remarkable, and to many it is quite inexplicable. The One Hundred and Twentieth Regiment New-York Volunteers, recruited under the last call, arrived in this City by steamboat and barges yesterday morning. They were quartered in the Park Barracks during the day, and left for Washington at 6 o'clock last evening, via the New-Jersey Railroad.

A few days since we gave the official figures of our public debt, and deduced from them the probable expenditure of the current year ending 1st of July, 1863. The debt of 1st of July, 1862, we know to be five hundred and four and a half millions after deducting the money subject to draft then in the Treasury.

Since my last letter there has been very little news that was calculated to startle the world. Everything is quiet; even the noisy Secessionists, since the battle of Baton Rouge, appear to be subdued, though, not mollified. The news from our armies in Virginia is meagre, but good what there is of it. A dispatch from Washington, dated Sunday, states that skirmishing had been going on during the past three days--several attempts having been made by the rebels to cross the Rappahannock, which had all been successfully repulsed, and in one instance quite a number of prisoners captured.

The Twelfth Annual Festival of the New-York Turnverein was celebrated yesterday at Jones Wood, with great spirit. The Turner Association of this City is an extensive, powerful and influential body, and embraces among its members some of the finest talent to be found within the circle of the German community of New-York, if not, indeed, of the whole Union.

BROOKLYN MILITARY AFFAIRS. The men of the Empire Brigade returned yesterday in large numbers, and before night about 1,500 recruits had arrived at the barracks in East New-York. All the members of the First Regiment, Col. JOURDAN, are coming back, and by Wednesday, every man heretofore enlisted will be in camp.

The pith and essence of President LINCOLN'S letter to Mr. GREELEY is, that he regards Slavery and everything relating to it as subordinate to the preservation of the Union. He does not intend to regulate his policy by his opinions concerning Slavery, either way.

A dispatch was received to-day by Col. J.E. McMAHON, who is raising an Irish regiment here, from Brig. Gen. CORCORAN, saying that Gov. MORGAN had consented that McMAHON'S regiment should be recruited for CORCORAN'S brigade.

Judge-Advocate-General ANTHON and his aide are progressing rapidly with the work of enrollment. Yesterday a number of clerks were employed faircopying the returns of the enrolling-officers. The Evening Post raises a question as to the propriety of exempting Quakers from military duty. This is done in this State by law, and the law of Congress exempts all who are exempted by State laws.

No list of passengers by the Accacia has yet been received. Mrs. ROBERT DALE OWEN and Mrs. RICHARDSON, wife of Capt. RICHARDSON, of the Fiftythird Ohio, are lost. It is ascertained that not more than thirty persons perished.

MILITARY AFFAIRS IN BROOKLYN. Recruiting continues brisk with both Col. JOURDAN'S and Col. CONK'S regiments, and the prospects now are that both will be filled within the coming week. A camp for the first regiment will be formed on the parade ground at East New-York to-day, when the barracks will be relieved of a sufficient number of its overcrowded occupants to make it more comfortable for those who remain.

THE FOOD FOR SOLDIERS. The ladies having the control of the Society for the Relief of Sick and Wounded Soldiers, sometime since complained publicly that those people were not well treated at the hospitals on Bedloe's Island.

Gen. CORCORAN, with his "bully boys" of the gallant Sixty-ninth, will be here to-day. God bless them! It is understood that the regiment is returning home to reorganize for the war, and to be a portion of the Irish Legion which Gen. CORCORAN proposes raising immediately.
The latest news from New-Ulm is to Saturday night. This village is nearly burnt up.
It is impossible for me to longer resist the temptation to send you a few lines from my delighful Summer retreat, amid the parks, and groves, and hillside gardens of this very ancient little town.

Passengers from Virginia to-day report that there was an engagement at Warrenton, Va., yesterday, in which our forces were successful, having driven the enemy out of the town. We were still holding it at the latest advices.
Three more full reviments, from New-England, passed through this City yesterday, on their way to the seat of war, viz.: the Fourteenth Connecticut, Eighteenth Maine and Ninth New-Hampshire.

A special dispatch to the Commercial from the Chaplain of the Seventy-first Ohio Regiment, dated Fort Donelson, 25th inst., say's that the rebels under Col. WOODWARD, the same that took Clarksville, made an attack on the fort and were repulsed with the loss of thirty killed and wounded.

The firemen having had their reception of the brave Capt. DOWNEY, of the Ellsworth Zouaves, just returned from southern captivity, the Municipal authorities in turn gave a banquet in honor of the same gentleman, last evening, at the St. Nicholas Hotel.

CABINET MEETING. The Cabinet had a meeting to-day. The general Meeting over public affairs was decidedly more hopeful than for some time past. The President is understood to have said that the crisis is past, and the dead point of danger turned.

The rain of Friday afternoon and night, and Saturday last, in the vicinity of the Upper Rappahannock, served to swell the river so as to make it unfordable anywhere below the mountains, a few miles back of Warrenton Springs, which, of course, put a stop to efforts of the rebel army on its western and southern bank to repeat their apparent attempts of Thursday and Friday last to cross the river in force.
Two miles from here to-day the guerrillas rushed from an ambush on our cavalry. They fell back and diamounted, when they drove the guerillas back a mile, and waited for infantry.

There is no longer any room for doubt that the repulse of the rebels at Baton Rouge was a severe and most disastrous defeat. As one by one the particulars of the affair are slowly and reluctantly brought to light, the actual extent of their discomature magnifies and expands.

The Commercial's Lexington, Ky., dispatch says that there is no occasion for alarm about Gen. MORGAN'S position. A courier has arrived, who reports that there is no fear of starvation among his forces. The rebels have 15,000 men in front of him and 30,000 men in his rear, commanded by Gens. BRAGG FLOYD and KIRBY SMITH.

THE REBELLION. We gather from various sources a variety of interesting information from our armies in Virginia all of it, we are glad to say, of an encouraging character. Passengers from Virginia, who reached Washington yesterday, report that there was an engagement at Warrenton on Monday, in which Our forces were successful, having driven the enemy out of the town.

We under A DIVISION FOR GEN. CORCORAN. We under stand that, up to this time, Gen. CORCORAN has received the offer of over twenty regiments, of which, so far, he has accepted but two, Col. HEENAN'S, and Col. McMAHON'S Buffalo Regiment, which, with the original New-York Sixty-ninth, will leave him only one vacancy he can fill, under his Brigadier's commission.

A force of 50,000 rebels their whole left wing crossed the Rappahannock on Sunday morning last, near the Warrenton Springs. The force embraced infantry, cavalry and artillery, and the indications were that they had crossed with a determination to stay. The Vermont State Election for the choice of Governor, Lieutenant-Governor, Treasurer, and Members of the Legislature, was holden to-day. An interesting interview took place at Centreville, Sunday evening, between Gens. SIGEL, MILROY, CARL SCHULTZ, and Capt. ROSLY, when the affairs of the army were freely discussed. Gen. SIGEL said distinctly that he was going to Washington to tell Mr. LINCOLN that in his opinion Gen. McDOWELL was a traitor, and he could not serve under him longer.
A general strike for higher wages among the harnessmakers has taken place here. They are parading the streets in large numbers, and calling upon all workmen to join them.

About 7 o'Clock, yesterday morning, a fearful boiler explosion occurred in the manufactory of J. M. SINGER Co., on the corner of Delancey and Mangin streets, from the effects of which three men have already died, and four others are scalded so badly that the physicians state it will be impossible for them to recover.

Conductor WOODALE made a reconnoissance yesterday with an engine on the Kentucky Central Railroad. He proceeded to a point ten miles north of Cynthiana, where he discovered three men, who' upon being hailed, said they belonged to a Georgia Regiment. He afterwards discovered their camp, but it was so much hidden by bushes that he could not make out how many they numbered.
The city maintains its usual quiet. There is nothing new from the front. Everything in the military line is working well, and a feeling of security everywhere prevails.

Accounts show that three or four hundred rebel cavalry endeavored to cross the Potomac into Maryland about noon on Friday, at Edwards' Ferry, approaching from Leesburgh. Our forces, consisting of one infantry and one cavalry regiment and a battery, opposed the passage, and repulsed them after a sharp contest. About 2 o'clock this morning the attempt was successfully renewed, the enemy crossing at several different points.

Some of our friends, not unmindful of the importance of drawing good out of evil, are looking forward to an irruption of the rebels into the Northern States as a means of increasing the vindictiveness of the North, so that our leaders, our Generals and our soldiers should be brought to conduct the war with something of the ferocity which characterizes the rebels.

DEAR SIR: Your letter of the 27th of June, informing me of my nomination for Governor at the Democratic Convention held at Bangor the day before, has been received. My illness will excuse the delay of the answer.

The annual fete of the Emperor passed off on the 15th with its usual eclat. On this day the more fastidious Parisians speed away to some quiet retreat and abandon their haunts to the soldiery, the "blouses," the country-folk, and to the sight-seeing foreigner.
The United States Sanitary Commission steamship Daniel Webster, Capt. BLETHEN, arrived at this port Friday, from Alexandria, bringing five hundred and eighty-eight sick and wounded soldiers.

A gentleman who has arrived at his home in the South, after a sojourn of about six weeks in New York having been taken with a captured vessel in attempting to run the blockade says the reaction for peace is making swift though silent progress.

Byxby vs. Wood. GOULD, J. Some of the grounds here urged for reversing this judgment are of little moment. Such is the point that the referees erred in refusing to allow the defendant's set-off or counter-claim as to certain moneys paid by him. To which point it was sufficiently answered below that the pleadings set up neither counter-claim nor set-off, and therefore none could be allowed.
The United States iron-clad irigate New Ironsides arrived at this portion Tuesday evening last, at 8 o'clock, direct from Fortrees Monroe.

A special dispatch to the Philadelphia Press, dated Cincinnati, Sept. 3, says: "Martial law is being very strictly enforced here, and the citizens remain obedient and very quiet . The drinking saloons have all been closed, and business is very generally suspended, and but for the newspapers and the markets, life would be truly intolerable.

Gen. BURNSIDE has been occupied, during the last three days, in putting himself in condition to meet any emergency that may arise at this place. He has disposed of his surplus baggage and commissary stores, placing them out of reach of any descent of a force in this direction, and leaving him free to dispute the advance of the rebel army.

The affair at Bolivar creates considerable sensation. It appears that the rebels first made their appearance in the vicinity of Bolivar on Friday afternoon. The One Hundred and Twenty-eighth Regiment New-York Volunteers, arrived here yesterday morning in the steamer Oregon, from Hudson, and took up their quarters at the Park Barracks. This regiment has been recruited during the last four weeks, mostly in Columbia and Dutchess Counties. It numbers over a thousand men, and is in every respect one of the finest regiments that have left the State during the war.

Brig.-Gen. TAYLOR, who died recently at Alexandria, of wounds received in battle, was born near Clinton, Hunterdon County, N.J. He was a cadet in the Military School of Col. ALLEN PARTRIDGE, in Connecticut, until he was eighteen years of age and then entered the navy as a Midshipman. After making several cruises he resigned his commission and returned home from the Mediteranean, where he was serving.

A dispatch from Calais, Me., received last night, states that the Norwegian has passed Cape Race, with later news from Europe. Owing to the nonworking of the telegraph lines East, we are unable to lay this news before our readers this morning.

Prob ably few have looked into the present condition of maritime law with sufficient attention to know how the treatment of the Tuscarora is to be judged by the principles of that code. All they see is the gross violation of international comity involved in the refusal of hospitality to the war vessel of a friendly nation, and her dismissal from British ports without the privilege of coaling, and while in a leaky state.

General Order, No. 11, issued by Maj.-Gen. WRIGHT to-day, says Maj.-Gen. WALLACS is relieved from duty at Cincinnati, and will repair to Covington, where he will make his headquarters for the present, and proceed to organize into brigades the troops, mustered into service, and concentrating at and in the vicinity of Newport and Covington.

It is announced that Gen. POPE has been relieved of his command in Virginia, and assigned to another command in the west. We hope this is not so. It would indicate a willingness to shuffle aside the gravest and most important responsibilities connected with military affairs.

The steamship Australasian, from Liverpool on the 30th, via Queenstown on the 31st of August, arrived off Cape Race at 9 o'clock on Sunday morning. She was boarded by the News Yacht, and a synopsis of her news was obtained, which is two days later than that per the Norwegian, which passed Cape Race Sept. 6.

Gen. POPE has gone West to take command of his new Department. We believe he has assured the President that the charges preferred against him are entirely untrue, and that his failure to destroy the enemy in front of Washington was not his fault. It is evident, from the fact of his receiving so promptly a new command, that he retains the undiminished confidence of President LINCOLN.

Mr. B. FRANK PALMER, the invetor and manufacturer of the artificial limb, which bears his name, has recently tendered to the Government his services, with the free use of his time and abilities, for the assistance of the halt and mutilated of our annies.

Sailed, ship Sagamore, Liverpool, with breadstuffs. The ship Decatur has been chartered to convey breadstuff's to Liverpool.

The Washington National Republican of yesterday morning says: "During the last two days, large bodies of troops have been on the move in various directions. We cannot say how large. We shall not be surprised to hear of a heavy battle in a few days, and we think it will be a decisive one. But we will not speculate."

Wash, Alfred S. Stowell, W.S. Bigelow, W.K. Wells and Abraham Quackenbush, Vice-Chairmen. Messrs. A.J. Morgan, L. Randall and W.H. Lyon acted as Secretaries. Yesterday was another exciting day for Baltimore, owing to numerous reports in circulation that the rebels were "marching on." Capt. F.F. WELLS, of Boston, Mass., with twenty divers, three hundred men, and four whale-ships, arrived here yesterday, for the purpose of raising the sunken vessels at Hampton, Newport's News, Gosport, and James River. Their contract compels them to raise the Cumberland whole, but Capt. WELLS intends to raise the Merrimac whole if possible.

Pursuant to a stirring call published in the TIMES and other City papers, a considerable number of the citizens of the Ninth Ward assembled last evening in the long hall of the Bleecker Building, in the street of that name, to devise ways and means of forming a Ward military organization for local defence, in view of the threatened rebel irruption in the Northern States.

The United States steam gunboat Ottawa, Lieut.-Commanding J. BLAKELEY CREIGHTON, arrived at this port last evening from Stono River, S. C., which port she sailed from on the 7th inst. She had heavy weather during the passage.

ARRIVAL OF REBEL PRISONERS. Forty-three rebel prisoners, captured in the vicini ity of Sugar Loaf Mountain, arrived here to-day in charge of Lieut. NOIS, Second United States Cavalry. A number of them were dressed in uniforms taken from the dead bodies of our soldiers at Bull Run.

All along the Northern Central and the York and Gettysburgh Railroads, the wildest excitement prevails. There is not a little village hamlet, of ever so humble pretensions, that does not boast its band of patriots, who are drilling and otherwise making preparations for resistance to State invasion, and protection of the General Government.

Recruits for the various regiments connected with this brigade are coming in thick and fast. During the whole of Wednesday the recruiting stations were crowded, and the recruiting officers were busy in making out the papers preparatory to the men being examined and mustered into the service of the United States.

There is no doubt that the rebels occupied Hagerstown, Maryland, in force, yesterday evening. They are estimated at twenty thousand strong, with forty-eight pieces of artillery. Since then their movements are unreported, as the telegraph operator left that locality.

A party of rebel cavalry, under Capt. MOTTER, formerly of this place, made a dash through Middle town, about noon, tearing down the only American flag exibited, and swearing and cheering vociferously.

As previously stated, our cavalry occupied the town of Poolesville yesterday, but on the same night retired about two miles on the road to Dawsonsville' for the purpose of allowing the rebel cavalry to again enter the town, so that our own might have an opportunity of taking them prisoners.

JAMES FORBES has just arrived here from Snake River, and reports that two trains were attacked by the Indians at Sublett's Cut Off, three hundred miles north of this city. Fifteen or twenty per- sons were killed, including women and children.

Parties coming direct from Poolesville and Barnesville, report that a large force of rebels under JACKSON crossed the Potomac last Thursday at a point near the mouth of the Monocacy River. On the following day another force, under LONGSTREET, crossed at the same point. Gen. PLEASANTON, Chief of Cavalry, has received information corroborating the above statement. It is estimated that the rebels have no less than 50,000 men on the Maryland side of the Potomac.

Another splendid regiment from Gov. SPRAGUE'S small, but gallant State, passed through the City yesterday, on its way to the seat of war. Quite early in the morning not much past 7 o'clock this regiment,the Seventh Rhode Island, arrived. By 10 o'clock they were aboard the cars on the Camden and Amboy Railroad.

CINCINNATI, Friday, Sept. 12. There have been no rebel movements in this vicinity since the dispatch of last night. The city is safe. All is quiet.

The Fifty-third Regiment, or Vosburgh Chasseurs, whose tribulations we feelingly described a day or two since, are now represented by a fragment or nucleus, amounting to about 350 men, the majority of whom remain at the Park barracks, where a por tion of them have made the last night or two hideous with bacchanal songs, dances and gymbastic performances.

The wholesale grocers met in considerable strength yesterday, at 1 P.M., in the Sales Rooms corner of Wall and Front sts., for the purpose of adopting measures preliminary to the organization of a special military force to serve the country for the term of three years or until the close of the war.

The officers of the various Brooklyn Railroad Companies announce that hereafter they will sell only twenty, instead of twenty-five, tickets for $1, in consequence of the Government tax of 1 per cent. imposed on all city railroad corporations. In their circular they state that, by the provisions of the tax law, they are authorized to act as agents for the Government in paying this tax.

I arrived here to-day, and found affairs decidedby on the rampage. "Skedaddling" is the order of the day, and with good reason, many think, for the enemy have been looked for every moment since yesterday morning.

There is no doubt, however, about the occupation of Hagerstown, and the approach of the rebels in force toward the Pennsylvania border.

While coming into the city from the Soldier's Home, to-day, President LINCOLN's life was put in peril by his horse, a spirited and powerful animal running away with him, and nearly throwing him. He succeeded in checking the career of his steed, at the cost of a sprained wrist.
The Chambersburgh telegraph operator says that he heard firing all the afternoon from the vicinity of Martinsburgh.
The rebel army has fallen back beyond Florence.

We present to our readers this morning a statement of a portion of the work recently completed in the various ship-yards in this City and vicinity; we also annex a memoranda of several vessels about to be launched.

MASONIC LIBERALITY PRESENTATION. At the Annual Communication of the Grand Lodge of Free and Accepted Masons, of the State of New-York, held in this City in June last, Past-Grand-Masters WARING, SIMOND, and LEWIS, were appointed a Committee to devise and present, in the name of that Grand Body, to the then retiring Grand Master, M.W. FINLAY M. KING, some fitting token of fraternal esteem.

Mr. WILLIAM S. GODBE, druggist, arrived in this city, per mail stage, on Tuesday night. He had been on a business visit to the States, purchasing goods for himself, and purchasing and freighting for others. He reports the Indians "ugly," particularly on the Sweet-water route, they still persisting in killing a white man or two occasionally.
Gen. HURLBUT's Division commenced moving yesterday, destination unknown. In fact, it is reasonable to suppose it will not go far.

A correspondent of the Philadelphia Enquirer writing from Harrisburgh, under date of Sept. 12, says:

Late on Saturday night, Sept. 6, a telegram was received by His Honor the Mayor, from the Secretary of War, to the effect that there had been a very severe battle at Bull Run that there were immense numbers of wounded upon the battle-field, and that all surgeons who could be spared from New-York should report at once to the Surgeon-General at Washington.
Four persons were killed to-day by the Indians, near Mankato, while threshing wheat. This was done within a mile of a company of troops.
Joseph L. Porter vs. Daniel L. Sullivan. This was a motion to vacate an order of arrest, on the ground that the affidavit upon which it was granted related to matters only on information and belief.

In discussing the loss of the Golden Gate a few days ago, and endeavoring to fix responsibility for the lamentable loss of life on that occasion, we pointed to the self-evident fact that the vessels of the Pacific Mail Steamship Company are not properly constructed or fitted out for the business in which they are employed, or else that the discipline of the ships is far less perfect than it ought to be.
Reports received this morning state that Gen. LONGSTREET is in command of the forces occupying Hagerstown. His force is estimated at from 6,000 to 10,000 men.

Very early indeed yesterday morning the Twenty-first Connecticut Regiment arrived at Jersey City, coming in by the steamer City of New-York, instead of on the railroad. The regiment mustered over a thousand men, splendidly armed and equipped. After breakfasting at the railroad depot it proceeded on its way to the seat of war. A list of the field and line officers was published in the TIMES of Friday.
The steamer Orizaba sailed for Panama to-day, carrying forty passengers and $750,000 in treasure for New-York, and $160,000 for England.
The authorities have received important information regarding the rebel army in Maryland from a gentleman who visited their camps, and spent considerable time within their lines.
The Baltimore American of yesterday morning has the following:
An old resident of Richmond, Va., adroitly managed to escape from the city a few days ago, and arrived here yesterday, with the latest information from the rebel capital.
A gentleman from Frankfort arrival here today. He says there is a rebel cavalry force there, 150 strong. Most of the troops have removed some disance from town.

The United States Steam Transport St. Mary, Commander Wm. H. TALBOT arrived at this port last night from Hilton Head Sept. 9, at 7 P.M.; arrived at Fortress Monroe on the evening of the 11th, and sailed from thence the following day, at 4 P.M. She brings 100 passengers from Hilton Head, and a mail.

The rebel campaign in the West is beginning to show signs of unsteadiness. After very vigorous push of considerable armies through Kentucky, almost to the bank of theOhio River accompanied with the usual threats of invading the North the enemy's columns are seen to waver, and now they are reported falling back precipitately and in some confusion.

The Church of the Puritans was crowded to its utmost capacity last evening, by a dense congregation of both sexes assembled to hear the Rev. Dr. FRENCH, of the Port Royal Freedmen's Relief Association, relate a chapter of his experience among the negroes recently reclaimed from Slavery, by the arms of the United States in the Department of the South.
The report that the rebels had made an attack on the Northern Central Railroad is unfounded.

The United States store-ship National Guard, W. LES HAYS, commander, from Key West, Sept. 7, arrived at this port on Friday. She left at Key West the United States flag-ship St. Lawrence and gunboat Huntsville.

About 1 o'clock Sunday morning, the 7th inst., QUANTRELL, with two hundred and thirty men, dashed into and took possession of Olathe, the county seat of Johnson County. From that time until he left, at an early hour in the morning, he and his men were engaged in the work of murder, plunder and devastation.

Yesterday, a cavalry reconnoissance was made at Sugar Loaf Mountain. The force engaged in the expedition consisted of the Sixth United States Cavalry, Eighth Pennsylvania Cavalry, Etghth Illinois Cavalry, and Third Indiana Cavalry the whole under the immediate command of Capt. WM, P. SAUNDERS who is the present acting Colonel of the Sixth United States Cavalry. Two pieces of artillery, attached to BENSON'S Battery, now commanded by Lieut, HAYNES, were also with the expedition.

The rebel invasion of Maryland has evidently proved a failure; and the proof is now ample that the army which ten days ago crossed the Potomac near its junction with the Monocacy, has already recrossed or is now recrossing the same river some fifty miles higher up.
A gentleman who left Poolesville at 10'0 Clock this morning says that heavy firing was heard there from daylight till the time he left, from the direction of Haper's Ferry.
The rebel army has fallen back beyond Florence. Some stragglers taken by our scouts say they had 20,000 men, while others say that only 10,000 advanced to this side of Florence, under Gen. HEATH.

The Board of Supervisors met at 11 o'clock yesterday morning, President PERDY in the Chair.
Further particulars of the Munfordsville fight have been received from Mr. THOMAS, who arrived from there this evenning. He was present during the battle.
All business was resumed to-day except the sale of liquor.

By the steamship Bohemian, which passed Cape Race on Sunday morning, we receive advices from Europe one day later. The news is not important. Italian affairs remained unchanged. It was still uncertain what disposition would be made of GARIBALDI. Cotton had advanced only 2d, on the week, owing to expected heavy arrivals. Breadstuffs were quiet and steady, and provisions dull. Consols were held at 93 3/8@93 for money.

The London Times correspondent at Blackburn says: "I find that my estimate of the total number of people here entirely dependent on relief is considered to be much below the real truth, and I have heard it put as high as 30,000. I am told that there are at least 30,000 worth of articles in pledge at the different shops of the town."

Benaniah Barker vs. George W. Chadwick.-- This was an action brought to recover damages for a fraud alleged to have been committed in an exchange of property, by means of false representations by the defendant of the value or condition of the property given him on such exchange.
A fight at Coldwater, Miss., between Col. GRIERSON'S cavalry and the rebels, resulted in the rout of the latter with a loss of eight killed. There was no loss on the Federal side.

A special dispatch to the St. Louis Union says, Bloomfield was attached on Thursday morning by the rebels. It was defended by 1,500 enrolled militia, including a detachment from here. The fight lasted two hours. The rebels tools one 24-pound howitzer and withdrew. The militia abandoned the place with one iron 12-pounder, but spiked it two miles from Bloomfield.
H.W. Halleck, General-in-Chief: After a very severe engagement, the corps of Gen. HOOKER and Gen. RENO have carried the height Commanding the Hagerstown road by storm.

In compliance with a call issued by Mayor OPDYAE, a private joint meeting or caucus of the two Boards was held in the Chamber of the Board of Councilmen, at 11 A.M., yesterday. The only Aldermen absent were Messrs. GENET and WALSH, and the only Councilmen, President Pinckney and Messrs. Desmond, Lent, Miller and Snyder.
The steamship New-York, from Southampton on the 3d of September, arrived at this port yesterday. Her news is four days later than any yet received by mail.

Very many thousands of our soldiers and their families will be interested in the notice published in another column, of Messrs. NETTLETON, GILBERT CAMP, a respectable law firm of this City, who offer to make collections of pay, bounties, pensions, , due to soldiers, at greatly reduced rates.

The following is to the Baltimore American: The intelligence from the front this morning is of the most cheering character. Notwithstanding the bad news from Harper's Ferry, Gen. McCLELLAN was pursuing them with a vigor most destructive to the enemy. McCLELLAN pursued the enemy on Monday morning with his reserves a large body of fresh troops.

The clear and graphic account of a special correspondent of the TIMES, in our columns this morning, of the recent battle between the forces of Gen. McCLELLAN and the retreating rebel army, removes all doubt as to the character of the engagement. It was a deliberately-planned assault by the Union army upon the rebels in force, holding the most formidable position known in war a mountain pass, overlooked and flanked by heavily wooded heights.
Dispatches received from Hagerstown say Gen. McCLELLAN came up with the rear of the rebel army at Sharpsburgh, and that a battle is now in progress.

GENERAL ORDERS No. 129. First, The President directs that the first, second and third corps of the Army of Virginia, announced in General Orders No. 103, be hereafter designated the first, eleventh and twelfth. The several army corps will now stand as follows:

We have this morning the intelligence that the bulk of the rebel army in Virginia crossed into Maryland yesterday, and effected a junction with the force already in that State. A battle, of which we have yet no details, was fought between our army under Gen. McCLEL- LAN and these combined forces, at Sharpsburgh, a few miles from the line of the Potomac.

My whole trip from New-York to this beautiful city was of the most cheering character. Passing through New-Jersey, I was surprised to find numbers of people collected at every station, cheering vociferously, and at every window ladies waving their handkerchiefs as we passed. I soon found out that it was owing to our having a large number of soldiers on board, going to the war portions of the Second, Fifth and Sixth New-Hampshire regiments.
The rebels advanced again yesterday, and drove our pickets two and a half miles this side of Florence. They seem disposed to occupy their old camping grounds in sight of our lines.
The Royal Mail steamship Arabia, from Liverpool on the 6th, via Queenstown on the 7th inst., passed this point en route to Boston at 12 o'clock last night, and sailed soon afterward for Boston.

A dispatch reached us at midnight last night, from Harrisburgh, announcing the reception of intelligence at headquarters in that city that JACKSON had recrossed the Potomac, and that Gen. McCLELLAN had engaged him with tremendous force about ten miles from Sharpsburgh, on the Potomac, and between that place and Middletown. The dispatch expresses the belief that the entire rebel army in Maryland would be annihi- lated or captured last night.

WALLACK'S THEATRE. This evening Mr. WALLACK reopens his beautiful theatre for the reular Fall and Winter season. To look at the bill of entertainment offered, one can searcely believe the house has been, for more than three months of the Summer, given up by him to the temporary management of others. There is one of the (comparatively) old comedies.

After the lapse of several days, your correspondent has at length reached his destination from Baltimore, which place he left last Saturday morning, for Harper's Ferry; a considerable time to occupy in getting to the distance of eighty-eight miles, yet I have considered myself fortunate in reaching this beleaguered village by any route, no matter how circuitous. Many changes have taken place since I left two weeks since.
Messengers arrived yesterday evening from Fort Abereromble, having left the fort on Saturday evening. The dispatches to the Governor are very urgent for reinforcements.

Another serious reverse has overtaken the National arms. Harper's Ferry, the Union stronghold on the Upper Potomac, has been overwhelmed by the rebel hordes, and on Monday morning, at 8 o'clock, surrendered, after three days' fighting. What so many feared was successfully accomplished; the heavy siege guns on the Maryland heights were successfully attacked in the rear, and we lay at their mercy.

Major-Gen. JOHN POPE, now in the city, was serenaded last night at the Tremont House. During the day the General received the calls of hundreds of tha citizens of Chicago, and in the evening the Light. Guard Band and a band of martial music paid him the compliment of a serenade.

The United States Grand Lodge of Odd Fellows assembled a Baltimore on Monday, delegates from all the States except those in rebellion being present. R.W. Deputy Grand She MILTON HERNDON, of Indiana, presided, the Grand Sire ROBERT B. BOYLSTON, of South Carclina, being absent. A frightful explosion occurred yesterday at the United States Arsenal at Pittsburgh, by which seventy-five or eighty lives were lost. The cause of the explosion is unknown, but no doubt is entertained that it was accidental.

Helena is to be the base of our operations hereafter, and a large army of contrabands are employed here in building fortifications. When they are finished, the place can be held by a small force. REBELS IN THE SHENANDOAH VALLEY. Paroled prisoners from Richmond say that troops continue to arrive there from the South, but are sent thence as fast as possible. This is corroborated from other sources, leaving no doubt of the fact that the rebels are concentrating a large force in the Shenandoah Valley, with a central military depot at Winchester, which is strongly fortified.

ORTAIRE FOURNIER, a gentlemen of high literary attainments, who has served the French Government in the Consular capacity, and is well and favorably known to many of our most respectable citizens, lectured on Wednesday evening, at Cooper Institute, to a select and appreciative audience, on "The Prosperity of the American Republic, before the present Civil War, and the Causes and Authors of that War."

On a noted occasion in sacred history, a wicked king of a wicked people was sore afraid and distressed when he saw the Children of Israels coming up out of their house of bondage in Egypt, pitch their tents in the plains of Moab.

A few days since one of Commodore FARRAGUR's men was tied to a tree and disembowled by a party of Mississippians, who captured him while wandering to the shore near the gunboats, in the neighborhood of Vicksburgh.

Staten Island has responded, with unexpected emphasis, to the calls of the Government. The town of Southfield has completed its quotas, with a surplus, and tenders the extra men to its neighbor, Middletown. The northern shore has done nobly, and it is probable that no draft will be required in any part of the county. Large and enthusiastic war...

The steamship Ocean Queen, Capt. TERRY, from New-Orleans Sept. 10, and Pensacola 13th, to D.B ALLEN, is in port. The Ocean Queen left in Pensacoa, Sept. 12, steamers Honduras, arrived 10th, and Mary H. Bowman. Sept. 14, off Sombrero Light, signalized bark Quincy, bound west. There was nothing new at Pensacola. The health of the troops there is good.
The steamboat Vanderbilt arrived this morning, with about 1,100 Union paroled prisoners, from Aiken's Landing.

I was on the battle-field up to 10 o'clock yesterday morning, and left with confidence that all was going on right. It was a grand battle the most severe of the war every division of the rebel army being on the field.
The news received during last night indicates that the result of yesterday's fight was decidedly in our favor; but still another battle is necessary to determine who shall finally be the victor.

We are still without official details of the great battles of Tuesday and Wednesday, but sufficient is known to indicate that the advantages were all on our side. It appears, according to the best information received, that the battle of Tuesday did not commence until about 5 o'clock in the afternoon, but it raged until late at night, and closed, as before stated, without any definite result, the two armies resting upon the field. Gen. BURNSIDE'S Corps is again in the advance, and reached this village last evening. As at Frederick City, our forces met with some resistance. The rear-guard of the rebels, as is their usual wont, resisted the advance of our troops, as was stated in my letter of yesterday, near Fairview, about five miles from Frederick City. A random skirmish continued...

Miss Dix has definitely settled one part of the question so often put: "What can woman do for the country?" and a Convention of Boston women thus sets forth their ideas as to how their sex can be of assistance inthe present crisis.

This has been an eventful day in the history of the rebellion. A battle has taken place, in which the army of the Potomac has again been victorious, and which exceeded in extent any battle heretofore fought on this continent.

Before this is in print, intelligence will in all probability have reached us that will fill the whole country with rejoicing, or the reverse. Authentic information has reached this place that a desperate battle is at this moment being fought in what is called the Middletown Valley between the South Mountain and Coshacton Hills, and some two miles from Sharpsburgh, Md.

The military commenced fortifying the city yesterday. Negroes were impressed throwing up riflepits and digging breastworks.

A great battle has been fought, and we are victorious. I had the honor to open it yesterday afternoon, and it continued until 10 o'clock this morning, when I was wounded, and compelled to quit the field.

A special dispatch, dated Hagerstown, yesterday, to the Press, says of the fight on Tuesday: "The battle raged with great spirit. The firing on either side was very heavy, until toward sundown, when the rebels were flanked by HOOKER and PORTER, and severely punished. Their fire became desultory, and it was evident that their ammunition was giving out.

Advices just received at headquarters, from Hagerstown, confirm the report that no fight had taken place to-day: that the rebels are supposed to be short of ammunition, and that the fight would probably commence at daybreak tomorrow.

The Grand Chapter of Royal-Arch Masons of New-Jersey held its annual convention in Trenton to-day. All of the chapters in the State were represented.
The four-mile race between the Kentucky horse Wagram and Kentucky mare Verge, owned in Canada, was won to-day in two heats by Wagram. Time 8:5 ; 8:12.

The retrograde movenment of our troops, on the part of Gen. BUELL, has at length taken place. On the breaking up of our camps at Battle Creek, our men took possession of Dechard, whence, after being oined by BUELL in person, they took their line of march for Murfreesboro. Since closing and dispatching my letter this morning, I am satisfied that the estimate of the enemy's loss which I gave, is entirely too small. A visit to that portion of the field where HOOKER'S Corps were engaged, and particularly along the route fought by GIBBON'S Brigade, of KING'S Division, on the turnpike, reveals a carnage of which I had previously no conception. The enemy's dead are piled everywhere

A force, consisting of artillery, infantry and cavalry, under command of Lieut. Col. KILPA- TRICK, left Gen. SIGEL's headquarters, yesterday morning, on a reconnoisance toward Leesburgh. On arriving at Goose Creek, the passage of that stream was disputed by a squadron of rebel cavalry, who, however, were soon put to flight by our artillery.
By a special dispatch from the TIMES correspondent in Baltimore we learn that orders have been received there to prepare for the arrival of a number of wonnded to-morrow.

A special dispatch from Fredericksburgh states that fighting has been desperate at Sharpsburgh, and that among the wounded are Gen. HOOKER. Gen. MEAGHER, and Col. HINKS of the Nineteenth Massachusetts, and the Surgeon of the Twelfth Massachusets is reported killed.

Kentucky has been emphatically the field for manoeuvering in this war. Her soil has been alternately marched over and held by opposing armies of great strength. This regiment, which has performed such useful service, under the command of Col. W.A. HOWARD, late of the Revenue Service, is completed the last detachment of 337 men, under command of Lieuts. HAMPSON and BENJ. H. FRANKLIN, having left yesterday, in the steamer Guide, for Newbern.

The Twelfth Regiment New-York State Militia, Col. W.L. WARD among the troops captured and paroled by the rebels at Harper's Ferry arrived in Baltimore yesterday, (Thursday,) and will be in Philadelphia this forenoon. The regiment will reach New-York this afternoon or on Saturday morning. The Board of Councilmen, at its meeting yesterday, passed a resolution tendering to the regiment the hospitalities of the City.

The ship W.H. Prescott has been chartered for a load of wheat to Liverpool. Business from the hands of importers during the week has been remarkably dull. Sales 500 bbls, Crushed Sugar, 14c. Legal tender notes 15 per centdiscount.

To-day we have had out a strong line of skir- mishers, and, up to 3 o'clock, there was constant firing going on in front. Out troops are all lying upon their arms, ready for action. Burial parties are engaged in burying off the dead and removing the wounded.

A dispatch just in from Gov. CURTIN, on the battle-field, says that the battle is raging fearfully, and progressing favorably for our side. McCLELLAN has been largely reinforced. The Pennsylvania militia were also advancing to the field, under Gen. REYNOLDS.
Adjutant SLAUSON, of the Seventeenth Indiana Regiment, who escaped from Munfordsville immediately after the surrender of that place to the rebels has reached this city.
Adjutant SLAUSON, of the Seventeenth Indiana Regiment, who escaped from Munfordsville immediately after the surrender of that place to the rebels has reached this city.
COTTON The sales of Monday and Tuesday were only 3,000 bales. The market is irregular and dull, and prices are 1d, lower than on Friday last. Speculators and exporters took 1,000 bales.

CIRCULAR: Maj.-Gen. FOSTER, commanding the Department of North-Carolina, has called attention to an article in the New-York Evening Post, of september 4, in which is published the numbers and positions of his troops. He remarks that the New-York papers always reach the enemy in a few days after publication, and that such information from our friends is more injurious than that gained by the rebel spies.

On Wednesday morning, Sept. 17, the sun rose in a cloudless sky, and all nature seemed to smile as if the world were filled with the elect of God. But its splendors were soon dimmed with the smoke rising from the battle-field.
A dispatch received at official quarters up to this hour (midnight), from a person who visited the battle-fields, reports the rebel loss two to our one.

Stephen A. Griffin et al., vs. William Banks and Wright Pomroy. The plaintiffs, as assignees of Bruce McKinney, claim to recover certain property and moneys held and received by the defendants, as assignees of Mary B. McKinney.

A gentleman from Chambersburgh this evening, says all the troops stationed there have been sent to Hagerstown and Boonsboro. A company from Philadelphia refused to go over the line, Gen. REY- NOLDS said they might go home and be d d, and disgrace would forever after rest on their shoulders. After the General's reprimand they finally went over the border.

Brig.-Gen. J. K. F. MANSFIELD, killed at the battle of Sharpsburgh on Wednesday, was a native of Connecticut, from which State he was appointed a cadet to the West Point Military Academy in Oct., 1817. He was at the time of his death about sixty years of age.

The St. Paul Pioneer and Democrat, of the 16th instant, contains a letter from LITTLE CROW, Chief of the Sioux, to Col. SIBLEY, in which he says he want to know in what way he can make peace for his people. He also says that the white prisoners in his possession are as well treated as his own people.
Yesterday was occupied in burying the dead and caring for the wounded. The rebels sent in a flag of trues in the morning, asking permission to bury their own dead, which was granted.

To-day we have had out a strong line of skir- mishers, and, up to 3 o'clock, there was constant firing going on in front. Our troops are all lying upon their arms, ready for action. Burial parties are engaged in burying off the dead and removing the wounded.

FOSTER, Commanding the Department of North-Carolina, has called attention to an article in the New-York Evening Post, of Sep- tember 4, in which is published the numbers and positions of his troops. He remarks that the New-York papers always reach the enemy in a few days after publication, and that such information from our friends is more injurious than that gained by the rebel spies.

The conviction we have often expressed of late as to the approaching collapse of the re- bellion, are based partly on our National strength, and partly on the weakness of the rebels. Of this weakness, the chief cause is a bankrupt exchequer.

A cavalry reconnoissance, made from Gen. HEINTZELMAN'S headquarters yesterday morning, accomplished one of the most rapid and brilliant achiev- ments of the campaign. They went within three miles of Thoroughfare Gap, performing a distance of eighty miles in less than twenty hours.
A gentleman who left the battle-field at 9 o'clock on Wednesday night, confirms the statement of the reporter of the Associated Press at headquarters, in every particular.
About 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon, the Twelfth Regiment, New-York State Militia, arrived at Pier No. 2, North River, landed, and from thence marched up Broadway to the Park.
The steamship Borussia, from Hamburg, via Southampton the 10th inst., was boarded by the News yacht at noon to-day, en route to New-York, and the annexed summary of her news obtained.

A cavalry reconnoissance, made from Gen. HEINIZEIMAN'S headquarters yesterday morning, ac- complished one of the most rapid and brilliant achiev- ments of the campaign. They went within three miles of Thoroughfare Gap, performing a distance of eighty miles in less than twenty hours.

At 1 o'clock this morning, a fire broke out in the brick building, corner of Water and Norton's street, used as a grain drying house. The fire spread rapidly to the Evans and Sterling Elevators, which, with their contents, were destroyed. The fire then crossed Norton-street, communicating to BELL'S foundry, KLEIN DOBSON'S pump and block factory, and a number of tenement houses on Evans, Fly and Leconlaleux streets, all of which were burned.

At a special meeting of the Board of Aldermen yesterday, a communication was received from the Corporation Counsel, giving it as his opinion that the removals of Heads of Departments made by the Board at its previous meeting was per- fectly legal, and within the province of the Board.

I returned last night from the wreek of the Golden Gate, having been absent four days. Although the wreck lies but fifteen miles from here just above the White Rock you will scarcely comprehend that to reach it by land requires it journey of ten hours' hard riding, and through a road the worst I have ever seen.

Following are some extracts from a letter from Rev. Dr. SCOTT, late pastor of Calvary Church, San Francisco. It will be remembered that Dr. SCOTT was banished on account of secession sentiments. The enrollment of the City of New-York, so far as the enrolling officers are concerned, is now completed, and all that remains to be done is the copying and examining of the three sets of corrected books.

GARIBALDI is on the ground, never again to rise. Whatever events the future may have in store for Italy, GARIBALDI'S game is played out. He is old, prematurely old, broken in health, worn by fits of excessive activity; still more wasted by long periods of involuntary repose. The gout tortures and paralyzes his limbs, sorrow will soon gnaw into his very soul.

The news to-day from the Upper Potomac fully sustains the belief of last night, that the enemy has succeeded in escaping into Virginia with the bulk of his force, and assures us that part of our army has crossed the Potomac in pursuit.

About a year ago, Mr. JOHN A. MACHADO, a merchant of this City, was arrested on a charge of fitting out the bark Mary Francis, and divers other vessels, for the Slave-trade; and from representations made by the United States Marshal, it was supposed that in the person of MACHADO the law had at length got possession of the ringleader of the Slave-traders who have so long plied their vocation in this City.
