BURNOS AYRES, S.A., Wednesday, July 30, 1862. A rare opportunity offers to send a letter two days after the mail, and I post up the news to the latest hour.

From a dispatch from Baltimore to CLINTON RICE, Esq., of this city, we learn that the remains of Col. HUGH W. McNEIL, the late gallant chief of the "Bucktail Regiment" Pennsylvania Volunteers, will arrive here this evening under charge of one of the officers of that famous corps.

I have just returned from a fortnight's trip to Hayti, and I have thought right to forward you an account of my observations in that country; but time will not allow me to write in full by this mail, and so I send you on a brief summary.

Who has heard of an Agriculturul Fair at the South since the beginning of the war? Nobody. Yet we have plenty of them at the North, and the Twentyfirst of the Queens County Agricultural Society, opened at Fashion Course on Thursday, was the most creditable yet held by that organization.

The Confederate Government is evidently advancing in civilization. Its Senate, a few days ago, defeated a bill which proposed to legalize the guerrilla warfare and bush whacking, which have been practiced by their predatory bands of murderers for a year past, under the polite name of partisan ranging.
The Governors of Louisiana, Arkansas, Texas and Mississippi have issued an address to the people of their States, of which the following is an extract:
The week that has just passed away will, for all coming time, be one of the most memorable in our history, and in the progress of this gigantic war.

M. FOURNIER, whose excellent lectures have obtained so marked a succes d'estime here and in Philadelphia, delivered the third of his course, last evening, at Cooper Institute, before a numerous and highly respectable and intelligent audience.
HENRY R. MCIVOR, a paroled prisoner, who arrived in this city on Tuesday, gives us some interesting information of the treatment of our prisoners who were captured by the Yankees on the 28th.
On Monday last the President sent the following dispatch to his Illinois home, announcing McCLELLAN'S victory of Sunday:
GARIDALDI has, for the past week, nearly absorbed public attention. He is wounded and a prisoner, on his way to be tried by the Senate at Turin.

Col. WILDER'S Fifteenth, Seventeenth, Sixty-seventh and Eighty-third Indiana, with four pieces of artillery, at Munfordsville, certainly repulsed, with heavy loss, 4,000 to 6,000 Louisiana rebels, under DUNCAN and SCOTT. This occurred yesterday forenoon. Our troops were behind intrenchments and rifle-pits.

The rebel army has succeeded in making its escape from Maryland. They commenced to leave about dusk on Thursday evening, and by daylight yesterday morning were all over, except a small rear-guard. They saved all their transportation, and carried off all their wounded but about 300. Between 300 and 400 rebel stragglers were taken during the day by Gen. PLEASONTON'S cavalry, who took the advance.

Commander PORTER, whose services have told so fearfully upon the rebels since the commencement of the rebellion, pays the officers and men with whom he has been associated the following high compliment:

It has not unfrequently been seen that two powerful men would wrestle together and one bring the other down with a heavy fall. The two would quickly rise again, but instead of renewing the struggle, one would turn away in silence from the ring. To the eye it might seem at the moment that no hurt was done, but that a like contest might any day be renewed between them.

Gen. ROSECRANS commenced moving from Rienzi to Iuka, Mississippi, yesterday morning. During the afternoon his advance came in contact with the enemy's pickets, and heavy skirmishing ensued until night. The fight was renewed this morning and lasted until nearly noon, when the enemy gave way in a southerly direction.

By the arrival of a vessel from Fort Jefferson we earn that the steamer Creole from New-York to New-Orleans, got ashore on one of the Tortugas shoals at 10 A.M., and so remained until evening, when she was enabled to get off without assistance or damage and has tone on her voyage.

By the politeness of Gov. CURTIN I came through on the special car bringing him and staff from Hagerstown with the following late information of army movements obtained through dispatches from the TIMES correspondents with the advance, dated-" On the Potomac, opposite Shepherdstown, Va., Saturday-3 P. M.

The Fourth Michigan, with a few men from SYKES' Brigade, crossed the river at Shepards- town ford late yesterday afternoon, for the purpose of making a reconnoissance. They met with a stout resistance from the enemy, but succeeded in reaching this side of the river with but slight, loss, bringing with them four pieces of artillery, which they took from the rebels.

The United States transport steamer Patuxent leaves this port at 7 o'clock A.M., for Roanoke Island, to connect with the mail steamer for Fortress Monroe. The sad disaster at Washington, N.C., by the accidental explosion of the magazine in the gunboat Picket leaves a perfect wreek of that noble boat. The loss of lives is not quite so great as first reported, while the number of wounded is more 18 being killed and 12 wounded.
Surgeon CUYLER, Medical Director, is now in this city, making every exertion to provide for our sick and wounded soldiers.

The clouds begin to gather attain in Southwest Missouri, that theatre of important and exciting campaigns. Wilson's Creek and Pea Ridge may have to be fought over again, as the plains of Manassas have been.

The Steamboat Canonicus left here this morning with a flag of truce for Aiken's Landing, Mac LUDIEW in charge, taking up five ladies from Norfolk and intending to bring down all the Union prisoners that are able to come.

Yesterday our lines advanced toward the enemy, when the discovery was made that the entire rebel army had retreated during the night, leaving their pickets along the entire line, so as to prevent us ro m gaining a knowledge of their movement until they had accomplished their purpose. Those left behind to perform this duty, generally surrendered as soon as our skirmishers appeared.
JOHN D.D. ROSSET, Esq. Dear Sir: I rise from a sick bed to give you a brief history of what has been transpiring in this portion of Western Virginia within the past few days.

Our State election this year derives its chief importance from its bearing on the rebellion. There are no domestic issues likely to be very seriously affected by the result: but the course of our National affairs may be influenced in a manner that will affect the history of the nation for all time to come.

For two months previous to the date of my last letter, three weeks since, our location had been constantly changing, and our occupation varying up and down between interesting and exciting, feeding us with that variety which?scorning spice?was the aroma, yea, the very mint-julep of life.
rebel Congress voted, a few days ago, to adjourn on the 30th inst. That is to-morrow week eight days hence.

The second day's races took place yesterday. The first race was for three-year olds, one mile, sweepstakes. Jack Homer, Miss Jessie, aed Blackbird, were entered. The race was won by Blackbird. The first heat was won by Jessie by a nose Blackbird second; time, 1:49 . Second heat Blackbird came in two lengths ahead of Jessie; Homer distanced; time, 1:48. Third heat Blackbird won easy; time, 1:51 .

The Washington Star of Saturday evening says that a reconnoissance in force to Harper's Ferry was made on Friday night by a part of Gen. STONEMAN'S force. They found only three hundred sick and wounded rebels at Harper's Ferry.

Shelling was kept up at the enemy across the river at Shepherdstown until Friday night. A report has come into Frederick that a force was crossing at Williamsport, and that a part of our army was sent to meet them. Heavy firing was heard at noon to-day in that direction and at Sharpsburgh, but up to to-night no intelligence has been received from either place.

City Banquet to the Twelfth Regiment. In pursuance of resolutions by the Common Council offering the hospitalities of the City to the Twelfth Regiment, N.Y.S.M., who so gallantly remained in service after the expiration of their three months' term, and were captured by the rebels on Monday week with the garrison at Harper's Ferry, a superb entertainment was prepared last evening for the officers of that deserving corps at the St. Nicholas Hotel.

By way of Fortress Monroe, we receive Richmond papers to the 20th inst., which contain various matters of interest.

We were unable to print the following account of a presentation to Gen. CORCORAN, on Monday night a presentation which possesses more than ordinary interest, from the fact that it was made by the fellowprisoners of that officer, and is therefore an exponent of their regard and esteem for the recipient of a nation's honors.
Major-Gen. WRIGHT, in a special order issued to-day, says the daily prohibition of business after 4 P.M., is hereby rescinded.

From reliable information received here through private sources, we have good reason to believe that the rebel army has not entirely left Maryland. On the contrary, they are reported to be in considerable numbers in the neighborhood of Williamsport, and that heavy skirmishing is still going on at that point and on both sides of the river.

The Republican Convention to-morrow will be one of the strongest in point of numbers, inside and outside, ever convened in the State. Already, every hotel is crowded. The St. Charles, Veorhees, Globe and Syracuse Houses are full. The streets are covered with people. The struggle for the nominations promises to be unusually bitter, and from present apperances, the Convention is likely to hold three days.

This place may be considered the extreme right of the Union lines. Since the departure of the rebels across the river last Saturday, nothing of interest has occured. For the first time during the past four days I am enabled, by being upon the spot, to ascertain the facts in regard to the rebel proceedings upon the Upper Potomac, subsequently to their crossing the river, near Shepherdstown, into Virginia last Thursday.

Information received to-day from a servant, who deserted from the rebels yesterday, shows their loss in general officers in the late battle was greater than ours. Gen. WRIGHT, of Georgia, was wounded in two places. Gen, BRANON of North Carolina, was killed. Gen. LENGSTREET was wounded.

The Daily News has an editorial in defence of the heroism which is being displayed in America, and in regretting the lack of sympathy which is shown for that heroism and patriotism. It admires the good spirit and courage which prevails in the North, and sneers at those who querulously wonder what the Americans mean by not being miserable.

The event of most interest, during the past week, has been the advent of Maj.-Gen. MITCHEL, our new Chief. He has only been here four days, but I venture to say that he is already better known to the soldiets than was either of his predecessors, up to the time of their departure from the command.

The flag of truce boat Cunonicus returned from Aiken's Landing this afternoon, bringing down over 300 paroled Union prisoners, who are to be sent immediately North from this place.

The recent conflict in Maryland is the engrossing topic of conversation here. As it becomes clear that the rebel army has made good its escape, the tendency of public opinion is to depreciate the advantages secured by our trimph at Sharpburgh.

Affairs are very quiet. Good order prevails among the military. Information has been received here that parties of rebel cavalry are scouring the country in the vicinity of Warrenton and the Rappahannock, impressing every able-bodied man they can find into the rebel army. Many refuse to serve, and some suceed in escaping and reaching our lines.

Three months ago coal was plenty at $4.50 per ton a few weeks later it ranged at $5.50, and to-day we are informed by a respectable dealer that for the cheerful sum of $7.50 we can stock our cellar with the choicest of shining black coals. In less than thirty days the price will be $10, and possibly, $12, per ton.

"There has come a lull, in which the contending armies are lying quitely, with the Potomac between them, awaiting developments which will, at no distant day, probably bring them again in collision. Neither will rush unadvisedly to a new contest without exhausting all precautions that generalship and military skill can suggest.

If the reports which come to me from the newspaper offices be true, the Mexican questions is assuming a gravity which requires all the attention of the Government of the United States. The Mexican army is to be carried to 80,000 men, instead of 30,000, and this army, for which the provision contracts have already been made, is to remain in that country.

A large crowd assembled at the Executive Mansion to-night, on the occasion of a serenade to President LINCOLN.

Human, floral and pomological beauty, fragrance and lusciousness permeated the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Tuesday evening, on the occasion of the annual exhibition of the Brooklyn Horticultural Society. The display of fruit, flowers and plants was enchanting, though creditable to Brooklyn mainly from the good taste shown in importations. Indeed, so far as Brooklyn proper was concerned, the most interesting item was a fine dish of sweet potatoes, "grown in the City."

In casting around to test the impressive spectacle of the armed uprising presented by the loyal population of the United States during the past eighteen months, by like mani festations in the history of other nations, it is soon discovered that the circle of comparison really narrows itself down to one single historical point the uprising of revolutionary France to repel the invasion of the armed coalition of 1793-4.
AFTERNOON SESSION, The Convention reassembled at 4 P.M. The rates of the State Assembly were adopted to govern the Convention.

The intense excitement of the last few days has given place to great rejoicings at the immediate proximity of seven divisions of Gen. BUELL'S army, which are coming up from the direction of Salt River.

The Sanitary Commission is daily answering the requirements of eighty General Military Hospitals, not to speak of Regimental and other Hospitals. Of these forty-five hospitals, containing twenty thousand sick or wounded men, are in the District of Columbia. Whatever the surgeons want, which they cannot procure, according to regulations of the United States Purveyors, they can get from us, and they want enough to keep our vast storehouses, continually on the drain.

The Governors of nearly all the loyal States met here to-day, according to agreement, at noon. Fourteen Governors were present, and three States were represented by proxy. The whole party this morning visited the summit of the Alleghanies in a special train, and returned at 11. They held an informal meeting from 1 till 2 o'clock.
A special meeting of this Board was held yesterday, the President in the Chair, and three-fourths of the members present.

Military officers are too apt to forget that American soldiers are not mere "human machines," made to load and fire Enfields, or perform "double-quicks." Grant all that may be said of the "fit food for powder" of a portion of the rank and file of all armies, and it remains true that our ranks of volunteers are crowded by self-respecting, intelligent, moral and religious men conscious of their rights as well as their duties.

Whereas, It has become necessary to call into service, not only volunteers, but also portions of the militia of the States by draft, in order to suppress the insurrection existing in the United States, and disloyal persons are not adequately restrained by the ordinary processes of law from hindering this measure, and from giving aid and comfort in various ways to the insurrection;

With great pleasure we call the attention of a generous public to the fact that to-night, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, will be given a grand floral promenade concert in behalf of the widows and orphans of the dead soldiers of the army of the Union. The Brooklyn Horticultural Society, under the efficient management of the President, Mr. J.W. DEGRAW, and the Secretary, MR. C.B. MILLER, deserves the credit of the affair.

The morning freight train on the Northern Central Railroad, and a troop train coming North, came in collision at Parkton Station. Both engines were smashed, and SHANNON HORDE, of the Thirty-Second Ohio Regiment, killed. This Regiment was among those taken prisoners at Harper's Ferry and panoled, now en route for the Western border.

This, the only public school in the Second Ward, held its opening exercises yesterday morning. The crowd of visitors was so great that access could not be gained even to the reception-room, by those who were tardy in getting there. Two hundred and forty-two children comprise the regular attendance at this establishment, and yesterday, in their holiday attire, looked admirably, going through their various juvenile exercises with much credit.

A further issue of Treasury notes having, on the 19th inst., been authorized by the rebel Congress, as a means of carrying on the war and replenishing their exhausted exchequer, it may be of some interest to review the present condition of the Southern currency, and to compare it with that existing in the peaceful and prosperous year preceding the rebellion.

The armies of BUELL and BRAGG left Lebanon, Penn., and Carthage, respectively, on the 21st, BUELL following the arc, and BRAGG the chord of a circle. Our army traveled 361, and BRAGG'S 206 miles. BUELL got into Northern Kentucky one day ahead of BRAGG notwithstanding the immense excess of our transportation over that of the enemy.

The Episcopal Convention of the Diocese of New-York yesterday transacted a large amount of routine business. The Standing and Missionary Committees were elected, and a very important debate took place on the all-absorbing question among Episcopalians in this State of the division of the Diocese of New-York. No decision was arrived at. The question on the reports will be taken this morning.
The Republican State Convention assembled in this city to-day, and nominated the present State officers for reelection, excepting the Lieutenant-Governor, Auditor and Attorney-General.
Gov. CURTIN reached Harrisburgh to-day and proceeded directly to Washington, where another meeting of the loyal Governors will be held.

George Wilkes vs. William Mulligan. This was an order of arrest issued against the defendant, the notorious "William Mulligan, Esq.," upon the application of the plaintiff, the editor and proprietor of Wilkes' Spirit. Mulligan is charged with making certain actionable declarations against Wilkes.
The following official dispatches have been received at Headquarters of the Army of the United States:
Yesterday afternoon the Steamer Thomas Swan arrived with seventy Secesh prisoners from NewYork, which caused the flag of truce boat Canonicus to return immediately to Alken's Landing.

SUNDAY IN THE ARMY AND NAVY. The Sabbath Committee have issued a brief and well-considered appeal in behalf of the soldiers' and sailors' Sab- bath. Conceding all that can justly be claimed for the emergencies of military service, they simply ask "that the period of rest and worship to which our citizen-soldiers have been accustomed at home, shall not be thoroughly or needlessly interrupted by camp, fatigue or field duties."

An arrival from St. Cloud reports more murders by the Sioux in the town of Richmond on Monday, and the killing of two children. The inhabitants are flying to St. Cloud, leaving the town to the ravages of the Indians.

The State canvas is fairly opened, and according to all appearances it bids fair to be one of the most hotly contested which we have ever known. The spirit and temper of the Syracuse Convention indicated a purpose, on the part of the War Unionists of all political parties, who were there represented, to join issue directly with the peace and submission Democrats, and to give them as sharp a fight as they may desire.

BOONSBORO, Md., Saturday Night, Sept. 20, 1862. I have been traveling in the track of the army to-day, and came to-night, here at Boonsboro, within sound of our guns, a few of which I heard firing briskly just after sundown in the direction of the Potomac, which the advanced guard of our army is reported to have crossed to-day, in pursuit of the feeling rebel army.

Nothing of military importance is at present transpiring in Hagerstown. The chief point of interest is at Williamsport, where the right of the line is stationed. Near that place we are massing troops, but whether for the purpose of crossing into Virginia or intimidating the rebels from again coming to this side does not seem clear.

It becomes my painful task to inform you of the sudden and unnatural death of First Lieut. ALON- ZO COY, of the Eleventh Massachusetts Regiment, and A.A. Quartermaster of this Brigade, who about noon to-day shot himself throught the brain at these headquarters. It was not an accidental casualty, but the deliberate work of his own hand.
GENTLEMEN: You are doubtless aware that a fund is raised annually by the citizens of San Francisco for the celebration of Fourth July.

The main interest among City politicians now centres upon the Street Commissioner. Mr. KNAPP yet acts in that capacity, and has not served, as rumored, any injunction upon the Mayor, restraining him from nominating a new man, while Comptroller HAWS refuses to sign any of Mr. KNAPP'S checks. This unpleasant state of affairs is not likely to last long, as there is a strong probability of a nomination at the next meeting of the Board.

COMPLAINT OF THE VOLUNTEER SURGEONS. Great complaint is made in regard to the conduct of many of the volunteer Surgeons, who recklessly amputate the limbs of the wounded, and leave them destitute of the care needed for their recovery. The object seems to be to secure practice for operating Surgeons. Many operations are performed without judgment, and in a totally unjustifiable manner, frequently hastening the death of the patient.

The Court-Martial appointed for the trial of Gen. McKINSTRY assembled this morning. In the absence of Gen. HARNEY, who has been ordered to Washington, and who left for the east this morning Gen. S.B. GRAHAM was elected acting President. The charges and specifications were called for, but the gentlemen having them in charge could not at once be found. After discussion of preliminary matters, the Court adjourned to meet on Friday.

New-York is emerging from its Summer chrysalis as bright and beautiful a butterfly as ever. The war, which it was supposed would paralyze all its energies and reduce infinitely the demand for and consumption of luxuries of all kinds, seems rather to have operated in a contrary direction, and by placing wealth in different hands from those which formerly held it, given an impulse to trade which is unexpected as it is gratifying.

We have no intelligence from the Army of the Potomac this morning further than that a reconnoissance in force was to be made across the Potomac yesterday. It is understood that the President's Emancipation Proclamation has been well received by the soldiers, especially among the volunteers.

At the meeting yesterday morning, the Church of the Resurrection of this City was admitted to union with the Convention. After the transaction of the customary preliminary business, the Chair decided that the matter before the House was the motion of Mr. RUGGLES to postpone to the next Diocesan Convention, the question of dividing the Diocese.

The Tax Assessors and their Assistants will commence business on Monday next. Only a small portion of the necessary blanks have been sent to the Assessors from Washington, but there are enough to begin with. Their chief business, at first, will probably be to look after the multitudes of trades and occupations requiring licenses.

THE MEETING OF THE GOVERNORS. Great indignation is felt by the Governors who met at Altoona, at the mendacious statements professing to be an account of their proceedings. There was no discussion at the meeting of the relative military qualities of either Gen. McCLELLAN or Gen. FREMONT, Indeed, the name of Gen. FREMONT was not men- tioned in connection with any command.

The correspondent of the American, writing from Sharpsburgh, 24th, says:

There is little local news to add since the sailing of the last steamer. Matters have settled down on the Isthmus, and we are quietly awaiting the result of a new revolution, which is said to be in embryo.
The steamship Philadelphia from New-Orleans for New-York, has stopped here to coal, in prefer- ence to going to Key West, fearing sickness there, but there is little or no fever now at that place.

The recent magnificent donation of one hundred thousand dollars, made by San Francisco to the Sanitary Commission, ought to and we hope will serve to fix the public attention more closely and profitably than ever upon this great practical agency of Christian civilization in the camp.

The steamship Anglo-Saxon, from Liverpool on the 18th, via Londonderry on the 19th inst., was boarded by the news yacht of the Associated Press at 3 o'clock (Saturday) morning, and a summary of her news obtained.

COTTON The sales of the week amounted to 24,000 bales. The market was irregular, and had declined d, for American, d for Surats, and 2d, for other descriptions. On Friday the sales were 2,000 bales, the market closing at the above decline. Orleans Middling was quoted at 26 d.

The Hospital (steam) Transport Daniel Webster, Capt. BIRTHEN, arrived at this port last night from, Washington D.C., which port she left on the 25th Inst., at 5 A.M. She brings 589 sick and wounded soldiers, whose names will be found below.

The continued encroachments of the guerrillas upon, private property, in the counties adjacent to this, have awakened serious apprehensions here. ROE. MORRIS, Esq., President of the Masonic College and Provost-Marshal of the County, summoned the loyal citizens to organize a camp near this place, styled Camp Recovery.

The steamship Matanzas, Capt. LIESEGANG, from New-Orleans on the morning of the 20th inst., arrived at this port last evening, with a large freight, the United States mails, and the following passengers:

Fearful as was the loss of the Excelsior Brigade at Bristow a battle which, fought, as it was, almost alone by this brigade, it claims as its own victory the services of that brigade could not be dispensed with, and the remnant of it was hurled into the deadly vortex of that fearful Bull Run fire, at one of the most critical periods of the first day's fight.

Do our readers remember WIGFALL? It is some time since we have heard anything of this individual, and for ourselves we had almost forgotten his existence. But WIGFALL "still lives," and enlightens the Confederate Senate now and then as formerly he did our own. And, by the way, that we have got him out of the Senate Chamber of the United States, is no small good result of the rebellion.

The advance of Gen. CRITTENDEN'S Division arrived last evening, and will be immediately followed by the remainder, and then comes Gen. McCook's. There has been considerable skirmishing between the guerrilla scouts of the rebels and our troops in the vicinity of Franklin, Tyree Springs, and Woodburn.

As none of the semi-monthly mails that centre at this Isthmus from all portions of Spanish-America, connect with this steamer to New-York, I have little else but local items to send you, and of interesting ones we happen to be very scent.

The Proclamation of Emancipation by President LINCOLN, looking at its possible economical and moral results in the future, is undoubtedly one of the great events of the century. Still, it should be remembered that it has been given out, especially as a military measure, with the authority indeed of Congress, but by the Commander-in-Chief of the armies and navy of the United States, for the purpose of putting down the rebellion.

A collision occurred last evening on the Camden and Amboy Railroad, resulting in a smash of locomotives and cars, but no loss of life. The Southern mail was delayed by the accident, and had not arrived at the time of our going to press.

The Government of the United States is certainly the worst behaved in the world. It is drawing upon itself the frowns of the friends of political morality everywhere. Ringel vs. Victor Heuback et al.; Bithofer et al., vs. Heuback et al. and Davenport, Receiver. The facts in this case, as stated by appellants, are these: Bilhofer et. al., brought a creditor's action against Heuback, et al., judgment debtors, and Henry Heuback, fraudulent vendor of a stock of goods, and filed their complaint Sept. 19, 1860.

It is now over four months since the Government decided to adopt a postal currency in other words, to issue notes of various denominations, from five cents upward which should be receivable at any Post-office for stamps, and should supply the deficiency in a circulating medium. In the meantime, the people, forbidden to use individual shinplasters, reluctantly adopted the use of ordinary postage-stamps as a temporary expedient.

Last night the Union Association of New-, Orleans held a meeting in Lyceum Hall. The room was soon filled with an overflowing auditory of Union-loving citizens, while to heighten the interest of the occasion a splendid brass band discoursed most eloquent music.

A PUBLIC MEETING IN AID OF THE FOURTEENTH REGIMENT N. Y. S. M.-Friday evening a public meeting was held at the Washington-street M. E. Church, for the purpose of aiding in recruiting the Fourteenth Regiment N. Y. S. M. to at least a minimum standard. The meeting was very well attended, and was very enthusiastic. We have had successful skirmishes at Owensboro, Shepherdsville, Lebanon Junction and Boston, Nelson County. But BRAGO is believed to be advancing with 50,000 to 70,000 by the way of Bardsown, Elizabethiown and Shelbyville. However, nobody knows.

The firemen of New-York paid a splendid tribute of appreciation to Commander PORTER, of the gunboat Essex, last evening. Learning that the gallant sailor was stopping at the St. Nicholas, they planned a magnificent torchlight procession and serenade, which was carried out with the most gratifying success. Among the companies participating, were:...
The Eighteenth Annaul Fair of the Society of Agriculture and Horticulture of Westchester County, opened on Tuesday, at Fordham, under most favorable auspices.

Gen. HOOKER is rapidly recovering from his wound. He speaks in the highest terms of the conduct of the volunteer soldiers, and says he would always prefer to go into battle with them than with the regulars Coming from this source one of the bravest and truest soldiers in the service the compliment to the volunteers is indeed important.

SERENADE TO GEN. WADSWORTH. Gen. WADSWORTH was, last evening, complimented with a serenade by the marine band, at his residence, in evidence of the public satisfaction with his nomination for Governor of the State of New-York.

Gen. WADSWORTH hits the nail exactly on the head when he assumes that he has been nominated for Governor because he is believed to be in earnest about crushing the rebellion. The men who made him a candidate do "believe that the rebellion can be crushed that it ought to be crushed, and that it shall be crushed."
The following dispatch was received by MajorGen. SMITH from Col. DAVIDSON, Military Commander at Staunton:

Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER preached last night, to about three thousand people, a sermon suggested by the recent proclamation of the President. We give a sketch only of the discourse, of which the was text taken from 1st Chronicles (O.T.), xxixth Chapter, the 10th and 13th verses inclusive.

Military operations are not conducted on haphazard chance; nor do generals march their armies about "like roaring lions, seeking whom they may devour," but accomplish their purposes by prearranged campaigns, having certain and well defined objects.

Miss BATEMAN mad eher last appearance for the present, at the Winter Garden, on Saturday evening. During her engagement, she has played in "The Hunchback," "The Lady of Lyons," Romeo and Juliet," "Geraldine," "Rosa Gregorlo" and "Macbeth," and has produced a new piece called "Beatrix, the Madonna of Art."

The following ridiculous lie, by telegraph, from Boston, is published in tho Northern papers, of the 18th inst.:

The business of this port since the war commenced has exceeded the expectations of the most sanguine. When, at the commencement of our troubles, everything looked dark and gloomy, it was freely prophested that the result of the war, should it long continue, as far as our City was concerned, would be to greatly injure its material prosperity.

The steamship Anglo-Saxon passed Cape Race early on Saturday morning, with advices from Europe five days later, and the City of Baltimore arrived here yesterday, with mails to the 18th. A summary of the news, which is of little importance, is given elsewhere.
From the Washington Star of Saturday We believe that BURNSIDE'S corps d'armce did not cross the Potomac into Virginia at Harper's Ferry yesterday, as we thought likely to take place.

Information has been received at headquarters, to-day, that the enemy is massing his forces in the vicinity of Winchester, Va., for the purpose of making a stand at that point. Citizens, who live along the line of the Upper Potomac, report that the rebel pickets extend as far up as Lincoln.

It is evident that the good people who put their faith in HORATIO SEYMOUR, and shudder at the prospect of an American nationality purged of Slavery, have been not a litle cast down and disquieted by the recent apparent progress of the rebel arms.

CARLYLE has at last finished the third volume of his history of Frederick the Great, and the HARPERS publish it for the benefit of American readers. FREDERICK obtained the name of a mighty warrior, in his time and hence is designated the Great, as ALEXANDER was. The present day is excessively warlike.

DEATH FROM A FALL AN AWFUL CASE. A young seaman, named JOSEPH STRINGER, just returned from a cruise in one of the United States ves- sels, fell from the third-story window of the premises No. 56 Monroe-stroet, of a late hour on Saturday night. Deceased was out on a "lark" with some brother sailors, and had been drinking with them.

CORONERS' INQUESTS. Coroner NORRIS held an inquest, on Saturday, upon the body of a boy named ALBERT SELLS, who came to his death from injuries sustained by falling from the front platform of one of the Jamaica Railroad cars, in Atlantic-street. The deceased and brother jumped off while the cars were in motion, and, falling under the wheel, one of his legs were crushed.

The special correspondent of FORNEY'S Press, writing from Pensacola, 19th, has the following items: Commander Caldwell has been detached from the Itasca to the command of the iron-clad Essex. Capt., Palmer is detached from the steam-sloop Iroquois to the command of the Hartford, in lieu of Capt. Wainwright, deceased. Commander Nichols is detached from the gunboat Winona, and ordered to the command of the Iroquois.
We have no intelligence of the movements of the Army of the Potomac which it is proper to publish at present. Important operations are in progress, however, which will be developed in good time.

During the Summer months the Brooklyn Academy of Music has undergone considerable changes in its interior arrangements, by which the faults which formerly existed have been corrected, and it is now, probably, one of the best houses in the country for the performance of opera.

Gen. NELSON, whose name has become famous during the war, in connection with the operations of our armies in the Southwest, was shot and almost instantly killed yesterday morning at the Galt House in Louisville by Gen. JEFF. C. DAVIS, also famous in the same connection.

The Board of Aldermen met at 5 o'clock yes- terday afternoon, President HENRY in the Chair. The lobby was densely crowded with spectators, in anticipation of some action in reference to the Street Department.
Present John T. Henry, Esq., President, Aldermen Smith, Walsh, Hall, Brady, Reed, Chipp, Mitchell, Dayton, Jeremiah, Frear, Boole, Allen, Ottiwell, Froment, Farley, Genet.

A very large assemblage of colored people of all sexes and ages convened at 8 P.M. yesterday at the Shiloh Church, corner of Hammond and Prince streets, for the purpose of listening to an expression of the sentiment of their chosen leaders and spokesmen, on their behalf, in reference to the recent Proclamation of the President emancipating the slaves in all the States persisting in rebellion after Jan. 1, 1863.

The otherwise unhappy condition of things in Kentucky is just now rendered still more so by the unfortunate collision between two Generals of the Union army, Gens. NELSON and DAVIS, resulting in the death of the former.

The Board of Councilmen, last evening, adopted a facetious resolution abolishing the Board of Aldermen, "for dereliction of duty during the past year," and calling upon the Corporation Counsel to inform the Board on whom the duties of the abolished Aldermen devolve.
The following is from the American's letter dated "camp of the Fifth New-York Zouaves, near Sharpsburgh, 29th:"

Major ANDERSON, commanding a detachment of the Tenth Missouri Militia, recently had a skirmish with guerrillas in Monroe County, routing two companies of them, and capturing the notorious guerrilla chief ELLIOTT MAJORS, and three of his party, together with some horses, arms and camp equipage.
The Gazette says that a gentleman reached Covington yesterday from the vicinity of Lexington. He reports that a great conflagration occurred in that city on Friday.

We regret to announce the death of Hon. J. PRESCOTT HALL, at Newport, R.I., in the 67th year of his age. Few men have enjoyed a healthier political or physical existence than he, and few could, at the expiration of a long and honorably active life, pass away leaving so few enemies behind him, and so many friends to mourn his death.

Our naval reporter, yesterday, visited the yards in which iron-clad ships are building for the Government. In them all the utmost energy and industry were visible. The following is a rough estimate of the number of hands employed in the different places named: Delamater Works, 1,000; Greenpoint, 2,000; Jersey City, 1,200; Dry Dock, (WHITNEY'S ship,) 500; Mr. WEBB'S, 500 Total men, 5,200.

I have been busily engaged to-day in looking thoroughly into the condition of affairs here, with a view to furnishing the readers of the TIMES with a clearer and more truthful idea of the "position" than they have had furnished them by any paper, so far as I am aware.

MR. GOTTSCHALK AT IRVING HALL. Mr. GOTTSCHALK gives a concert on Thursday evening, at Irving Hall. He will be assisted by Mr. THEODORE THOMAS and Mrs. KEMPTON, a contralto of great estimation in private circles, who, on this occasion, makes her debut in public.

Mr. KELLY, the Receiver of Taxes, has not met with the great success in tax collecting this season that he did the last, when the first day's receipts of personal taxes, on Sept.30, amounted to over quarter of a million dollars.

The steamship Europa, from Liverpool on the 20th, via Queenstown on the 21st inst., arrived off this point at 4 o'clock yesterday. (Sunday) afternoon. She was boarded by the news yacht of the Associated Press, and a summary of her news obtained.

The Atlantic, for October, opens with a charming paper "Autumnal Tints" by the late HENRY D. THOREAU; "King of the Gypsies" he was called while he lived, the forest was his home, and birds and herbs his most familiar companions. He was on talking terms with oaks.

It is understood that the War Department has determined on the exchange of the State prisoners confined in the Old Capitol Prison for Union citizens held by the rebels in Richmond. Mr. WOOD, Superintendent of the Old Capitol Prison, will soon leave for Richmond, to effect the exchange.

Gen. CURTIS, with his Staff, paid a visit this morning to the fortifications surrounding the city and expressed himself highly pleased with their appearance and the manner in which the military arrangements are conducted at them. The appearance of the General and staff on the street collected quite a crowd of citizens.

Last night the rebel cavalry captured Augusta, Ky., on the Ohio River, forty miles above this city. After robbing the houses, they destroyed the place. The citizens fled to the Ohio side as speedily as possible.

At an early hour yesterday morning, the neighborhood of Sullivan-street, in the Eighth Ward particularly the colored residents were thrown into a state of intense excitement, by the report that a colored man named JOSEPH P. THOMPSON, residing at No. 41 Sullivan-street, was murdered, by having his throat cut by his wife.

The steamship S.R. Spaulding arrived here this morning, as also did the Ironsides. The steamboat Metamora left here this afternoon, with a flag of truce, in charge of Capt. Saunders, of the Third New-York Regiment, for Alken's Landing. She takes up four rebel officers paroled, also Dr. JOHNSON, Assistant Surgeon of the Third New-York, sent by Gen. DIX to aid in administering comforts to our sick and wounded soldiers imprisoned in that place.

Brig-Gen. JEFF. C. DAVIS killed Major-Gen. NELSON at the Galt House, this morning. An altercation look place, when NELSON slapped DAVIS in the face. DAVIS then drew a pistol and fired, killing NELSON instantly. Intense excitement prevails at the Galt House.

The Richmond newspapers are busily engaged in covering the retreat of Gen. LEE from Maryland. They announce Antietam as a glorious Confederate victory, which enabled the Confederate General to withdraw his troops in safety after accomplishing the "real object of his campaign," the capture, to wit, of Harper's Ferry, with all its stores of arms and munitions of war.

On Thursday, Col. McLEAN, with a detachment of cavalry and one battery of artillery from Pierrepoint, Va. started on a reconnoissance towards Warrington Junction, via Manassas. They halted at Bristow Station until Friday morning, when they proceeded along the Orange and Alexandria Railroad to Warrenton Junction, where they arrived about noon.

Gen. STAHL still makes his headquarters at Centreville, and has abundance of work for the force at his disposal. The whole country about here, as far as our scouts have been, is filled with small parties of guerrillas and scouts of the enemy, who are not unfrequently quite bold in their operations. Only yesterday a squad of rebel cavalry came within our lines, and fired upon a superior picket force composed of infantry.

There are many conflicting accounts of the shooting of Gen. NELSON by Gen. DAVIS. About a weeek ago NELSON placed DAVIS in command of the Home Guard forces. At night DAVIS reported to NELSON the number of men working on the intrenchments and enrolled for service. NELSON cursed him for not having more.

A dispatch to the Gazette from Indianapolis states that an army officer, just arrived from Washington, says that he read an order while in the War Department on Friday, relieving Gen. BUELL from command in Kentucky, and assigning him to Indianapolis, to organize paroled prisoners into regiments.
THE STREET DEPARTMENT. Business proceeded quite as usual at the Street Department yesterday, notwithstanding the removal of the Street Commissioner and his Deputy.

Maj.-Gen. H.W. Hallock, Commander-in-Chief, Washington: Gen. MERRILL reports that Col. GOITAN, of the Missouri State Afilitia, has captured Maj. WELLS, Capts. EHONY and ROBINSON, and Lieut, MORRISON, with several privates, and important correspondence of the rebels; also, that on the 25th inst., with a detachment of the Missouri State Militia, be routed a party of some fifty guerrillas, taking five prisoners, with a quantity of arms, horses, etc.
The flag-of-truce boat John A. Warner, from Alken's Landing, arrived heree this morning, bringing down only two families from Richmond on their way North.

The Government, the party of the first part, being required to furnish Stamps, (Sec. 102.) and not furnishing them, is the first delinquent. The people, the party of the second part, are relieved, for the time being, from the pains and penalties of the law. This is common law and common sense.

The Board of Supervisors met at 3 o'clock, yesterday afternoon, President PURDY in the Chair. The first interesting subject that came up was a motion by Mr. BLUNT to discharge the Special Committee on the New Court-house from the further consideration of the Mayor's nomination (Mr. TIMOTHY CHURCHILL) for New City Hall Commissioner.

One question must come up vary seriously before all our readers, and will be considered from various aspects, and that is, What shall be the length of this war? Are we to have a weary contest of many years, or a struggle short and desperate?
The State Convention of Anti-Prohibitionists assembled in this city to-day. The Convention met at Voorhees Hall, and was called to order at 12 o'clock noon.

The Board of Aldermen met at one o'clock yesterday afternoon, President HENRY in the chair. The excitement about the Street Commissionership again filled the lobby to overflowing with a crowd of spectators.

We publish on the second page of this morning's TIMES a full report of Judge TREMAIN'S speech at the Syracuse Convention, in review of GOV. SEYMOUR'S elaborate statement of his own position in the pending canvass.

A RECONNOISSANCE TO WARRENTON JUNCTION. Col. McLEAN, with a detachment of Gen. SEIGEL'S corps, left Centreville on Thursday last on an extended tour of reconnoisance which has resulted most satisfactorily.

One of our special correspondents with the Army of the Potomac gives an account of several important reconnoissances into Virginia on Monday. Col. FARNSWORTH'S brigade of cavalry, accompanied by two batteries, crossed the river below Shepherdstown, and reconnoitred the country for a distance of five or six miles toward Win- chester the result being the discovery that the enemy still holds his position near Winchester.
The "Anti-Prohibitionists" held their State Convention at Syracuse yesterday, and adopted the Seymour ticket for State officers.

Gen. MORGAN left Cumberland Gap about two weeks ago, with all his forces, and is supposed to be marching in a northeasterly direction, so as to strike the Ohio somewhere about Portsmouth. He brought away all his artillery and stores, and blocked up the Gap with stones, so as to render it impassable.
The President's Emancipation proclamation contains one feature that has escaped attention in the more absorbing interest drawn around its leading edict.

It is rumored here to-day that the reason of the existing quietude on the part of both armies on the Upper Potomac is, that Commissioners are now either in or on their way to Washington, sent by the Confederate Congress to procure terms of peace. These Commissioners are appointed by a resolution introduced by FOOTE, and acted upon by the rebel Congress.

The reported receipts of the principal kinds of produce since our last have been: 33 bbls. Ashes, 15,836 bbls. Flour, 200 bbls. Corn Meal, 158,338 bush. Wheat, 139,539 bushels Corn, 7,500 bushels Rye 45,253 bushels Oats, 4,251 pkgs. Provisions, and 463 bbls. Whisky.

I have read with great interest what has been said in your papers about Senator POMEROY'S colonization scheme. I am glad to see it has received its quietus for the present. If the colonists should leave, as proposed, on the 1st of October next, it would meet with a most disastrous fate.
The steamboat Canonicus arrived this morning with the One Hundred and Forty-eighth New-York Regiment. The regiment is full and is a fine body of men. They go to Suffolk to-day.
Gen. JEFFERSON C. DAVIS is under arrest for killing Gen. NELSON, and will be tried by Courtmartial.
Ninth Ward Wadsworth and Tremain Club. PREPARATIONS FOR ORGANIZATION SPEECHES BY JOHN KEYSER AND HENRY J. RAYMOND.

Yesterday morning a portion of Gen. SUMNER'S corps, consisting of the Fifth and Sixth Cavalry, (regulars,) and a horse battery, made a successful reconnoissance in the direction of Charlestown. The party, under the command of Major WHITING, proceeded nearly four miles, drove in the enemy's' pickets, capturing five, suffered no loss, and established the fact that the enemy are in force at Charles- town.

Capt. C. McKeever, Ass't Adjt.-Gen. Third Army Corps: I have the honor to report that under the in- structions received through the Headquarters Third Army Corps, dated May 4, "to support STONEMAN, and aid him in cutting off the retreat of the enemy," my Division marched from its camp before Yorktown, about noon that day.

The wounded in the late battles have now all been provided for, and are doing well. The surgeons say that the weather is very favorable, the nights be- ing cool, and the pure Fall atmosphere in these hilly regions greatly assisting in the process of healing, while the general health of the patients is well sustained.

The reconnissance recently made by Col. FARNSWORTH'S Cavalry, the statements of citizens and information received through official sources, confirm the report that the rebel line is the western bank of the Opequan Creek, extending from the Potomac River to a point beyond Windchester.

Trade is very dull and greatly depressed. Considerable quantities of drills, turpentine, tar, pitch and resin are going on shipboard for New-York. Money is tight and in active demand, at an advance in rates of 1 to 2 per cent. The stringency is caused by the large shipments of corn and the inadequacy of the mint to supply the deficiencies for the time being.

PAYMENT OF THE BOUNTY AT CAMP SCOTT. The payment of the bounty to the troops at Camp Scott, Staten Island, has given the greatest satisfaction to the troops at present stationed there, and has inspired them with a degree of confidence in the United States Government which has had the effect of causing a great number of fresh recruits to join.

The regular monthly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce was held at its rooms at 1 P.M. yesterday, ALBERT GALLATIN, Esq., presiding, in the absence of PELATIAH PERIT, Esq., the Chairman of the Board. The attendance, owing to inclement weather and other causes, was very meagre.

One of the most difficult problems in the science of taxation has always been to adapt internal duties to agricultural districts. The inhabitants, in their ordinary business, have so little money passing through their hands, that direct taxation, in such cases, has usually disappointed financial legislators. Such taxes are difficult to realize, and their collection is therefore expensive.

There are three classes of men from whom votes may be expected to be cast for SEYMOUR. First and foremost are those whose secret sympathies are with the rebels, who would aid them if they could without danger to themselves.

The One Hundred and Sixty-ninth Regiment, N.Y.V., Hon. CLARENCE BUEL Commanding, expect to leave Camp Van Vechten, New-Dorp, S.I., for Washington and the field, to-day. This fine command is composed of most intelligent, able-bodied men, recruited in Rensselaer and Washington Counties.

PORT ROYAL, Friday, Sept. 26, 1862. I learn that the Nashville is at present penned up by three gnaboats at the Railroad Wharf on the Great Okeechee River. There is no possible chance for her to escape, one of the gunboats being stationed at Hell Gate, another at Buzzard's Island, and another in the centre of the river channel.

The Street Commissionership difficulty is an interesting chapter in the history of a struggle between two factions of the Board of Aldermen, one headed by Mr. GENET and the other by Mr. BOOLE, The ultimate object of the strife is the Tammany nomination for Comptroller, GENET battling to secure it for Senator CONNOLLY, and BOOLE maneuvreing to obtain it for himself.
Bishop McCOSKRY, of Michigan, preached in the Church of St. George the Martyr, yesterday afternoon, from the text, "Redeeming the Time."

The advantage of vocal gymnastics as an aid to physical development has induced the principals of our first-class private institutes to introduce it as a regular branch of their scholastic course. Arrived, ships Rattler and Christopher Hall, from New-York. Also arrived, ship Lotus, with Hong Kong dates o Aug. 11.

Bardstown advices say the rebels have from 30,000 to 35,000 men within a circle of eight miles diameter around Bardstown. Our central advance was this afternoon four miles this side of Bardstown. They have been skirmishing and driving the rebels before them for the past three day. We have captured six hundred prisoners.

We publish in another part of this morning's TIMES a letter from Gen. WADSWORTH accepting the nomination for Governor. It is characteristic of the man clear, manly, bold and unmistakeable in its sentiments and style.

The long threatened and expected draft in this State, will undoubtedly take place on next Friday or Saturday, as all the enrollments have been completed, and everything is now in readiness for the drawing. The Quartermaster-General states as his opinion that about 25,000 men are still wanted to fill up the quota of the State.

The President's visit to Frederick was one of the most joyous and enthusiastic ever witnessed in this city, and must have presented a startling contrast to those who, but a few days ago, saw the Union flag trailed in the dust at the feet of rebels' horses.

The free blacks and the slaves in Western Virginia have nearly all come to Ohio. This town has been filled with some five hundred of them at a time, while some of them left for the army at Pomeroy, and others have worked their way out into the State from this point.

Maj.-Gen. BUELL, yesterday, announced the death of Maj.-Gen. NELSON, in feeling and befitting terms. " History will honor Gen. NELSON as one of the first to organize, by his own individual exertions a military force in Kentucky, his native State, to rescue her from the vortex of rebellion, toward which she was drifting. On more than one battlefield he was conspicuous for his gallant bearing."

A proposition is pending in the Board of Aldermen authorizing the Comptroller to issue $500,000 in small notes. (of the denomination 5,10,25 and 50 cents,) in exchange for bank bills, for the convenience of our citizens in making change. There seems to be a necessity for some new measure of relief in this direction, for each day aggravates the difficutly the community is laboring under.
At 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon, worship was held at St. Thomas' Episcopal Church, corner of Broadway and Houston-street.

Reliable information reached this city last night of the arrival of Gen. G.W. MORGAN at Greenupsburgh, Ky., on the Ohio River. Greenupsburgh is about fifteen miles above Portsmouth, and as any map will show, is the point within easiest reach of Gen. MORGAN, provided he can strike the river above Maysville.

A company of the Fifty-fourth Pennsylvania, who were guarding the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Bridge, at Paw Paw, about half way between Hancook and Cumberland, were, yesterday, attacked by a rebel force and all taken prisoners.

A very large attendance signalized the meeting of the Convention at St. John's Chapel yesterday morning, and as the day was exceedingly fine, the concourse of ladies was noticeable.

LOUISVILLE, Monday, Oct. 6. Saturday the rebels inaugurated RICHARD HAWES as Governor of Kentucky, at Frankfort. BRAGG and HUMPHREY MARSHALL made bitter Anri-Union speeches. KIRBY SMITH was there. BUCKNER was expected, but was not present.

Margaret Moncrief vs. John Moncrief. The argument on this appeal before the General Term has been before mentioned in the TIMES. The action was for a limited divorce on the ground of alleged cruel and inhuman treatment.

At the meeting of the Board of Councilmen, last evening, President PINCKNEY in the Chair, a resolution to give John McCauley, a member of Hook and Ladder Company No. 18, a testimonial, at a cost of $100, for his heroic devotion to duty and for saving three lives at the fire in Mott-street, on Sept. 22, was presented and laid over.

A dispatch to the Register, dated Tupelo to- day, says: Sixty Yankee cavalry scouts penetrated to the railroad two miles south of Baldwin, and cut the telegraph wires. They were attacked by twenty-five of the Second Tennessee Cavalry, and routed, with a loss of seven killed and two prisoners.

The reported receipts of the principal kind of Produce since our last have been 36 bbls. Ashes, 20,807 bbls. Flour, 650 bbls. and 500 bags Corn Meal, 272,245 bushels Wheat, 184,970 bushels Corn, 30 bushels Barley, 24,951 bushels Oats, 2,450 pkgs. Provisions, and 708 bbls. Whisky.

We suppose we may take it as true that Gen. ROSECRANS has won us a great victory at Corinth over the rebel forces of Gens. PRICE and VAN DORN. The dispatches so far received all go to confirm the first reports of the Union success.

The Express Train from the West, on the Central Road, due here 3:30 P.M., ran off the track four miles west of Little Falls, through the displacement of a switch, throwing the locomotive, baggage smoking and five passenger car off the track.

Whig of last Saturday discourses upon the chances of foreign recognition of the rebel Government. The prospects it concedes to be not very cheering, but it argues that the "imagined peril of the in institution of Slavery " has frightened the commercial classes of England, and that the favors the rebels receive from the English Press and Government must be owing to their desire to prop up that institution.

The next three months will test the firmness, the nerve, of the Administration, as it has never been tested before. A highly respectable and influential meeting of the citizens of the Fifteenth Ward was held last evening at the corner of Broadway and Eighth-street, for the purpose of ratifying the nominations made by the Union and Republican Syracuse Convention.

The Richmond papers of Saturday are received The Examiner says: "Congress again indicates an adjournment, coincident with a feeling of depression and apprehension in the public mind. The general acquiesence in the Executive management, right or wrong, has brought to us its bitter fruits. A close, vigilant, and firm performance of Congressional duties is as much demanded by the public exigencies, as a wild and bold control of the army."

MY DEAR GENERAL: I have just read the letter you wrote to the New-York Times, in answer to the misrepresentations circulated about our departure from America, and I hasten to thank you for having taken up the pen under these circumstances.

The Fifth Daily Session of the Episcopal Triennial Convention was held yesterday. The Special Committee of Nine on the Rebellion was announced. The Treasurer's and other reports were read and approved.

The People vs. Johnson. Judgment apppealed from reversed. Tiffany vs. Warrin et al. Judgment reversed, and new trial ordered; cots to abide the event. Opinion by LEONARD, INGRAHAM dissenting.
A large fire occurred in this City this morning entirely destroying the Bastable block, on the corner of Genessee and Warren streets, fronting Hanover square.

The number of our sick and wounded soldiers "paroled" by the enemy's cavalry at Warrenton, last week, is 811. The proceeding can scarcely be recognized as a parole, from the information which has reached us. The Yankees merely took the names of the patients, giving few paroles in writing. The large majority were not required to take any oath or sign any paper.

Thousands of Well-meaning persons have been alarmed at the prospective emancipation of the slaves, from a belief that they would flood the North and bring their labor into direct and disastrous competition with our own.
The Southern public are indebted to "Per- sonne," the army correspondent of the Charleston Courier, for the most graphic sketches of the operations of our armies which have appeared in print.

The two Committees, one from Mozart and the other from Tammany, met yesterday afternoon at the last-named Hall, and, with many sacrifices on each side, cemented the division which has so long estranged these factions.

Recruiting for the regular army in this vicinity is improving slowly. The officers at Chathain and Cedar streets get a few men each every week probably about a dozen between them, and as many or more music boys.

It has been decided by the authorities at Albany that the Draft cannot take place on the 10th inst., as the enrollment is not completed, and no Commissioners to hear claims of exemption, or to superintend the drawing, have yet been appointed.

The U.S. transport steamer Baltimore leaves Beaufort this morning via Fortress Monroe for Baltimore.

Faneuil Hall was crowded at noon to-day, to hear addresses from CHARLES SUMNER and others. WILLIAM CLAFLIN, Esq., of Newton, presided.

The United States iron-clad gunboat Naugatuck is now ready for active service again. She is at present at the wharf foot of Eleventh-street, East River, where she was removed from Hoboken some time since to undergo repairs, but will return to her old berth on to-morrow or Thursday to take in provisions and stores for her future cruise.

Dr. CHITTENDEN, Surgeon of the Sixteenth Regiment, returned from Kentucky yesterday, leaving Richmond on Monday and Lexington on Tuesday. He has been attending on our wounded, and in constant contact with the rebels, and is therefore able to speak intelligently of their strength, and the events of the past few weeks.

A trotting match for $2,500, which was made six months ago between the owners of the black stallion Henry Clay, 9 years, and the sorrel stallion Shepherd F. Knapp, 5 years, took place yesterday on the Fashion Pleasure Ground Association Course.

As yet we can only state the general results of the fighting at Corinth, Skirmishing commenced Tuesday last, and there has been more or less fighting every day since. The rebel loss is aoout 800 killed and from 1,500 to 1,800 wounded. We have 3,500 prisoners at Corinth and 300 on the Hatchie River and more constantly coming in.

Gen. GILBERT with his corps is at Lebanon. It is supposed here by military men that the whole rebel force is retreating to Hall's Gap, a few miles south of Crab Orchard, where they intend to make a stand.

To Major-General Halleck, General-in-Chief: Generals ORD and HURLBERT came upon the enemy yesterday, and General HURLBERT having driven in small bodies of the rebels the day before, after seven hours' hard fighting, drove the enemy five miles back across the Hatchie towards Corinth, capturing two batteries, about three hundred prisoners, and many small arms.

Lexington is mostly evacuated by the rebels, there being only 100 remaining. They took and sent to Camp Dick Robinson 7,000 barrels pork from CHEWAULT Co., packed on their own account and for other parties, mostly Secessionists.

It has been proposed to send an expedition to Texas sufficiently powerful to hold that State, and then to colonize it with free labor for the production of cotton. A similar project has been suggested for Florida. Both deserve the earnest, prompt and practical attention of the Government.

By a special dispatch from the TIMES' correspondent with Gen. SIGEL, dated this morning, we learn some interesting facts in regard to rebel operations in our front. His information is obtained from statements of rebel prisoners and deserters and from Government scouts.

The American has received the following spe- cial dispatch from Cumberland: IMBODEN'S entire wagon train, embracing supplies of all kinds, two pieces of artillery, 100 small arms, and 50 prisoners were captured, and Col. McREYNOLDS is in pursuit of him up the Great Cacapon River.

The steamer Star of the South arrived here yesterday with Port Royal dates of the 4th instant. Among her passengers are Maj.-Gen. HUNTER's Staff.

Capt. JOB RUARK, of the schooner Statesman, who arrived here to-day, reports that the rebels had succeeded in placing a battery at Cockpit Point on the Potomac River, and that just before sunset yesterday one of our gunboats ran into the Point and shelled the battery, entirely destroying it.

No more passes or permits will be issued to take supplies into the country, except a certificate from the Clerk of the Market, that the persons ap- plying for the permit actually brought supplies to town. Supplies will only be allowed for the family use of those who take them.

One of the largest and most interesting meetings in connection with the General Convention of the Episcopal Church, was that in behalf of the above above-named Society, held in the Church of the Holy Trinity, Brooklyn, on Sunday evening last.

The army now, as ever since the commencement of the war, is exceedingly anxious for active work against the rebels. There is nothing the soldiers dread so much as delay nothing they fear so much as inaction and Winter quarters. They leave worked hard during the hot months; they have fought splendidly, and achieved memorable victories.

To-day promises to to alike interesting and eventful in the history of the American Church, for to-day a Special Committee are to report upon the schism introduced into the Church by the Southern rebellion, and also upon the duty which that rebellion imposes upon the Church toward the National Government and the American people.
NO DANGER OF INTERVENTION. There is no foundation for the various sensation rumors in regard to foreign intervention in the affairs Of the United States.

The steamboat John A. Warner (flag of truce) returned from Alken's Landing to-day, arriving at Fortress Monroe at 1 o'clock.

In the war of 1813, as our readers know, the Louisiana negroes and mulattoes fought well, and were complimented by Gen. JACKSON, Fortified by this precedent, and justified by the position of the people concerned, Gen. BUTLER has invited into his force all the men of color, in the state militia or out of it, who are willing to serve under the title of Native Guards.

A meeting of the political Association which bears the above designation, was held last night at its headquarters, No. 932 Broadway, corner of Twenty-second-street. Its object appears mainly to have been the indorsement of the views inculcated in an address delivered by RICHORD O'GORMAN, Esq., in compliance with the Association's request. Hon. LUKE T. COZZENS presided, and amid much applause, introduced Mr. O'GORMAN, who in substance, said:

The Repub licans and Union men throughout this State are putting forward very strong and able men as their candidates for Congress. We have already mentioned the nomination of Hon. LEMUEL STETSON, in the Clinton County, and of Hon. C.T. HULBURD, in the St. Lawrence District. We see that in the Auburn District Hon. T.C. POMEROY, the present member, has been nominated for reelection.

ANTIETAM IRON WORKS, Md., Monday, Oct. 6, 1862. The rebels made their appearance yesterday, in small force opposite this place, for the evident purpose of showing themselves. They were mounted, and numbered two hundred or less. As they seemed anxious to attract attention, a sectien of a Parrot battery was brought up, and a few shells were sent after them across the river. Of course, they made tracks.

The trial of Mrs. Mary Real for the alleged murder of her husband, Peter C. Real, at No. 256 Broadway, on the afternoon of the 13th June last, commenced in the Oyer and Terminer, before Judge BARNARD, yesterday. The circumstances of this homicide are so fresh in the memory of most readers as to require no more detailed recapitulation than may be found in the opening remarks of the District-Attorney, and the testimony which follows.

Permeating the intricate ramifications of the Cooper institute filling the many nooks nd crevices of that architectural labyrinth, packed like sardines in a can or herrings in a box about three thousand of the loyal citizens of New-York really without distinction of party met for the purpose of indorsing the Union nominations for the gubernatorial State canvass, as set forth in the following call:

The Union Republican Ratification Meeting, last evening, at Cooper Institute, was most successful. The vast assemblage cordially indorsed the Syracuse nominations of the 24th inst. WM. CURTIS NOYES, Esq., presided, and stirring speeches were made by Hon. DANIEL S. DICKINSON and Hon. LYMAN TREMAIN, whose patriotic utterances were applauded to the echo.

The Batavia Spirit of the Times, which seems to be a specially virulent champion of the secession interest in this State, has dished up a variety of slanders upon Gen. We have a report by way of Richmond and Fortress Monroe, that a fight has taken place at St. John's River, Fla., but the result is not stated.

The Episcopal Convention met, as usual, at 9 A.M., in St. John's Chapel. It had been generally understood that there would be an animated debate on the position of the Church in the face of the rebellion, and that the Committee of Nine would report. The throng of visitors and members was, consequently, unusually great.

The fourth of the new Monitor fleet, the Montauk, the third iron-clad put afloat within six days, was successfully launched yesterday at Greenpoint, from the wharf at the foot of the Continental Iron Works. Extensive notification of the event having been given, a numerous assemblage was present.

So far as any Central American country is concerned, the negro colonization enterprize may be considered at an end for the present. Not only has the Costa Rican Minister protested against it for the several countries he represents here, but other Ministers of neighboring States have done the same thing.

The large Sabbath School Hall of Lee-avenue Church, Williamsburgh, was filled last evening by a highly respectable portion of the citizens of the Eastern District of Brooklyn, a large proportion of the audience being ladies, called together for the purpose of aiding in filling the ranks of the Ironsides Regiment. The meeting was presided over by JAS, D. SPARKMAN, Esq., assisted by a large number of Vice-Presidents.

It is very unlikely that the army of Gen. LEE will again attempt offensive operations, or the invasion of loyal territory, this Fall or Winter. The rebels threw their whole available strength into Maryland, and marched up to the very borders of Pennsylvania; but they were driven from Maryland soil and across the Potomac with great ignominy and loss, and without having achieved a single object of any importance.

The steamboat South America arrived from Aiken's Landing last evening, with about 300 prisoners, sick and wounded, which are to be transferred to the St. Marks, and sent to New-York.

The delegates to the Fifth Congres- sional District Republican Union Convention, comprising Hudson County and the City of Newark, met yesterday afternoon, at Commerical Hall, in Jersey City, for the purpose of nominating a canditate for Congress from that District.

The weather is beautiful and mild, and under the influence of our genial sun and breeze the streets and hotel-stoops are more productive, move blossom- ing, more riant with verdure, and polypetalous "Canards," (a flower indigenous to this climate,) than ever heretofore.

The expe- rience of VICTOR HUGO justifies a new beatitude: "Blessed are the miserable, for they shall bring a man to a banquet." The tendency of our modern civilization to "resume" all its triumphs, as the French have it, in a dinner-party, is very remarkable. It is a tradition of the old regime; perhaps, as well as a tendency of the new, but it exists, and has become a part of history.

McCLELLAN'S army, between the Chickahominy and the White House. He also made an incursion into Gen. POPE'S lines, and secured the portfolio and other appurtenances of the General's headquarters.

To Maj-Gen. Hallack, General-in-Chief: I have already advised you of the movements of the army under my command from Louisville. More or less skirmishing has occurred daily with the enemy's cavalry. Since then it was supposed the enemy would give battle at Bardstown.

Maj.-Gen. Pope: Yesterday I came to this point with my command, having been met by several half-breeds with a flag of truce. I encamped within five hundred yards of a large camp of about one hundred and fifty lodges of friendly Indians and half-breeds, who had separated themselves from Little Crow and the miserable crew with him, and had secured from them most of the white captives, awaiting my arrival.

A special dispatch to the Commercial from Corinth says that Gen. GRANT recalled ROSECRANS from the pursuit on the 9th. He returned on the 10th, and reports the enemy dispersed, demoralized, and incapable of further mischief.
Private dispatches from Lebanon say that a great battle was fought yesterday between Harrodsburgh and Danville heavier than Wednesday's battle.
