Mr. FORREST, on Friday, made his first appearance, during his present engagement at NIBLO'S, as Richard the Third. The character is one in which he has always been severely criticised; yet there is no character he plays that he has tried more conscientiously to elevate from melo-dramatic energy to something like intellectual refinement.

MASSACRES. The recent massacres of white settlers in Southern Minnesota by the Sioux savages, have resulted in great distress and want among the survivors in that region. Many of those who escaped the tomahawk of the red men had their houses burnt down, their crops destroyed, and lost everything they had.

We give elsewhere today such facts relating to the movements of STUART'S cavalry as have reached us by telegraph. On Saturday morning they destroyed a large amount of property at Chambersburgh, including the machine shops, railway and rolling stock of the Cumberland Valley Railroad Company at that place, and burned the railroad bridge at Scotland, five miles to the eastward.

The Canadian Screw-Steamship Company's steamer Hibernian, which left Liverpool on Thursday, the 2d instant, and Londonderry the afternoon of Friday, the 3d, passed the Point at 9 o'clock this evening. She was boarded by the news-yacht of the Associated Press.

The operations of guerrillas still continue to occupy a considerable portion of public attention. I sent you a few days ago a full and circumstantial account of the attack of FAULKNER'S gang on the steamer Eugene, and the subsequent destruction of the village of Randolph in consequence of it.

A long day's ride over the vast space of hill and valley covered by the Army of the Potomac closes to-night, gratefully for both man and beast, on the Pisgah-tops of Maryland Heights. I am enabled to furnish you some accurate intelligence concerning the rebel army of the Potomac. A week ago Saturday, Gen. LONGSTREET commenced moving southward from the neighborhood of Martinsburgh with a large force. He moves to the defence of Richmond.

In compliance with orders from Col. MUNDAY, Chief of Military Police, Maj. SPENCER, commanding Louisville Barracks, notifies all liquor dealers, where they are found selling liquor to soldiers, that their houses will be closed, their stock confiscated and poured into the street, and the proprietors arrested and confined.

It was announced from Cape Race, last evening, that the steamship Asia passed that point at 2 o'clock, with two day's later news from Europe. Our dispatches had not reached us at 1 o'clock this morning.

The Granada Appeal of the 13th inst. makes the result of the Corinth battle even more disastrous to the rebels than our own reports. It is stated that the attack was opposed by all but one of the rebel Generals, meaning, probably, VAN DORN, against whom there is great indignation manifested.

The last advices received by the Government from Europe, in regard to American affairs, confirm the belief that no purpose of present interference is entertained by any of the Great Powers. The result of the battle of Antietam and the retreat of the rebel army into Virginia were well known, and regarded as important results in favor of the Union cause, giving increased stability to the non-intervention policy of England and France.

Our regular mails from south and Central America, and from Bogota, are all due to-day or to- morrow, but the prospect now is, that none of them will arrive in time for the steamer. If they do, the telegraph from Panama will give me such items of importance as may reach there from the former States.

A WELCOME EXAMPLE. We are glad that Mayor OPDYKE has at last effected what he and his predecessors so often threatened, viz: the arrest of a mockauctioneer under the mock-auction law of 1853. The case in point is the arrest of MOSES B. CHAPMAN, mock-auctioneer, and ZENO BURHAM, his agent.
Ex-Gov. SEYMOUR made a speech last even- ing designed to aid his election. It was very long and very elaborate. We publish the essential part of it in another part of this morning's TIMES.

Our special correspondent at Harper's Ferry sends us the gratifying assurance that a forward movement of the Army of the Potomac has been determined upon, and that in a few days, at furthest, it will be on the Virginia side of the Potomac, engaged in offensive operations against the rebels. Our correspondent traces this promise of action directly to the late visit of the President.
REPUBLICAN CITY CONVENTION. But little was done at the Convention last night, as will be seen by reference to the following report of the proceedings.

The trial of this case was resumed yesterday morning at 11 o'clock. The public interest in the trial appears to be unabated, and, as on the previous days, the Court-room was thronged with people. The examinations of witness for the defence was resumed by calling to the stand.
At the opening of the Court yesterday morn ing, the District-Attorney resumed the examination of witnesses, in rebuttal of the evidence for the de- fence, by calling to the stand.
The Second District Republican Congressional Convention met at No. 9 Court-street, Brooklyn, yes- terday afternoon, at 3 o'clock, for the purpose of nom- inating a candidate for Congress.

A special reconnoissance made by the regular cavalry last evening, demonstrated the fact that the party of rebel cavalry marauding near Cashtown, have disappeared and gone in the direction of Mercersburgh. By this time they are probably out of the State.
The Episcopal General Convention met again at 9 A.M. yesterday, Rev. Dr. HOWE in the Chair, in the absence of the regular President, who is quite ill.
The election passed off very quietly. The Democrats have elected the entire county ticket. PENDLETON, Dem., in the First District, and the pres- ent member, is reelected.
The following letters were captured some time ago by Gen. BUELL, while in process of transmission for file to Brig.-Gen. THOMAS JORDAN, Assistant-Adjutant-General of the rebel army:

This place is rapidly becoming civilized--if rumors are any indication of civilization. During the last forty-eight hours we have had all sorts of rumors, most of them to the effect that this command was in great danger of being annihilated.
The Court has been occupied all day with the second trial of SAMUEL B. HAYNES, the first mate of the slaver Nightingale.

Herman Frost et al. vs. John Kelly, Sheriff, --This was an action of replevin for six packages containing crockery and glassware, shipped by the plaintiffs on board the ship Robert Center, in the Fall of 1860, marked "Philipp Runkel, New-Orleans, La." The Sheriff seized the property under an at tachment against Philipp Runkel.

I have already sent you by telegraph a brief statement of the successful retreat of STUART'S Cavalry over the Potomac at this point, after their daring and brilliant raid into Pensylvania. I now transmit you such details as I have been able to learn by personal presence and inquiry on the spot.

Last night the Nominating Conventions of the Republican, Democratic and People's Union parties met for the purpose of placing before the voters of the Fourth, Fifth, Sixth, Seventh, Eighth and Ninth Congressional Districts, candidates to be voted upon at the coming election. The districts comprise the following localities:

Seven hundred and fifty wounded soldiers from Perryville, mostly slightly wounded, and gen erally belonging to Ohio and the Northwestern States, have arrived. Nearly all of them were accommodated at our hospitals, and the remainder taken to New-Albany.

Your reporters give you a great many de tails of the war, with a good many speculations of what never happens. It would be good thing to have these connected together in a general view of the passing drama. I will aid you with a glance at some general facts occurring in the Central West.
The flag of truce boat Metamora arrived from Aiken's Landing this morning, bringing down about sixty civilians, sixteen of them ladies, among whom is Gov. BRADFORD'S wife

Very few returns of the elections held yester day had reached us up to the time of going to press this worning. In Pennsylvania, so far as received, they indicate a Union triumph. THAD- DEUS STEVENS is reelected to Congress from the Lancaster District, by about three thousand ma- jority. In the Fifth District, BAILY (Union) is probably elected.

GENERAL ORDERS, NO. 79.--I. The enrollment of the Militia of this State being now nearly com- pleted, a draft from the population liable to bear arms will be made on the tenth day of November next, equal in the aggregate to the number of men required on that day, to complete the quota of one hundred and twenty thousand apportioned to this State.

An enthusiastic meeting of the citizens of the Eastern District of Brooklyn was held at Washington Hall last evening. The room was tastefully deco rated with the national colors, and enlivened with music from a fine band. The crowd outside was re- galed with an artillery salute, which broke a few panes of glass in the vicinity, and was therefore somes what circumscribed.

The steamship Asia, from Liverpool on Saturday the 4th, via Queenstown on Sunday the 5th inst. passed Cape Race at 2 o'clock this afternoon (Monday,) en route to Halifax and Boston. She was boarded by the news-yacht of the Associated Press and a summary of her news obtained.

Recently the Board of Councilmen adopted a resolution presented by Mr. JONES, inquiring of the Corporation Counsel what authority the city have for taking the business of the New-York. Manhattan and Harlem Gas Companies into municipal charge and control. In the Board of Aldermen the resolution ...

Washington was considerably excited, yester day, by rumors following and growing out of the raid of STUART'S cavalry into Pennsylvania. We receive assurances that the excitement was with out adequate cause. Frederick, Md., was also suffering much excitement last night, under ap- prehension of an attack by the rebels.

The October elections in the great States of Pennsylvania, Ohio, Indiana and Iowa, on Tuesday last, though the results are as yet but meagerly reported from some of the Northwestern States, are full of cheer for the supporters of the Government, and the advocates...

There was skirmisking yesterday all along the line from Harrodsburgh to Stanford. The rebels are trying to get out of the State. It is thought that Gen. BRAGG is hurrying outward because on the day of the Perryville battle he heard that Gens. PRIOE and VAN DORN had been beaten at Corinth, and could not get any reinforcements from that quarter.

Somebody in authority told us at the commencement of this war, that cavalry was of no use to us. Whatever advantage it may or may not be to us, it is very certain that the rebels have hitherto proved its value to them. The aerobatic performances of STUART and his men, are really of a nature--if we could forget the seriousness of the subject and the insult conveyed--to excite a feeling akin to the ludicrous.

The English frigate Racer came up the roads last evening, and cast anchor above the fortress, and left, passing down the roads at 7 o'clock this morning. About the same time another English man-of-war, the Petrel, came up and anchored abreast the Fortress.

Reports reach here this morning that a consid- erable force of the enemy's cavalry crossed the Potomac into Maryland, yesterday, at a point near Han- cock. A movement of cavalry and artillery, up the river, seems to warrant the belief that the enemy has either crossed, or is making some active demonstrations.
In the Matter of the Petition of Jno. M. Minne, , for Sale Real Estate. Reference ordered to report on matters stated in the petition.

On Friday afternoon last, a dispatch was received by the telegraph operator here, from Greencastle, stating that information reached there that about 3,000 rebel cavalry had passed through Mercersburgh, and were going in the direction of Chambersburgh. This information was not made public, or the reason that it was not credited.

The result of the election in Pennsylvania is still in doubt as we go to press this morning. So far as known, ten Union men, one straight Republican, and eight Democrats are elected to Congress. Several districts are yet to hear from.

There was considerable excitement yesterday over an announcement that the rebels were crossing the Potomac River again in large force at Hancock, but it is believed that there was no good foundation for the report.
[The following letter was written by an officer of the Ninth Kansas Cavalry to his parents, who reside in Williamsburgh;]

The Bulletin says that it has received a private letter, dated Shippensburgh, Cumberland County, which states "that the rebels are crossing the Potomac River again, at Hancock, in large force."

The Triennial Episcopal Convention reassembled at the usual place of meeting, at 9 A.M. yesterday, Rev. Dr. HOWE presiding. The morning religious services were performed by Rev, Mr. GARDINER, of Maine, Rev, Mr. McALLISTER, of California, and Rt. Rev. Bishop STEVENS.

-By the steamer from Europe, whose news was published yesterday, we have an enlarged list of American ships destroyed by the rebel pirate Alabama, or "290," near the Island of Flores, one of the Azores. It comprises no less than ten vessels nine ships and a schooner some of which were large first-class vessels, and others smaller and less valuable.

A dispatch from Washington to the Philadelphia North American yesterday pronounces all the statements erroneous that indicate an early forward movement Of McCLELLAN'S army. The reason assigned is, that the con-...

One of the ablest of the Border State organs, the Baltimore American, in a recent moderate and thoughtful article on the President's Proclamation, predicted one result which deserves serious consideration...

For the first time we are made to realize that it is the season of Autumn. So Summer-like the atmosphere, the forest foliage and the fields, surely the sun must still be journeying north of the Equator.

The indignation aroused by the recent order of the Post-office Department has called forth an explanatory letter from the Postmaster in NewYork, published by us on Saturday, which practically nullifies the most objectionable feature of the order instructing Postmasters "to treat as...
It having been announced that Mr. James would commence the summing up for the defence in this case yesterday morning, the opening of the Court found an immense throng of people eager for admit...
There is no truth in the statement, recently published, that the Secretary of the Treasury has decided to ask a new loan for the Government.

The regular Democratic County Convention, to which was assigned the nominations for Surrogate, County Treasurer, one Superintendent of the Poor, and Coroner for the Eastern District, met at Uris Fall, Fulton-street, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, and selected the following ticket:
Capt. CONGER, of the Third Virginia Cavalry who, while out with fifty men, was attacked at Aldie on Wednesday last, has just returned from another reconnoissance in that vicinity.
First District--The Convention met at Central Hotel, in Chambers-street, but adjourned without making any nomination.

THE MURDER OF THE POLICEMAN IN THE NINTH WARD. Capt. SERRING, in announcing the death of patrolman HENRY L. WILLIAMS, of that President, who died on Tuesday from the effects of a pistol shot wound, as reported in the TIMES of yesterday, pays the following just tribute to that deceased officer:
Take Richmond, and then, if they insist, let them go, argues Prince JOHN, next to Mr. SEYMOUR, the principal speaker at the Ratification Meeting.

At KNOEDLEE'S (late GOUPIL'S) on Broadway and Ninth-street, can be seen the new picture by LANG, to which, during its preparatory state, we have so often alluded. The subject is the Return from the War of the Sixty-ninth Regiment.

The Surgeons appointed to act under the Commissioners of the Draft in this City, assembled last evening at the Central Office, No. 82 Broadway, to receive from Gen. ANTHON instructions relative to the course to be pursued by them in reference to exemptions.
The following special dispatch for the TIMES is just received, dated.

The Boston Courier of Tuesday invents or reports a conversation supposed to have been held on board of a Sound steamer, between some Down-Easter of an "inquiring mind" and a paroled Louisiana prisoner from Antietam, in which conversation the captive rebel is described as declaring that the election of SEYMOUR in New-York and of other Democrats throughout the North would bring the rebel cause to immediate ruin.

The popular interest in the protracted, but highly interesting trial, has continued unabated from the day of its commencement, and the last day witnessed no diminution in the throng of cigar specta- tors who sought admission to the court-room. As on previous days, the ladies had first to be accommodat-...

Before describing the Battle of the Hatchie, let me give your readers a statement of the rebel forces which first attacked Corinth, and then were attacked on the Hatchie. It is a statement which comes through...

A NUMBER OF CHILDREN INJURED. Yesterday afternoon, as the children in Public School No. 20, in South Fourth-street, E.D., were engaged in their studies, smoke was discovered issuing from the flues of the heating apparatus.
Innumerable authenticated rumors are afloat this evening. Among them, that HUMPHREY MARSHALL, with his whole force, is retreating toward Irvin, Estell County, with Brig. Gen. A. J. SMITH after him.
Capt. HAGAR, of the ship Brilliant, Capt. TILRON, of the bark Virginia, and Capt. GIFFORD, of the bark E. Dunbar, vessels destroyed by the pirate steamer Alabama, or "290," have arrived at this port.
The steamship Potomac, from New-Orleans on the 7th inst., with mails, merchandise and passengers, arrived at this port last evening. She has experienced strong northerly winds since leaving Hatteras.

The forward movement of the Army of the Potomac, promised a few days ago in our special correspondence, has commenced. A portion of the army advanced early yesterday morning and occupied Charlestown, after an artillery fight of about two hours duration with the outer force of the rebels. Gen. McCLELLAN was at Charlestown last night, and the indications were that the place would be held, even at the risk of a general engagement.
By the steam frigate Massena, which arrived at quarantine Wednesday, we have news from Vera Cruz up to the 26th of September, a week later.

Some gentlemen reached here from Nashville yesterday. To one of them I am indebted for copies of the Nashville Union, which contain full accounts of the breaking up of the rebel camp of Gen. ANDERSON, at Lavergne.

The Draft, so great a bugaboo to our easily-annoyed citizens, will certainly take place on the 10th of November. To-day, at No. 82 Broadway, the NewYork Commissioners are notified to meet Gen. ANTHON in relation to the matter, and on Friday the Kings County Commissioners will meet him at the City Hall.

PUBLIC WORK. The bids awaiting opening at the Street Department, were deferred, for the fourth time, for five days, yesterday, till the 21st inst., the Comptroller declining to attend. The term of post- ponement is the least length of time specified by ordinance, and it is likely that the opening will continue to be deferred every five days till a Streat Commissioner is appointed.
We have dispatches from the TIMES special correspondents in front of Washington, dated at Centreville and Green Springs, to the following effect:

Brookfield, Assignee of James D. Sherman, vs. Home Insurance Company and John Kelly, Sheriff. The plaintiff sued to recover about $5,000 cash held by the Home Insurance Company, and which had been attached by the Sheriff at the suit of the creditors of James D. Sherman, a citizen of Illinois.
The annual New-York Trade Sale of Books opened yesterday at the spacious and elegant ware rooms of Messrs. GEO. A. LEAVITT Co., Nos. 21 and 23 Mercer-street.

Among the bloodiest of all the bloody dramas of this war has just been enacted. We left our camp on the morning of the 8th, at 7 o'clock, taking a hilly, dusty road across the country, which, leading in a northwesterly direction, entered the Harrodsburgh turnpike, about two miles from the village of Perryville, which we approached from the southeast, or perhaps a little east of southeast.

The rebel force which robbed the steamer Hazel Dell yesterday, at Caseyville, Ky., commanded by Cols. ANDERSON, JOHNSON and MARTIN, is supposed to have numbered 2,000. They took about $3,000 worth of clothing, groceries and powder, and threatened to burn all the boats falling into their hands after the first of the month.
I wrote from Harrisburgh and telegraphed from Carlisle yesterday whatever I could learn, reliably, of the movements and doings of the rebels in and about Chambersburgh.

The French steam frigate Massena, now at this port, brings advices from Mexico to the 26th ult. Gen. FOREY arrived at Vera Cruz on the 22d. It is understood that, in addition to his military command, the General is intrusted with diplomatic powers superior to those of SALIGNY, who is suspected of being too much mixed in Mexican politics. No fighting had taken place, with the exception of a few guerrilla skirmishes.
The authorities of Demerara, it seems, are moving to secure the colonization there of negroes who may be captured by our vessels of war on board slavers. The Demerara Gazette of a late date says:

The United States steam frigate Ticonderoga, was successfully launched at the Brooklyn Navyyard yesterday afternoon. She is a wooden vessel, and rates with the Sacramento, Lackawanna, and others of that class. Capt. BOGGS, of the Varuna, Admiral PAULDING, Capt. THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing.

An important reconnoissance was made, to-day, by a portion of the Army of the Potomac, in the direction of Winchester. The Division of Gen. HANCOCK, late Gen. RICHARDSON'S, left Harper's Ferry as an early hour this morning, on the road to Charlestown.

We are all prepared to be pleased with our new Mayor, Col. H.C. DEMING. I tell you candidly, that after Gens. SHEPLEY and WEITZEL, I had serious misgivings as to whether their places could be filled, for they were both satisfactory to all, and were universally esteemed.

The depreciation of paper money is inconveniently felt by the Government in its transactions, including the difference in exchange to pay the Navy and civil expenses distant from points where the United States notes can be made available.
The inquest in the case of HENRY L. WILLIAMS, Policeman of the Ninth Ward, who was murdered on Monday evening last, was held yesterday, by Coroner WILDEY, at the Station-house, in Charles-street.

The gunboat Wyandotte arrived here yesterday, and was placed as the blockading boat, her duties being to board all vessels coming in or going out of the Roads, and to see that their passes are correct.

The following items are from the Newbern Progress of the 6th inst.: A party under command of Lieut. NUTTING, recently left Washington, N.C., on the steamer Eagle, for Pungo River. On arriving in the vicinity of the late fire,...

A recent Richmond paper, in speaking of the devastation caused to the State of Virginia by the invasion of the National armies, declares that 30,000 slaves have been lost to their owners. In the States of Tennessee, Kentucky, Arkansas and Missouri, so many have not been...

At 9 A.M., yesterday, the members of the Episcopal Convention came together briefly at St. John's Chapel, and thence adjourned to Bellevue Hospital, at the foot of Twenty-sixth-street, on the East River. By 10 A.M., a goodly number of distinguished churchmen, both clerical and lay, had asembled at the hospital.

Yesterday morning, when HANCOCK advanced his division to Charlestown, Gen. WOODBURY'S Division crossed the Potomac at the Shepardstown Ford, taking the road leading to Smithfield, a small village half-way between Charlestown and Bunker Hill.

Since my last communication, the all-engrossing topic in this island has been, as it still is, the advantages which are held out for repeopling the island and giving it an effective laboring population, by obtaining a portion of the contraband slaves for whose location in foreign countries the Govornment of the United States has manifested some solicitude.
The following is the conclusion of Mr. SPENCE'S letter to the London Times, already alluded to in our dispatch from Cape Race:

The diplomatic intellect of Europe is very much disturbed concerning our domestic troubles, and, thanks to the persistent reiteration of the statement, has finally persuaded its of that the delay which has occurred in the adjustment of our difficulties is altogether unparalleled in the history of civilization, and highly discreditable to us.

Reliable information was received at this place yesterday, that Gen. STUART, with cavalry and artillery, was advancing and threatening this position. Thwarled in his attempt to cut off Gen. STAHL'S Command when a reconnoissance was made to Middleburgh, Snickersville and vicinity, last Monday, Gen STUART no doubt hopes to make amends for the lack of energy then displayed, by foreing this command to fall back from its present position.
Fashion Pleasure Ground Association, Friday, Oct, 17, March, $1,000. Mile heats; best 3 in 5, to wagons.

The Detroit Free Press, of Oct. 11, has the following in its editorial columns: "We are requested by Gen. CASS to say that the letter which has just been published in the Chicago Tribune, from Mr. EASTMAN, of that place, requires correction. That gentleman called upon Gen. CASS, and a conversation took place upon various topics, in which opinions were freely expressed.

Our advices from the Army of the Potomac, this morning, indicate unmistakably that Gen. McCLELLAN is again about to measure strength with the rebel hosts under LEE. There appears to be no doubt that the latter intends to give battle at or near their present location, which is now well known to our Generals, through the thorough reconnoissances recently made.
The big trot for the big purse, in which Lanceb Prince, Dirigo, Belle of Portland and Lady Sherman are entered, will come off to-morrow (Saturday) at 2 o'clock P.M.
The Santa Fe Mail, with dates to the 10th, has arrived.

A writer in Richmond Enquirer assigns as a reason for expecting an early peace, that "the bitterness and animosity existing between the Northern political parties is daily increasing in intensity." He declares that "this state of things alone, without a conflict, must obstruct seriously, if not absolutely defeat, any efficient prosecution of the war."

GARIBALDI has ad dressed "To the English Nation" an impassioned and somewhat grandiloquent address, in which, after expressing his intense gratitude for benefits bestowed on him by the people of England, he advocates the calling of an International Congress to settle the disputes between peoples. He urges the English nation to call the French nation to cooperate in this work, to call the "bold sons of Helvetia" to aid in it, and, says he:

Once more is the reality of war brought home to us. This morning while breakfasting, we were startled by the booming of cannon, not far away, but seemingly very near. Hastening to an adjoining hill, I could see wreathes of blue smoke slowly rising heavenward, from near Charleston, and distinctly hear the roar of our artillery. There have been several reconnoissances in that direction, but no such heavy firing as this.

Advices received at headquarters state that Gen. SCHOFIELD, with the advance guard of his army, has left Cassville, moving southward towards the Arkansas line. Scouts sent forward had penetrated as far as Cross Hollows, but had been driven back by the enemy.

Though Fortress Monroe and this Peninsula may not for the present perhaps not at any timeresume its importance as the centre of war operations to the extent of several months prior to the withdrawal of the Army of the Potomac, yet it is manifest that it is not intended that this point, as the base of important movements, shall long remain in the quiet state into which it has relapsed.

There are rumors of an engagement at Blackwater River, beyond Suffolk, on Tuesday last, between out troops and the rebels. A Lieutenant and three men belonging to the Eleventh Pennsylvania Cavalry were killed. We have no further particulars.

We have startling intelligence, this morning, announcing the approach of a rebel column of several thousand, under RAINS, COCKERELL, JACKMAN, and others, upon Fort Scott. The capture of this post would indeed be of immense service to the rebels, as it contains a large amount of supplies, ordnance stores,

The General Hospital here has been swept and garnished preparatory to being occupied as a headquarters by the General commanding, whoever that may be. This large and roomy mansion, occupied before the war by Dr. MURPHY, (rebel,) Paymaster of the Armory, is located on a beautiful knoll commanding a full view of the picturesque and romantic scenery which meets the eye in every direction.
The Convention reassembled at 9 A.M. the usual hour. Religious services were conducted by Rev. Drs. HUTTON and DOANE.

The St. Louis papers publish a long address of Hon. F.P. BLAIR to his constituents. He refers in the first place to his appointment as Brigadier-General which he says was entirely unsolicited and given that he might more easily raise a brigade of loyal troops. He then discusses at length the relations between himself and the Press of St. Louis as regards Gen. FREMONT, and says:

The steamship Saxon, Capt. GEO. W. CLAPP, arrived at this port late last night, bringing advices from New-Orleans to Oct. 4th at 7 P.M., and Havana 10th, at 1 P.M. She took pilot off Barnegat on the 17th, at 2 P.M.

Gen. McCLELLAN has broken the spell that has rested upon the two armies of the Upper Potomac since the battle of Antietam. On Thursday he threw forward division, well supported, to Charlestown, driving the rebel pickets before him; and rested at night on the hills two miles beyond the town, spending the night himself in the place.
Reports from Mexico, brought by the British steamer Trent, are to the 1st from Vera Cruz.

The chief product of South America is animal. The chief export is in bales of wool or cargoes of hides. In killing animals the operators manage to save every hoof, hair, bone, muscle and tendon, besides the hide and flesh. Nothing is lost but the blood. A patent has just been issued for a method of making the blood into guano.

At a meeting of prominent citizens of Brooklyn, held at the Mansion House, and after its organization' by the appointment of SAMUEL SLOAN, Esq., as Chairman, and PETER G. CORNELL, Esq., as Secretary, the following resolutions, reported by Mr. VAN COTT, Mr. CRITTENDEN and Mr. HOWE, were adopted:
The Journal discredits all the reports of a recent fight at Big Hill.

The steamer Pembina, which left the Navy-yard on Tuesday last, remains at anchor in the harbor, near the powder magazine on Ellis' Island. She has all her powder, ammunition and stores aboard, and will proceed to sea as soon as the crew become familiar with their stations.
The following translation of an address in Italian to the English nation appears in the London Morning Post:

Gen. ANTHON has issued the following important notice: Persons who claim that they are, for any reason, exempt from military duty, and therefore not liable to draft, are hereby notified to attend before the Com- missioners appointed to hear and determine such claims at the Police Station-houses of the Wards in which they reside.
CENTRAL PARK MUSIC. There will be music, as usual, in the Central Park to-day, if the weather be fine. The band, under the direction of HARVEY DODWORTH, will play the following programme:

FLOUR advancing and active; sales 5,000 bbls. WHEAT dull. RYE Sales, 8,000 bushels Wastern NewYork, 77c. OATS in demand and firm, at 55c.@56c. The following are the main features of the report of Gen. PLEASANTON relative to the late rebel raid into Pennsylvania:
A SCENE IN THE HARBOR. Yesterday afternoon at three o'clock, a very interesting and animating scene came off in the North River, opposite the Cunard Dock, on the Jersey side.

The advance of Gen. BUELL'S army occupied Danville on Sunday night, Of course Gen. B. had occupied Harrodsburgh. We are informed that some fighting occurred, but we have no particulars. We only know that the result must have been favorable.

The heavy reconnoitering parties under Gens. HANCOCK and HUMPHREYS, which proceeded from the Army of the Potomac in the direction of Winchester on Thursday, returned to their positions again on Friday, as stated in our special dispatches.

The troops under Gens. HANCOCK and HUMPHREYS, who left Thursday morning to make the re- connoissance in the direction of Winchester, returned after arriving at Smithfield, five miles from Bunker Hill.

As the smoke clears away from the battlefield of Antietam, we have startling revelations of the conduct of men who appeared in response to the call of Surgeon-General HAMMOND for aid in the treatment of the wounded.

The sudden disappearance of the pursuing columns of the Army of the Mississippi must have taken the fleeing rebels greatly by surprise, as soon as they found that the advance was merely shell, out of which the bird of prey had flown backwards.
In a speech delivered at Jackson, Mich., on Oct. 9, Senator Trumbull said:

The remains of Commodore WM. L. HUDSON were yesterday afternoon, interred at Greenwood Cemetery, after solemn funeral ceremonies performed at St. Anne's Church, Brooklyn, by the Right Rev. Bishop McILVAINE and the Rev. Drs. JOHNSON, VINTON and CUTLER, the latter preaching the discourse. A battalion of United States Marines escorted the remains to their final resting place.

The return of Brig.-Gen. BRANNAN and his command from Jacksonville yesterday puts me in full possession of the particulars concerning the successful expedition against that place, and as only an in- complete account has gone North, I shall send a brief and connected narrative of the circumstances.

Among the BEEF FOR THE REBEL ARMY. Among the advantages which the rebels have gained by Gen. BUELL's permitting them so long to occupy Eastern Kentucky, is the large supplies of beef cattle they have obtained from that region.
Contrary to our just expectations, the weather at this time is unnaturally hot, and the four days of the second month of Fall have been more disagreeably warm than midsummer.
We have spoken recently with some earnestness of the importance of an organized "Ambulance Corps" in the national armies.

In the case of Demarchi, convicted of murder on the high seas, Judge SHIPMAN then gave his decision on the motion in arrest of judgment, which was argued some time since by Mr. James for the prisoner and District Attorney Smith for the Government. The opinion is as follows:

Indian tragedies continue on the Northern Emi- grant route, as well as in Minnesota. Mr. W.H. GROVES and a party of seven dropped into this city on Saturday. Traveling by starlight and in by-paths or no paths, they managed to miss their Indian friends, and avoided delay and loss on that account. The party sighted about seven hundred emigrant wagons, whose destination was for the most part the gold-fields north.

The people of the North western States are loudly demanding that the Government open up to commerce the Mississippi River. They have been deeply disappointed, as indeed the whole country has been, in this matter.

After capturing our pickets, the guerrilla MORGAN dashed into Lexington yesterday morning at the head of 1,500 men. Before surrendering, our troops fought him gallantly, killing and wounding several. PERSONAL--Lord ERNEST VANE TEMPEST, bet ter known as Capt. CHARLES STEWART, will leave today en route for home. Capt. STEWART has been in the United States service since the opening of the war. When Gen. STONE was appointed to his command Capt. STEWART was made his Adjutant-General, in which capacity he discharged with credit the onerous duties assigned him.

--The large number of officers and soldiers who are now in and around this city are not wanted, we suppose, in the army of Gen. McCLELLAN. If they were, so many of them would not be here on leaves of absence from that army. Let them, then, be all massed together and sent on other work.

The Washington Star publishes a plea for the quietude in the Army of the Potomac. which we transter to our columns. It opposes the policy of attacking the rebels at present, or for some time to come; and instead of seeing disasters, perceives naught but advantages in delay. The argument is old enough, and pretty well worn, but is restated as if it were quite a refreshing novelty.

GEN. PLEASONTON came up with the enemy's cavalry and artillery at Phillimont about 11 o'clock yesterday. The fight, which was conducted wholly by artillery, lasted about five hours, when the enemy retreated to Union--a small town three miles beyond. Our lose was one killed and fourteen wounded. The enemy's force consisted of a portion of STUART'S cavalry and one battery, Five of them are known to have been killed.

To-DAY decides whether New-York stands by the Government, or takes ground against it, and throws her weight into the scale of the rebellion. This is the simple issue. No sophistry can disguise it, nor can any ingenuity divert attention from it. It is not a matter of nice points to be argued:--it is simply a question of taking sides.

It will be a terrible crime if the loyal voters of New-York throw away their victory and their power to-day, by failing to put in their ballots. The Delaware Bank at Delhi, Delaware Co., N.Y., was entered and robbed in a similar manner a year or two ago. The burglars effected their object by tunneling under the building and attacking the bottom of the vault; this, although covered by heavy flag-stone, was broken and forced upward by two powerful jack-screws, and thus the bank vault was relieved of its valuable contents.

The Buffa to Commercial Advertiser reads the political public a timely and just admonition on the prevalent vice of President-making. The whole country swarms with would-be Warwicks, eager to nominate the next President. "There seems," says the Advertiser, "to be a strife on the part of these seekers after cheap notoriety for precedence; they each shoulder a candidate and rush into the political ring, challenging popular approbation."

Now that the circulation of the new currency is becoming quite general in this City, many stores, saloons, stage routes, and car lines have concluded, on and after the 15th instant, (Saturday next,) to accept no more postage stamps as a circulating medium. Probably before the lapse of many weeks the use of postage stamps as a substitute for small change will have become a thing of the past.

The Petersburgh Express Nov., 10th has the following: The Ghost of Recognition of the Southern Confederacy by France and England after having been solemnly revoked for the tenth time, has again been dismissed to the shades below, where we hope it will remain for the balance of the war. We are tired of the freakish reappearance of this phantom, and wish never to see it again paraded before the public eye.

Cheers for the out-going, cheers for the in-coming all blending in one undistinguishable swell of admiration for the men, and devotion to the cause.

CORONER'S INQUESTS. Coroner MORRIS held an inquest yesterday upon the body of PETER FITZGIBBONS, who died suddenly, York-street, on Thursday night, from disease at the heart. The deceased was employed in the Navy-yard. He leaves a wife and several children. An inquest was also held upon the body of DENNIS SHEHAN, residing at No. 29 Statestreet, who fell down stairs on Thursday night and sustained injuries which caused his death.

To all appearances, the backbone of the rebellion, in the West, is thoroughly broken. In no quarter, from the Ohio River to the Gulf, are the rebels found to exist in formidable force. Their late chief columns, that threatened to advance, and actually did advance, with proud menace, are falling back everywhere, beaten and demoralized, before our victorious armies. And no point appears on which they can rally.

On the 29th, Mr. CORDEN addressed a large meeting of his constituents at Mr. TATHEM'S machine shop, Rochdale. The room, which will hold about three thousand persons, was densely crowded. The Mayor of Rochdale presided, and there were present the Mayors from several of the neighboring towns, a large proportion of the principal manufacturers, and a mass of operatives.

At the regular meeting of the City Council, held on Tuesday last, the Mayor stated that, in accordance with the resolution passed at the last meeting, he had conferred with Mr. FORMAN, Chairman of the Commission appointed by the Governor and Council for providing for the removal of the women and children from the city in the event of an attack, and found that the Commissioners were progressing in the work assigned them.

At 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon the Tammany Committee of twenty, appointed to nominate a candidate for the Comptrollership, met in Room 33, Tammany Hall. During the discussion, which was extremely animated, the sidewalk in front of Tammany, the halls and lobbies, were crowded with Democrats, anxious to hear the result.

Henry Dieffenback el al. vs. A. Wallach et al.-- The plaintiffs sought to recover of defendants some $1,400, principal and interest, alleged to be due for 1,082 pennyweights of gold sold defendants in February, 1859. The defence set up was, that the plaintiffs took in payment, at their own risk, a note made by H. Solomons Co., upon which they had sued and obtained judgment.

The Atlanta Confederacy has been informed that the citizens of Huntsville, Alabama, lately hung in effigy, NICH, DAVIS, JERRY CLEMENS and GEORGE LANE, of that place, on account of their Unionism. LANE is openly for LINCOLN, and went off with the retiring Yankees. CLEMENS and DAVIS remain at home, but it seems that the people have no confidence in their fidelity to the South.

Gen. ROSECRANS and Staff arrived at dusk night before last. Yesterday he was driving matters ahead. He had a conference with his Generals all night and yesterday morning, and in the afternoon of yesterday there was a review had of the brigades of Gens. NEGLEY and PALMER. It was a grand sight--those men, in full health and equipment, and all in fine spirits, ready and eager for the march.

The English steamer arrived from Vera Cruz on the 5th inst., bringing dates from that port up to the 1st inst. We have advices from the City of Mexico up to the 28th ult.

To-day we publish the text of the remonstrance of the New York Chamber of Commerce. They have issued a "report" upon this subject, in which not one word occurs as to the negligence or inefficiency of their own navy; but they declare that "the most wide-spread exasperation" is rising...

A Madrid telegram of the 6th inst. says: "The Queen will open the Cortez in person, and deliver a speech upon the occasion. At an early period of the session the Ministry will submit documents referring to the action of Spain in Mexico, and will invite discussion on the course they have pursued."

The steamer America, of the Nicaragua line, entered this port yesterday morning, on her way to NewYork, for the purpose of taking in coal, etc with 572 passsengers on board. Her news was up to the 21st ult., and mention is made of a meeting of Mexicans in San Francisco, on the 19th, for the purpose of arranging means to assist the Mexican Government ...

THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. In addition to containing the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the diderent departments from the pens of our special correspondents.

THE BROOKLYN BOARD OF ALDERMEN.--Now that the election is over, and the majorities of the successful candidates declared, there is an animated contest for the various positions in the gift of the Common Council.

The New-Hampshire Democratic State Convention to-day nominated IRA A. EASTMAN for Governor, and JAMES S. CHENEY for Railroad Commissioner. The resolutions adopted affirm the preservation of the Constitution as it is and the restoration of the Union as it was. There was a large attendance and entire harmony.
Your respondent at Falmouth sends the following " Yesterday the rebel pickets made their appearance on the opposite bank of the river, and are now within easy musket range."

The Times editorially traces the reverses of the Federal armies in the past to their magnitude, and the consequent difficulty in handling them, and as they promise to be just as unwieldy in the future, it thinks there is nothing to warrant the expectation of more success from the new army which the Federal Government is now preparing.
Before Justice Potter. Stephen D. Dillaye vs.Emanuel B. Hart.-- This case was stated in the TIMES of yesterday, and is familiar to the public.

TRICT.--In several papers the name of the Republican candidate for Alderman in the Seventeenth District is given as WILLIAM DOWNING, it should be WILLIAM DUNNING, an honest, upright citizen, who stands pledged to an economical and straightforward administration of the City's affairs; who is capable and efficient and deserving of the support of his fellow-citizens.

GENERAL ORDERS No. 20.--That portion of Kentucky, including and lying west of Oldham, shelby, Spencer, Taylor, Washington, Russell and Clinton, will constitute the district of Western Kentucky, under command of Brig.-Gen. BOYLE, to whom all reports and returns will be made. Headquarters Louisville, Ky.

It is understood that a number of the Expeditions which were being gotten up for operating on the Southern coast and against points of secondary importance, have been abandoned, and that the forces in the field will now be directed to the main purpose of capturing Richmond and defeating the principal rebel army. The Paris correspondent of the London Times says: "It is rumored that overtures have been or are to be made by France to the Russian Government, with a view to taking into serious consideration the state of affairs in America; the disastrous effects of the civil war on Europe generally; and whether the time is not now come for the Powers to make a move toward mediation, or recognition of the Confederate States."

Such is the question put by the London Times, in response to the remonstrances of our Chamber of Commerce against the construction and equipment and manning of the Confederate cruiser, Alabama, in an English port. Like a certain other question of old, it is not seriously asked, and yet is a serious question.
Dress and Soft Hats attract unversal attention. N.B.-- FANCY FURS FOR LADIES AND GENTLEMEN, AT No. 216 BROADWAY.

The twenty-ninth annual Festival and Fair of the Brooklyn Orphan Asylum came off on Tuesday and Wednesday evenings. The children, numbering between one and two hundred, assembled in the large hall, and gave their friends a most acceptable treat in the rendition of certain melodies appropriate not only to their quiet existence, but descriptive of our country's disturbance.
The Asia has arrived. COTTON-Sales, to-day, 1,250 bales. Market very dull and easier. All qualities slightly lower. Speculators and exporters took 600. Breadstuffs quiet but steady. Provisions heavy.
Many active rebels are preparing to leave Middie Tennessee, in anticipation of the retreat of the rebel troops.

Yesterday morning was set apart by the Police Commissioners for the trial of Police-Superintendent Kennedy on the charge of the alleged imprisonment of Mrs. Brinsmade, of New-Orleans. There was a large attendance of witnesses, Police Captains and interested spectators.

We publish this morning an interesting account of a recent reunion at Santiago, the Capital of Chili, at which were present the American Minister and Dr. MACKIE, of the State Department, with many distinguished Chilian and other South American Statesmen.
The savannah Republican of the 13th, says that on Sunday last the Federals attempted to land at St. Mary's, Ga., but were repulsed. The gunboats then shelled, and completely destroyed the town.

The Pajaro del Oceano arrived here on the 13th, bringing news from New-Orleans up to the 10th inst. Admiral FARRAGUT arrived in New-Orleans at 2 o'clock in the afternoon of the 9th.

MASON JONES AT IRVING HALL.--To-night, at Irving Hall, Mr. MASON JONES, the gifted Irish orator, whose entertainments have created the greatest enthusiasm among the leading literary circles of the City, Will lecture upon "Milton, his character and Writings." Mr. JONES deserves, as he will undoubtedly have, an overflowing audience.

Very unexpectedly, yesterday morning, Capt. WILSON, of the Revenue-battery Naugaluck, received orders to prepare for sea at once, and leave NewYork as soon as possible.
Before Judge McCunn. In this Court, yesterday, Bridget Verden and Michael Logan, jointly indicted for grand larceny, pleaded guilty to petit larceny and were remanded for sentence.
Passengers from Holly Springs report the army at a stand still. Hospitals are being prepared, and large quantities of grain being collected.
A decree of the Governor-General of Poland raises the state of siege in the towns and districts of Grodno. Bilsk and Brjesk, and maintains it in force in the town and district of Bjalistsck.
Before Justice Barbour. Howell vs. the Madison-avenue Baptist Church.--The complaint must be dismissed with costs. Application for papers must be made to the Clerk of the Court.
The funds continued inanimate, but there was rather a tendency toward improvement on the 7th. Consols close at 93 @ 93 5/8.
We have Gates from San Francisco to the 21st ult., brought by the steamer America, from Nicaragua. She reports that 572 passengers left for NewYork this morning.

The steamship Persia arrived at this port last night, with advices from Europe three days later than were received by the Nova Scotian. She left Liverpool on the 8th inst., and Queenstown on the 9th. Some of the papers were again giving currency to mediation rumors.

o'clock, yesterday morning, the clothing store of Messrs. MARCO SILVERSTEIN, No. 410 Grand-street, was entered by burglars, and robbed of about $70 worth of overcoats and $5 in money. Officers ROBERTS and GRAY, of the Thirteenth Precinct, discovered the thieves as they were about leaving the premises, but the latter were too swift of foot for the Metropolitans, and therefore made good their escape.

HANNAN, eight years of age, residing at No. 90 Baxter-street, was run over by car No. 54, of the Fourthavenue line, at the corner of White and Centre streets, on Wednesday night, and almost instantly killed. MARK HALEY, the driver of the car, was immediately arrested by Officer GOLDEN, of the Sixth Precinct. Coroner RANNEY was notified to hold an inquest upon the body.

DEAR BROTHER: I suppose you read my letter to mother, describing an excursion along the mountains up the Shenandoah Valley. While we were three we sent out two companies at a time every day on picket at fords on the Shenandoah River, which at this place was about as wide as Grandpa's Mill Pond, but not so deep.

The Bank of France, on the 6th inst., raised its minimum rate of discount to 4 cent.

Before Judge Daly. The Matter of Frederick Freund.--This was a habeas corpus for the discharge of the petitioner from custody. Freund was convicted of arson in the Oyer and Terminer, in January, 1860 and sentenced to the State Prison for life.

The Fiftieth Massachusetts arrived here yesterday morning, from Boston, vid the Norwich line. It comprises nine hundred men, who were principally recruited in Essex County.

A serious and rather threatening riot had taken place at Blackburn, owing fo some convictions for poaching under the Game laws. Considerable damage was done, and military aid was invoked, but quiet was restored without loss of life or any material bloodshed.

The Broadway Railway is now so far advanced that it is expected the cars will be running on it by New-Year's day. Aside from this, a road is now laving from Tenth-avenue through Thirty-fourthstreet to Broadway, thence down the Broadway Railway to Fourteenth-street; thence east to the other side of the City, and down other streets to the foot of Grand-street.

The inquest in the case of Miss CLEMENTINA ANDERSON, of Bleecker-street, was continued yesterday by Coroner BANNEY, at the Ninth Precinct Station-house. The evidence of the deceased's father was taken, in part, and his testimony throws considerable light upon the affair. The investigation will be resumed at 2 o'clock this afternoon. No further arrests had been made at a late hour last evening.

The quiet which, since my last letter, had so uninterruptedly settled over this peaceful city, was again, to-day, rudely broken by another, less sad, but by no means pleasant occurrence. In a large city like New-York, the departure of a regiment is nothing uncommon in times like these, but in a place like Middletown it is an entirely different thing.

The inquest in the case of Miss CLEMENTINA ANDERSON was concluded at a late hour last evening. The jury found a verdict to the effect that deceased came to her death by inflammation produced by abortion, at the hands of Dr. BROWNE, and that SIMMS was an accessory before and after the fact. BROWNE was thereupon committed to prison, to await the action of the Grand Jury. SIMMS has not yet been arrested.

RICHARD HIATT, WM. FITZER and JOHN RAFFERTY were undoubtedly killed or drowned by the railroad drawbridge disaster at Charlestown yesterday morning. Their bodies were probably swept away by the current. These, added to those already reported, make seven death in all from the catastrophe.

Gen. CRITTENDEN'S Corps of the army left Gallatin on the morning of the 10th, the Twenty-third Brigade of the Fifth Division, commanded by Col. STANLEY MATTHEWS, taking the advance, and going in the direction of Lebanon. A portion of MORGAN'S men, who had fled from Gallatin as we approached, had gone to Lebanon and taken a stand there.

The United States steamship Massachusetts, Commander S.H. COOPER, arrived at this port yesterday from Bahama Banks, via Port Royal on the 16th inst, Washington Bar 18th, and twenty-four hours from Hampton Roads. She brings no news from Port Royal, except that the yellow fever has entirely disappeared, and the health of the place greatly improved.

Guerrillas apparently are at work again on the line of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad, below Munfordsville or Bowling Green, for telegraphic intercourse with Nashville was cut off last evening. ROSECRANS' forces appear somewhat scattered, in order to guard his communications and flanks, and are probably sufficiently strong and alert at every important post to prevent any suprise or surrender.

The news from the Army of the Potomac, this morning, is important and exciting. It indicates that the passage of the Rappahannock at Fredericksburgh is to be disputed by the rebels to the last--perhaps that a battle will he fought there which will have a commanding influence on the progress of the war.

The forts in Nashville are the most complete of the kind in the country. "Fort Negley," situated on St. Cloud Hill, is the masterpiece, and was constructed almost entirely by negroes, under the engineership of Capt. MORTON, a Philadelphian. The work covers nearly twelve acres of ground, and communication is carried on by means of subterranean passages from one portion of the fort to another.

A correspondent of the St. Paul (Minn.,) Press writing from Camp Sibley, Lower Agency, Minn., under date of Nov. 7, gives some interesting particulars regarding the trial of the Indians charged with having taken a prominent part in the recent outrages. He says:
A letter from Fort Scott, dated the 17th inst., says that the burning of Lamar, Missouri, by the rebels, has been confirmed.

On last Saturday morning an expedition under command of Gen. KELLY, composed of infantry, cavalry and artillery, numbering about 800, left here for Moorefield, for the purpose of capturing or driving off the notorious guerrilla, IMBODEN, and his band. Our force arrived at Moorefield about 1 o'clock on Sunday morning, having marched all day Saturday and Saturday night.

THE SANITARY COMMISSION.--Dr. BELLOWS has been invited to deliver an address at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, on Monday evening next, to inform the public of Brooklyn of the organization of the Sanitary Committee and of the facilities which have been granted to it by the cooperation of the Government, and of the immense amount of relief it has been ennabled to dispense. The lecture will be free.
Gov. OLDEN to-day appointed RICHARD S. FIELD, of Princeton, United States Senator, to fill the vacancy occasioned by the death of Hon. JOHN R. THOMPSON. The term expires on the 4th March next.
A correpondent of the Delta, writing subsequently to the battle of Thibodeauxville, under date of Nov. 1, says:

The Mayor of Brooklyn has issued the following proclamation: In accordance with a time-honored custom, the Governor of the State has recommended the observance of Thursday, the 27th inst., as a day of general thanksgiving.

The only notable event of the day at this place. has been a flying visit from Major-Gen. BURNSIDE. His advent was entirely unexpected. Soon, however, as the fact became known, the troops stationed at the junction were called out to do him honor.
The steamship Nova Sotian sailed from Quebec at 11 o'clock this morning, taking out ten cabin and thirty-three steerage passengers for Liverpool.

The Vidette, a paper issued under the supervision of the notorious guerilla MORGAN, publishes a long defence of Gen. BUELL. After giving him credit for wresting the victory from the Confederates at Shiloh, the writer says:

--Miss R. C. Dayton is a young lady who is not ashamed of having been one of the parties to an elopement. Having heard that her brother had undertaken to chastise, in Wheeling, Va., the one who attempted her ruin, Miss Dayton addressed the following note to the editor of a paper in the place where she had taken refuge:

Every mail we now receive from England is full of painful details in regard to the sufferings in the cotton manufacturing districts. It is the prominent topic in the English newspapers, and the first thought in the minds of English statesmen and humanitarians.

We lately published an interesting letter from Mr, ROBERT RHODES, of Pawtuxet, executive officer of the United States steamer Clifton, describing the capture of Sabine Pass and Galveston. We are now permitted to print an extract from a private letter, in which he describes the operations of the fleet in Matagorda Bay.
A member of Maj.-Gen. GRANT'S Staff, direct from Lagrange, says that Gen. BRAGG is not in that vicinity, and that the report of the Memphis Bulletin of the l8th inst. is untrue.

The statistical list of the exchange of prisoners effected at Aiken's Landing, James River, by Col. LUDLOW, Chief of Major-Gen. DIX's Staff, which we published a few days since, in its simple array of figures, hardly conveyed to the reader a proper conception of the importance and intricate nature of the arrangements which have been so successfully accomplished through the energy and labors of Col. LUDLOW.

The Commercial Advertiser of the 20th inst., assumes that France "will be able to go just as far as she may elect to go in her present purpose toward Mexico," and upon this assumption remarks: "We presume that we have no good ground for interfering in any mode or degree. Every nation has an inherent, indisputable right to compel, if it can, other Powers to fulfill contracts into which they have entered with it.
Mayor WIGHTMAN has been renominated by the People's Union Party for reelection.

The Baltimore American's Harper's Ferry letter, of yesterday, says it is rumored that JACKSON is still near Winchester, with 40,000 men. The general impression is, that he is retiring toward Gordonsville. All is quiet along the lines.

ABEL HOCKING, cabinet-maker, was murdered last night, while at his work in his shop in Dorchester, Lower Mills, by blows from a hatcher. The Selectmen have offered a reward for the apprehension of the assassin. The deceased was agood citizen, and leaves a wife behind him. He has two brothers in the army.

Several cool nights and a little touch of frost have tended to improve somewhat the health of this place; still, cases of (supposed) yellow fever are of daily occurrence, by far the majority of which have resulted fatally. On Saturday afternoon, BRIGHAM and his party returned from their trip to Cache Valley, having held preachings at most of the places they passed through, and particularly a two days' meeting at Logan, the Capital of Cache County.
The Anti-Slavery Standard published a full report of an address delivered at Music Hal, Boston, on Nov. 2, by WENDELL PHILLIPS. We make the following extracts:

The Supreme Court of Georgia, on Nov. 12, unanimously decided the Conscription law of the Confederate States to be constitutional. Judge JENKINS delivered the opinion of the Court. The case was one brought up from the Ocmulgee Circuit.

A drizzly rain, which has been falling at intervals during the last forty-eight hours, has turned the dust, gathered thr last Summer upon the macadamized roads in this vicinity, into a sticky, slimy, porridge, from two to four inches in depth, rendering locomotion by man or horse a very difficult task, and the passage of wheeled vehicles almost impossible.

Eleven Yankee soldiers, belonging to a NewYork regiment, who were captured at Gaines' Cross Roads, were brought to this city yesterday, and lodged in the Libby Prison. The night train on the Central road also brought down a number of Yankees, who were captured a few days ago at Snicker's Gap by our cavalry.

"At the time this column of the army marched from Bolivar it was thought that a movement straight to Holly Springs was in progress. A halt of three days has somewhat set at naught the speculations of the would-be wise ones.

Col. CAMERON, of the Thirty-fourth, Indiana Regiment, who recently went from Helena to Little Rock with a flag of truce, has returned. Of his interview with Gen. HOLMES you have already received full accounts. He found three passable roads leading west from Helena as far as White River, all well supplied with water and forage.

The whaling schooner Rising Sun, of Provinceton, Capt. YOUNG, last from the North Atlantic Ocean, after a cruise of ten months, with 210 barrels sperm oil, to order, arrived yesterday. On Nov. 1, in lat. 21, long. 67 36 she spoke schooner Morris of Gloucester, nine days from Boston. The Rising Sun line had heavy weather.

Brig.-Gen. PATTERSON was found dead in his tent, at Fairfax Court-house, this morning. His body was (this P.M.) sent to Philadelphia, where he resided. He is a son of Major-Gen. PATTERSON, who commanded at Harper's Ferry at the time of the first battle of Bull Run. It is said he committed suicide. FEMALE SPIES.

Since Friday last the arrival of troops has been continuous, and the woods upon the opposite bank of the river, at night, are ruddy with the light of camp fires. The city is now under command of Maj.-Gen. A. McDOWELL McCOOK, who occupies Gen. NEGLEY'S former quarters, on High-street, Gen. NEGLEY having now taken up his abode in the house owned and formerly occupied by Gen. ZOLLICOFFER.

The obsequies of Capt. ALFRED ASHER DONALDS, who was mortally wounded at the battle of Bristow Station, Va., took place yesterday afternoon from the Governor's Room, City Hall.

The Mississippi is lower than at any previous time during the last seven years, and recently fell six inches in 24 hours. Considerable ice is floating in the river, and large boats are unable to reach the city. The mail is now carried by stage, and navigation may be regarded as practically closed.

The past week, although an inclement one as regards the weather, was not very disastrous to the theatres--except perhaps those two or three establishments where dress is as much an object as any other kind of pleasure. The writer says: "In an extreme corner of an inner room of a small and apparently poor house, have been discovered some human bones--a rare thing in Pompeii, where most of the population had time to escape. Further researches--and it was interesting ...

The reported receipts of the principal kinds of Produce since our last have been 203 bbls. Ashes, 17.394 bbls. Flour, 496 bbls. and 357 bags Corn Meal, 163,145 bushels Wheat, 153,020 bushels Corn, 4,997 bushels Barley, 40,168 bushels Oats, 860 bushels Malt, 3,132 pkgs. Provisions, and 908 bbls. Whisky.

The rebels have announced their purpose of disputing Gen. BURNSIDE'S occupation of Fredericksburgh. He will have to cross the river in face of the rebel army--always one of the most difficult and dangerous of military operations. That it will be attempted, there can be no doubt.

The rain-storm continues and military operations are almost at a stand-still. The more water the deeper the mud, and the difficulty of locomotion is, of course, proportionately increased. The enemy, notwithstanding the bad condition of the roads, still press around us, and, if we can believe the scouts, in considerable force.

Mr. WHEATLEY'S management at the Brooklyn Academy terminated on Saturday night. During the two weeks of his Brooklyn career he has been embarrassed by high rental, favored with an almost perpetual rain, and doubtless perplexed by the peculiar desires of the public.
The Journal of Commerce notices the difficulty encountered by the people of the West India Islands on the subject of supplying labor for their plantations. It says:

An impression prevailed quite extensively in front yesterday and this forenoon that Gen. EARLY'S and Gen. MACEALL'S Divisions of Stonewall JACKSON'S Corps were advancing upon Washington, and had arrived in the vicinity of Middleburgh and Leesburgh.

Since the capture of the rebel battery on St. John's Bluff, but little of interest has transpired here. The gunboat Hals makes her regular trips up the river to Jacksonville, and since Gen. FINNEGAN'S failure to impede navigation, has been unmolested.

The steamship Arabia passed Cape Race yesterday morning, and her advices, which are one week later, are telegraphed. By this arrival we receive the important intelligence that the Emperor NAPOLEON has made a proposal for mediation between tho belligerents in the United States to the British Government, but that the latter has declined to become a party.

Gen. McCLELLAN very properly declines the hospitalities of the City, as will be seen in the annexed letter, but we understand the Committee on National Affairs hope to prevail on him to give a public reception at the City Hall.

MY DEAR UNCLE: I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letters, dated in Mexico, the 16th of July--the delay in the arrival of which had caused me so much uneasiness--not coming to hand until four days after the receipt of the July mails, that I could not help manifesting it in my last letter of the 15th August.

nals a few days since announced the arrest of two gentlemen well known in this City, on charge of having defrauded the Government. We copy from the Albany Argus an article giving the details of the alleged fraudulent transactions.
There is a rebel brigade at Shelbyville, under Gen. JOHNSON. Union men are making armed resistance to the conscription in several portions of Middle Tennessee.
The Democrat of this city, has information that the rebels are now busily at work fortifying Port Hudson, a hundred and fify miles from New-Orleans.

The day has passed off quietly, without anything worthy of note transpiring. The church-bells in Fredericksburgh were ringing to-day, announcing the hour of Divine worship, although most of the inhabitants have fled the doomed city.

We have received the following from the TIMES' Special Correspondent, dated SIGEL'S Headquarters, Nov. 24:

The President has issued an order directing that the Attorney-General be charged with the superintendence and direction of all proceedings under the Confiscation Act, and authorizing him to call upon the military authorities to aid him in carrying out its provisions.

JECKER, EUGENE CLARIN, CLEMENTE A. CARRABURNE, ANTONIO BONHOMME, GUSTAVE DESARCHE CARLOS DE BARRES and ADOLFO FRISSAC, detected in active correspondence with the French army marching on the capital.

The reported receipts of the principal kinds of Procude since our last have been 23 bbls. Ashes, 36,668 bbls. Flour, 174 bbls. and 498 bags Corn Meal, 177,640 bushels Wheat, 61,929 bushels Corn, 2,285 bushels Barley, 32,083 bushels Oats, 5,681 pkgs. Provisions, and 420 bbls. Whisky.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--MEYERBEER'S new opera, "Dinorah," was produced here last evening, for the first time in New-York, and met with decided success. An extended notice of the opera is unavoidably crowded over. The house was crowded to its greatest capacity. Among the visitors was Gen. GEORGE B. McCLELLAN, who, being recognized, was greeted with cheers and honored with the National anthems.
Four hundred Union prisoners arrived here from City Point to-day. The Richmond papers say that nearly a hundred thousand dollars worth of tobacco was destroyed at Fredericksburgh by the Confederates.

About 5 o'clock yesterday morning, Capt. SEBRING, of the Ninth Precinct, aided by his officers, DAY and ACKERMAN, succeeded in effecting the arrest of AUGUSTUS L. SIMMS, who was implicated in the Coroner's verdict, rendered on Saturday night last, as being an accessory to the death of Miss CLEMENTINA ANDERSON.

The Army of the Potomac has probably never experienced two days and nights of greater discomfort than since they encamped near the Rappahannock on Wednesday. The symptoms of a storm, which were apparent during the march hither from Warrenton, led many to fear that bad weather would overtake us before we were established in camp. The day was drizzly, and the ground on which the various commands pitched their camps was already ...

greatly comforted by a statement made about a month ago by our Virginia correspondent, as to the imperfect morale, the defectiveness of supplies, and the feuds of idle officers, then existing in the Army of the Potomac. It quotes the statement in big types no less than twice, in its issue of the 8th instant.

The steamship Ariel, A.G. JONES, commanding, from Aspinwall on the 15th, with mails, passengers and specie, to D.B. ALLEN, arrived at this port yesterday afternoon, 24th, at 2 o'clock.

The public did not fully understand the military position in the Southwest at the time of Gen. GRANT'S recent advance toward Holly Springs; and hence anticipations have been indulged in, of immediate and decisive results, that were not fully justified. The bulk of Gen. GRANT'S army is still at Lagrange, Tennessee: the rest is at Grand Junction.

It will be remembered that, a few days ago, the daily papers contained an account of the arrest of MR. SOLOMON KOHNSTAM and a Mr. TRACEY, who were charged with defrauding the Government to a large extent. The fact of the arrest and the incarceration of the culprits in Fort Lafayette was duly mentioned, and there the matter ended.

The steamship Arabia from Liverpool, Saturday the 15th, Queenstown 16th, passed this point at 6 o'clock this A.M., and was boarded by the news yacht of the New-York Associated Press.

The most important piece of news that has reached us from Europe the present year, is that brought by the Arabia, and telegraphed off Cape Race last night, in relation to the proposed mediation of France and England in the American quarrel.

Some one writing from this place appears to censure the Railroad Department for neglect to make timely provision for the reconstruction of the wharves and buildings at this point, and the railroad to Fredericksburgh. The very reverse of all this is the fact, and the most extraordinary energy, activity and forethought have been exhibited.

TWENTIETH WARD CONVENTION.--At a meeting of the Republican Ward Convention of the Twentieth Ward, held at Continental Hall, last evening, the following gentlemen were nominated for School Officers: For Commissioner--John Hooper; for Trustees--Adolph Ran, Geo. N. Seymour; for Inspector--William Ross.

Some additional advices from Mexico are received by way of Havana, at which port the Roanoke touched on her way from New-Orleans. Gen. FOREY was still at Orizaba. Jalapa was in possession of the French, the place having been surrendered without a show of resistance.

This morning at daylight a body of rebel cavalry, said to be sixty strong, entered Poolesville, seized Messrs. CHERRY AND SARGEANT, the Government telegraph operators stationed there, in bed, paroled them, and permitted them to telegraph their mishaps to Washington. This boldness of the rebels has caused much excitement in this neighborhood.
Two more Massachusetts Regiments, the Eighth, Col. COFFIN, and the Fifty-first, Col. SPRAGUE, embarked this afternoon on board steamers Mississippi and Merrimac, for Newbera, N.C.

A special dispatch to the American, from Harper's Ferry, states that Gen. KELLY yesterday sent out scouts from New-Creek, who captured a rebel cavalry picket of twelve men, with horses and accoutrements, within four miles of Winchester. The prisoners say that JACKSON has started with his whole force for Richmond, by way of Front Royal, leaving only a regiment of cavalry at Winchester, instructed to follow in a few days.

Before Justice Bosworth. Ira M. Edsall vs. James and Erastus Brooks.-- The plaintiff, it appears, was a police officer, and was discharged from the force for receiving money from citizens for services, without the permission of the Board.

THE NORTH RIVER FERRIES.--The Jersey City Ferry Company gives gratifying evidence of public spirit, in furnishing fresh facilities to the traveling community. It recently established a new ferry, connecting with the foot of Desbrosses-street, thus enabling the railroad passengers to reach a point up town with the least possible delay.

Do we mean to kill this rebellion or not? If we do, why this hacking at the extremities? Why this skin-deep scarifying of the sides? Why this mere pricking at the vitals? Why don't we drive our lance, with might and main, straight into the heart of the monster? Will it be said it has no heart? It has.

Your elaborate leader, containing a most thorough epitome of Gen. BUTLER'S administration of his military department, was published here by the local papers, and read by the citizens with lively pleasure. It was a proper compliment and an evidence of just appreciation of the mental labor and herculean industry of Gen. BUTLER.

From various Southern papers received here, the following extracts are made: The Savannah Republican says: "We have reason to believe Government has again put the wheels of war in motion in the right direction, which, properly conducted, will thwart all the cherished plans of the enemy, and secure his overthrow at every point. We shall hear of the result at an early day."

The reported receipts of the principal kinds of Produce since our last have been 38 bbls. Ashes, 23,529 bbls. Flour, 127 bbls. and 320 bags Corn Meal, 83,890 bushels Wheat, 87,972 bushels Corn, 4,696 bushels Barley, 11,991 bushels Oats, 603 bushels Malt, 4,373 pkgs. Provisions, and 458 bbls. Whisky.

To-day, from 8 A.M. to 9 P.M., the Board of Registrars of the several Districts, set for the purpose of revising and correcting the list of voters for the coming election. Urge upon all voters, the importance of having their names registered in time, in order to avoid delay in voting on the day of election.

The Commissioner of Internal Revenue hss decided that an incorporated Bank does not require a broker's license, simply because it sells to its customers its checks for a surplus of its funds accumulated in another Bank in another place, or in the same place.

The inquest at Port Richmond, Staten Island, on the murder of ALABAMUS HARRISON, is yet in progress. From the testimony of Drs. EADIR and HARRISON, (the latter a brother of the victim,) it would seem that the murder was committed in doors, and the body left in the street afterward, as the underclothes were not at all wet, although a heavy rain fall during the night.

Before Justice Barbour. Oswald Rehn vs. Thomas Mulligan.--This action was brought against the defendant, who is a constable, for an alleged wrongful taking of the plaintiff's horse in satisfaction for an execution issued against the property of the plaintiff's father.

The effect of this storm upon the soldiers has been depressing, but what it will be upon the campaign yet remains to be seen. "You are just six weeks too late," remarked a loyal citizen to me last evening.
A dispatch received last night from the Army of the Potomac informs us that there is nothing of importance to communicate.

The iron-clad battery Passaic left the Delamater Iron Works early yesterday forenoon, and arrived at the Navy-yard soon after. She was then turned over to the Government to whom she belongs henceforward. Her ensign had been hoisted, and her commission filed before.

The departure of the present Captain-General, the Duke De La TORRE, and the arrival of his successor, Gen. DUICE, may now occur every day. The latter is daily expected from Spain, when the departure of the former may perhaps immediately occur.
Some 400 hundred of MORGAN'S cavalry left camp, seven miles from Lebanon, to attack the Federals at Wood's Ferry, on the Cumberland Road, but were shelled, with the loss of two men.

The Board of Supervisors met at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon--President PURDY in the Chair. The Commissioners of Taxes and Assessments transmitted to the Board an order upon them from the Supreme Court to reduce the tax on the bank assets so far as to exempt the United States Bonds held by them. The order is in pursuance of the recent dedision of the Court, that these stocks are exempted from tax by law of Congress.
A dispatch received to-night from the Army of the Potomac, says there is nothing of importance to communicate.

Gen. PATRICK returned from Fredericksburgh at 7 o'clock last evening. He carried orders demanding the surrender of the place, and ordering that no more supplies should be sent out of town. The Mayor of the town was willing to accede to the request, but the military authorities refused to listen to the demands. Gen. PATRICK was contined all day in the guard-house which he himself constructed last Summer.

Owing to the fact that the Secretary of the Treasury has not yet received from the War Department the necessary estimates on which to base his recommendations to Congress, he will not be able to present his annual report to that body at the commencement of the session.

The resolutions recently passed by the friends of Gen. BANKS and ordered to be engrossed, were duly presented to the General, in a formal manners yesterday afternoon, by the Special Committee, Hon. Charles A. Peabody, Charles Gould, Esq., Moses Taylor, Esq., R.H. McCurdy, Esq., and Capt. C.H. Marshall.
