La Paz, the principal city of Bolivia, finally surrendered to Gen. ACHA, Provisional President, on the 16th of October, Gen. AGREDA, commanding there for the revolutionary leader PEREZ, retiring. For twenty days, previously, not a shop had been opened in the city, and the distress among many was getting to be very great.

The Murfreesboro Banner of the 20th, states that JOE. JOHNSTON will assume command of BRAGG'S army. GEO. B. CRITTENDEN has been released from arrest and reported for duty. McCANN has been assigned to the defence of Cumberland Gap.

D.V. Freeman vs. Hiram Barney.--This was an action brought to recover an amount paid by the plaintiff as extra duties levied by the defendant. The penalty was levied on the ground that on appraisement the appraisers had advanced the value more than ten per cent.
Anna, Caroline Smith vs. John J. Smith.--This action was brought to procure a divorce, the plaintiff charging cruel and inhuman treatment.

From Rosario dates are up to Sept. 16. The Provinces are all quiet; but at Buenos Ayres the people were a good deal agitated about the question as to the place for the permanent location of the Capital. The local Legislature had rejected the bill for the federalization of the Province (?) of Buenos Ayres, or that for the municipal area of the city. The public mind was restless at the new turn of affairs.
Rev. WLLIAMS R. WILLIAMS, D.D. pastor of the Amity-street Baptist Church, delivered to his congregation a discourse from the following text:

THE GERMANS FOR HAWS FOR COMPTROLLER. --The adopted citizens of German birth very generally support HAWS for Comptroller. We are assured that a large German Democractic Club, in the Seventeenth Ward, went so far as to indorse HAWS as their candidate for Comptroller on Wednesday night.

THANKSGIVING IN BROOKLYN.--This anniversary was observed in the usual manner. The city had the appearance of a Sunday. Business was suspended, with the exception of the liquor saloons.

If the war has called into activity many of the most selfish and unscrupulous qualities of our people, it has also given occasion for the display of the most generous and lofty attributes of human nature.

Major FREUDENBERG, of the Fifty-second NewYork Volunteers, (German,) has come to this city, by order of the War Department, to fill up the ranks of his regiment. This gallant and now war-worn body of men was organized in New-York, and left for Washington on the 11th of November, 1861.
The attendance at St. Thomas' Church was large and respectable. The Rector, Rev. W.F. MORGAN, D.D., preached an able and eloquent sermon, suited to the day.

The day appointed by the Governor of the State for Thanksgiving and Prayer way fully kept and honored in the good old-fashioned manner. The inauguration of the new Lord Mayor of London (Alderman ROSE) took place with the usual formalities on the 10th instant--the 9th being Sunday. The customary banguet an Guildhall was a magnificent affair, but the speeches were without political significance.

The Jewish Synagogue B'Nai Jeshurun, situated in Greene-street, between Houston and Bleecker streets, was filled some time before the commencement of the services yesterday morning.
The services held in St. George's Episcopal Church, yesterday, of which Rev. Dr. STEPHEN H. TYNG is Rector, were appropriate to the day, and were conducted by the Rector and his assistant.
The screw steamer City of Washington, Capt. MIREHOUSE, which sailed from Liverpool at noon on the 12th, and from Queenstown on the afternoon of the 13th November, arrived here yesterday morning.

THANKSGIVING IN NEWARK.--Thanksgiving Day in Newark passed off very pleasantly and quietly, the attractive weather causing an unusual throng of people in the streets, many of them being from the country, which on holidays always sends its quota to swell the crowd of passers-by. Business was entirely suspended, which gave the City the aspect of a Sabbath day.

A question has arisen in Missouri between a Union officer and the rebel Government, which demands the prompt attention of our authorities at Washington. We find in yesterday's Tribune a statement of the case. ANDREW ALLSMAN, an old resident of Palmyra, Mo., was a well known adherent of the Union cause, and had made himself especially valuable to our armies by his services as a guide.

The affair of the Blanche and Montgomery threatens to assume serious proportions, Spain, in view of the fratricidal struggle of the United States, comprehends the weight she can throw into the balance by opening the ports and arsenals of the Antilles to the Confederates. Pushed to extremes by her lively sympathy with the South, she seems determined to profit by the circumstance, and show herself as evangelic in language as in act.

Fredericksburgh is not occupied by the enemy in force, merely a picket guard is there on duty. Business is totally suspended. The only flag visible is a British one, floating from a private residence.

A correspondent of the Boston Journal writes from this City under date of Nov. 24 "Gen. BANES is at work night and day. He is known to be at work as late as 3 o'clock in the morning, and no one gets up so early as to find him asleep.

IRVING HALL.--Miss TERESA CARRENO'S debut, on Tuesday night, more than fulfilled the promise of her private performances, to which we have before referred. She deserves to be ranked, not as a child-wonder, who at the age of eight years has vanquished nearly all the technical difficulties of the piano, but as an artist of first-class sensibility.

A large detachment of United States marines arrived here, yesterday, from the National Capital. They were temporarily transferred to the Flushingavenue barracks, where they will remain until Monday. On that day they will embark for California, in charge of Major GARLAND and Capt. COHEN, being reinforced by another troop from this station. A new barracks is to be built at Mare Island.

The iron-clad steamer Keokuk, now building by Mr. WHITNEY at the foot of Tenth-street, East River, will be launched on Tuesday or Wednesday of next Week. She is nearly ready to be put afloat.

GERMAN OPERA.--LORTZING's comic opera, "Der Wildsehutz" (the Poacher,) was produced here lastnight with a degree of uproarious success that will justify its repetition on many succeeding evenings. It is a work peculiarly German in character, and depending largely on dialogue and jocularity of a provincial kind.

Advice from Gen. BURNSIDE's army headquarters inform us that the enemy are still industriously engaged in extending and strengthening their earthworks in the rear and to the right and left of Fredericksburgh--their operations being distinctly visible from the signal stations. No movement of importance has taken place for several days, on our side.

To the Editor of the London Times: SIR: The principles involved in the question commonly termed the "recognition of the South," seems to be so imperfectly apprehended by some recent writers and speakers, and so much confusion appears to exist in the public mind respecting this interesting topic, that I venture to ask your indulgence in an attempt to elucidate the maxims of law and the practice of nations applicable to the matter.

We trust that no Republican will refrain from doing every thing in his power to secure the election of Republican candidates to-morrow, by the apparently slight prospect of success which the November result would warrant. A Democratic majority of 30,000, in the ordinary course of things, is not easily overcome, and every one must concede, that under ordinary circumstances, the chances are against it.

Congress meets to-day, and the Message of the President will be delivered to that body in time for publication in the afternoon papers. The reports of the Secretaries of War and the Navy are also ready, and will accompany the Message.

VETERINARY SURGEON-GENERAL--Dr. SIEGFRIED NEUMANN, well knomn in Newark as a veterinary surgeon, has received the appiontment of Veterinary Surgeon-General, with the rank of LieutenantColonel in the United States Army. Dr. NEUMANN is said to have passed a most searching examination, in competition with over one hundred applicants. The office is a new one, and the appointment for life.

In the very able communication to the London Times, which we published on Saturday, attributed to the British Secretary of War, it was said that "in 1849 the American Government chose to recognize the independence of the Hungarian insurgents." This is an error which does us great injustice. In fact, our Government can ask nothing better from the European Powers than that they shall conform precisely to its action in that case. Let us see.

FELLOW-CITIZENS OF THE SENATE AND HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES: Since your last annual assembling, another year of health and bountiful harvests has passed; and while it has not pleased the Almighty to bless us with a return of peace, we can but press on, guided by the best light He gives us, trusting that, in His own good time and wise way, all will be well.

Brig.-Gen. STAHL has just returned. He attacked the enemy at Snicker's Ferry, and followed them with 300 cavalry into the camps on the other side of the river, and near Perryville. Our men charged splendidly whenever they met the enemy. WHITE's Cavalry was driven in all directions, nearly all their officers captured, and their colors taken. WHITE himself fled, and hid himself at a house in Perryville.

BLUNT, with his division, made forced marches and attacked the enemy yesterday morning, at Cane Hill. The battle lasted for several hours. The enemy, under Gen. MARMADUKE, began to fall back about one o'clock, but retreated, fighting, until sundown.

We devote so large a space to the publication of the report of the Secretary of the Navy, that we cannot afford to accompany it with a complete analysis in these columns. We are obliged to omit considerable portions, in order to get in even a general view of its contents.

The President's Message was shortly afterward received, and after its reading the Senate adjourned.

It is no longer a question that the Army of the Potomac owes its failure to cross the Rappahannock promptly, on its arrival, to inexcusable delay in the furnishing of pontoon bridges and means of transportation.

Mr. HOOPER, of Massachusetts, (Rep.,) from the Committee on Ways and Means, reported a bill providing that all judgments recovered by the United States, in suits now pending or which may hereafter be brought for the collection or recovery of duties on imports or money due the United States from Collectors or other officers, shall be paid in gold and silver coin of the United States.

Commissioner DOLE'S report on Indian Affairs is very long, and presents the subject in all its aspects. He opens the document by recommending the plan of placing all the Indians upon reservations, teaching them civilization, and when developed sufficiently, dividing up the lands among them. Then they will some time be so far advanced as to have interests identical with those of the citizens of the various States.

Commander WORDEN, whose services on the Monitor have been so highly appreciated by his country, will sail from this City next week, in command of a better ship than even the Merrimac's antagonist. His eyes are well enough for duty, and his spirits excellent. By the laws of rank alone he is a commander, no special promotion having been conferred on him. His new craft, the Ericsson Battery Montauk, now ...

THE REBELLION. We have intelligence from Falmouth that the rebels have been attempting to post pickets near our lines on the right, but that they were driven back by a judicious display of force, of cavalry and infantry. The rebel force was not large, and did not offer to dispute the ground.

The elasticity of the American temperament, its easy transition from gloom to gaiety, its happy faculty of forgetting the evil of the day in the event of the evening, are just now singularly illustrated in the uniform and remarkable prosperity of all the places of Metropolitan amusement. In the olden times the Muses hung their heads when strife was in the land; now they are friskier than ever.

Gen. BURNSIDE has returned from Washington, and grievously disappointed the mawworms here, who have been swearing that "his head would be off next." To an audience that crowded the Academy, Mr. MASON JONES last evening delivered the fifth of his orations. In many respects, this one--the subject whereof is "Dean Swift and his Critics"--is the most interesting of the whole series. It is interesting from the nature of the subject itself, from the comparatively novel view taken of it by the orator, and, specialty, from the evident earnestness and sincerity with which that view is presented and advocated.

The bill which passed the House to-day, amendatory of the act to provide Internal Revenue, to support the Government and pay the interest on the public debt, approved July 1, 1862, authorizes the As sessors, and Collectors, and Assistants, and Deputies, to administer oaths and affirmations in all cases where they are required, but no fees are to be charged or allowed therefor.

The election of Chief Engineers of the Brooklyn Fire Department took place last evening at the different engine-houses, and although it excited a greal of interest among all firemen, every thing passed off quietly and in order. The polls remained oven from 7 to 9 o'clock P.M., when the boxes containing the votes were taken to Fireman's Hall, in Henry-street, and canvassed. The result was not declared until a late hour.

The admission of a new State into the Union is a very serious public event-- something like admitting a grown-up stranger into a family. Will the new member be agreeable, is he honorable, will be pay his way, will be conform to household rules and customs--or will be be factious, cross, and a pauper? In the early and even recent days of this Republic, very little heed was paid to such questions.

In this Court yesterday, HENRY TIETJEN was tried for an assault with intent to kill JAMES HENRY, by striking him with a slung-shot. In consequence of the blow, HENRY lost his left eye. At a late hour last evening, the jury had not agreed upon a verdict.

A special general meeting of the members of the Liverpool Chamber of Commerce was held on the 25th ult., in the Exchange-rooms, for the purpose of considering the question of belligerent rights at sea and the abolition of commercial blockades. There was a large attendance of members--Mr. THOS. CHILTON, President, occupied the Chair.

McCLELLAN on the Peninsula.

In the Federal Court, now sitting in Covington, case of much interest to the legal profession and to the holders of corporation bonds was decided yesterday.

Fredericksburgh is at last in possession of our army. The telegraphic details of the work of yesterday are few and brief, but they exhibit fine maneuvering, splendid bravery, and, so far as the first ahd most difficult operation was concerned, success. The previous night had been all bustle and activity among the troops, for it was fixed that they should cross the Rappahannock, in the face of the foe, in the morning.

The fact seems at last to be fully conceded that Hon. CALEB B. SMITH, Secretary of the Interior, will resign his place about the 1st of January next. Most of the indications from Washington point to Hon. JOSEPH HOLT as his successor--provided the office is not continued in the hands of a citizen of Indiana.

In this Court, yesterday, THOS. SULLIVAN, a blind man, aged 26, native of Ireland, was tried and convicted of stealing $67.50 from JOHN McGUISS. The parties slept together in the same room, and during the night SULLIVAN robbed the pocket of his companion of the above sum. The prisoner was sentenced to two years in the State Prison.

The news from the Army of the Potomac is suddenly invested with the most startling interest. Yesterday morning the movement for crossing the Rappahannock commenced, and last night the city of Fredericksburgh was in possession of our forces, with comparatively trifling loss. During Wednesday night pontoon bridges were got in readiness for throwing across the river, and at 6 o'clock yesterday morning the construction of three of them commenced infront of the city.
Gen. BLUNT telegraphs Gen. CURTIS that the rebels with whom he fought the battle of Prairie Grove, near Fayetteville, Ark., have probably crossed the Arkansas River.
This morning there are indications both of an advance and of Winter quarters. It is believed that the War Department is undecided in reference to the immediate disposition of the army.

The schooner Alice, from Point Petre, Guadeloupe, arrived yesterday. She has on board the chief officer and crew of the ship Levi Starbuck, of New-Bedford, Capt. MELLON, from New-Bedford, five days out, bound for the Pacific, captured Nov. 2, in lat. 35 30'. lon. 66 , by the Confederate steamer Alabama. The Alabama took all the clothing and nautical instruments from the vessel, and then set her on fire.
The Philadelphia Press has the following special dispatch:

The Speaker laid before the House a message recommending that JOHN L. WORDEN receive the thanks of Congress by resolution, for his gallant conduct on the Monitor, in combat with the Merrimae, such thanks being necessary, under the law, to advance him one grade on the naval list of officers of the navy. Referred to the Committee on Naval Affairs.

A splendid audience thronged the Academy of Music last evening, on the occasion of a meeting under the auspices of the Woman's Central Association of Relief, in aid of the United States Sanitary Commission. The stage was filled with distinguished gentlemen of all the professions. Mayor OPDYKE presided, and, after a neat introductory address, introduced the various speakers, first of whom was Rev. Dr. BELLOWS.

SUPPOSED POISONING OF THREE SEA CAPTAINS IN CUBA.--JOHN M. GRIFFIN, first mate, and THOMAS LEE, cook, of the bark Belsey Williams, arrived here yesterday in the steamship Eagle, Capt. ADAMS, from San Juan Remedios, Cuba, having been sent hither by the American Consul at that place as prisoners. They are charged with having poisoned three successive Captains of the bark Betsey, Williams, while the lay in the port of San Juan Remedios.

The message of Gov. VANCE, of North Carolina, to the General Assembly, dated Nov. 17, has been received here. It is very lengthy and betrays nothing like Union sentiments, but appeals to that stern and determined devotion to our cause, which can alone sustain a revolution. He reflects severely upon the Confederate Conscript law, and bitterly denounces the spirit of speculation and extortion ...
The steamship Marion arrived at this port last night, from New-Orleans on the 4th inst.

The Annual Convention of the delegates belonging to the "National Association of Base Ball Players," was held in the Lecture-room at Clinton Half, last evening. The President, D. MILLIKEN, of the Union Club, (Morrisania,) occupied the Chair, and J.R. POSTLY, Esq., acted as Secretary.
Our island has been so barren of events of any distant importance for a long time, that silence has bean clearly the greater wisdom.

The steamship Kangaroo, from Liverpool on the 26th ult., arrived at this port last night. Her advices are not so late as had already been received. The mails by the steamship Arabia reached this City from Boston last evening. The summary of her news was telegraphed from Halifax, and contained everything of importance.

A city soulless, rent by wrack of war, and shooting up in flames athwart night's sky, is the pretty little antique spot by the Rappahannock, erewhite the peculiar scene of dignified case and retirement.

Attorney-General BATES, in a case officially submitted to him, has pronounced that the law confining the command of American coasters to American citizens, does not exclude colored masters. This is equivalent to declaring that black men map be citizens of the United States, and that the dicta to the contrary in the Dred Scott case are incorrect. We say the dicta and not the decision itself.

HOVEY was famously gazetted quite recently for having captured Grenada, Miss.--one of the most valuable railroad centres of the rebels.

In this Court yesterday, JACOB PICININI, a native of Italy, 36 years of age, was tried and convicted of grand larceny from JAMES FEEHAN, of 473 Broadway. The prisoner was remanded for sentence on Saturday.

In accordance with the announcement which appeared in the papers on Monday morning, a large number of clergymen belonging to this and adjoining cities met at room No. 24 Cooper Institute, at 7 o'clock last evening, to take some action regarding the National crisis, Rev. Dr. FERRIS occupied the chair. Among those assembled were about a dozen ladies, and probably the same number of laymen, attracted thither out of curiosity.

One of the most busy departments of the military service just now is that of the Medical Director, Surgeon McDOUGALL. Most of the hospitals under his charge are full, and with the exception of Fort Schuyler, Governor's Island, and a few other smaller hospitals, no more sick and wounded can be accommodated. There are at present over seven thousand under treatment.
The battle of Fredericksburgh, which has been raging since 10 o'clock this morning, without a moment's pause, was closed by darkness to-night.

The attention of the musical public is respectfully invited to the very valuable improvement recently made by HORATIO WORCESTER, in the construction of the piano forte, and for which letters patent have been granted.

After a somewhat tedious march of three days --over numerous streams and muddy roads--we have arrived at the point indicated above. No incident of importance has transpired since we left Fairfax Court-house and Centreville, except that at Dumfries, HAMPTON'S Legion made a dash into the town, early Friday morning, and captured the telegraph operator, Mr. LAME, of Boston, Lieut. BOWERS and fourteen men, of the Third Virginia Cavalry, seventeen loaded and seven empty Sutlers' wagons.

Early yesterday morning the enemy appeared roaming over the plain vacated by us the night previous. Sharpshooters were thrown down near the river bank to pick off the engineers employed on the pontoons, which, though taken up, had not been mounted on the wagons. They also attempted to plant a battery on a woody crest about half a mile back from the Barnard House.

We have tried, and for the moment failed. But no time should be lost in trying again, on some other line. We cannot afford to lose the Winter in idle repining. Our armies, in all probability, will never again be so strong as now. Volunteering has substantially ceased. Conscription seems to have about finished its work. Every army, without new recruits, constantly and rapidly grows weaker by disease, even without battle.

TESTIMONY OF BRIG.-GEN. RUFUS KING. I have served about a year under Gen. McDowell--first as commander of a brigade, and afterward as commander of a division. One of my brigades was posted in Fredericksburgh, and three toward the river. Gen. Patrick was Military Governor. I do not recollect the instructions issued with regard to passes.

We cannot help wondering oftentimes at the excessive audacity in falsehood, which we cannot avoid observing. It prevails everywhere, but especially is politics. One would have said that the political untruth which had disgraced this country in years past could not be excelled this side the bottomless pit. But the rebellion has given increased virulence to it.

Hon. Horatio Ballard, Secretary of State: MY DEAR SIR: To serve our country in any hour of peril has been my highest ambition. I have looked fondly in many distant climes upon the emblem of her greatness, power and glory floating from the masthead, and ever with the determination that it should never be sullied, if my life could avert such a calamity.

Personal security is not to be numbered among the blessings which foreigners enjoy in Japan. Whatever disposition the Government of the Tycoon may have to protect them, there can be no doubt that the Princes and their followers regard outside barbarians with aversion, and avail themselves of every opportunity to give vent to their animosity.

NEW-JERSEY REGIMENTS.--The Ninth NewJersey Regiment has had its scattered companies consolidated at Newbern, N.C. Col. HEEKHAN, of the Ninth, is in command of a brigade in Gen. FOSTER'S department. Lieut. Col. WILSON, also of the Ninth, has resigned, and several other officers of the regiment have been discharged for disability, caused by the severe and harassing duty they have performed.

SENTENCES IN THE COURT OF SESSIONS.-- GEORGE PRICE, colored, was brought up on Friday on an indictment for manslaughter in the fourth degree, in causing the death of MICHAEL FARRELL by stabbing him with a butcher's knife in the abdomen. He pleaded guilty.

A brief dispatch in yesterday's TIMES announced the resignation of Secretary SEWARD. We give elswhere such information on the subject as has reached us. The resignation, it is un derstood, has not been accepted by the President, although tendered with the request that it might be accepted immediately.

The London Times of this morning copies a report that certain New-York merchants have talked of fitting out a piratical steamer to capture British merchant ships. That such a thing has been talked about, in Wall-street, as a good offset to the Alabama, is not unlikely.
Rourke vs. Duffy.--This was an appeal from the Eighth District Court. The plaintiff sued the defendant for a balance, which he alleged to be due to him upon an excavation of rock.

The following has just been received at the Headquarters of the Army of the United States: Maj.-Gen. Halleck, General-in-Chief, Washington: I have the honor to inform you that I left Newbern for this place on the 11th instant, but that owing to the bad roads and consequent delays to my trains, etc., I did not reach Southwest Creek, five miles from this town, until the afternoon of the 13th instant. Yesterday morning, about daylight, about 100 of HAMPTON'S rebel cavalry entered Occoquan and captured a Lieutenant and thirty privates of the Tenth New-York Cavalry, who were guarding the telegraph lines. Eleven sutlers and six sutlers wagons were also seized by the rebels.

The City of Brooklyn is one of the most orderly and quiet cities in the Union. Its inhabitants include people of every nationality and of every grade of life, with every disposition of good or evil as in the citizens of other places, but for some reason not clearly perceptible there are fewer rows and less trouble there than in any place of equal size in Chritencom.

The receipts of the principal kinds of Produce, since our last have been: 32 bbls. Ashes 14,287 bbls. Flour, 101 bbls. and 933 bags Corn Meal, 3,300 bushels Wheat, 128 bushels Corn, 12,346 bushels Barley, 3,000 bushels Malt, 25,916 bushels Oats, 5,156 pkgs. Provisions, and 769 bbls. Whisky.

A member of Congress has given notice of his intention to bring in a bill, giving soldiers and officers convicted by Courts-martial the right of appeal at any time within six months after receiving sentence, and giving the President the power of ordering a new trial. If we concurred in the principle of this bill, we should object to it on the ground that it does not go far enough.

The political thunder gust seems nearly spent, which, for a few days past, has agitated with tempestuous emotion the Senate, the Cabinet and the President. There is now every reason to believe that to-morrow's sun will set, if it do not rise, in a sky purified of vapors, and serenly emiling promises of peace.

The announcements at the various places of amusement are more than usually interestinig to night. Mr. WERATLEY, the spirited manager of Niblo's Garden, will produce a new version of "Faust and Marguerite," for the purpose of introducing Mr. J. R. ROBERTS, a gentleman who has won much distinction as Mephistophiles.

U.S. steam transport Thames, Arey, Port Royal 16th inst., in ballast to U.S. Quartermaster. The steamer Jersey Blue, hence, arrived 15th in a disabled condition, and would proceed no further; the steamer Quincy had repaired, and gld. 15th; the Quinnebaug was still in port. Nothing new had transpired since last advices.

A body of rebel cavalry, variously estimated at from 2,000 to 8,000, made a raid on the railroad three miles this side of Jackson, Tenn., yesterday morning. After firing into a train, they tore up the track for a considerable distance, and burned a long trestle-work. The operator at Trenton this evening reports an attack on that place. There has even been considerable excitement at Columbus, in anticipation of a rebel visit to that place.

The Sixtieth Anniversary of the Philolexian Society of Columbia College was the occasion of the assembling of over two thousand five hundred of the elite of our City at Irving Hall, on Friday evening last. The Hall was crowded to its utmost capacity, and many were unable to obtain admittance.
The price of the NEW-YORK TIMES (Daily) hereafter will be THREE Cents, except of the Sunday, morning edition, which will be FOUR Cents.

The "Hall of the Union," Cooper Institute, was filled to repletion last evening by a most intelligent audience, fully one-half of whom were ladies, brought hither to hear the views of Hon. GERRITT SMITH touching the connection of Slavery with the rebellion. OLIVEE JOHNSON, Esq., editor of the Anti-Slavery Standard, presided, and the proceedings were enlivened by choice selections of vocal and instrumental music by Father EZMP'S band of "Old Folks".

One of the many delusions of the Southern people has been that the white man, by his own labor, could not raise cotton and sugar, and hence the necessity of negro Slavery to retain the valuable crops as part of the agricultural wealth of the country.

The gunboat Marmora arrived to-day from Yazoo River. She brings the crew of the Cairo, which gunboat was destroyed by a torpedo, twenty-one miles up the Yazoo. Friday last, at noon. In a reconnoissance made up the Yazoo some time ago, by the Marmora and Signal, torpedoes were discovered in the river, two miles below Horn's Bluff, where the rebels have a battery of four or five guns.

Our Havana correspondent gives an interesting account of the arrival there of the new CaptainGeneral of Cuba, DULCE, which event took place on the 9th instant, although he did not make his public entry into the city until the 11th. His predecessor, Gen. SERRANO, took his departure a day or two afterward. The addresses delivered on the two occasions are given in our correapondent's letter. PIERRE SOULE is now a resident of Havana.

Affairs at the Brooklyn Navy-yard are exceedingly brisk, over five thousand men being employed, many of them by night and day. The caulkers, especially, are kept busy incessantly. The different houses and shops, of which hardly more than a single department of each was used in time of peace, prove too small for the exigencies of war.

Steamship Bavaria, (Hamb.,) Weler. Hamburg Nov. 30. and Southampton Dec. 3. with mdse and 167 passengers to Kunhardt Co. Had heavy westerly gales, with a great deal of snow and heavy head sea, during the passage. Arrived off Sandy Hook this morning, at 7 A.M. and off the Battery at 8 A.M.

It will be seen from the Richmond newspaper account of the battle at Fredericksburgh, that while Gen. LEE, in his official report, places their loss at 1,800 killed and wounded, the same papers containing it say that up to Monday, 2,000 Confederate wounded had arrived in Richmond, and mention many more at Fredericksburgh depot, drenched with rain and unprovided for.

The Sons of New-England held their annual festival at the Astor House last evening. At 7 o'clock the three large tables running the entire length of the dining-room were filled with the members of the Society and the prominent natives of New-England residing in or transiently stopping in New-York. NEWBERN, N.C., Tuesday, Dec. 16--3 o'clock P.M. On the 11th instant, Major-Gen. FOSTER left Newbern with an adequate and well appointed force, and proceeded toward Goldsboro.
Mr. SHEFFIELD, of Rhode Island, (Union,) presented the credentials of Hon. MICHAEL HAHN, Representative elect from the First Congressional District of Louisiana.

The United States mail steamship Union. THOS. W. WILSON, commander, from Havana Dec. 15, 3 P. M., arrived here yesterday. She left in the harbor of Havana the United States steamers Wachusett and Sonoma, of Admiral WILKES' squadron.
The Board met pursuant to adjournment in their Chamber, No. 16 City Hall.

In the Senate yesterday, a message was received from the President, transmitting the report of Hon. REVERDY JOHNSON, as Commissioner to New-Orleans. The House resolution, to adjourn over for the holidays, was concurred in. Kane, upon defendant, payable to the order of Edith Kane, the wife of the drawer, three, four, and six months after date, respectively, and indorsed by her and duly accepted by the drawer before maturity.

In the engagement at Kinston, on the 14th, Company K, Third New-York Cavalry, Capt. COLE, which was in the advance, charged over four deep ditches, eight feet wide, and captured seen pieces of rebel artillery, bringing them off in triumph.

Adolphene Kluender vs. James Lynch, Sheriff, plaintiff sues to recover the value of the contents of a cigar store, recently owned by her, as claimed, at No. 78 Bowery. Mrs. Kluender claims that the cigar store was her separate property, and that the defendant wrongfully seized upon its contents and carried them away.

The schooner Mary E. Mangum, HALLETT, from Dominica in twenty-five days, reports that on the night of Nov. 27, while entering the port of Rosean, Dominica, she was fired into by the rebel steamer Alabama. She fired two shots at her and then steered away. Dec. 1, at night, when passing the Island of Guadaloupe saw the Alabama making signals to the shore. Next day saw her anchored close in shore, apparently receiving provisions.

Annually the children of Plymouth Church Sunday School have a jolly good time on Christmas. This year they give a Christmas entertainment in the Church, when there will be singing, declaiming, and various other interesting performances, not to mention an address from HENRY WARD BEECHER.

The war needs many amendments doubtless; but the prime one is this: the people must deal more fairly by the Government, and the Government more fairly by the people. The Government and the people have reciprocal rights and duties. These must be better observed on both sides, or failure is inevitable.

Last night Mr. STUART opened at the Brooklyn Academy with Mr. BOOTH in "Ruchelieu." The house was crowded with an appreciative audience, very many of whom went from this City, tempted by the beauty of the night and their devotion to the star of the evening.

In this Court, yesterday, Julius J. Smith was tried and convicted of obtaining eighty odd dollars from Rachael Stoesser. The prisoner was remanded for sentence.

A reconnoissance last night by a squadron of the Third North Carolina Cavalry, under Capt. CARROWAY, found the enemy encamped about two miles below Whitehall. The citizens represent them as scared and out of food and ammunition. A rumor on the streets this morning says reinforcements have passed Kinston, on the south side of the Neuse, to succor their skedaddling friends.
My expedition was a perfect success. I burned the railroad bridge at Goldsboro and Mount Olive, and tore up several miles of the track of the Wilmington and Weldon Railroad.

A supplementary dispatch from Gen. FOSTER has been received by the Government to-day, in regard to the capture of Goldsboro, in which he states that the rebels are reported to be advancing upon him in heavy force, estimated at 25,000, for the purpose of driving him from his position. He is confident of his ability successfully to resist until reinforcements can reach him.

Mr. PENDLETON, of Ohio, (Dem.,) rising to a privileged question, moved that the protest he offered yesterday, against the passage of the bill indemnifying the President and others for arrests under the suspension of the writ of habeas corpus, be entered upon the journal. This he said was embodied in his resolution a part of which only appeared in the journal.

CHRISTMAS AT THE INSTITUTIONS--Through the liberality of the Commissioners of Charities, who have voted to the several charitable institutions sums of money, with which to supply some extra luxuries to the inmates, they will all have a holiday.

THE FINANCIAL PROJECT OF SECRETARY CHASE. Secretary CHASE has sent to Representative STEVENS his financial project, recommending a loan of nine hundred millions of dollars, at rates of interest not exceeding those now authorized by law. The Secretary does not suggest any augmentation of Treasury notes. The Committee of Ways and Means have not yet considered the subject.

NATHAN BREED, Jr., proprietor of a respectable grocery store in Lyan, Mass., was murdered last night by a young man named HORACE DAVIS. The murder was perpetrated in the store with a hatchet, while Mr. BREED was engaged in putting up some article which DAVIS had called for. DAVIS has been arrested.

In the absence, for the present, of more exciting news, it may, perhaps, be well to say something of regal cotton. After having spent months in offering inky incense to red-browed Mars, it is no more than right to pay one's duty to the white-headed monarch, to whom Manchester, Jewery, and the hungry and speculating world, generally, pine to pay allegiance.

Advices have been received from Gen. CURTIS, from Brig.-Gen. DAVIES, commanding at Columbus, Ky., to the effect that he is receiving reinforcements in ample season to prepare against the contingencies of an attack upon that place by the rebels. Gen. DAVIES thinks, however, no attack is meditated by them.

Richmond papers contain a dispatch from Charleston, dated 19th, announcing that a very large steamer, freighted for the Confederate States Government, safely arrived yesterday at a Southern port, bringing a heavy stock of shoes and blankets, an immense quantity of cloth, and other supplies.

The Children's Christmas festival took place yesterday afternoon at Trinity Church. The Rev. Dr. OGILBY, delivered a brief address to the children, after which the Christmas Carol was sung, at the end of each chorus the bells chiming in as an echo with delicious effect. A large Christmas tree was exhibited in the middle porch, brilliantly lighted, and laden with presents, each Sundayschool scholar received one, and left the church perfectly happy.

--John A. Tainter, who died in Hartford, Conn., a few weeks ago, left all his property, about $1,000,000, to his wife and two daughters. In his will he forbids either of his daughters to marry a foreigner or a native of a Southern or slaveholding State, under penalty of forfeiting her interest in the property.

His Excellency, Gov. STEPHEN S. HARDING, has issued a proclamation to the inhabitants of the Territory, setting apart Thursday, Jan. 1, as a day of thanksgiving and praise to Almighty God for his mercies to us as a people.

Another great battle has been fought in Northwestern Arkansas. The speculations of your correspondent, concerning the probability of an immediate, uninterrupted advance to Fort Smith, were premature. The battle of Cane Hill was not decisive.

In the revulsion of 1857, Chicago, as well as all the Western towns, received a severe blow. Speculation had carried the price of everything--real estate particularly--to such a height that the sudden fall was terribly crushing to thousands of our citizens. Then came two years of poor crops throughout the West, adding greatly to our embarrassments. We were recovering slowly from the effects of these,

The circumstances connected with the case are of such a nature that the Government should feel bound to demand an immediate explanation, and unless it be clearly shown that a breach of orders has been committed, retaliatory measures should at once be instituted.

HAVRE COTTON MARKET.--The sales of Cotton for the week foot up 13,000 bales, the market ruling active and buoyant, with a demand for all descriptions at full previous prices. Stock in port, 51,000 bales. PARIS, Saturday.--The Bourse is steady. Rentes 70f. 65c.
Coroner COLLIN yesterday held an inquest at Bellevue Hospital, on the body of MICHAEL HANEY, who was fatally stabbed in the neck, by a knife said to be in the hands of OWEN KEEFE.

Lieut.-Col. STIETSELL, of the Eleventh Pennsylvania Cavalry, Col. SPEAR'S regiment, had a warm engagement with the enemy at Joiner's Bridge, on the Blackwater, yesterday, four miles above Franklin. They drove the enemy's pickets on this side of the river, capturing four of their pickets, one cavalryman and horse, and three infantry soldiers and their arms.

In the McKinstry Court-Martial at St. Louis, on Tuesday, Gen. HARNEY was called by the defence. After several preliminary questions, he was asked: Was or was not the performance of duty here by yourself and staff, on the breaking out of the rebellion, attended with great difficulty in consequence of persons not connected with the War Department claiming and exercising control over yourself and staff?

Gen. SIGEL, in his cross-examination, having desired to give some explanations of his previous testimony, Gen. McDOWELL, objected, and the Court went into secret session. Upon reopening, the Court decided that Gen. SIGEL, might make corrections of what he had already said, but that other explanations must be deferred until the close of the cross-examination.

Whitlock vs. Benton, Auditor.--In this case, the Court below held that the authority given to the Canal Board to appoint Collectors of Tolls is not limited by any provision respecting the place where the persons appointed shall reside or have their office. FINAL MEETING OF THE BROOKLYN COMMON COUNCIL. The final meeting of the Common Council for the present year was held yesterday afternoon, the object being to confirm the appointment of Commissioners of Deeds for 1863. The names of 104 were presented, when Alderman STRONG moved that all whose names appeared on the list of last year be reappointed, which was adopted. The Board then adjourned sine die.
Information from Corinth to Saturday night states that the garrison at that place were on halfrations. Foraging parties, however, were able to supply the deficiency.

The Board of Aldermen met at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon, and concurred in making the appropriations (amounting to $47,197,06, and chiefly for interest on the Family Aid and Union Defence Fund bonds) which the Comptroller recently discovered had been omitted at the time the regular appropriation bill was passed. The Mayor's veto on the resolution increasing the salaries of the Police Justices to $5,000 per annum, was taken up and overruled.

INTERNAL REVENUE TAX NEWWARK. The books of Mr. GEo. A. HALSEY, Assessor for the Fifth District of New-Jersey, comprising Essex and Hudson Counties, show the following totals of taxes assessed on manufacturers products the same being exclusive of the tax for licenses: September, 65,000; October, $74,000; November, $65,000. Of the above, the highest amounts paid are for ale and beer, some manufacturers paying $3,000 per month.

The following is a special dispatch to the Commercial: NEAR MURFREESBORO, Tenn., Tuesday, Dec. 30. The Fourteenth Army Corps made a general advance yesterday, and pushed the rebels back seven or eight miles. COLLINS' Brigade, of Gen. McCook's Corps, had a sharp brush with the enemy just beyond Nolinsville. Cannonading took place for an hour, the enemy wasting considerable ammunition.
The steamship Etna, Capt. BROOKS, from Liverpool on the 17th ult., calling at Queenstown on the 18th, arrived at this port yesterday.
A reconnoissance in force went out yesterday morning, which will probably be heard from in a few days.

In our review, yesterday, of our military successes during the year that has closed, it was made very apparent that the rebellion could not survive another twelvemonth of similar experience. It was shown that the reduction of a like amount of territory to the old flag in 1863, as in 1862, would literally wipe the Confederacy from the face of the earth.

Our advices from Tennessee, this morning, are extremely important. Gen. ROSECRANS made a general advice with his army on Monday, against the rebel army at Murfreesboro, and at last accounts up to Tuesday, heavy fighting was going on at various points. The rebels were pushed back seven or eight miles on Monday, a portion of Gen. McCOOK's Corps having a sharp brush with the enemy beyond Nolinsville.

The examination of Brig.-Gen. Charles Griffin was resumed: To the Judge-Advocate At the time we halted on the Gainesville road, as I stated in my evidence, a trooper came up and said," Look out! a man has been taken in front," referring to a cavalrymen. I asked what forces we had in front; he said none, a few cavalry, referring to our forces.

Our little island was thrown into a very unusual state of excitement on Thursday morning, the 18th, by the arrival of the transport steamer Cosmopolitan, with the Forty-seventh Regiment of Pennsylvania Volunteers, Col. T.H. GOODE, from Hilton Head, sent here by order of Brig. Gen. BRANNAN, to take the place of the Ninetieth Regiment New-York Volunteers, Col. Jos. S. MORGAN, in the garrisons of this place and Fort Jefferson.

A steamer from below reports that the gunboats accompanying Gen. SHERMAN'S Expedition have gone up the Yazoo River. At Drumingol's Bluff. twenty miles above the mouth, a rebel battery was discovered. A severe cannonado followed, during which the gunboat Benton was struck sixteen times, the shots penetrating.

The Emancipation Proclamation of President LINCOLN was given to the world on the 1st inst., and has probably been already perused by the great majority of readers in the loyal States. It declares the freedom of all slaves in those portions of the country now in armed rebellion against the Government. Those portions comprise the States of Arkansas, Texas. Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama, Florida, Georgia, South Carolina, North Carolina and Virginia, excepting

THE ARRIVAL OF GEN. BUTLER. The arrival of Gen. BUTLER this evening, accompanied by Col. SHAEFER and other members of his Staff, caused a very decided sensation, and his rooms at the National Hotel were immediately besieged by numbers of people anxious to see and hear the man who succored Washington, captured Baltimore, and evangelized New-Orleans. He was visible to very few, however, as his duty called him early in the evening

Gen. BUTLER'S farewell address to the people of New-Orleans will command general attention. It is brief, forcible and patriotic. It breathes the spirit of conscious rectitude of purpose, and of substantial and triumphant success. By reference to results, Gen. BUTLER vindicates the general tenor of his rule, and no one who has followed carefully and dispassionately the history of his administration will question the truth of his claims.
A regular monthly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce was held yesterday, President PHLATIAH PERIT, Esq., in the Chair. About twenty members were in attendance.
The cross-examination of Gen. SIGEL was resumed:

About 8 o'clock on Thursday evening, a fire was discovered in the extensive cracker baker establishmeet of Mr. JOHN T. WILSON, situated at No.73 Fulton-street, and owing to the combustible nature of the material of which the stock in the building was composed, the flames spread with alarming rapidity, and very soon, not only Mr. WILSON'S building, but others in the immediate vicinity, were found to be on fire.

The United States steam transport R.S. Spaulding, Capt. S. HOWES, arrived at this port Thursday, from New-Orleans, which port she sailed from Dec. 24. She brings as passengers Maj.-Gen. BUTLER and Staff, and a number of officers attached to Gen. BUTLER's command.
Our whole line suffered terribly this morning. Four regiments of regulars lost half their men and all their commanding officers.
The day has been unmarked by any movement of importance. The officers of the various Corps have exchanged the ceivilities of the day.

The Anti-Administration journals of this City have prophecied cunningly since the result of the late election, concerning the probable action of Gov. SEYMOUR in reference to the support of the National Administration, and to other matters more local.

Gov. SEYMOUR was inaugurated yesterday. Aside from the general public interest belonging to the occasion, his political friends gathered in unusual numbers and gave special brilliancy to the ceremony. His inaugural address, as well as the words of welcome addressed to him by Gov. MORGAN, will be found in another column.

The Federals encountered the rebels on the 30th ult., near Stewart's Creek. After heavy skirmishing, the rebels were driven back. We captured one hundred prisoners, and killed and wounded a large number of rebels. Our loss was seventy killed and wounded.

This is a dull Christmas, truly. The sun shines beautifully overhead; the air is balmy as June; it is, moreover, a day that should ever be joyous. Yet the Union people of New-Orleans are dispirited and dull. The papers of the 16th have reached us, and again have our gallant armies received a repulse on the way to Richmond. Comment is useless, complaint is of no avail, to despair would be criminal; we must, therefore,

The last day of the old year went out in quiet all over the great theatre of military operations excepting in Middle Tennessee. But there, on that day, one of the greatest, and we judge it will prove to be the very greatest battle yet known in the Southwest, was fought. The only other Southwestern battle that equals it in the magnitude of the

The prophecies of thousands were proved false when, on the morning of the New Year, the sun peeped above the horizon of the East, bright and clear. The atmosphere, the cloudless sky, the well-cleaned pavements, proved together a strong temptation to many who had predetermined that calling was a bore, and that home was the best place, after all.
The American's correspondent at Suffolk announces the arrival there of Gen. CORCORAN with his entire brigade. He is to take command there.

In the absence of later intelligence from Murfreesboro, we subjoin the special dispatches to the Philadelphia Press, of yesterday. They furnish some items of interest, although the statements made do not fully coincide with other reports:
A dispatch to the Press, dated Fortress Monroe, Jan. 1, says:

The British steamship Peru, from Valparalso and intermediate ports, arrived at Panama on the 22d. She brings dates from Valparaiso and Santiago de Chili to the 2d of December, from Bolivia to the latter part of November, Callao and Lima to Dec. 14, and from Ecuador to Dec. 16.

At the time of going to press this morning, our latest advices from the Murfreesboro battle-field are to the afternoon of Friday--the third day of the tremendous struggle. Our troops were then apparently in possession of Murfreesboro. Gen. ROSKCRANS had reorganized his forces during the previous night, and on Friday he had driven the enemy nearly two miles. Reinforcements were arriving, and the prospect, on the whole, looked favorable.

--Among the passengers hither by the Scotia the other day, was Mr. THOMAS SILORR, a noted English engineer and inventor. Mr. SILORR purposes to establish, a line of large Transatlantic Express Steamers." to ply between New-York and Bristol, Eng.

I do not think that reflecting Englishmen are surprised at the feeling expressed by American papers, since the postponement of the French proposal for joint intervention. Well-informed Englishmen understand the motives of the Government, and they give Americans credit for some degree of "cuteness." It has never been concealed that the disruption of the Union sent a thrill of joy through the governing classes of English society.

The price of the NEW-YORK TIMES (Daily) hereafter will be THREE Cents, except of the Sunday morning edition, which will be FOUR Cents.

The New-York Police Commissioners did not appear at 2 o'clock, and Gov. SEYMODE postponed the consideration of the matter until 6 o'clock, for the purpose of giving them opportunity to be heard should they so desire.

[In consequence of several serious blunders of the telegraph, the circumstantial and graphic account of the great battles before Murfreesborn, published in Saturday's TIMES, was very much confused and impaired. A series of conflicts, destined to have so important a bearing on the course of the war, deserves a clearer chronicle, and we republish the letter of our correspondent, with the proper corrections, today.--ED. TIMES.]

The Message of GOV. GAMBLE, of Missouri, opens by congratulating the Legislature and the State that at last a loyal General Assembly is convened. After describing the treachery by which the State was pushed into rebellion, he reviews the military efforts of Missouri, which now has in service for the war 38,031 loyal soldiers. The State debt is now $24,734,000.

It being generally believed that Gen. B.F. BUTLES would be serenaded to-night, there was a large crowd in and around the National Hotel. There were also several thousand persons in the vicinity, waiting over two hours. Gen. BUTLER dined with Secretary SEWARD, and returned to his hotel at 10 o'clock. In obedience to the voctferous calls of the crowd, Gen. BUTLEE appeared on the balcony of the ladies' parlor, and spoke as follows:

About 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon a fire occurred in the Petroleum or Kerosene Oil Manufactory of JOHN REED, Jr., No. 190 Duane-street. The alarm was promptly given, and the firemen were immediately on hand, but owing to the combustible nature of the stock in the building, the entire premises were soon destroyed.

We have no local news of special importance. The Legislature of the State having insisted upon its vote to raise $34,000 by a forced loan. Gov. DEAS resigned his office. Subsequently the vote was reconsidered, and the Governor withdrew his resignation, and was regularly installed as Chief of the State.

The Panama Railroad Company's steamer Guatemala arrived at Panama, from Central American ports, on the 20th. Dates are to the middle of the month. The news is of but little importance.

GENERAL: The Stars and Stripes now wave in triumph over Van Buren. On learning that HINDMAN had been reinforced, and contemplated making another attempt to force his way to Missouri. I determined to attack him. Leaving my transportation north of the mountains. I marched from Prairie Grove at 8 o'clock yesterday morning upon this place, a distance of fifty miles.
We have some interesting intelligence from a gentleman who arrived here yesterday morning from Winchester, which is once more under the flag of the Union.

There was, up to a late hour last evening. a painful suspense in regard to the result of the, great battle at Murfreesboro. Commencing with heavy skirmishing on the 30th ult., the conflict assumed the proportions of a gigantic and bloody battle that raged for eleven hours on the 31st.

The pleasant weather which we have been favored with for so many days, has at length been superseded by rain. This change in the weather will doubtless be accompanied by a change in the position of the troops, it having been frequently observed that marching orders usually follow a rain storm.

On Saturday the enemy made four desperate attempts to force our lines on the Chickasaw Bluffs, with heavy loss. The Seventeenth Louisiana greatly distinguished itself, repulsing, unaided, the assault of three full regiments of Yankees.

Sales of Cotton to-day, 5,000 bales, including 2,000 to speculators and exporters. Market flat, and quotations barely maintained.

The opening of the opera season at the Academy, of Music tonight is, of course, the principal event of the present week. It is rendered more than ordinarily interesting from the circumstance that Miss KELLOGG makes her rentree on the occasion in a new role, and during the season makes her farewell appearances under Mr. GRAU'S management.

Everything is quiet and unchanged. Richmond papers of the 3d inst., contain dispatches from Murfreesboro of the 1st. BRAGG says the expedition under Gen. FORREST fully accomplished its object. The railroads are broken in several places. A large amount of stores have been destroyed, many arms captured and 1,200 prisoners paroled.

A steamship Asia arrived at this port yesterday, with advices from Europe to the 21st ult.-- three days later than by the Etna. The news is not important. The report of the burning of the ship Harriet Spaulding by the Alabama proves to have been unfounded, she having arrived in safety at Havre.

Official dispatches from Gen. ROSECRANS, published this morning, put at rest all doubts of the fact that the rebels have suffered a defeat at Murfreesboro. Congress was again in session yesterday, the holiday recess being over. In the Senate, a joint resolution of the Legislature of Connecticut was presented, requesting a modification of the Internal Revenue law, so as to prevent the accumulation of taxes on the same article in different processes of maufacture.

The ill effects of Gov. SEYMOUR's first move against the Police Commissioners are already painfully manifest. Insubordination on the part of some of the men, and irreverence for the Police authority on the part of the liquor dealers being the more immediate and most observable consequences.

The Tribune and TIMES are members of the Press Association, One of the rules of that body prescribes that whatever news may be received by telegraph, except from certain designated points, shall be shared in common--each paper paying its proportion of the expense. On Saturday morning, under this rule, we received from the Tribune certain dispatches from Nashville, in time to publish them in a small part of our edition of that morning.

Probably half the people of New-York are yet unaware that there is a political territorial organism in the United States called Colorado, which is rapidly rising to the proportions of a State, and is even now contributing largely to the National wealth. Many of those who have heard of the Territory, have simply a cloudy and undefined idea that it is situated somewhere beyond the great plains and in the region of the Rocky Mountains.

We have done injustice to Gov. SEYMOUR, and we hasten to correct it. We assumed that in summoning the Police Commissioners to appear before him on Saturday at 2 o'clock, to answer charges preferred against them, be intended to fix that time for hearing and deciding them.

The Memphis Bulletin, just received, says the steamer Rattler has arrived direct from the fleet at Vicksburgh, which place she left on Monday evening.

We learn from Albany that the Republican Caucus met in the Assembly Chamber, yesterday, and nominated HENRY SHERWOOD, of Steuben, as candidate for Speakership, and JOSEPH B. CUSHMAN, of Oneida, for Clerk. The Democratic Caucus nominated Hon. GILBERT DEAN, of NewYork, for Speaker.

Never in hot political campaigns, not upon any other occasion capable of attracting an immense crowd, were so many people bent upon forming a single congregation as those who last night strove to form the auditory in the spacious hall of the Cooper Institute, where joyous notes of jubilee echoed to the edict of negro emancipation.

To H.W. Halleck, General-in-Chief, Washington: On the 26th of December we marched from Nashville, in three columns. Gen. McCOOK by Nolinsville Pike; Gen. THOMAS from his encampment on Franklin's Pike, via Wilson Pike, and Gen. CRITTENDEN on the main Murfreesboro Pike.
There was a terrific rain-storm here yesterday. Almost every brook was flooded, but owing to a strong wind prevailing after the storm our operations have not been materially impeded.

The fighting at Murfreesboro closed with the close of the last week. The serious work extended only over Wednesday, Thursday and Friday, though there was heavy skirmishing for several days preceding the general actions, as well as on the Saturday following them. The result of the engagements was an undisputed victory to our army.

Interpose--that is the word. The State of New-Jersey is called upon by a piebald squad of Know-Nothings and Democrats to "interpose to arrest the existing civi1 war." In this there is nothing surprising. It has long been known that the breed of New-York politicians which furnished two Major-Generals to the rebel army, is not extinct.

Nothing new has, up to this date, reached us respecting operations up the river, the main body of the expedition being still here, massing, silently but surely, the forces that will soon fall like a thunderbolt upon the enemy, and clear the Mississippi in its entire length.

If the general accounts of the battle of Murfreesboro, in the absence of special details, are to be relied upon, we should have had no victory but for the admirable leadership of Gen. ROSECRANS. He was the master-spirit of the occasion--discovering every exigency with eagle glance, and doing on the instant the right thing to meet it.

The Annual Report of the Comptroller of the State, Hon. LUCIUS ROBINSON, has been received. It reviews briefly the financial policy of the State during the last four years; the enforced transition from prodigality to thrift in the management of the State

"NAPOLEON never, in all his bloody career, fought a hostile army intrenched in front of a fortified city, as McCLELLAN did at Richmond; or strongly fortified along a range of hills, with a non-fordable river a mile or so in front, like the position lately assailed by BURNSIDE at Fredericksburgh. He always found means to turn such defences, and compel their evacuation, as our Generals doubtless will in time."

If there were any lingering doubts of our success at Murfreesboro, they will be dispelled by the dispatch of Gen. ROSECRANS, published this morning. He informs Gen. HALLECK that we have been victorious in one of the greatest battles of the war. "Our entire success on the 31st ult.," he says, "was prevented by a surprise of the right flank, but we have, nevertheless, beaten the enemy after a three days' fight."

Both branches of the Legislature met at 11 o'clock yesterday forenoon. In the Senate, Lieutenant-Governor JONES, on assuming his duties as President, made a brief address, after which he announced his appointments of Sub-Officers. Committees were then appointed to notify the Governor and the Assembly that the Senate was ready to proceed to business. The daily sessions were fixed at 11 o'clock A.M., and the Senate soon afterward adjourned.

This morning, about 7 o'clock, an explosion took place in the percussion cap manufactory of Mr. GOLF, Sixty-second-street, between Tenth and Eleventh avenues, instantly killing one of the employes named WHIPPLE, and slightly injuring another of the workmen named ASTOR.

The People ex rel. Hermann Rothebilds vs. James Lynch, Sheriff.--The relator was imprisoned for contempt of Court, in refusing to comply with its order to pay to James V. Kearney. Receiver, $496.59, and delvier to him certain accounts. The relator, in October last, moved for his discharge. The case was then fully stated in the TIMES. All is quiet, as usual, in camp. Gen. STONEMAN'S Third Army Corps was reviewed yesterday, and Gen. WIZCOX'S Ninth Army Corps to-day. The appearance and condition of the troops were excellent. Gen. BURNSIDE and Staff were present on both occasions.
Michael Murphy vs. Antonio R. Fernandez.--This was a motion made on the part of the defendant to vacate an order of arrest.

AN ANIMATED TIME AND SPIRITED BIDDING. The members of Mr. BEECHER'S Church always make a marked occasion of their annual pew-renting. They assemble to have a pleasant, sociable time, and generally succeed. Their cheery pastor is sure to be present, seizing the opportunity to pay pastoral visits, and blending his bon mots with the business of the hour; while a general air of cordiality, good-feeling and liveliness pervades, which...

On motion of Mr. OLIN, New-York, (Rep.,) the Committee on Military Affairs were discharged from the further consideration of certain petitions asking for the introduction of the Homeopathic system of medicine in the army.

The battle began at 7 o'clock this morning and raged with great fury all day. We drove the enemy from all their positions except on the extreme left, where he successfully resisted us. With the exception of that point, we occupy the entire field. We have captured four thousand prisoners, including Brig.-Gen. WILLICH and FRY, thirty-one pieces of artillery, and about two hundred wagons and teams.

We meet under circumstances of unusual solemnity to legislate for the honor, for the interest and for the protection of the people of the State of New-York. The oath which we have taken, to support the Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of the State of New-York, and to perform our duties with fidelity, has at this time especial significance.

Trial Trip of the Weehawken--Experiment on the Patapace--The Nahans to Arrive Here To-day.

The receipts of the principal kinds of Produce, since our last, have been; 64 bbls. Ashes, 12,660 bbls. Flour, 148 bbls. and 839 bags Corn Meal, 90 bushels Rye, 2,525 bushels Barley, 16,383 bushels Oats, 3,690 bushels Malt, 6,408 pkgs. Privisions, and 941 bbls. Whisky.
Mr. TEN EYCK, of New-Jersey, (Rep.,) presented a petition in favor of a uniform Bankrupt law.

Lieut.-Col. Brinton, of the Second Pennsylvania Cavalry, was sworn for defence, and testified to the condition of the road from Warrenton Junction to Bristew Station on the night of August 27. He received an order from Gen. Porter at 12 o'clock at night to clear the road of wagons.

The steamer McClellan, Capt. GRAY, arrived here yesterday forenoon, with dates from New-Orleans to Saturday, Dec. 27.

The Washington correspondence of the Tribune announces that "Mr. VALLANDIGHAM will, in a few days, address the House in favor of foreign mediation as a means of settling the present National troubles." We are glad to hear it.
The steamship New-York, from Bremen, calling at Southampton on the 24th December, reached here yesterday morning.

The ob- ject of the expedition was to surround and capture rebel pickets in the vicinity of Richards' and Ellis'...

The Minnesota arrived here last evening at 6 o'clock.
Hon. WM. CLARK, elected from the Fifteenth District in place of Hon. JOHN WILLARD, deceased, appeared, was sworn, and took his seat.
We have one day's later intelligence from Vicksburgh, which is highly interesting and exciting.

The gunboat Pawnee left Philadelphia, on Tuesday, as convoy to the iron-clad Patapsco, bound to Fortress Monroe. The Hendrik Hudson, six guns, the Rover, seven guns, and the Lodona, converted from a prize, left the same port on the same day for the South.

The oath which we have taken, to support the Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of the state of New-York, and to perform our duties with fidelity, has at this time especial significance.
In the Senate, yesterday, notices were given of a number of bills, among them several to reimburse localities for moneys advanced to volunteers.

Gen. CARTER'S expedition reached Manchester, Ky., yesterday, on its return from East Tennessee. It left Landon, Ky., on the 21st ult. It comprised 1,000 cavalry. The results of the expedition are the destruction of two important bridges; the killing, wounding and capturing of 550 rebels;
Steamship Dudley Buck, Crane, Newbern, N.C., J.S. Whitney. Ships St. George, Cowen, New-Bedford, George Savery Co; Mary Ogden, Hathaway, San Francisco, Sutton Co.

Gov. SEYMOUR'S Message has made its appearance. There is nothing in it to revolutionize and very little to startle the country. For a document concerning which such extravagant expectations have been excited in advance, it is remarkably innocent and commonplace.

When Gen. BUTLER was withdrawn from the command at New-Orleans, the Administration was prompt to avow that no censure of that officer was intended, and that he would speedily be assigned to some other and important duty.

A special dispatch to the Commercial, from Murfreesboro, gives additional confirmation of the demoralization of the rebel army. BRECKINRIDGE'S di- vision whs terribly punished on Friday. Gen. BRECKINRIDGE was wounded in the ear, and his AdjutantGeneral killed. Wounded rebel officers estimate their loss at from 12,000 to 15,000, with a great slaughter of leading officers.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC. Although "La Traviata" was played here last evening as a hasty substitute for the "Sicilian Vespers" the change of programme being necessitated by the continued indisposition of Signor BRIGNOLI it was, we think, one of the best performances ever given under Mr. GRAU'S direction.
News from the rebel side relative to the fight at Murfreesboro is, in effect, that they have taken 4,000 prisoners and 26 guns.
The follow- ing extract of a letter from Washington conveys information of some importance concerning the efforts of the Navy Department to capture the rebel privateer Alabama.

Monday and Tuesday were spent, as you have been advised, in getting the army into line and securing positions. The great contest commenced on Wednesday morning, and the account of that day I send in full.
The Vice-President laid before the Senate a communication from the Secretary of the Navy, transmitting the correspondence and reports concerning the accident to the steam battery Passaic.

It was curious to note this morning how sanguine certain parties who, since the adjournment yesterday, had been hard at work in "fixing things" were that it has now "all right." Some were entirely confident that Mr. DEAN would be chosen Speaker before the voting had proceeded much ...

Our news from the scene of operations on the Mississippi River does not come very rapidly. The latest is up to Monday, the 29th of December ten days ago. At that time there had been nothing decisive, though the losses suffered give abundant indication of the great severity of the fighting ...

We have intelligence from Vicksburgh one day later than proviously published, which brings the lighting up to Tuesday, Dec. 30. The information corresponds very nearly with that contained in a rebel dispatch from Vicksburgh published in the Richmond papers, and reprinted in the TIMES ...

The Third Army Corps, commanded by Gen. STONEMAN, was reviewed to-day by Gen. BURNSIDE. The ceremony took place on an extended plateau near the camping ground of the troops, and was witnessed by a large number of officers from other corps. The men presented a fine appearance and gave evidence of a high state of discipline.

In the Senate, yesterday, after some business of minor importance, the petition of certain citizens of Maryland, asking for the repeal of the act abolishing Slavery in the District of Columbia, was reported back from the Judiciary Committee, with the recommendation that the prayer of the petitioners be not granted.

Gen. ROSECRANS is reported to credit his success against the rebels, in his well-fought battles around Murfreesboro, in a great degree to the timely cooperation of Gen. CARTER, who conducted a successful raid against the East ...

The screw-steamer City of Washington, Capt. MIREHOUSE, which left Liverpool at noon on the 24th, and Queenstown on the 25th of December, arrived here last night. Her news has already been received by telegraph from Cape Race, and her mails are no later than those by the NewYork, from Bremen and Southampton, which arrived here on Wednesday.
Richmond papers of the 6th inst. contain the following interesting items of news:
The Indiana Legislature convened this morning.

Quite a breeze has been stirred up in this capital by a recent difficulty between the English and American Ministers at this Court. The affair in question dates from a diplomatic reception at the house of the Russian Envoy, where it would seem that the English Representative, Mr. CHRISTIE, so far forgot the proprieties of the occasion, as to make use of language derogatory to the honor of our country.

After caucusing to a late hour last night, the members of the House came together this morning, actually no nearer, so far as the voting indicated anything, to an organization than before. There were, however, rumors afloat that the caucusing had resulted in an arrangement which would be developed before the adjournment, while others rather knowingly said, "Not yet."
Mr. WASHBURN, of Illinois, (Rep.,) introduced a bill to promote the efficiency of the Commissary Department. Referred to the Committee on Military Affairs.

FATAL AFFRAY IS THIRTY-SIXTH-STREET--ANTE-MORTEM EXAMINATION OF THE VICTIM.--Coroner WILDEY was yesterday called to the house No. 272 Mott-street, to take the ante-mortem examination of JOHN CONNOLLY, who was dangerously beaten on the night of the 1st instant, while in a drinking-place in Thirty-sixth-street, near First-avenue.

The ques tion has been very generally asked why Gen. BANKS, with his army and Com. FARRAGUT, with his gunboats, are not at Vickshurgh, to cooperate with Gen. SHERMAN in his attack upon that formidable position.

Secretary CHASE has prepared a finance bill for the Senate Finance Committee, to whom was referred the House joint resolution in regard to the immediate payment of the troops. The bill is designed to afford temporary relief to the Treasury, and provides for the issue of treasury notes and bonds to the amount of two hundred millions dollars.

[The following graphic and thrilling narrative of the great struggle of Wednesday, before Murfreesboro, was telegraphed to us so late on Wednesday night that it could appear in but a small portion of our morning edition of yesterday.--ED. TIMES.]

A dispatch from Gen. PEMBERTON, commanding the rebel forces at Vicksburgh, to the rebel War Department, announces that the National forces, finding all efforts unavailing to make any inroad upon the rebel position, had reembarked on the 2d inst., leaving a considerable quantity of intrenching tools and other property behind, and apparently relinquishing the design upon Vicksburgh.

There has been a good deal of talk in certain quarters about the Grand Jury of this County finding an indictment against EDWIN M. STANTON, Secretary of War, in connection with the alleged "arbitrary arrests," of which so much has been heard, and upon which Gov. SEYMOUR amplifies so largely in his Message.

President LINCOLN, in his Proclamation, declares that emancipated slaves "of suitable condition will be employed in the armed service of the United States." This declaration, made by the highest military authority, and announcing a policy which the Government has decided to adopt, renders it desirable that the public should look at the matter a little more attentively than it has yet done. To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your paper of the 1st inst. you refer your readers to a communication charging the Engineerin-Chief of the United States Navy with gross mismanagement, incompetency, and, in a disguised manner, with want of integrity in his official acts.
The usual quiet prevails throughout the camp. The Fifth Army Corps, Gen. MEADE, was reviewed to-day by Gen. BURNSIDE and Staff, who passed encomiums on the troops.

ELOPEMENT, CONSPIRACY AND ROBBERY.--A short time since a young man, named WILLIAM HOWARD, a paroled naval prisoner, was paid off at Washington the sum due him, amounting to about $700. From thence he proceeded to Baltimore, and took lodgings at a sailor's boarding-house, kept by a good-looking young woman named BRIDGET BROWN, and her husband.

Steamship City of Washington, Mirehouse, Liverpool Dec. 24, and Queenstown Dec. 25, with U.S. mails, 25 cabin and 94 Steerage passengers, all well. Experienced heavy westerly gales: landed telegrams, , at Cape Race Jan. 4, 1863, at 7 A.M. Same day, 50 miles west by south from Cape Race, passed an iceberg.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--Siguora LORINI will appear to-night as Leonore, in VERDI'S opera of "H. Trovatore." Being the last night of the season and the first appearance of a favorite artiste, there will undoubtedly be a fashionable and, we hope, a crowded house.

Yesterday, the first day of the new year, 1863, was an important day to the negroes here, and one of which they will long retain the remembrance as the first dawn of freedom. There are ten vessels blockading this port now, the steam sloops Brooklyn, Commodore BELL, the Oneida, Capt. JENKINS, the gunboat Pembina, Capt. W.G. TEMPLE, Kanawha, Aroostook, Pinola, Kennebeck, Pocahontas, and the purchased steamers R.R. Cuyler and Montgomery.
The Richmond Examiner, of the 6th inst., is received, containing the latest advices from Murfreesboro:
The President announced Messrs. FOLGER, MURPHY and ANGEL as a Special Committee to investigate the alleged frauds of engrossing the Militia bill of last year.

Senator LITTLE's bill, amendatory of the Act for punishment of crimes, provides that any person convicted of offences punishable by imprisonment in the State Prison, who is over 16 and under 25 years of age, may, in the discretion of the Court, be sent to the Penitentiary, without charge being made against such county for board. It empowers the Governor to appoint an Inspector of Penitentiaries, who shall receive no salary.

At noon to-day the California section of the Pacific Railroad was inaugurated with imposing cere- monies.

The steamship Africa, from Liverpool, at 11 o'clock on the morning of the 27th, vid Queenstown, on the 28th of December, arrived here at 8 o'clock this morning. she did not call off Cape Race. Her dates are three days later than those already received.
Mr. BUFFINGTON, of Massachusetts, (Rep.,) presented from the Committee on Military Affairs a majority and minority report on the bill authorizing the raising of 20,000 volunteers for Tennessee.

The wailings from Lancashire, which, a few weeks ago sounded so piteously in our ears, blending with the mockery from Liverpool and the scoff- ing from St. James, touched a deep chord in the hearts of our people, and awoke a sympathy as potent as it was generous.
From official returns it has been ascertained that the total loss in Gen. NEGLEY's Division, comprising killed, wounded, and missing, is one thousand three hundred and fifty-six (1,356.)

In the Senate yesterday, Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, introduced a bill for the construction of a ship canal between the Mississippi River and Lake Michigan, and to enlarge the locks of certain canals in New-York, to allow the passage of gunboats. It was ordered to be printed. Notice was given of a bill to aid Western Virginia in emancipating her slaves.

Private letters from the blockading fleet off Mobile, dated Dec. 23, says that many deserters to the United States from the rebel forts and neighborhood, state that "General Hardship" commands in Mobile. Beef once a week-oysters at all other times no sugar, no tea, no coffee.

The State Legislature met to-day. The Message of Gov. ROBINSON recommends that Kentucky reject President LINCOLN'S Proclamation to liberate the slaves, and protests against any interference with her State policy as unwarranted by the Constitution.
Sandwich Islands dates to the 20th ult. have been received.
