We are without any later news from Vicksburgh this morning, either Union or rebel. There is no doubt, however, of our final success there. We receive authoritative assurances from Washington that Gen. SHERMAN will be reinforced (if it is not already accomplished) by Gen. GRANT.
Murfreesboro is entirely deserted. Our army and Gen. ROSECRANS' headquarters have advanced ten miles beyond that place.
There is nothing from Vicksburgh, to-day.
The Tribune, ... in reply to our statement concerning the Nashville dispatches, says:

The story of the three preceding days need not be repeated, varied, as they were, only by the passing off of Mr. PEINPLE and Mr. McLAEN, (the latter having heard of the death of a brother, and the former being quite ill.) and for the two or three ballots of Mr. MURPHY and Mr. CHURCR, thus reducing the vote by so many, but continuing the dead-lock.

Gen. Tom Thumb, like, Gen. McCLELLAN, is at present off duty. His name is on the retired list, and he has his time at his command. Not having a new house to look after, or Courts-martial to attend, Thumb has been idling, like many other young men of fortune, about the theatres and museums of the Metropolis.

The ... Legislature of Kentucky met on Thursday, and Gov. ROBINSON yesterday sent in his Message to the body. It will be seen by the telegraphic mention of it, that the Governor utters his emphatic displeasure with the Emancipation Proclamation of President LINCOLN, and calls on the Legislature also to put on record its protest against the Proclamation.

By an Executive order, dated on the twentieth day of October, A. D., 1862, ABRAHAM LINCOLN, President of the United States, has constituted an "United States Provisional Court for the State of Louisiana," and appointed Hon. CHARLES A. PEABODY to be a Provisional Judge to hold said Court.
A special to the Press from Augusta, states that the Secretary of State, Attorney-General, AdjutantGeneral and seven Executive Councilors, nominated by the Republicans, were elected to-day.

The Message of Gov. YATES, of Illinois, is very long, and discusses many measures of general interest. The total real and personal wealth of the State is estimated at $1,000,000,000--the census of 1860 having placed it at $871,860,282. Grand Requiem Mass will be celebrated in St. Patrick's Cathedral, Mott-street, at 10 o'clock this morning for the repose of the souls of the officers and soldiers of the Irish Brigade who have fallen in battle or died since the commencement of the war. Archbishop HUGHES, and other distinguished prelates, will officiate on the occasion. An address will be delivered by Brig.-Gen. THOMAS FRANCIS MEAGHER.

The Atlas and Argus this morning explains the theory of the action of the Democrats in preventing an organization, and gives to them the cue for their future guidance. It says, if the Assembly is not organized by the election of a Speaker by the 3d of February, the statute relating to the choice of a United States Senator will be expended, and it will cease to he operative.

Our Washington correspondent informs us that the Army of the Potomac is again on the move. The nature of the movement is not disclosed, further than that it is toward Richmond.

In the Senate, yesterday, a communication was received from the Secretary of the Interior, asking for appropriations for the Capitol extension and the new dome. A memorial from the widow of the late Col. BAKER, asking for a pension, was presented.

WALLACK'S THEATRE. VANBRUGH'S famous, but seldom played, comedy of the "Provoked Husband," will be revived here to-night, for the first time in thirty years. It has been prepared with unusual care, and the distribution embraces nearly all the best artist of the establishment.

It is extraordinary that, though it is now over a year since the National and the rebel forces under arms have each comprised many hundreds of thousands, the number of firstclass battles by which we mean battles wherein at least fifty thousand are engaged on each side have not exceeded four all told. These are Shiloh, Antietam, Fredericksburgh, and Murfreesboro.

In the celebrated stumping tour which Mr. FERNANDO WOOD made in Connecticut, during the canvass prior to the last Presidential election, he assured the electors of that benighted State that the Southern negroes were so lazy, stupid, ignorant and unfit for freedom, that, if liberated, they would all start North, and compete in the labor market with such skill, energy and eagerness for work, that they would throw white mechanics out of employment.
The remains of the late Gen. MITCHEL, brought on here from Port Royal last Wednesday by the steamship Star of the South, were yesterday conveyed to their final resting place in Greenwood Cemetery.

In the McDowell Court of Inquiry to-day, Gen. RICKETTS' was examined, testifying that the road by which he was ordered to march by Gen. McDOWELL on the morning of the 28th of August, was so obstructed by wagons in his front as greatly to impede the progress of his command.

Funeral services were performed at the Church of the Pilgrims yesterday afternoon over the remains of the late Gen. MITCHEL. An eloquent address was delivered by Rev. Dr. STORRS. The remains were subsequently taken to Greenwood Cemetery for interment.
The Vice-President presented a communication from the Secretary of the Interior, asking for an appropriation of $500,000 for the Capitol extension, and $200,000 for the new dome.

I have just returned from a three days' visit to the battle-field of Stones River, or, as some term it, Murfreesboro. The battle was fought some four miles this side of the town, and the ground embraced cotton, corn and wheat fields, a grove of forest trees, and the banks of Stones River, a small stream, which winds around the town, easily fordable at this season.

The redemption of soiled postage stamps, which has been in progress at the New-York Postoffice about a month, will positively close on Tuesday afternoon. All those who have any soiled postage stamps must avail themselves of the opportunity to have them redeemed on Monday of Tuesday as no more stamps will be redeemed after those days.

The price of the NEW-YORK TIMES (Daily) hereafter will be THREE Cents, except of the Sunday morning edition, which will be FOUR Cents.
The steamship Arabia, from Liverpool on the 10th, via Queenstown on the 11th instant, arrived here at 6 o'clock this morning. Her dates are two days later than those already received.

SIR: The gunboats Louisville, De Kalb, Cincinnati and Lexington attacked the heavy fort at the Post, on Arkansas, last night, and silenced the batteries, Killing twenty of the enemy. The gunboats attacked again this morning, and dismounted every gun, eleven in all.

REPUDIATION "SQUELCHED" IN ORANGE. A large mass meeting of the citizens of Orange was held at Library Hall, on Saturday afternoon, at which the proposed supplement to the Town Charter, authorizing the issue of $40,000 in bonds to make good the town certificates now held by volunteers and citizens, was unanimously adopted.

In the TIMES, of the 5th, "Crucis" attempts to answer my letter of the first, on the subject of the "Steam Navy," and I presume it is the best answer that can be made. He does wisely not to meet the grave accusations contained in it, but duly to attempt to discredit them by attacking with verbal criticism some of the minor points.

The President has sent a message to Congress, announcing that he has signed the Joint resolution recently passed, proceeding for the additional issue of $100,000,000 in Treasury notes, to provide for the prompt payment of our soldiers and sailors.

Gen. MORGAN'S command returned to Tennessee Saturday last. Another budget of rebel letter has been intercepted. Tney were taken from Maj. SANDERS, when he was recently captured off Charleston. Some of them are dated as far back as Dec., 1861, and the latest last December. The information contained in three papers affords an interesting inside view of rebellion, relative to domestic troubles and wants.

COMFORT FOR OUR SOLDIERS. We would suggest to our readers, and especially those interested in providing comforts for the sick and wounded soldiers, that boast is one of the greatest luxuries that can be sent them. A large quantity has been sent by the citizens of Albany, but all they can furnish is but a tithe of what is needed.

No one has made the trip between NewYork and Washington, by railroad, within the memory of man, without being convinced that it is the most uncomfortable route of travel, for its importance and amount of patronage, in the United States. We have THE INTERNAL REVENUE REPORT. We have every reason to congratulate the country on the operation post and prospective of the Internal Revenue Bureau. In another column we publish Mr. Commissioner BOUTWELL'S first official report, which affords abundant proof both of the administrative efficiency with which he has discharged his trust, and of the ultimate certain success of our new system of internal taxation as a source of public revenue.

The verdict of the Court in Gen. FITZJOHN PORTER'S case was approved to-day by the President. Contrary to the former reports, the Court found him guilty of the charges preferred, and he was accordingly cashiered and dismissed the service!

Odd Fellows' Hall, on Washington-street, was destroyed by fire this morning. Loss on the building $5,000, of which $4,000 is insured.

MICHAEL LALLY, a deserter from the rebel army, has just reached New-Bedford, Mass, He formerly resided in Fall River, but about six years since went to Charleston, S.C., where he lived at the breaking out of the rebellion. ESSEX COUNTY OYER AND TERMINER. The case of THOMAS RYDER, indicted for manslaughter, in causing the death of his wife, by kicking her, was closed yesterday forenoon in the Essex Oyer and Terminer, at Newark. The Jury retired about 11 A. not agreed upon a verdict, they being understood to stand ten for conviction and two for acquittal.

It did not take long for the House to clear away the rubbish which had accumulated during the past week and get to a vote for Speaker. The Democrats were hopeful, on account of various circumstances. The Unionists reserved all opinion. One hundred and twenty-four members responded to the calling of the roll, and then, with no thought of fillibustering, went straight to a vote for Speaker.

The workmen employed in exhuming the remains of persons deposited in the vaults of the Sullivan-street Church have nearly completed their labors. The vaults in which the bodies of white persons were placed have been cleared, with the exception of about twenty coffins, which will be privately removed by the friends of the deceased. Six bodies have already been removed in this manner.

We have information from Mobile to the 31st. Gen. SIMON BUCKNER is in charge of the troops and fortifications, and is at work preparing for an assault. Only 20,000 troops are in Mobile proper, though it was understood others were in easy supporting distance.

A recent Paris telegram announces that a conference of the representatives of the Great Powers is to be shortly held in London, in order to determine the conditions on which the Ionian Islands shall be ceded to Greece. Those islands, then, are not to be a free gift from England. Their cession is to be made dependent on the assent of the Greeks to certain terms, not yet formally promulgated.

Gen. BURNSIDE was again in Washington, yesterday, and had interviews with President, Secretary STANTON and Gen. HALLECK. A telegram from the Army of the Potomac says there is nothing of interest to communicate.

Mary Ann Burdick vs. Dennis F. Root. Plaintiff sued the defendant to recover $416, being the balance of rent of house No. 157 West Forty-third-street. It appeared in evidence on the trial that two contracts were made between the parties, by the first of which the rent was fixed at $375 per year, and by the second $400.

One of our correspondents with the left wing of the Army of the Potomac, gave us, in a letter which we published on Friday last, some facts in reference to the more stringent discipline which has recently been put in force in that Grand Division, and cited some instances of severe punishment inflicted upon soldiers for misbehavior before the enemy, for absenteeism, for skulking and other military offences.

The steamer Die Vernon, from Memphis, brought up to-day a considerable number of the sick and wounded from the late battle-fields of Vicksburgh and Arkansas Post. Twenty of these died on the passage up from wounds, sickness and exhaustion. Among them were men belonging to the Eighty-third Indiana, Third Iowa and One Hundred and Eighth Illinois Regiments, one Lieutenant of the latter, besides five rebel soldiers.

IMPORTANT CONFERENCE AT THE WHITE HOUSE. A conference was held last evening at the White House, in which Secretary STANTON and several prominent Senators and Representatives participated, and in which political matters of grave importance were discussed and determined. That a change of administrative policy in many essential respects will be the result, is regarded as certain, even if it occasions official changes in important places.

Gen. ROSECRANS hopes the Cincinnati, Louisville and other newspapers will desist from the practice of publishing reports of shipments of supplies to the Department of the Cumberland. This is substantially a notification to the rebels to prepare their forces for the capture of such supplies. We learn, by way of San Francisco, that four French war vessels bombarded Acapulco for three days, commencing on the 16th inst. The fort was finally silenced, when a force was landed which spiked the guns, and the fleet then left.

The report of the United States General Hospital, Newark, for the week ending Jan. 31, shows: Admitted, 5; returned to duty, 77; discharged, 2; deserted, 5: died, 1; total remaining, 758. The general condition of the patients is excellent, and deaths are now extremely rare. Recent improvements have added materially to the comfort of the institution, which will compare favorably with any military hospital anywhere.

The news from Fortress Monroe, this morning, is important. The rebels under Gen. PRYOR advanced across the Blackwater on Friday, and made a demonstration with artillery on Gen. PECK'S advanced Brigades. Our forces were immediately disposed to meet them, and advancing, drove PRYOR back again across the Blackwater, in the direction of Franklin. The fighting appears to have been quite brisk, and resulted in a loss to us of some 100 men killed and wounded.

INAUGURATION OF A NEW TEMPERANCE HALL. --The new Hall of the Father Matthew Total Abstinence Benefit Society, located in Fulton-street, corner of Pineapple, was inaugurated yesterday with appropriate ceremonies. The building was formerly used as a concert saloon and gymnasium. It has recently been rearranged and fitted up for the above Association, and is now one of the finest and most capacious halls in the city.

Postal laws should be changed or tinkered as little and as seldom as possible. If there is anything in which simplicity, uniformity and permanence are required, it is in those business matters in which the great mass of common people have daily transactions. Our postal system, though it is improved, or at least altered, in some of its details, at almost every session of Congress, is greatly deficient in these respects.

NEW TELEGRAPH ENTERPRISE. The Independent Telegraph Company having completed the extension of their line to Philadelphia, have laid across the North River a large and substantial cable probably the largest and best cable ever made in the United States. It is composed of four conductors of No. 14 copper wire, each one coated with gutta percha three coatings 5-16 inches in diameter outside, and each strand wound with fine jute, well tarred.

It has pleased His Majesty the Emperor of the French to publish to the world a letter from his own pen to the commander of the French forces in Mexico, setting forth the reasons of his invasion of that country, and the advantages he expects to gain by it. The Imperial document is most certainly an astonishing one, and was not put forward at this moment without a design.
The iron-clad Patapsco left Hampton Roads last evening at 7 o'clock, and went to sea under convoy of the United States gunboat Pawnee.

In the Senate, Saturday, the joint resolution tendering the thanks of Congress to Commander WORDEN, was passed. A joint resolution was also reported, tendering thanks to other naval officers, but with an amendment limiting such votes in the future to those who shall command expeditions, or be engaged on some special service. It was passed. The bill to increase the salary of the Chief Clerk of the Paymaster's Department to $2,500 per annum was lost.

BROOKLYN ACADEMY OF MUSIC. The brevity of Mr. GRAU'S New-York season, occasioned by the necessity of transferring his company to Boston in time for Monday next, enables the enterprising manager to give but a single supplemental performance in Brooklyn. This will take place to-night, when an unusually attractive programme will be interpreted by the full force of the company. The performances commence with the whole of VERDI'S "Ernani" ...

The steamboat New-York, which was to have left last night for City Point has been detained till noon to-day to take up 120 rebel prisoners, which arrived this morning on the Baltimore boat from Fort McHenry.

A communication was received from the President of the Smithsonian Institute, transmitting a resolution of the Board of Regents, stating that GEORGE E. BADGER had not attended the meetings of the Board, and they understood that he was in the rebel army; and they suggest that he ought no longer to remain a member of the Board.

The waters between here and Beaufort are black with vessels of all kinds, which are only waiting the abatement of the severe gale which has been prevailing for the past five days, to take their departure for their destination.

The long agony of our dispute respecting the action of the Government is over. The President has proclaimed the freedom of three millions of slaves. It he leaves another million in bondage, it is because they are blessed with loyal masters. Their turn for freedom may come, either when their masters become disloyal, or are ready to surrender them to freedom for a compensation.

THE PASSAGE OF THE NEGRO SOLDIER BILL. Mr. STEVENS' Negro Regiment bill, which, with CA SEY'S amendment, passed the House this evening, after six days' mingled fillibustering and debate, by a vote of 83 to 55, provides for the enlistment of any number of negroes, not over 300,000, to be paid $10 a month, to be armed and equipped as other soldiers, and officered by white men.

THE WISDOM OF A NATIONAL FREE BANKING SYSTEM. It is a mistake to suppose that gentlemen who are directly interested in the management of local bank corporations generally look with disfavor upon Mr. CHASE'S proposed system of free banking. On the contrary, very many of them nearly all, indeed, who bring patience, care and a little patriotism to the study of the proposition give it their hearty and earnest support.

Information is brought by the Princess Royal, of the attack, by the iron-clad Moutauk, on Fort McAllister, on the 28th ult. She was not at all disabled. She received seventeen shots in her side and twelve on her turret without suffering any injury whatever, although engaged for five hours. She returned to her anchorage for want of shells. It being foggy next morning, she did not return to the attack.

Whisky.

The grand expedition which for the last month has been fitting out in this harbor is just starting on its southward journey. A series of adverse storms and various mishaps have delayed the departure much beyond the time originally fixed upon.

Gen. HOOKER'S General Order, which I inclose, doing away with the Grand Divisions, though dated the 5th, were not distributed to the various commands until to-day. The order is to take effect immediately.
The Tribune makes another attempt to enlighten us as to the meaning and drift of its recent support of Foreign Mediation, and of peace at the end of this campaign.
COTTON Sales, to-day, 5,000 bales, including 2,500 to speculators and exporters; market firmer, though quiet, but quotations unchanged.
The steamer North Star, with New Orleans dates to the 30th of January has arrived here. Her advices are not so late as were received by the Marion and published yesterday.

Our forces entered Lebanon, Tenn., on the 8th. They captured some 600 rebels, most of them being men of MORGAN's Command. Many field officers were taken. Among the prisoners was PAUL ANDERSON, a violent rebel member of the State Legislature of 1860 and 1862. He was an original secessionist, and one of the earliest advocates for a Southern Confederacy.
Mr. COLLAMER, of Vermont. (Rep.,) called up the bill reorganizing the Post-office Department, which passed.
At last, after a complete dearth of news of importance since the Arkansas and White River expeditions, we have interesting items to chronicle, which gives token of activity.

In consequence of the grand masquerade ball of Arion society taking place tonight, there will be no performance at the German Opera. To-morrow evening Mr. LOTTI takes his benefit, when FLOTLOW's popular opera of "Martha" will be played.

U.S. steam transport North Star, Lefevre, New-Orleans Jan. 30, via Key West Feb. 4, with passengers to U. S. Assistant Quartermaster. Died on the passage between New-Orleans and Key West, of chronic diarrhoea, J.H. Palmly, of 30th Mass. Vols., and Albert Counan, of the same regiment.

It was within a few days of each other that the attacks were made upon Murfreesboro by Gen. ROSECRANS, and upon Vicksburgh by Gen. SHERMAN. The two battles were the closing scenes in the great and sanguinary drama of 1862. One of them had an auspicious issue, the other terminated disastrously. In one case the struggle is about to be renewed on the same ground; in the other apparently but a few miles further South.

Those who did and those who did not attend the wedding of Gen. Thomas Thumb and Queen LAVINIA WARREN composed the population of this great Metropolis yesterday, and thenceforth religious and civil parties sink into comparative insignificance before this one arbitrating query of fate Did you or did you not see Tom Thumb married?

The steamship North Star arrived at this port yesterday from New-Orleans via Key West. Her advices are not so late as those by the Marion, but are interesting. She brings as passenger Col. HENRY C. DEMING, late Acting Mayor of NewOrleans, and Commander of the Twelfth Connecticut Volunteers, who has resigned both positions.

The receipts of the principal kinds of Produce, since our last, have been: 20 bbls. Ashes, 12,578 bbls. Flour, 30 bbls. and 1,732 bags Corn Meal, 1,055 bushels Wheat, 5,350 bushels Corn, 4,415 bushels Rye, 1,143 bushels Barley, 7,335 bushels Oats, 1,380 bush. Malt, 11,139 pkgs. Provisions, and 1,260 bbls. Whisky.
In the California Legislature to-night, Mr. CONNESS was elected on the first ballot. The following is the vote:

A case has recently been brought to light which reveals the infamous practice resorted to by a military officer to impose upon an unsuspecting and confiding person placed temporarily in his custody. Through the active exertions of Gen. DRAPER and his assistants, one of the guilty party implicated in the base act has been arrested, and is now in close confinement.

One of our New-Orleans correspondents writes us concerning the terrible condition of the poor in that city. The destruction of its trade and commerce, by the blocking of the Mississippi River, has long kept them out of work; and more than thirty thousand men, women and children, of all nations, (but mostly natives of the British isles,) have, since our occupation of the city, been supported by...

Secretary SEWARD has made a report to Congress, in which he explicitly denies ever having made any communication to the rebel authorities through M. MERCIER, the French Minister. No person, he says, has been authorized to make any representations of any kind, on any subject, to the rebel authorities.

Assemblyman JAMES SMITH, of Newark, to-day introduced into the House the following important resolutions, which are preceded by a long preamble: Be it Resolved, by the Senate and General Assembly of the State of New-Jersey:

It is extraordinary that a man of the practical sagacity of the French Emperor, and with a personal knowledge like his of the character of the American people, derived from a prolonged sojourn in our midst, should ...

The following communication was transmitted to the Senate to-day: To the President of the United States: The Secretary of State, to whom was referred a resolution of the Senate, passed on the 9th day of February, instant, in these words, viz.:

The report of the Treasurer of the State Agricultural Society, which met in the Assembly Chamber in Albany, yesterday afternoon, shows the receipts of the year to be upward of $17,000, while the expenditures were upward of $13,000, including nearly $4,500 for premiums.

It will be seen that Secretary SEWARD has furnished to the President, who has transmitted to the Senate, a very explicit, specific, and decisive answer to the resolution of that body, alleging that he had held, through M. MERCIER, communication with the rebel authorities in Richmond.
The Bonapartist journal, La Nation, which was founded in view of the approaching election for Deputies, and which gives us, therefore, the ideas supposed by the people at the Tuileries best ...

When the West India or Flying Squadron was organized, under command of Commodore WILKES, its depot for supplies and rendezvous was established at Turtle Harbor, an outlandish place on the coast, about 120 miles northeast of this place.
It seems that the rebels not only have preliminary knowledge of all military movements in the North, but of all political schemes. A fortnight ago there was quite a little flurry in ...
The annual meeting of the State Agricultural Society has called to the Capital a large number of the representative men of our State, among the most conspicuous of whom is the venerable Ex-Gov. KING.

We have received files of papers from Richmond and other points in the rebel States, which contain matters of interest. We give below such extracts as are of the most immediate importance. The tone of these papers, in regard to the so-called blockade raising, has wonderfully changed. The Richmond Whig has the following:

At an early hour on the morning of Jan. 16, 1859, there were committed, in the Sixth Ward of this City, two of those deliberate and unprovoked murders for which that portion of our city has for very many years been notorious. On the morning cited, a man named DECKER was shot twice in his own house in Elm street by ruffians outside; and almost ...

We learn from Washington that the President has restored to the rank of Brigadier-General of Volunteers, Major H.W. BENHAM, of the Engineer Corps of the army, and has assigned him to a command in Gen. HOOKER'S army.

The Copperheads are fast getting into line. They of Indiana briskly follow those of NewJersey and Illinois. In fact, they take the track with a little more fierceness. The others have as yet only asked for an armistice; these demand one, and threaten independent State action unless the Government complies.

Resolutions were introduced into the Legislature of New-Jersey yesterday, appointing five Commissioners to proceed to Richmond and ascertain whether the Southern States will consent to reaffirm their adhesion to the Union; ...

In the Senate, yesterday, an adverse report was made from the Military Committee on the bill to construct a marine cable. The same Committee was discharged from the further consideration of the bill for the construction of a military and postal road from Washington to New-York.

The flag-of-truce boat New-York arrived here this afternoon from City Point, bringing down two hundred and sixty-nine exchanged prisoners. Among them are two officers, one a Colonel and the other a Lieutenant.

The late collision of the steamer North Star with the Ella Warley, as fully described in the TIMES of yesterday, is still a topic of general conversation "down town." Owing to the many rumors afloat to the effect that the Ella Warley was lost in consequence ...
Mr. GRIMES, of Iowa, (Rep.,) from the Committee on Naval Affairs, reported a resolution to compensate the sailors of the gunboat Cairo for loss of clothing. Passed.

As anticipated in our last evening's dispatch, the Bank bill to-day overrode all other questions in the Senate, and was debated nearly the whole day without a vote being reached. The speech of Mr. COLLAMER against it, and Mr. SHERMAN in favor, were both strong efforts.
The Court-room was thronged with spectators, yesterday, as on the two previous days. Mr. SEDGWICK, for the defence, resumed the examination of witnesses by calling to the stand.

In the Senate yesterday the bill to amend the charter of Brooklyn was reported favorably; also, the bills to extend the Chenango Canal. Among the bills introduced was one relative to the acknowledgment of legal instruments by persons in foreign countries.
A special dispatch from Cairo to-day, says that news has been received from Vicksburgh to Saturday. The ram Queen has returned from below. Her trip down the river was most successful.

By an order to be issued to-day the Grand Divisions of the army known as the "Right, Centre and Left," are to be done away with, and the old organization of corps restored. The project of dividing the army into divisions, each one composing two or more corps, was first discussed by Gen. McCLELLAN ...

On the 1st of January the American Minister at Copenhagen, Mr. WOOD, presented to the King of Denmark a pair of Colt's revolvers, the gift of the President of the United States to his Majesty. On delivering the pistols, after the usual felicitations, ...

The loyal members of the Illinois Legislature have threatened to withdraw, and leave the two Houses without the constitutional two-thirds quorum, in order to prevent the passage of the Armistice and Convention res olutions of the Copperhead majority.
The Vice-President laid before the Senate the credentials of Hon. WILLIAM SPRAGUE, elected United States Senator from the State of Rhode Island for six years from the 4th of March next.
This has been a working day in the House, the General Orders having been gone through and some dozen bills of a local character considered, and most of them passed. PROCEEDINGS OF THE LEGISLATURE.

The attention of the French people is today almost exclusively directed to the suffering from the cotton crisis. The Emperor has given another hundred thousand francs from his private purse, and he has decreed a gift from the State ...

We publish this morning the diplomatic correspondence sent to the Senate yesterday by the President, in response to the resolution adopted a day or two ago, calling for any correspondence between our Government and that of France on the subject of mediation.

This vessel, which arrived here on Sunday from off Charleston, S.C., is a beautiful propeller of 470 tons. She has an iron hull, new and splendid machinery, and is said to be able to make from fourteen to sixteen miles an hour. In appearance, she is very much like the prize steamer Lodona, which was captured off Charleston last summer and brought to this port.

Your correspondent G.M. seems to doubt the correctness of "A Veteran Observer," in his ideas relative to the increase of our national wealth by the war. The following may show him the possibility of such a result:

Maj.-Gen. Mc DOWELL presented his defence to the Court of Inquiry on Tuesday last. It is a formid able document, which, if printed in full, would occupy nearly three pages of the TIMES. Gen. McDOWELL says, in opening his defence:

The Moniteur contains a report to the Emperor, signed by M. ROUHER, the Minister of Agriculture, Commerce and Public Works, and M. DE PERSIGNY, the Minister of the Interior, recommending that in each of their Departments a credit of 2,500,000 francs shall be opened for carrying out local and other public works, with the view of relieving the distress of the operatives thrown out of employment by the cotton famine. The report says:
The mails from Europe by the steamship Europa, at Boston, from Liverpool on the 24th ult., were received in this city early yesterday morning.

Parliament meets in a fortnight, M. DISRAELI has issued cards for the great Conservative dinner, which precedes the opening, and at which the business of the session will be settled. The political position is unchanged. The Conservatives are actually stronger in votes, but it still rests with Earl DERBY to take the Premiership, or have his work done for him by Lord PALMERSTON.

The Promenade Concert given to aid the Woman's Relief Association, at the Academy of Music, last evening, was a remarkable success, and must have furnished a most gratifying increase to the means of the Association, which was organized for and has long been engaged in preparing comfortable clothing and other necessaries for the sick and wounded soldiers of the Union army.

AMERICAN INSTITUTE ANNUAL ELECTION OF OFFICERS. The annual election of officers and Committees of the American Institute was held yesterday at the rooms of the Institute, Cooper Union Building, the polls being open from 3 to 7 o'clock P.M. The following gentlemen were elected without opposition: President, WM. HALL; Vice-Presidents, Dudley S. Gregory, Edward Walker, Sylvester Comstock; ...

Last Wednesday morning Major-Gens. HUNTER and FOSTER, accompanied by Brig.-Gens. SEYMOUR, NAGLEE and POTTER, and the officers of their respective staffs, made a tour of reconnoissance, on board of the steamboat John Farron, to inspect the localities around Fort McAllister, on the Ogeechee, with a view of determining what land cooperation might be necessary to assist the naval attack on that stronghold, First visiting Fort Pulaski, which they found ...

Since my last communication, nothing of importance has occurred until within the past week. The secession trade is full as brisk as it has been at any time during the war. There are now about forty steamers and sailing vessels, of a large class, in our port, with cargoes for the rebels, and besides these our warehouses are all full of goods for the same market.

The prolongation of the war, though it has been productive of much suffering and of much loss, is nevertheless proving instrumental in furnishing us abundantly with the thing, of all others, which, as a nation, we most needed experience.
The House took up the Naval Appropriation bill, as reported from the Committee of the Whole on the State of the Union, with amendments.
At the opening of the Court, yesterday morning, A. OAKEY HALL the District Attorney, summed up the case to the jury, on behalf of the people, occupying about 2 hours.

In the Senate yesterday, not much business of importance was done. Among the bills introduced, was one by Mr. MURPHY, to establish a jail within the limits of Kings County. The General Bounty Tax bill was considered throughout the session, without result.

Several thousand of the many who have long known the late Rev. BENJAMIN CLARK CUTLER, D.D., of St. Ann's Church, Brooklyn, attended his funeral yesterday afternoon. Large numbers of the clergy and laity of the diocese, together with as many of the parishioners as could gain admission to the edifice, were present during the three hours consumed in the last sad rites of reverential affection.

Gen. BANKS has issued an order, which we have already given, making public the President's Proclamation, and declaring the slaves, within the designated portions of the State of Louisiana, to be free. One paragraph of that order reads thus:

The telegraph has informed you of the result of the Democratic caucus, in adopting, after a bitter fight, the resolutions of Senator RANDOLPH, of Hudson, in preference to those of Senator HOLSMAN, of Bergen. Some modifications were, however, made for the purpose of taking the edge off the anger of the "radicals," and inducing them to accept the more moderate resolutions of Mr.RANDOLPH.

The steamer Champion, Capt. WILSON, arrived at this port last night, having sailed from Aspinwall, under convoy of the United States gunboat Connecticut, on the 4th inst. The steamers from Central and South America, with fifteen days later news, are not due here till tomorrow.
COTTON The sales yesterday and to-day reach 6,000 bales, including 2,000 bales to speculators and exporters. The market is irregular and easier, and quotations are barely maintained.

The steamship Elna arrived at this port yesterday forenoon, with advices from Europe four days later. She left Liverpool on the 28th, and Queenstown on the 29th ult. The most striking news by this arrival relates to an insurrection in Poland, which assumed quite formidable proportions in some quarters, but which, at last advices, had apparently been quelled by the military.
A dispatch from Brig.-Gen. KELLEY, dated Harper's Ferry today, to Lieut.-Col. CHEESBROUGH, A.A. General, says:
The rumors which were current at the departure of the Europa, in regard to the new mediation designs of France, continued to circulate.
The Inman steamer Etna, Capt. BROOKS, which sailed from Liverpool at 1 o'clock on the afternoon of the 28th, and from Queenstown on the 29th ult., arrived here yesterday morning.

The Levees on the Mississippi side of the Mississippi River, twelve miles below Helena at Yazoo Pass, have been cut by our forces. They have also been cut at Greenville, and on the Louisiana side opposite Lake Providence.

The following intelligence relative to the events in Poland has been received at Berlin: " The garrison of Warsaw has been increased to 40,000 men, who have been supplied with ball cartridges. The 2,000 conscripts lately enrolled have deserted and assembled at different points. Hostages have, however, been seized in their place. Some students and married men who here arrested have been set at liberty.

Yesterday I forwarded you an order in relation to supplying the troops with fresh bread, potatoes, , Dr. LETTERMAN, Medical Director of the Army, has issued a written circular to the various surgeons, enjoining upon them the necessity of enforcing the above order. We give some extracts:

The construction of a Ship Canal around the Falls of Niagara is no new idea; and its revival at this time is a necessary result of the present condition of affairs. Two or three surveys have been made over as many different routes. To the sole considertion of commerce at the time they were made, is now added that of the public defence, which, at the present moment, is the leading argument.

The steamship Champion arrived at this port last night, from Aspinwall on the 4th inst., whence she sailed under convoy of the gunboat Connecticut. She brings nearly $360,000 in treasure. No later news had reached the Isthmus from Central or South America, though a report had been brought from Callao that there was much excitement on the coast of Peru regarding the visit of a large Spanish fleet to the contiguous waters.

To the Senate and House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Pensylvania: GENTLEMEN: I desire to call your attention to a subject of moment. When the present infamous and God-condemned rebellion broke out, Congress was not in session, and the occurence of such a state of things not having been seen in former times, no adequate legislation had been had to meet it.

Messrs. WADE and WILMOT presented petitions for a reliable camp hospital and ambulance corps. Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, (Rep.,) presented the petition of 400 disabled soldiers for the same; also a petition from persons in the military service, asking for legislation to prevent their being cheated by defective pay-rolls,

CONVICTION OF MURDER. JONATHAN PICKLE was, on Tuesday last, convicted in Morristown for the murder of his brother, FURMAN PICKLE. The prisoner was sentenced to twelve years hard labor in the State Prison.
Word vs. Ruckman et al. This was an appeal from an order denying the defendants' motion to open a default taken against them. The case was stated in the TIMES, of the 29th of July, 1862.

From the tenor of dispatches by the last foreign steamer, it is thought the feeling in regard to the American question is slightly improving, not merely in Great Britain but on the Continent. There has been a ministerial crisis in Turkey, in consequence of the irascible and ungovernable temper of the Sultan. This, it is said, is causing much concern, and apprehension of grave political dangers in the East.

In the Senate yesterday, a bill to limit the number of Notaries Public in all the counties of the State, was reported favorably; also a bill relative to the acknowledgment of written instruments by persons residing in foreign countries. The General Bounty Tax bill was reported complete, ordered to a third reading, and subsequently passed. The Select Committee of last Session, on the manufacture of salt, was called upon to report immediately.

THE CONSCRIPTION BILL. The Conscription bill has been made the special order in the Senate for Monday. An entirely new bill has been prepared by Mr. WILSON, and reported by the Military Committee, and an exciting debate may be expected, as the " Copperheads" will use their utmost endeavors to defeat it.

GENERAL ORDERS No. 6. The General Commanding, desiring to increase as far as possible the effective force of this army, by returning to their regiments able-bodied men, now on detached service as teamsters, laborers and hospital attendants, directs that their places be supplied, as far as possible, by the substitution of men hired for the purpose.

In the Senate, yesterday, the Military Committee to whom was referred the petition of Dr. W. T.G. MORTON, asking for compensation for the use of ether in the army, made a report of the facts, without auy recommendation. A bill to increase the efficiency of the hospital department of the army was referred to the Military Committee.

Is this really to be the cry? Shall we throw thought and care to the dogs, while things generally topple down upon our heads? Is it an earthquake that is rumbling? or is the foundation on which the fabric of Government rests turning into quicksand? No matter; some folks have got an idea that their rights are in danger unless the Government is thoroughly shaken into a sense of its weakness, ...

We have advices from New-Orleans to the 6th of February by the arrival at this port last evening of the steamship Empire City. The news is important as showing that the work of preparation is now complete, and that we may expect soon to hear a good account of Gen. BANK'S army.

Mr. DAWES, of Massachusetts, (Rep.,) from the Committee on Elections, to whom, was referred the credentials of JENNINGS PIGGOT, claiming a seat from the Second Congressional District of North Carolina, and the protest of CHARLES HENRY FOSTER against the former, made a report adverse to the former.

Gen. ROSECRANS used to belong to the Democratic party; but he has also demonstrated by his career that he belongs to the grander party of patriotism. He has shown this both by his sword and by his pen.

The King of Prussia and the Prussian Chambers are again face to face, and everything indicates that the strife of the last session will be renewed with ten-fold bitterness in this. A King who has once wielded the sceptre of despotism, can seldom brook to descend to the condition of a Constitutional Monarch. Rather than do so, the second of the STUARTS died on the scaffold, and the last ...

About 1 o'clock yesterday morning, a serious explosion occurred on board the Government ironclad gunboat Keokuk, lying in the dock at the foot of Eleventh-street, East River. The steam-pipe of the boat exploded, instantly scalding to death four of the men on board of her, and seriously injuring one other person.

In a former letter I spoke of the painful condition of the poor of New-Orleans, and said that something must be immediately done to prevent them from lapsing back to a condition worse than that in which they were when our troops took possession of the city.
The steamer Empire City, Capt. BAXTER, with intelligence from New-Orleans to the 6th of February, arrived here at 10 o'clock last evening.

Concert Hall, Newark, N.J., (the Newark Theatre,) was last night filled to overflowing, by an audience assembled to hear Hon. C.L. VALLANDIGHAM, of Ohio, on the "Political Issues of the Day." The stage boxes were filled with ladies, and on the stage itself were the officers and most prominent members of the Newark Democratic Union Club, under whose auspices the lecture was delivered.
A semi-annual meeting of this Society was held on Tuesday, in the City Hail, Albany. Prof. J. BEAKLEY, of New-York City, President of the Society, was present, and occupied the Chair.

The late offical order respecting slaves becoming free by going with their masters to the United States, North, or any other free country, has been followed by another important edict, or rather code of regulations, which has been ordered by the present Captain-General to be put into effect, and which has been accordingly published in the official gazette of the Government.

ALTERING TREASURY NOTES. EDWARD DALTON BLISS, the young man who was arrested on Thursday for attempting to pass a $50 United States Treasury note at Niblo's saloon, had a preliminary examination before United States Commissioner OSBORN yesterday. It appeared from the evidence that BLISS is only 15 years of age, that he has three brothers in the army, and was himself, until lately, in the naval service where he maintained a good character.
The People vs. Albert Uhl. The prisoner was tried on an indictment for the murder of one William Lee. The defence was that the act was committed in self-defence.

Gen. SMITH left at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon, by special train, for his new field of operations. He desired to go North and spend a brief period among friends before assuming command of the Ninth Army Corps, but his immediate presence being demanded, the War Department ordered him to proceed forthwith to .
Following is the letter to Commissioner DOLE from Indian Agent JOHNSON, in Southern Kansas, mention of which was made the other day:

The late campaign of Gen. BLUNT was only one of ninety days duration, and during that time his army marched at least over a thousand miles, fought five battles, crushed the guerrilla operations of the enemy, lived a large part of their time on half rations, held the country, captured an immense quantity of stores, and defeated an enemy always outnumbering us three to one, and in some cases meeting even greater odds.

The inhabitants of this far Southern military colony are still excited with discussions of the late ram raid at Charleston, and the other trial of iron in the obstructed channel of the Ogeechee. As is always the case, upon the occurrence of great events here, they await the arrival of the New-York papers, to replace the exaggerated stories which have prevailed, with the full and accurate narration of the facts.
Senator MURPHY's bill, providing for the protection of the harbor of New-York against invasion, provides as follows:
A correspondent of the Chicago Times, writing from Fort Donelson under date of Feb. 4, gives the following description of the battle of that point:

Coroner RANNEY was called to hold an inquest, yesterday, upon the body of Mrs. ANN CBOSBY, who died at Bellevue Hospital, from the effects of injuries received at the hands of her husband, WILLIAM CROSBY. The facts of the case, as detailed upon the inquest, are truly shocking, and almost too inhuman to relate. It appears that CROSBY and his wife had for several weeks past been residing together ...

Several of our City cotemporaries owe an apology to Mr. SEWARD. They have represented him as being guilty of an atrocious libel upon the Nation. This representation of theirs may have sprung out of an error of the types, but though that excuses their intention, it leaves the charge still standing against him. Mr. SEWARD, in his letter to Mr. DAYTON, of Feb. ...

JOHN VAN BUREN, in his speech, on Tuesday evening, conceded that the Proclamation of Emancipation "does nothing but what any General commanding the army might do." This is more of a concession than most of his ...
A few days since, R.M.T. HUNTER, Chairman of the Financial Committee of the rebel Senate, submitted the following important report to that body:
A large and enthusiastic meeting of unconditional Union men was held here last night. Resolutions were adopted unanimously, declaring as follows:
Several petitions were presented for a camp hospital and ambulance corps.

Lieut.-Col. DOOR, of Gen. FOSTER'S Staff, arrived here to-day, direct from Port Royal, with dispatches for the Government. He utterly denies the recent sensation reports in regard to a quarrel between Gens. HUNTER and FOSTER. The same denial is made by the President, and no reason exists to believe that anything has occurred likely to impair the efficiency of our army in the Department of the South.

The London Times has a characteristically gloomy article on the prospects of the North both in a financial and military sense, and as regards the latter, it says perhaps at no time during the war has fortune declared so decidedly against the North over the whole area of military operations.

Steamship Asia, (Br.,) Shannon, Liverpool Jan. 31, and Queenstown Feb. 1, with mdse, and passengers to E. Conard Feb. 2, 100 miles west of Cape Clear, passed steamship City of Baltimore, hence for Liverpool.
SOLDIERS: Not by your own volition, but in spite of yourselves, you are the instruments of an iniquitous war, which sordid interests, unjust hatred and low intrigues have brought upon us.

The receipts of the principal kinds of Produce, since our last, have been: 38 bbls. Ashes, 14,489 bbls. Flour, 370 bbls. and 1,956 bags Corn Meal, 956 bushels Wheat, 4,725 bushels Corn, 1,250 bushels Rye. 53 bushels Barley, 10,383 bushels Oats, 4,130 bushels Malt. 7,771 pkgs. Provisions, and 1,606 bbls. Whisky.

ARREST OF AN ALLEGED SWINDLER. A man named GIOVANNI PACININI, was brought before Justice CONNOLLY, at the Tombs, yesterday, by Officer GOLDEN, of the Sixth Precinct, charged with swindling his brother Italians.

A great demonstration in favor of negro emancipation was held in Exeter Hall, London, on the 29th ult. Mr. W. EVANS Chairman of the Emancipation Society, presided, and was supported by Mr. P.A. Taylor, M.P., Mr. Thomas Hughes, the novelist, Hon. and Rev. Baptist Noel, Rev. Newman Hall, , , while letters of apology and sympathy were read from many distinguished men. The Daily News says:

Yesterday afternoon His Excellency, Lord MONCK, proceeded in state to the Chamber of the Legislative Council, at Quebec, with the view of opening a new session of our Canadian Parliament, but Sir ALLAN N. McNAB, the late Speaker of the Council having died during the recess, and his successor not having been yet appointed, the Speech was postponed until to-day. Immediately after His Excellency's departure from the Council Chamber, on ...
The General Commanding has been informed that General Orders from the War-Department, authorizing enlistments of volunteers into the regular service have been rescinded.

The Tribune's Washington correspondent says: "A distinguished Massachusetts statesman, not now in public life, in a private letter written weeks ago, expressed regret that England and Russia had not accepted the proposition of NAPOLEON to mediate in our affairs, in order that an opportunity might be afforded to state the case of the country authoritatively to the civilized world."
COTTON firmer, and all quotations slightly higher; in some cases, d, higher. Salee 5,000 bales, including 2,500 to speculators and exporters.

The Emperor's very admirable discourse, delivered on Sunday last at the ceremony of conferring honors on the most notable of the French exhibitors at the London Exhibition, is proclaimed by the "independent and devoted" Press as the great future political programme of the present dynasty. It foreshadows, they say, the longlooked for crowning of the edifice, the finishing stroke to the grand mission of the Bonapartes in France.

La France announces that Rear-Admiral BOSSE has been appointed Commander of the French Naval Divison upon the Mexican coast, in place of Admiral JURIEN DE LA GRAVIERE, who is about to return to France at his own request.

The ship Planter, Capt. DAILY, was wrecked on the 14th January, on Stranger Key, near Abaco Light, whilst transporting troops, mechanics and horses for the Banks Expedition. The troops and mechanics arrived here on the 5th inst., in two small English schooners, and from Capt. WALLING, of the One Hundred and Sixty-first New-York Volunteers, and Lieut. J.G. STEVENS, of the Twenty-third Connecticut, I learn these details of the disaster.
The funds, on the 30th, opened weakly, but closed a shade better. Consols, 92 1/8@ for money, 92 @ 3/8 for account.

Operations on the Mississippi, below Vicksburgh, bid fair to be aided henceforth in a very effective manner by our gunboats. The most gallant ram of our Western flock, the Queen of the West, is still lying below Vicksburgh, taking a brief respite after her wonderful dash down the river; and we have news this morning that the new Monitor Indianola has run the batteries at Vicksburgh, and now keeps company with the Queen.

From statements of gentlemen who have returned from the Rappahannock, it appears that the rebels are working with great energy and industry. DESTUCTIVE FIRE IN NEWARK. Yesterday morning, about 2 o'clock, a fire broke out in the buildings of the Morris and Essex Railroad Company, near the depot of that Company at Newark, which consumed a large brick building 100x30 feet, used for storing wood, also a large building containing four locomotives the Passaic, Hudson, Orange and Pequest. The latter was undergoing repairs. Three of the engines were first-class and cost $10,000 each.

The rebel batteries at Vicksburgh have been run the second time this time by the new Monitor gunboat Indianola, the first one of this class built on the Western waters which has gone into active service. She seems to have passed down quite leisurely, as she is said to have obtained a full view of all the rebel batteries, which did their best to sink her. She passed all the batteries in safety.

CHARLES, LEWIS, convicted of the murder of JAMES ROWAND, of Princeton, in November last, was to day sentenced to be hung on the 3d of April next. The Court overruled the motion.

While the recent fire was prevailing on Mainstreet, Norfolk, the sloop Cornelia was discovered in Bell's Dock, attempting to move out, which aroused the suspicion of the guard. On examining her, about $1,500 worth of goods were found aboard, belonging to Mr. KING, one of the sufferers. One of the parties suspected was arrested, and, it is understood, has turned States evidence, implicating others. The affair is being investigated.

The storm which began yesterday morning is the most severe of any this Winter. A UNION LEAGUE IN NEW-JERSEY The loyal citizens of Newark are taking measures for the formation of a Union League, to comprise all loyal men without distinction of party. The most fearful storm the Army of the Potomac has ever experienced began on Saturday evening, and continued all day yesterday. The sun shone so brightly and the air was so balmy on Saturday morning, that we all supposed the unfavorably weather of the past six weeks ended. About 2 o'clock in the afternoon, however, the weather commenced growing colder, and by midnight the wind had blown up a furious snow-storm.

We publish elsewhere a very sharp and petulant note from CASSIUS M. CLAY, MajorGeneral in the army, and recently recommissioned to be Minister to Russia. He professes to find occasion for writing it in what he styles our "insinuation" that he "could serve the Government consistently with his private sentiments only in a foreign mission."

SOCIAL CHURCH GATHERING. Tuesday evening there was a large congregation at the John-street M. E. Church Rev. Dr. PORTER in the Chair. Very interesting speeches were delivered by the Chairman and by Messrs. FAIR, LOUNDER, GILLETTE and others. There is a debt of $13,000 upon the church, and the annual current expenses are about $3,000.

The Su preme Court, as was stated in our law reports yesterday morning, has issued a writ of mandamus ordering the Comptroller to complete the purchase of the Fort Gansevoort property, in accordance with the action of the Common Council. The writ was issued on the ground that the Comptroller's action in the matter is simply ministerial.

We cannot help indulging in the hope that the frequency with which officers guilty of the grossest breaches of military discipline escape without any heavier punishment than "dismissal from the service," is due rather to the desire of the authorities to get rid of worthless men, than to any notion on their part that discipline can be maintained by the infliction of such a penalty as this.
A large fleet of boats left Memphis, on Sunday, for below.

Anderson vs. Dickie The plaintiff sued to recover for injuries alleged to have been sustained by her in the month of June, 1862, in consequence of falling into a vault in front of the defendant's premises, Nos. 68 and 70 Lispenard-street, by reason of a defect in the fastenings of the grate used as a covering of the vault hole.

CHARLES H. GORDON, alias GRANT, was arraigned before Justice PERRY yesterday on charges of burglary, preferred by the following parties: CHAS. CHRISTMAS, Second place, corner of Henry-street; ISRAEL W. LEVISON, No. 254 Henry-street; ABEL DENNISON and Mrs. ADELA VAN BRUNT, No. 256 Henrystreet. The prisoner waived examination on all the charges, and was committed to jail to await the action of the Grand Jury.

In the Senate, yesterday, the bill authorizing the President to confer brevet rank was called up and passed. A bill to authorize the Covington and Cincinnati Bridge Company to bridge the Ohio, was referred to the Post-office Committee. The bill to promote the health, comfort and efficiency of the army was passed.

Regnart vs. Bredt.--This was a motion for a preliminary injunction. The plaintiff claimed to be the owner of a patent for the manufacture of the fivestaffs known as rose-anoline, which he alleged the attendant was infringing. The plaintiff's patent was issued in 1860, but he obtained a reissue on Dec. 7, 1862, and the infringement set up was of this reissued patent.

DEPARTMENT OF STATE, WASHINGTON, Sept. 26, 1862. SIR: Your dispatch of the 12th of September (No. 221) has been submitted to the President. In this official paper I must write with less freedom than you have done on both subjects.

In the house of Lords on Monday, Feb. 16, Lord DERBY commented on the want of business before the House, and asked whether the Government would give a list of the important measures dimly shadowed forth in the Royal speech. He condemned in very strong terms the conduct of Mr. CHRISTIE in the Brazils, and inquired whether it met with the approbation of the Government.

In response to a call for a meeting of the merchants of New-York, with a view of forwarding the project of the ocean telegraph, a large number of prominent merchants assembled at the rooms of the Chamber of Commerce yesterday, at 1 P.M. Mayor OPDYKE was unanimously called to the Chair, and, after briefly stating the purpose of the gathering, called upon PETER COOPER, Esq., to address them.

A large and very enthusiastic mass meeting of all different nationalities represented in this City, was held last evening at the Steuben House. The object of the meeting was to protest against the intervention of European monarchies in any of the American republics, to reaffirm the principles of the Monroe Doctrine, and to insist on their rigorous application by the Government of the United States.

The enemy under VAN DORN advanced again toward Franklin yesterday. The Federal force also advanced six miles and drove the rebels back. Two men were wounded. The rebels lost 13 killed. The fight was renewed this morning. No particulars have been received.

The consideration of the annual Appropriation bill, reported by Mr. DEPEW from the Committee of Ways and Means, engrossed the entire time of the House to-day, Nothing so clearly shows the great and varied interests of the State as the items of this bill.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--Mr. MARETZEK'S season will commence to-night, the opera being "H. Trovatore." It is rather a prodigal work to open with, inasmuch as it introduces nearly all the new artists of the company, and in that respect vio lates a rule of the musical HOFLE, which says that trump cards should be played separately.

The United States vs. The Schooner Florida.-- This vessel was captured by the Matthew Vassar, on Jan. 11, 1863, at sea, near Little River Inlet, off the coast of North Carolina. No one appeared to defend the suit. The vessel was a British vessel, with a register to H.R. Saunders, of Nassau.

Some additional particulars of the capture of the Indianola have been received. When she was attacked, the advantage was on the side of the rebel rams. The Indianola moved slowly, compared with them. They kept clear of her bow, where her best guns were, and butted the sides and stern.

Francis P. Leary vs. Thomas Cassidy et al.-- This was an action on a promissory note by one McGill, indorsed by Cassidy, and after him the in dorsement of the payee. The note was subsequently passed away with the two indorsers as surety on it. The payee took up the note after maturity, and passed it to the plaintiff; but the signature of Cassid V "was erased at the time of payment."

The British war steamer Petrel arrived in Hampton Roads last night and anchored a short distance from the United States gunboat Mystic. One of the best evidences that the right of free speech still exists in New-York, is the fact that Hon. C.L. VALLANDIGHAM, of Ohio, spoke before the Democratic Association, corner of Twenty-second-street and Broadway, last evening. The call for the meeting invited "loyal citizens in favor of the suppression of the rebellion." The hall was not filled as early as usual. In spite of the inclement weather, however,

Hon. C.L. VALLANDIGHAM addressed a full house at the Broadway Headquarters of the Democracy last evening. He opposed the war, advocated immediate peace, denounced our Conscription act as ten times worse than that of Poland and counseled resistance to it by the people of the North.

The Richmond Dispatch and Enquirer of the 6th inst., which have been received, contain several items of interest. A large audience assembled at the hall of the Democratic Union Association last evening, for the purpose of listening to a speech by Hon. GEORGE H. PENDLETON, of Ohio. At 8 o'clock that gentleman, accompanied by others, entered the hall, and, after the applause which greeted him had subsided, was introduced to the meeting by the Chairman, LUKE F. COZEENS.

The President has organized the Territorial Government of Arizona, by the appointment of a full corps of civil officers. JOHN A. GURLEY, late Member of Congress, from Cincinnati, O., is made Governor, RICHARD C. McCORMICK, of this City, Secretary, and Mr. GODWIN, of Maine, Chief Justice.

The Senate considered Mr. DAVIS' resolution, offered yesterday, requesting the President to furnish, at the commencement of the next session, the aggregate number for each State, Territory and the District of Columbia, of all officers and employes in the civil service of the United States, subject to removal by the President and by other officers, and their perquisites, etc.

We publish an excellent and patriotic letter from a New-York Volunteer serving on the Rappahannock. It is full of expressions of fortitude and hope; but the writer has been led to the conclusion, from various indications, that a large portion, if not a majority, of the Northern people look with doubt upon the issue of, this struggle, and are ready to abandon it upon any, even dishonorable terms.

So much has been said about the famous Vicksburgh Canal, and so much has been expected of it, that almost the first thing that one newly arrived at this place asks is, "Where is the Canal?" "Have any boats passed through it yet?" "When will it be finished?"

Rumors have reached Memphis, and are thence telegraphed, that an engagement has taken place at Port Hudson. If there has been a battle there, it is pretty certain to have been a victory for our forces--else we should before now have heard of it from the rebels.

Arrived ship Cosuimbo, from Boston. The steamer Sonora brought from Manzanilla thirteen boxes of treasure received from the wreck of the Golden Gate, making about $600,000 in all received here.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--VERDI'S Opera of "La Traviata" will be played here to-night, with an admirable distribution.

The annual Commencement of the Medical Department of Columbia College took place last evening, at Irving Hall, and was attended by a large and fashionable audience. Upon the platform were seated the Faculty of the College, also Luther Bradish, Preston King, John P. Crosby, D.E. Bradlee, Dr. Alexander H. Stevens, Major Delafield. Floyd Smith, F.A. Conkling and other members of the profession. The Alumni and Graduating Class occupied settees near the platform.
